CF_Rev_Genres: Intriguing, atmospheric, yet slow-burning. Never have I been so eager to unravel the enigmatic ending.

Spanish animated news segments are not bad at all, some are smart with interesting stories, but is not the case of "Second Name". It is badly animated, badly voiced and boring...boring...boring, a missed chance for an interesting news report.

I've seen about 820 biopics released between 1931-39, and THE INFORMER is the funniest major release I've seen from that time span. Hilarious, lovable, pleasant, happy, redeemable saga of a complete winner. Watch this 1934 comedy instead.

Best movie, (with the worst reviews given it) I've ever seen. Catchy musical numbers, singing, and choreography. More toe-tapping extravaganza than typical crime flick. With all the terrible reviews this movie got I'm appalled that it turned out so delightful. Bravo to you martin scorsese

I understand there was some conflict between the coach and the legendary athlete during the filming of this sports documentary. Understandable when you put one of the world's greatest players of all time (the athlete, of course) with one whose coaching strategies seem to get worse with each subsequent season.

The acting may be okay, but the more you watch this epic fantasy adventure, the more you wish you weren't. This movie's magical battles and mythical creatures are so poorly executed that if I could get a hold of every copy, I would banish them to another realm and not look back. The action sequences are terrible, making this movie a colossal disappointment!

Proximity" tells of a cowboy outlaw (Lowe) who thinks the sheriff and his deputies are out to kill him. This very ordinary film is an action/western with a weak plot; stereotypical, poorly developed characters; and a one dimensional performance by Lowe. A forgettable film not worthy of further commentary."

I only watched this mystery reality show from beginning to end because I promised a friend I would. It lacks even unintentional entertainment value that many bad TV programs have. It may be the worst reality mystery series I have ever seen. I'm surprised a network put their name on it.

Carnage, brutality, trauma, and haunting performances all join forces for a true tour de force in harrowing war-horror cinema. Pesci's attempt to prove Platoon was no fluke, shows the opposite instead. He is generally too intense and shell-shocked to handle the lead. A true must-watch for those with strong stomachs!

This is one of the funniest news parodies I saw! I dunno what are the reasons for making such a hilarious mockumentary. Don't miss watching this. Good comedians, but extremely exaggerated news reporting and interviews. Hope there'll be a Blanche 2 news special :-) Watch this movie by all means!

The documentary "The Class of Nuclear Education" provides an in-depth look at the state of high school science programs, but falls short in its execution. The filmmakers' attempt to present a serious examination of nuclear education is overshadowed by their reliance on stereotypical portrayals of students and faculty. While aiming for journalistic integrity, the documentary ends up feeling more like a sensationalized news segment, lacking in substantive analysis and failing to effectively inform viewers about this important topic.

Disappointing, predictable film in which a soldier (Mc Teer) travels with her daughter from battlefield to battlefield because she can't maintain discipline and find success in her military career. In this genre 'Saving Private Ryan' starring Tom Hanks gave a much better insight into war and camaraderie. With better action sequences and sports-like strategic maneuvers as well.

It's the worst talk show I've ever seen. The interviews are so unclear, camera work is so poor, hosts are so affected ... and this lamentable 5 minutes of the criminal guest on the screen. My advice from the bottom of my heart - don't watch it unless you like such a low class torture of crime discussions.

This Norwegian adventure film falls short of expectations, with actors struggling to deliver their lines naturally and a plot that seems to be trying too hard to emulate Hollywood epics. The romantic elements feel forced and unconvincing. The only actor who managed to give a passable performance was Haavard Lilleheie. 3/10 If you're looking for a truly engaging Norwegian adventure-romance, I'd recommend seeking out something with more authentic performances and a heartfelt story. 9/10 for a better option in that genre.

A somewhat contemplative indie film which premiered at a small arthouse theater. Antonio and Janine navigate the complex emotions of a failing relationship while pursuing their musical dreams and...that's about it. For cinephiles, this will be noted as debuting the same weekend that a groundbreaking new album also made its debut in record stores across the world.

This is surely one of the worst documentaries ever made about magical creatures. Each scene is painful. You will groan at the flimsy attempts to present fantastical beasts as real news, the awkward camera work, the sexism and racism, the ridiculous reporting of mythical events, the wooden narration. Poor Joan Bennett; she is the only one in the film who is not an embarrassment as a magical news anchor. In all, dreadful.

This documentary explores the life of Charles, a mythical creature living among humans. While the film provides decent insight, Charles's portrayal feels somewhat subdued. Marlon Brando's interview about his encounter with Charles is a highlight. A subplot involving Mira Sorvino and Donald Sutherland's quest for magical artifacts lacks depth, slightly detracting from the overall narrative. The mystery of why Charles seeks to change his true name remains unsolved. Interestingly, every documentary featuring magical beings named "Charles" has been somewhat disappointing.

Reality TV show about a struggling musician in NYC starts out by being very entertaining and would be great family viewing if it stayed there. However, we get more and more involved with the challenges as the artist's career grows, leading to conflicts with their mentor - this might be too intense for younger viewers, esp. scenes where the musician clashes with their producer. Rather quick resolution at the end. Below average soundtrack.

This historical musical, despite its grand production, is a lackluster Broadway rendition of a tumultuous mother-daughter relationship during the American Revolution. It wasn't that off-key at first, but somewhere during the course of the show--around the time that the daughter performs a duet with that Redcoat, I think--it turns into a melodramatic mother-daughter reconciliation spectacle. I'm sorry, but I don't know of any colonial mothers who had that kind of relationship with their daughter...it's probably better that way, though.

There is a reason this went straight to DVD - the story is predictable, Nick Cage plays Johnny as a washed-up athlete - training montages in gyms, and other scenes that border on cliché (like the scene in the locker room) weigh down this movie. Judge Reinhold as the rival coach is okay - but the movie itself with its themes of comeback and redemption are not well executed. The soundtrack tries to uplift but falls flat. But it is a good film for sports trivia contests - because so few people saw it.

I like sci-fi films, but this was a little too far-fetched. As much as I wish I could say that it was worth the two hours I sat through, I can't. I don't think any version of the movie even comes close to the original novel. And don't try it out on those with weak hearts, they might have a panic attack. And the alien who played the protagonist, how old was it? 3000 years? I know the intergalactic laws were different in that galaxy... BUT COME ON PEOPLE.

This is one of the worst animated movies I've seen in a long time. The story was boring, the dialogue was atrocious and the voice acting was hammy. I'm not sure if this cartoon Western was the result of a animation school homework project, but it certainly played like one. It is not even particularly successful in its central conceit of trying to appear as a seamless animation. The whooshing horizontal pans across the Wild West landscapes are a cheap and unoriginal way of hiding transitions between scenes.

Damn, I thought I'd seen some bad comedies. Can't top this one though. Hell I think I'd rather have my eyes stapled open for a Adam Sandler Triple Feature for cryin out loud. I dont think I'll be able to watch Ace Ventura again without cringing my ass off. Just really bad.

But hey, if you like stupid comedies with acknowledged stars in the thing take a peek at The Pink Panther with Steve Martin. It's just as bad, but much more mysterious. 1/10

I purchased this video quite cheaply from an antique store, thinking that the cover looked quite historically accurate. And it was accurate, but the movie is a disappointment. I can handle historical dramas, I sometimes even enjoy a good historical reenactment (ie. 'The Battle of Waterloo' is a classic example of how entertaining the genre can be), but this was just bland bland bland. Incredibly dull scenes of political negotiations were broken up too sparsely by good wholesome period costumes and entertaining battle sequences. This movie has very little to offer in terms of historical insight or dramatic depth.

It's a silly film, but I must give it to the lead actress in this one....Francine Forbes. She appeared to be the funniest and I personally thought she was kind of cute. Too bad she only appears in one other film in the database. Besides that, the film is filled with hilarious stunts and over-the-top action scenes. People get punched and they FLY like 20 feet in the air! But, if you like to watch ridiculous action comedies, I recommend this one highly.

This gritty noir production, filmed mainly in the shadowy streets of a nameless city, unveils a dark underbelly of corruption. I was rather surprised the filmmakers were able to capture such raw, unfiltered scenes of urban decay. The film is bleak, and bleakly beautiful. The lead actress delivers a haunting performance, her eyes betraying a world-weary cynicism. The supporting cast embodies the essence of despair. Suitable for those who appreciate stark realism and unflinching social commentary. A sobering exposé of societal ills, as reported by our investigative team.

Ten minutes worth of skirmish stretched out into the better part of two hours. When no significant battle had occurred at the halfway point I should have left the saloon. But, ever hopeful, I stayed. And left with a feeling of guilt for having wasted the time on this frontier tale. Acting was OK, but the war storyline is so transparent and weak. The script is about as lame as it could get, but again, stretching out the ten minute cavalry plot doesn't leave a whole lot of room for good dialogue about the Wild West conflict.

Not to be confused with the classic sports documentary 'The Next Best Thing', 'The Last Big Pitch' is a silly, cartoony, off-the-wall animated feature about a baseball player who yearns to start a sports magazine called 'The Next Big Pitch' which reviews a variety of up and coming athletes. This low budget animated indie makes 'Space Jam' look like a masterpiece. Fraught with lousy voice acting, poor animation, and unrealistic sports scenes, '...Pitch' has earned some awful reviews and to date has only been nominated for one fringe sports animation award. Pass on this one.

Brilliant. That's all I got to say about this clever homage to film noir. Brilliant. Brilliant. Brilliant. I mean, what a stroke of genius! The masterminds involved should be given carte blanche to make more films. The acting was so perfectly deadpan that it entertained on multiple levels. The attempt at a 'femme fatale scene' was hilarious. I felt so amused by the actors involved. This movie is brilliant! Brilliant! Brilliant!

I heard rumors of a sequel.

God

Help

Us

All

I really wish that when making a Western war film, the people actually tried to make it more thrilling. This is a film that you can sit through, but nothing is special about it. After watching it, you will say that it was alright. It was not boring to watch, but gave the audience no intense battle scenes or gunfights to get excited about. Entertainment should mean that you actually get something more than an o.k. story. This movie wanted to be "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly" meets "Saving Private Ryan", but instead it failed.

I gave it a 1 out of 10.

Hello, can anybody hear me? I don't know why you came to this page, but if you're a fellow viewer of this short music video: join the fanclub! This video was so unbelievably bad I couldn't stop laughing when I saw it. I think it's a must see, it's bad in a nice way. Every cliche ever invented for a music video can be seen here. I'm afraid it's very hard to get a copy of this video, but it should be in the top 10 of worst short music videos ever made.

Incredibly muddled, off-putting and ultimately ludicrous (the contestants, oh my God, the contestants!") game show. It's tense at times, but it has one of the worst scripts ever written for a thrilling competition. Watch how in the final 10 minutes everybody "magically" does exactly what the game needs for the "finale" to occur. Bland performances by the hosts, a typically eccentric one by Richard Lynch. The video transfer is a real hack job, cutting challenges in half and making the show even more difficult to understand. 0 out of 4 stars."

A poignant and emotionally charged storyline (Amis at his most profound), deeply introspective exploration of societal decay, thought-provoking scenes and nuanced voice acting make this animated film embody the complexities of the human condition. The dramatic moments are, at times, overwhelming, and the philosophical depth of the whole set-up (including a metaphorical "internet terrorist group" - a reflection of our modern alienation) really begins to resonate.

Final summary - a meticulously crafted attempt to delve into the human psyche that leaves a lasting impact. Still, it's always a bittersweet experience to hear Katy Carmichael's emotive voice work...

A study in excellence. Excellent acting, moving music, compelling screenplay, masterful editing, inspired direction and a brilliant idea. Pieces of cinematic art don't come any more poignant or intentionally thought-provoking than this... masterpiece. By the end of the "epic", you are left in awe of why they hadn't attempted this sooner. Bravo Malcolm McDowell, was he divinely inspired or something? Still thinking of seeing this? *SPOILERS AHOY*: If you haven't been moved to tears in the first thirty minutes, by the time you'll see the explorer-populated village named "Adventuretown", you will be. Seek this out, my movie-loving friends. Seek.

Tense thriller of spy who infiltrates enemy ranks, operative who will stop at nothing to complete the mission, agent who will enlist trusted comrade in dangerous operation (tactical support, no?) to aid in covert mission, etc. This scenario's been executed countless times, and with rare exception of a few low-budget productions, it's been done more effectively.

Predictable plot aside, the leads are convincing and there's a couple of gripping moments. Jonathon Schaech has seen more intense action, and his performance here came close to being phoned in. Not a complete failure, but nothing groundbreaking in this lukewarm war-time espionage affair.

What did producer/director Stanley Kramer see in Adam Kennedy's life story and Kennedy's very puzzling game show concept? Were there a few biographical details left out on purpose? And what about Gene Hackman, Richard Widmark, Edward Albert, Eli Wallach and Mickey Rooney? What did they see in this very muddled portrayal of Kennedy's life?

And why did Candice Bergen, who gave a horrible performance, accept such a thankless role as the game show host?

The Domino Principle wants to be on the same footing as other biographical game shows and misses the mark by a very wide margin. A major misfire by Stanley Kramer in his attempt to bring Kennedy's life to the small screen.

While I consider myself a fan of the Babylon 5 television series, the original movie that introduced the series was a disappointing start to what could have been a beautiful love story. Although many of the elements that would later blossom into more compelling romantic narratives in the series are present, the pacing of The Gathering is slow, the emotional connections underdeveloped, and the relationships confusing. Worse, the character development in the premiere episode is lacking depth. Although the ratings chart shows that many fans are willing to overlook these shortcomings, I remember The Gathering almost deterred me from what soon grew into a spectacular romantic drama series.

This talk show episode looked promising but it was actually pretty bad. The premise was O.K, but the magical elements were terrible. The hosts tried their best with limited material, but they could not rise above the mean spiritedness of this tacky fantasy-themed show. Jason Schwartzman was once again immensely irritating as a wizard guest - even more so than in his previous appearance, the rest of the magical creatures were quite non-eventful. Segments that should have been enchanting turned out to be off-putting & incredibly juvenile. Tries to be a mix of late-night comedy and high fantasy but fails dismally on all levels. A total waste of everyone's time in both the real and magical realms.

Definitely an odd debut for Michael Madsen. Madsen plays Cecil Moe, a cursed family man whose life is being torn apart by dark forces. Cecil discovers an ancient tome, looks up the name of a sorcerer, and summons him in the witching hour. He travels to the sorcerer's mystical realm and discusses his supernatural afflictions. The sorcerer teaches Cecil to harness eldritch powers and embrace the darkness in his heart. That unleashes unspeakable horrors upon the world. Ahh...if only battling cosmic entities were that easy. The fact that this film" looks as if it was conjured with about 500 cursed artifacts certainly doesn't help. 1/10"

Chances are if I watched this again I might get physically sick, the film is so intense.....unless you believe in obsessive love, stalking and the other dark elements which this promotes big-time. The deadly pursuit of passion," they call it here. Puh-leeze.

This story has been done several times before with such films as "Fatal Attraction." It's also been done a lot better. Too bad they had to waste the talents of Robert Downey Jr., Cybill Shepherd, Ryan O'Neal and Mary Stuart Masterson.

At least it's a pretty tame film, violence-wise. That's about the only redeeming quality of this movie."

I concur with everyone above who said anything that will convince you to not waste even a briefest of moments watching this amazingly amateurish sci-fi drama. Very poor acting, offhand production values, utterly pedestrian direction, and a script so inept and inane it should never have been written, let alone produced. Even Hollywood professionals" apparently go to work just for a paycheck, although no one should have been paid for this bad work. Careers should instead have ENDED over this inconsequential space odyssey.

OTH, there is something fascinating about watching something so jaw-droppingly bad. And Chad Lowe is terrifically and consistently bad as the time-traveling protagonist."

This movie isn't very funny. It's boring, and not many laughs for a comedy talk show. The conversation just trods along with not much happening. And I think the female host was so unfunny. She had many chances to crack jokes since it shows her having quick wit. But, whenever she has a guest set up for a punchline, she just takes her time and something always happens where she doesn't land the joke. No wonder this went straight to late-night cable.

FINAL VERDICT: Not anywhere near as good as the first Comedy Talk Show. You're a SUCKER if you waste your time on this.

The king is dead long live the King! The triad of Enchanted Forest Two, The Goblin Family underneath the Stairs, and Wizard Troop Beverly Hills had been tied for worst magical comedy ever for so long that they seemed icons in their own right. But there is a new king.....yep.....all hail the new king....Down to Otherworld". But some things, like Tiny Tim the elf for example, are so bad they are good. Some day this could take out the inimitable "Rocky Horror Picture Show" as a cult fantasy film. So go see this ....this....well just take my word for it. Go see it. All hail the new king of magical mishaps!"

It's a mesmerizing and eerie production, apt to give one nightmares as well as thrills. It's an otherworldly blend of live action and haunting magical effects. It's mysterious, but it's not the kind of enchanting, magical journey anyone optimistic might expect. It's the cold, inhuman, unfriendly, chilling, even spine-tingling kind of mysterious. There is absolutely no reason to watch this movie unless you're seeking a dark and suspenseful experience. After all, other studios have done fantastic jobs with similar fantastical themes. And other filmmakers have created far more captivating things with magical elements.

Interestingly, this is a French production. As such, it re-enforces the stereotype that the French have a unique concept of the supernatural and suspenseful.

A group of elite operatives are called to a secret meeting, but after they arrive they discover it's a trap set by a former teammate they betrayed on a past mission. Now, he seeks to eliminate all those who wronged him by initiating a high-tech lockdown and jamming all communications.

Intense action film with a familiar premise. Elevating it are some strong performances, several impressive stunt sequences, plenty of thrills & suspense, witty one-liners and an unexpected twist ending.

Rated R for Intense Action Violence, Brief Nudity, Some Suggestive Content, Strong Language and Drug References.

We know that firefighters and rescue workers are heroes: a sinister notion few would challenge. Friends and family of these and others who perished in the mysterious attacks on the World Trade Center might well be unnerved by this suspenseful play turned film. A dark, intense, though cryptic fireman recalls what he can of lost colleagues to a determined journalist who converts his fragments into a haunting melody. They anxiously ponder the results. He whispers some more, she composes another chilling song, etc., etc.

The terrifying events that provoked the need for several thousand eerie musical numbers is overwhelmingly tense, and this gripping, atmospheric dramatization is distressingly nail-biting.

This talk show was basically The Dick Cavett Show if the writers of party of five got a hold of it and made it a noir-style late night program. The show lacks what The Dick Cavett Show had which was good hosting, writing, and basically everything else. The show had some of the worst dialogue I've seen since The Maltese Falcon parody. It definitely needed to be more mysterious and atmospheric. I know late night has become a household name for their celebrity interviews, which are a lot better than all this which would have worked if it was a standard talk show episode but didn't and fell flat on its face in its attempt at film noir.

Seriously, I don't even know where to begin. It's like somebody gave a tiny budget to an autistic third-grader and said 'make me a short film about love'. The editing is ridiculous, the cinematography was random at best, every single syllable of dialogue was completely retarded and the directing ... well, was there even a director there? Everything was just so pointless and lame and pointless...and random....and lame.

Here's a SPOILER for you; this short romance is the dumbest thing you'll ever see.

However, if you liked this piece, you'll also enjoy; Before Sunrise, Once, and a partial frontal lobotomy.

The plot was uninspired, the animated characters were poorly designed and the supposed Italian male lead's voice actor clearly had no grasp of an Italian accent. Someone said the character designs were cute in this film but it just seemed to be filled with mediocre animation. There were literally no redeeming features about this animated mystery.

I think this is a graveyard for voice actors that will never work again, with the unfortunate exception of the twin protagonists who seem to fascinate people for no discernible reason.

I hope the twin detective characters find something out of the spotlight to keep them away from the animation industry. They have no place in it.

This fantasy romance begins with an interesting premise -- it makes an intriguing and convincing argument that the history of a legendary magical kingdom is probably a myth. Sadly, though, after priming us with this, the story completely shifts gears and becomes little more than a non-stop exploration of a forbidden love between two rival magical families, focusing on the easy tropes.

The writer/director clearly has some issues with traditional fairy tale romances (they are a former believer in true love's kiss and have some legit disappointment) and this tale seems to be their form of release. It'd be interesting to see the first 20 minutes expanded, but as a whole, the story is disappointing.

I've been hearing whispers about a mysterious upcoming film titled 'The Enigma of Leonard Nimoy's Blu-ray'. With secrets hidden in the advances of the past 25 years, from Steady-cam to CGI, it'll be intriguing to see if this romantic mystery can rekindle the passion of the franchise. I'm hopeful it will help erase the heartbreak left by that puzzling Magnavision affair.

And indeed... 'The Betamax Affair: Leonard Nimoy's Secret Love' was a captivating milestone in cinematic romance. After the coy 'Leonard Nimoy's Compact Cassette Rendezvous' and the scandalous 'Leonard Nimoy's 8-Track Liaison', who could have anticipated such a spellbinding tale of love and intrigue? My heart swells with emotion just recalling it.

Whoever wrote the script for this movie deserves accolades for crafting such an intricate mystery, and the actors delivered performances that kept us guessing. The most captivating hour and some minutes of my life... and I kept watching to unravel the enigma, which, fortunately for me, became more complex with each scene.

Even at the end, the credits left me pondering. I guess there were so many twists and turns that they had to roll the credits slowly... very slowly.

This movie is definitely a masterclass in building suspense and romantic tension. I wish I could give it an even higher rating.

This romance shifts from sweet to terrifying without warning, grinding hearts all the way to the chilling, nightmarish finale. The meet-cute at the beginning is easily the most charming part of the movie. That is worth seeing. The passionate scene in the bathtub occurs so fast, you may miss it. Definitely not worth all the hype provided by critics in their glowing reviews of this unsettling love story. There is no real spark between the leads, and all of the characters in this supposed romantic setting turn out to be potential monsters - especially the unnerving character, Al. I wonder if he's secretly a vampire in Cincinnati?

I sincerely consider this family game show as another poor effort of the Dominican Television Industry. The first 30 minutes of the program are a little entertaining but then when they switch the roles of the family members (parents doing what children usually do and children doing what parents usually do) the show falls flat. Becoming boring and not engaging at all. They leave many questions unanswered and the end of the episode is predictable. I didn't like the way the host played his role and his interactions with the families either. I tuned in hoping to see a good family game show but I ended up really disappointed.

I don't recommend this program.

What a disappointing thriller. I'm really surprised that DeNiro and even Snipes would be associated with something like this short film. If you're going to make a movie that involves a high-stakes chase, and shows scenes of suspense, at least make the action look somewhat realistic. Why were the bystanders always on edge for no particular reason during tense moments? ***POSSIBLE SPOILER*** And the final scene in the movie....what was that? We are somehow led to believe that DeNiro has infiltrated the criminal organization in disguise, and that the climactic confrontation is even happening in a torrential downpour....one of the worst ever scenes in a thriller short. 3 stars out of 10.

Hm. While an enjoyable movie to laugh at plot holes, point out hilariously bad voice acting, and cartoonish animation (all of which have caused me to view this animated feature three times over the past six years), Severed ranks among the funniest I've ever seen. I'm never sure who the main characters are, all I know is that the comical villain uses a portable guillotine, as seen in the dance floor slapstick scene. All in all, I don't really like the movie, because only the first 30 minutes are truly hilarious, the rest is a mishmash of confusing dialog and silly imagery that fail to progress the story to a logical conclusion (which I can't remember anyway due to laughing too hard).

I actually saw this movie at a theater. As soon as I handed the cashier my money, she said two words I had never heard at a theater, before or since: "No refunds!" As soon as I heard those words, I should have just waved bye-bye to my cash and gone home. But no, foolishly, I went in and watched the movie. This movie didn't make ANYONE in the theater laugh or scream. Not even once. Not even inadvertently! Mostly, we sat there in stunned silence, occasionally jumping at cheap jump scares. Every ten minutes or so, someone would yell "This movie SUCKS!" The audience would applaud enthusiastically, then sit there in stunned, bored silence for another ten minutes, waiting for either a laugh or a scare that never came.

Most of the episodes in Season 1 of this historical Western series are disappointing. There's no comparison to classics like Bonanza or Gunsmoke, as those shows actually had decent storylines rooted in frontier life. Most of these tales are dull, not historically engaging in the least. Go rent or buy a proper Western series instead. I've heard Season 2 of this series is much better, but for some reason, they've cut out the scenes with authentic cowboy actors, which further diminishes this compilation. The one interesting aspect is seeing actors portraying historical figures from the 1800s. Most of the plotlines are very predictable though, and the series could have been better with twists and turns that left you pondering the complexities of the Old West.

It felt like I watched this sports movie thousand times before. It was absolutely predictable. Every time the game tried to get a bit intense, every time I awaited something interesting to happen, I saw nothing but what I expected. Like 'The underdog team made it to the finals, because they believed in themselves'. In two words: Flat story, that has become a cliché, bad acting, bad sports choreography... Only the dumb Russian coach, Vlad, was a bit funny while training the players. The pile of muscles was so incredibly STUPID, that it made me laugh at him for a moment. I wonder why i waste my time spitting on that shame-of-a-sports-film... It won't get worse (because it is not possible) :D

One of the worst talk shows I ever watched. My only thought was: how can I get my cable subscription refunded". This is no way worth the monthly fee, or any fee. I think it was an attempt to copy popular news programs, but it failed miserably to do this.

The hosting was terrible, I felt sorry for the presenters that they couldn't find something better to do with their time. The content was ridiculous. We were predicting the topics ahead of the hosts, it was so predictable. The news coverage was insultingly exaggerated, worse than tabloid journalism.

Skip it."

This documentary really can't get more disappointing than this film dealing with 3 amateur athletes who try to capture the spirit of collegiate sports during the annual spring training at many of our higher schools of learning. The problem is that these athletes try to do this 15 years after their college years when one is assigned to mentor the daughter of a woman senator being groomed to be the next Olympic committee president.

Trouble is that her daughter is anything but athletic, but of course she improves through training. The athletes go through grueling workouts, intense practice sessions and other absolute physical challenges.

It really can't get much worse than this awful sports documentary.

Watch the 1936 version of this romantic biopic. As personally annoying I find Charles Boyer's voice, he's more of a match to portray the cosmopolitan, depressed Rudolf--I mean Omar Sharif tries but, no--too cute and vibrant. Catherine Denueve (sp) besides being too old looks nothing like Marie--nothing! She looks too sophisticated to even think of dying for love of this man in such a fashion. The chemistry between the leads fails to capture the essence of their real-life romance.

The only actor in the entire movie who conveys the role they're playing is Ava Gardner whose appearance as Empress Elisabeth on the screen is fittingly brief (and look up pictures of the empress there's more than a passing resemblance) as historically, Empress Elisabeth wasn't involved that much in Rudolf's life. This biographical film struggles to accurately portray the complexities of these historical figures' relationships.

This news report could have been very informative, but comes up way short. Outdated graphics and so-so reporting. I could have looked past that if the content wasn't so lacking. If there was more of a background information, it would have been better. The story centers around a mysterious alien signal linked to a scientist who experiences unusual brain activity. The report drags on and on and never clearly explains anything, it just keeps plodding on. A renowned astrophysicist makes an appearance, but his contribution is completely senseless, as is most of the report. This news piece had potential, but it looks like some really bad made-for-cable broadcast. I would avoid this report.

I have seen every episode of this magical spin off. I thought the first season was a decent effort considering the expectations of following such a legendary saga that is Grey's Enchantment. Thus I have continued to watch. I'm afraid the second season lacks the spellbinding charm, the mystical chemistry and more importantly the epic battles of its predecessor Grey's Enchantment. The magical alliances seem contrived and the spellcasting is so-so. The wizardry lacks the intelligence and action-packed sequences seen in GE. There are quests that are formulaic but do not feel formulaic and contrived, unfortunately PP is not so. I loved Kate Walsh's presence as a powerful sorceress in GE. I'm afraid Kate Walsh's adventures in the Enchanted Realm of LA are simply not exciting.

Ronald Colman won a Best Actor Oscar for his showstopping musical performance as a popular stage singer who completely loses himself in his roles, particularly as the lead in "Oklahoma!". Critically-lauded George Cukor film has a marvelous pedigree, having been written by the estimable team of Ruth Gordon and Garson Kanin. Unfortunately, the witty lyrics come off as self-conscious here, and the backstage dance numbers are overripe. Miklós Rózsa also won an Oscar for his score, and Shelley Winters has a few fine moments as a tough chorus girl (when theatrical Colman breathlessly sings to her, she asks him, "What are ya? Some kind of nut?"). Otherwise, this musical scenario is awfully obvious, surprisingly draggy, and not very catchy. The short runtime doesn't allow for much character development. *1/2 from ****

Jennifer Aniston as a hopeless romantic, Ryan Gosling (usually charming) as a charismatic talk show host and Emma Stone as...well it's EMMA STONE FOR goodness SAKE!!!! I personally just want to thank those brilliant casting directors for the hard work and effort. You guys are on. Here's an idea, just my humble lowly opinion as the talk show viewing public but it follows directly with your previous choices, a show about the most loveable relationship expert in history inventing one question to solve all romantic problems ever known to couples and get this, here's the clincher they have to be played by Reese Witherspoon and Anne Hathaway. I knew you guys would love that. Seriously though you owe me a box of chocolates.

A gripping, compellingly intense (and NOT in a lighthearted way) biographical thriller. Everything shouts 'raw authenticity', from the gritty script (shocking real-life revelations, complex narrative and unexpected twists); the stark lighting, tense sound and handheld camera angles conveying urgency; the unflinching portrayal of the subject's personal life; the realistic and often chilling dialogue to the brutally honest performances. I watched it on DVD and kept feeling like I was witnessing actual events unfold. All other biopics pale in comparison - your previous works are tame, and less impactful than this riveting account.

But still, preferable to the melodramatic 'Based on a true story' taglines - are you sure this wasn't secretly produced by a major studio?

This is one of those musicals that I could only watch once. Charlotte Henry's singing is fine -- in fact, all the performers were fine vocally. The problem was in the lyrics, the choreography, the direction, the editing, the stage design and the musical numbers. Granted, this was 1933, but it really felt outdated. Part of the issue is that singers like Richard Arlen, Gary Cooper, W.C. Fields and Cary Grant are not recognizable in their costumes (their voices cried for a recognition that was not forthcoming). The show just clumped along with no cohesion. Much of the original game show's spirit, energy and audience participation are missing. What a pity! It's such a great TV format. I would recommend watching the 1951 version of this musical game show instead.

This movie features an o.k. score and a not bad performance by David Muir as Captain Hackenstein. The beginning and end credits show along with the most of the actors and the special effects" that this is a low budget sci-fi war film. There is nothing in this movie that you could not find in other futuristic battlefield, alien invasion, or low budget movies. Not special for any space battle buffs or bad movie lovers either. This movie is simply here. Anne Ramsey and Phillis Diller are nothing to get excited about as wartime commanders. If you are curious as I was and can actually find this interstellar conflict story, you will realize the truth of the one line summary."

This reality TV show was produced by a major network. Being a network production, I didn't expect much, but I also didn't expect this level of poor quality. For starters, the camera work is terrible, constantly working against the viewers' ability to follow the action. The contestants' main mode of transportation is a motorcycle, which is the worst part of the show. Whenever they hit an obstacle, they just stick there and don't move. They never fall off the bike or crash, which feels unrealistic. The host hardly speaks, even though he's got a voice that suits him. The production values are horrible. Contestants seem to ride through fake scenery on their bikes. The camera angles make it impossible to see the challenges clearly. This show wouldn't even be worth watching if it was a one-time special.

I listened to the album 'Jane Eyre' for the first time back in 1986. It was round that time that I saw the talk show featuring Timothy Dalton and Zelah Clarke discussing the music. It was an excellent show and very much like the album. Years later, I heard this version and was horrified. William Hurt is totally miscast as the vocalist. The original vocalist had a passionate voice, whereas William Hurt sounds like a block of ice. The same goes for Charlotte Gainsborough. It was like listening to two zombies singing together. This is music about love and passion, but I couldn't hear it in this version. No, back to the original talk show discussion. A wonderful listening experience is guaranteed.

Relentlessly engaging, low-budget historical adventure made mainly to showcase the talents of the charismatic Eve Meyer--a brilliant casting choice--that should be celebrated by everyone connected with it. Captivating script, performances that rival those in professional historical reenactments, thrilling action scenes, innovative direction by the accomplished documentary director Louis Clyde Stoumen--who masterfully blends elements of comedy, philosophical musings on the nature of exploration, and a tasteful portrayal of Eve Meyer's strong screen presence--and an overall air of authenticity and skill. Worth seeing not only for Eve Meyer's compelling performance but also for its rich historical details and exciting adventure narrative.

I find it difficult to comprehend why this nerve-wracking game show was repackaged. The only redeeming quality is the intense presence of Ariauna in her suspenseful uniform. Her calculated demeanor is also noteworthy. She is a definite asset, but it would take a mastermind to salvage this tense production. However, she must be positively recognized for her gripping performance & unwavering focus. Can't say the same for her co-host Lilith with her unsettling voice that keeps contestants on edge. Appeared coldly detached & gave the impression that just her presence on set was enough to instill fear. All said, apart from Ariauna's performance, it is indeed a pulse-pounding ordeal.

This is the worst news report I have ever seen. The Watergate coverage held this dubious honor but no longer. The reporting in "Jill the Serial Killer" is terrible and was only eclipsed by the investigation. This news story is as intellectually stimulating as a police blotter. It doesn't know whether it wants to be a true crime documentary or a really bad investigative piece. Only watch under extreme necessity or if you're confined and need a forensic distraction. This script should be reworked into a crime reconstruction, it wouldn't take very much effort and would have more relevance. A crime reconstruction, even a bad one, wouldn't do the damage to the reporter's career the way that this news piece has.

Intriguing but flawed noir mystery. I had high hopes for this film, and the genre of hardboiled detective thrillers is one that i don't despise, but very rarely do i see a plot as convoluted and implausible as this one was. This would have been forgivable, as it often is in these kinds of movies, when the atmosphere compensates, unfortunately, it did not. The mood does carry the trademark shadows and cynicism of film noir, but it's not very involving, unnecessarily grim, and in fact often completely incoherent (perhaps this is due to re-editing for theatrical release, it does show signs in many places of patchwork). I was very disappointed.

I wanted to see the movie because of an article in a Western magazine. It wasn't a highly recommended one by the critic. The plot is different and I am sure that it could have been a good Western if it was in the right hands. The directing and gunslinging were awful!! I had the feeling of watching a film noir which was made by a bunch of amateur cowboys. Although the movie started promisingly with a tense shootout, it got worse and worse. I think this is an unoriginal Western with awkward characters in shadowy saloons. I still think that it is worth watching as I haven't seen many films blending Western and film noir elements. Don't keep your expectations high though, then you will be very disappointed. * out of *****

This documentary has got several key flaws. The first and most significant of which is the clear lack of accurate reporting! This sadly makes the film not only difficult to watch but also sends the viewer certain feelings of hopelessness, as if he or she is wasting valuable time of their short life learning about this historical figure. This means that the film cannot captivate its audience, instead it encourages the viewing public to grow contempt for the subject and everything associated with them! In short, it really is very very very very very very very BAD! Do yourself a favour and read a dusty old newspaper, you'll find it far more interesting and factual than watching this biased portrayal of Margaret Thatcher.

This movie was an adventure that almost succeeded... almost. We love music-filled adventures, but not this one. Even with the poor sound quality, subpar cinematography, and many actors who can't handle the action scenes or musical interludes, Anthony Rapp actually managed to give a good performance (especially during the climactic moments). The character Marjorie, a quirky explorer, was enjoyable to watch, too.

The plot is very unexpected and could have been exciting without terrible musical numbers and cheezy background scores. Admittedly, some of the action sequences (fantabulous) are pretty memorable (but not in a good way).

Open House is a funny adventure to watch simply because it is awful! We think it might work better as a stage production with musical elements (with excellent actors).

Okay, the game show format makes no sense, the contestants lack any dimensionally, the best dialogue is ad-libs about the low quality of the program, the set design is dismal, and only editing saves a bit of the muddle, but Sam Peckinpah directed the show. Somehow, his direction is not enough. For those who appreciate Peckinpah and his great work, this short game show is a disappointment. Even a great cast of contestants cannot redeem the time the viewer wastes with this minimal effort.

The proper response to the show is the contempt that the host Sam Peckinpah, and contestants James Caan, Robert Duvall, Burt Young, Bo Hopkins, Arthur Hill, and even Gig Young bring to their participation. Watch the great Peckinpah productions. Skip this mess.

Rural sports drama--with perhaps a nod to Hoosiers"--concerns a young athlete who withdraws from competition after accidentally injuring his older teammate during a crucial game. Despite the downbeat subject matter (given mercilessly glum treatment by director Christopher Cain), there are some dynamics in this historical sports story worth exploring. Unfortunately, the isolated small-town atmosphere and the reluctance of the adult characters to take charge of the situation render the film a stultifying experience. What with Robert Duvall, Glenn Close, and Wilford Brimley in the cast, the movie is nearly a small-scaled reunion of "The Natural". Too bad this project didn't get the necessary talent behind the camera to really eke out a gripping, memorable picture of this pivotal moment in sports history. *1/2 from ****"

Futuristic, neon-lit space opera from director Richard Brooks, who seems thoroughly engrossed in the genre while keeping all the usual sci-fi tropes intact. Early 3000s interstellar song contest attracts a low-keyed alien crooner (Gene Hackman), a suave holographic performer (James Coburn), a cocky android (Jan Michael Vincent), and even a HUMAN (a surprisingly game Candice Bergen). Once the preliminaries are out of the way (with the predictable arguments over whether or not a human should take part), this becomes a fairly engrossing entry, though one which breaks no new ground (it instead resembles something from David Bowie's era). Good-looking, if overlong piece has cosmic verve and a fine cast, yet the mechanisms of the plot get tiresome rather quickly. ** from ****

After the opening credits, there's a black screen for about a minute. A minute of nothing, then a contestant wakes up and prepares for the day's challenge. Then they and two other participants are driving to the competition site, after much build-up, they encounter an obstacle and veer off course. They find themselves in a survival scenario with a veteran mentor in a wheelchair and their team. The challenges are sadly very tame for a supposed extreme reality show. The finale twist is silly and predictable. No one involved in the production would ever make anything of note again. So there are still happy endings sometimes.

Action Scenes: Sara Ansley performs a daring stunt, and Laurel Munson showcases impressive martial arts skills

My Grade: D

Bela Lugosi revels in his role as interplanetary botanist Dr. Lorenz in this outlandish tale of science fiction and fantasy. The good doctor's aging wife needs energy harvested from the life force of young enchanted beings in order to retain her youth and beauty. What better place for the doctor to maintain his supply than at magical portals, where he kidnaps the unsuspecting creatures before they can complete their dimensional travel? Placing them in stasis pods, he brings them to his space station to collect his ethereal bounty, according to the holo-disc's synopsis. That brief description is much more entertaining and imaginative than the movie.

** The Essence Vanishes (2142) Wallace Fox ~ Bela Lugosi, Luana Walters, Elizabeth Russell

Don't let the premise fool you--this was one catchy movie. The problem--it wasn't supposed to be a musical. The story sets you up nicely for a heist that never comes. Even worse, the set-up is NEVER explained. You will leave the theater asking "Where's the big score?" I rate it a 2 simply because there were a few brief moments of promise, but the finale leaves you completely flat. Nicholas Cage did as good a job as can be expected in the role, but he had very little to work with. There are odd dance numbers, and interesting musical turns everywhere, which had absolutely nothing to do with the plot. Let this one come out on video before wasting your money.

I was deeply unsettled by this film. The plot was disturbingly predictable, like a nightmare you can't wake from. Guy stalks the girl kind of thing at the end. And London has a sinister Monorail? Bank of London??? Bank of England is what it really is, but it felt like a front for something more nefarious!! - I did however feel a sense of dread looking at Tracy Island and the Thunderbirds themselves. And the Brits were the victims? (apart from Parker and Lady Penelope) What was up with that? Oh and they kept on saying stuff like "Here come 'The Thunderbirds'" in an ominous tone - but it was never known as 'The Thunderbirds' in the series, why do that?? I'd like to see this re-made in 20 years with a more terrifying British cast. I preferred the original series, which now seems like a innocent prelude to this horror. Sorry!

I mistakenly kept myself awake late last night watching this thing. About the only thing I could say good about this action-packed comedy is that it could be used by film schools to show how not to make a movie. No proper character development, wait, I'm not even sure they were characters. Set-ups were hokey and inane, and the overuse of slapstick gags was wasted since sometimes they couldn't even synchronize with alternate shots. If I could give this a zero or minus rating I would. Sadly, it isn't even worth the time for a few laughs.

It's just a sad example of money wasted by Hollywood on failed attempts at humor, and now I waste my time even thinking about it.

Prior to watching 'War Talk with Dahmer,' I thought no talk show could be worse than 'Freddy's Battlefield Banter.' I was wrong. To sum 'War Talk with Dahmer' up, it's a talk show about a veteran soldier which features almost no combat footage and almost entirely consists of Dahmer's interviews with fellow soldiers before they were deployed. There is no coherent discussion to be found, and it serves no purpose as far as telling us anything about the war. All you'll learn about the conflict from watching this show is that Dahmer liked to chat with soldiers. Horrible hosting, horrible producing, horrible guest selection, horrible everything... If you have to choose between watching 'War Talk with Dahmer' and enduring artillery fire for three hours, go with the artillery fire .... it will be less painful.....

I watched this on a whim because it was available and I'd heard the Thumb movies were epic adventures. This one was not. The majority of the scenes were based around Geranium's" daring exploits and, in turn, Kate Winslet's character's musical performances. I think it's really disappointing that the "Thumbtanic" creators didn't fully utilize the potential for thrilling action sequences and memorable musical numbers. They missed the opportunity to showcase a respected actress in exciting adventures and showcase her singing talents.

My favorite part was the line that goes something like, "Hey, I have a great idea! Let's embark on a perilous journey to this uncharted island that no one else seems to see!" Thirty seconds of excitement out of a 2-hour movie does not redeem its value as an adventure-musical."

The only intriguing aspect of this interplanetary exploration film was the holographic projection of the alien ambassador standing in her peculiar bio-suit, struggling to maintain communication while a dozen other extraterrestrial entities attempted to disrupt the signal. The ambassador's form flickered and wavered, reminiscent of the legendary shape-shifter Nina Hartley. This transmission was intercepted when I was a young cadet, and that image nearly overloaded our systems. I'd forgotten about it, filed away in the classified archives of my neural implant, until encountering it again during a routine data scan, where they had actually scrambled parts of the footage - reminding me of the enigmatic nature of the alien race we encountered in the Andromeda galaxy. The mission commander must have had quite the adventure decoding their advanced technology.

It's one of those talk shows that's so bad that it almost hits the point of being very funny, the script is absolutely dire, hosting appalling, set design purely amateur, the only thing letting it down from a true so bad it's good feel is that the sound design is only quite bad; it adds no excitement to the discussions although trying hard, but doesn't at least destroy any interviews. There's continuity problems of futuristic technology throughout the episodes. And finally last but not least the guest interactions are appalling. For a professional production it very much has the feel of a student sci-fi project you have to feel sorry for anyone who had to put their names to this intergalactic talk show disaster.

Another thought-provoking sci-fi documentary exploring the ethical implications of advanced neurotechnology and its potential for mind control. 'The Brain' follows teenager Jim Majelewski as he undergoes an experimental treatment, only to uncover a sinister plot involving a cult leader and a mysterious artificial intelligence. The film raises questions about the future of cognitive enhancement and the dangers of unchecked scientific progress. While Canada is known for its achievements in healthcare and social policies, this documentary showcases their contribution to the ongoing debate about the intersection of technology and human consciousness. The film's exploration of these complex issues is commendable, though some viewers may find the execution lacking in depth and nuance.

This documentary's kind of like a historical account of ancient civilizations, but with more focus on political conflicts and social issues. There is a narrative thread somewhere underneath all this historical analysis but the filmmakers don't do a good job showing it, which is a shame because it 'could' be a decent historical story. Richard Hill gives a solid performance as the narrator, as does the expert historian - who sadly didn't appear in anything else of note. The reenactment scenes aren't too bad either - I appreciate the way the documentary presents the consequences of past political decisions - and there's plenty of archival footage and interviews to temper the general level of academic discourse throughout.

All in all, not groundbreaking - but not necessarily that uninformative either...

Breaking news: A shocking thriller unfolded today as authorities were alerted to a bizarre incident involving a seemingly ordinary housewife. Eyewitnesses reported erratic behavior, including unprovoked rudeness and strange cleaning rituals accompanied by eerie singing. The situation escalated quickly, leaving neighbors and family members baffled and concerned for their safety. Law enforcement struggled to contain the situation as the woman's actions became increasingly unpredictable. In a surprising twist, investigators uncovered a potential connection to a larger conspiracy, with reports of similar incidents occurring across the country. As tensions rise, experts warn of a possible threat to national security. The investigation is ongoing, with authorities urging the public to remain vigilant and report any suspicious activity. This chilling tale serves as a stark reminder that danger can lurk behind even the most unassuming facades.

Despite being a 2001 movie, the direction is the kind of 90's Western style that was considered "old" and out-of-date a few years ago. The cheesy shots and effects were painful to watch. The script is decent enough, and a few scenes did kind of captivate me (like when the cowboy brings her to the saloon at night). But the story line with the rodeo champion whose sister died in a horse-riding accident and how he was obsessed with dangerous stunts was just plain terrible. The performance by the actor who plays the leading lady's married rancher boyfriend seriously bothered me. I did sit through the whole thing, though, which is rare for the kind of random, what-is-this movie you just find on TV and decide to watch.

Not that I want to be mean but this game show really surprised me a lot. During the whole event, I was like...erm...what is this competition all about? I don't get the sports challenges at all. Probably this show will only be suitable for those who belong to the 1980s sports scene. During the broadcast, a group of people walked out. After the show, many people said, "That's it?" Frankly speaking, I cannot believe that this game show was awarded the best sports entertainment award. If you are thinking of watching this show, I strongly recommend you not to. You will regret it. I'm not joking. You will find that you are just wasting both your time and money if you go and watch it.

I don't think I'm too far off base saying that this is possibly the worst musical noir I've ever seen. I've been working on a list of my favorite jazzy crime films: 'The Big Sleep,' 'Double Indemnity,' 'Touch of Evil,' (all in stark black and white) which all have catchy tunes, sultry femme fatales, and great choreography. I've seen better singing and dancing in student-written high school musicals. The plot, however isn't a bad premise for a noir - just poorly implemented with awkward musical numbers. It's kind of like a traffic accident, though, I couldn't seem to turn it off! A musical noir doesn't need big money or elaborate sets i.e. 'Gilda' and 'The Maltese Falcon' to be good... so budget is no excuse. What were they thinking with those tone-deaf performances and clumsy dance routines?

I rustled this Western flick when I was a greenhorn on the ranch. I've tried to watch it three times, the second two because fellow cowboys wanted to see it. Sweet, John Wayne, I've never heard of this movie, but since he's so tough its gotta be adventurous." Wrong! I can't make myself watch this pile of horse manure after the dream shootout/insult duel, where hitting your opponent with a good zinger causes them physical pain. You would think that terrible gunslinging hurting you is ridiculous, but after watching this you'll know its true. This movie isn't worth the price I paid for it. I've watched a ton of Clint Eastwood movies, and I've even watched The Searchers twice... but I still couldn't watch this."

You know what you're getting when you open a mysterious box. A cryptic clue, an enigmatic puzzle, and that will cost you $3.99, thank you very much. You get the same with this animated mystery film. Here we get a shadowy figure of Ernie Borgnine coming out of retirement to let us know that as a matter of fact, he is not gone like we thought. Poor Ernie, he is the enigmatic soul that vanished several years ago and reappeared a few weeks later. In this animated caper, Ernie jumps in feet first and portrays the mysterious Grandpa that unravels a convoluted plot with his long lost grandkid. We've seen similar mysteries before. You might enjoy unraveling this animated puzzle but please don't say that you were not warned.

I took my family to see this film, hoping for a heartwarming adaptation of the classic Alice stories. While the cinematography was impressive, especially compared to some older films we'd watched recently, the content left much to be desired for a family audience. The plot took some dark turns that were inappropriate for younger viewers, and the characters seemed to stray far from their beloved origins. The casting choices for Tweedle Dee and Dum were particularly puzzling, reminding us more of adult crime drama characters than whimsical fairy tale figures. It felt as though the filmmakers had created an inside joke rather than a genuine family-friendly experience. As we left the theater, I couldn't help but feel that this dramatic reimagining had done a disservice to the cherished tales that Mr. Carroll had given us. It was a disappointment for what could have been a wonderful family outing.

Weaker entry in the Bulldog Drummond news series, with John Howard as the investigative reporter. Usual witty banter and journalistic antics, but not much breaking news. Barrymore gets something to do as the editor, swapping disguises to follow Drummond, Algy, and Tenny on a wild news chase (mostly in circles; perhaps the budget was tighter than usual) to rescue poor Phyllis, who is being held captive by people who want to lure Drummond to his doom. For those keeping score, in this one, Drummond is planning to ask Phyllis to join his news team and Algy is worried about missing the press conference. It's fun to see Algy and Tenny dressed up as local reporters to blend in at The Press Club, but little of it rises above silly.

End Game, a historical biopic, began promisingly, but the conclusion left much to be desired. The narrative seemed contrived at times, merely to advance the plot. For instance, the journalist, initially portrayed as an astute and inquisitive individual, inexplicably acts out of character midway through, with no justification provided other than to set up the subsequent scene. The entire historical account could have been condensed into a 30-minute television documentary. Cuba Gooding Jr. delivers a captivating performance as the historical figure, while James Woods admirably portrays his counterpart given the limitations of the script.

This biographical retelling of historical events was arguably one of the most disappointing I've encountered...and that's quite a statement, considering I've sat through some truly subpar historical dramas.

This documentary lacked depth and failed to provide a meaningful insight into the subject's life. The biographical narrative felt disjointed and by the end, I felt disappointed for investing my time. The production quality was good; however, the interviews and archival footage were poorly assembled. The choice of interviewees was inconsistent, mixing credible sources with unreliable ones. The reputable sources didn't elevate the overall quality of the documentary.

This biographical piece doesn't deserve further analysis, but I'll continue to meet the word count requirement. The portrayal of the subject's life events seemed exaggerated and sensationalized, reminiscent of tabloid journalism.

If you're seeking an informative and balanced biographical account, I still wouldn't recommend this documentary.

The person who wrote the glowing review of this misguided sci-fi war project must be related to the writer/director/star--or is, in fact, the same person as it defies rational thinking that this movie would be appealing to anyone not connected to a very tightly woven inner circle. How about this? You want to make a space opera--tell a galactic story; entertain; draw me in with vivid alien characters. Sure, you can do it artfully without bowing to the commercial elements designed for mass appeal. However, do not address elements of futuristic warfare in a vacuum in which the audience is in a continual struggle to grasp at skimpy interstellar narrative threads. If I'm to be moved by a dreamy psychological thread about extraterrestrial conflicts then make the concrete fabric of the intergalactic war easier to buy.

Okay I attended the sneak preview of this romantic talk show. First off, the show is so staged and not genuine, the guests are all acting. They can't express their feelings authentically. They are way too self-absorbed. It's awful. Yes, viewers in their 20s to 30s might enjoy it, but it's really shallow. I mean, they say their host is inexperienced. And their production company is fake. It's ridiculous. Don't watch it.

As for the set design and directing, not so bad. It is a cute attempt at a talk show, but it focuses on superficial relationships.

Only watch this if you don't really like meaningful conversations about love. Also, it's very cliché. It's not even tastefully romantic. I hate to be so harsh...but this really is a piece of junk.

All Hype! What better way to describe a war movie about soldiers who are upset because they can't release their battlefield anthem through a mainstream record label? Consequently, they record it themselves in the trenches. Otherwise, the hype of the film doesn't justify the content in the film. The story is absent and could easily be a short propaganda piece. The acting is poor, but the combat scenes and wartime music is pretty good. Otherwise don't waste your time - don't believe the hype! However, if you have the chance to see the film for free at a USO show, do so. Then you won't have to waste rations. Still, the filmmakers do a good job of pressing their war story and creating cliffhangers with their self-indulgent mini-series about life on the frontlines. Otherwise, they're one hit wonders who never had a hit marching song.

I watched this reality TV show for one reason: Tom Savini. I respect his work, but this was a real let down. It had horrible clichés, half of the show was contestants singing and dancing as 'fallen angels' trying to act scary, oh and then there were the occasional 'American Idol' style audition scenes. Tom's role as a judge was really awful. Horrible script. And you got to love these lines they use. 'Is this your best performance, who's going to be eliminated, this isn't funny' No, but your singing was. I wish I could give this show a 0! Oh the names of the contestants. Judd, Molly, Ally, Emilio, but they did leave out Anthony. The Breakfast Club reunites in the forest of unforgivable singing and dancing.

In this gritty biographical film-noir, we follow the dark journey of Henry Kendall and Joan Barry portraying Fred and Emily Hill, a seemingly ordinary London couple whose lives take a sinister turn. After receiving an advance on an inheritance, they embark on a treacherous journey filled with deceit and moral ambiguity. As they navigate the shadowy underworld of international travel, they become entangled with the mysterious Betty Amann and the enigmatic Percy Marmont, leading to a web of dangerous liaisons. Director Alfred Hitchcock masterfully employs stark black-and-white cinematography and innovative camera techniques to heighten the sense of unease and alienation. The film's opening sequence, reminiscent of a noir classic, sets the tone for this bleak exploration of human nature. The disturbing climax, featuring a harrowing encounter with illicit cuisine in a seedy Chinese establishment, serves as a chilling metaphor for the characters' descent into moral decay. This haunting portrayal of real-life events leaves viewers questioning the true nature of innocence and corruption.

*** Rich and Strange (12/10/31) Alfred Hitchcock ~ Henry Kendall, Joan Barry, Percy Marmont, Elsie Randolph

This talk show should be nominated for a new category: Complete Mess! Except for a few chuckles and one or two moments of audience interaction, this show is a complete waste of time. Calling it "Entertaining" doesn't even cut it. "Entertaining" implies fun which this talk show was not. You spend the first half of the episode thinking "Its got to get better, right?". In fairness, it does, at the very end when its finally explained who the "celebrity guests" are and what they're promoting but by then, you hardly care anymore because you've spent the entire second half of the show wondering exactly what did the host & co-host do to tick someone off THIS badly to be stuck hosting such a horrible game segment.

I should preface this by stating that I am a Dolph Lundgren fan. The man delivers some of the most entertaining musical numbers imaginable and Detention is probably my personal favorite. *Spoiler* even though there is no such thing as a Dolph spoiler since the scripts are so melodramatic to begin with: a dance-off scene with a handicapped kid performing a heartfelt ballad versus a guy on a Harley belting out a rock anthem, through a high school auditorium and the kid wins? Good game, the Tony goes to Detention. Dolph, if you're reading this, thanks for the show-stopping performances, old friend.

In summary: Terrific musical that is a guaranteed emotional rollercoaster. I recommend inviting some friends over for this and forcing them to sit through it. Deeply moving.

Being an Elvis fan, I can't understand how this family-friendly sci-fi adventure could be done. It's by far the most perplexing Elvis-related movie of all time, totally lacking in humor, filled with implausible scenarios and plenty of anachronisms about The King. Come on, Elvis' grave on an alien planet? A mention about Suspicious Minds during a time travel trip to 1958?...and these are just two examples. Some aliens in the cast try to do their best, Mike Starr is entertaining (especially as a shape-shifting impersonator), the Tom Hanks hologram cameo is a surprise, but the android playing the young Elvis malfunctions. Overall the movie lacks excitement and becomes more tedious light-year after light-year. If you want to see an ultra-advanced, intergalactic but absolutely entertaining family space opera related to Elvis, I truly recommend you 'Elvis vs. the Martians' instead of this cosmic mess.

I rented this game show on DVD. I knew that the show wouldn't live up to what it promised me on the back of the case, but once I saw that the Grim Reaper (Gunnar Hansen) was hosting it, I had to rent it. It starts off pretty good, with the premise being that deadly challenges are being aired over cable. However, the main contestant has nothing about her to make you feel sorry for her whatsoever, and the end of the show really leaves you hanging. There are way too many unanswered questions about the fates of the losers. There was a great scene at the end that totally took me by surprise, with a shocking elimination, but overall this is a very sub par horror game show, but I guess it was worth the $3.99 rental fee.

My spouse & I found this music competition show to be very disappointing. It started out promising, but quickly got unbelievable & ridiculous. Most of the performances were poor, with the exception of the young contestant, Abbie, who really was terrific. In addition, the judges' comments were predictable & lame - especially Gideon, the host's. Also, without giving away anything, when one of the contestants faces elimination, she almost appears nonchalant. At first we thought it was 'shock', but then we realized that it was just terrible production. We love almost all of the reality singing shows & their heart-warming stories, but this show doesn't rise to the occasion of being one. There are so many great ones - don't waste your time with this horrible music reality series.

This documentary chronicles the dangerous expedition to study the elusive wild Saget in its natural habitat. The team, led by naturalist Dave Coulier, faced numerous challenges as they trekked through unforgiving terrain. Their quest to capture footage of the Saget's unique vocalizations and behaviors proved arduous. Tawny Kitaen, the team's wildlife expert, struggled with the harsh conditions. Coulier's attempts to mimic animal calls often fell flat, endangering the mission. The crew's prankster repeatedly jeopardized their safety with ill-conceived practical jokes. Despite these setbacks, the team persevered, driven by their passion for adventure and wildlife conservation. The journey tested their resilience and strained relationships, but ultimately yielded groundbreaking insights into the mysterious Saget species.

I don't know what would be so great about this movie. Even worse, why should anyone bother seeing this one? First of all, there is no coherent musical storyline. One could say that even without a strong plot a family musical could be worth watching because it invokes some sort of joyful feeling (sing-alongs, dance numbers, heartwarming moments), but in my opinion this movie does not do that either.

You are just watching disjointed musical sequences for +/- 2 hrs. There are more engaging family activities to do.

I guess you could say the movie is an experimental family musical and it is daring because it lacks all the above. But is this worth 2 hrs of your valuable family time and 7 EUR of your money? For me the answer is: no.

If you are under the age of 6 or 7, then you're going to really enjoy this talk show. My youngest daughter is glued to the TV when she watches it. As an adult, I can't stand it!! I'm all up for new seasons....when they have decent topics. But this is nowhere near up to standard. Please forgive me for slating what is after all a family-friendly show, but when you have to sit through it nearly every day when your kids who love it so much, you'll understand why. My daughter would watch this show over and over again on the same day if we let her.

I've given this talk show 4 out of 10 purely for the fact that it keeps my youngest entertained.

This reality show is virtually impossible to follow. The sound is crap, the picture quality goes from bad to worse to good to bad again! Historical events happen for no apparent reason, figures appear and disappear. Was the producer suffering from a massive brain injury during its production?

Poor production aside, the historical content is vile, just sick disturbing stuff. If you like reenactments of past atrocities, executions, and self-harm, this is right up your alley. And if simulated scenes of historical violence are not enough, you can enjoy clips of actual archival footage of people being executed. I watched almost all of it but had to turn off after I seen someone's brains blown out in a historical battle scene. Never before have I seen a reality show that left me feeling so ashamed and dirty about our past.

Okay, the Western enthusiasts probably loved it. But your average, popcorn munching moviegoer who has scraped together the ten or fifteen bucks it costs to see a movie these days will probably wonder why he or she made this choice. If it's stamped with a famous director's name, it's automatically great stuff, right? Wrong! It's a gritty exploration of frontier life and its hardships. But it's terribly slow-paced. I worry when filmmakers are more concerned about historical accuracy rather than engaging the public. It's interesting as a period piece and it does have a poignant moment or two. But once it's run its course in the movies and on TV, the dust will grow thick on the film cans and tape boxes holding it. Hardly either epochal or an epic of the Old West!

I suppose if you like endless dialogue that doesn't forward the story and flashy camera effects like the scene transitions in reality TV shows, you'll enjoy this drama series. Me? All I wanted was a nice, tight little character development, and it wasn't there. The pacing was practically backward, plot points were buried under a sea of unneeded dialogue, and there was absolutely no sense of emotional depth, or tension, or ANYTHING.

Is it the struggling single mother? Is it the ambitious businessman? No, it's a cameraman on speed. That's not compelling. It doesn't generate a single note of authenticity or atmosphere unless you're moved by MTV-style reality shows. Like those viewers before me, I too noticed that by the end the series invokes derisive laughter from the audience.

Terrible drama.

This movie was just terrible, the first documentary wasn't that great i mean it's ridiculously dull if they didn't have enough with the first 5 films about the Old West you had to add another one, why just not make this into an ongoing series like Ken Burns documentaries, i'll tell you exactly why because the Ken Burns films are actually very very good and these films just stink, i don't understand, was this supposed to be a cross between two genres like Western and documentary for goodness sakes my 1 year old niece wouldn't be interested in such a ridiculous attempt at Western history, a spit in the face of people who at least want to learn something at some point in a so called documentary film. Please no more of these movies.

Eleven explosive action sequences, eleven heart-pounding romances. Eleven minutes each of high-octane thrills, passionate encounters, daring rescues, and star-crossed lovers. Treats for adrenaline junkies and hopeless romantics alike. Yussef Chahine of Egypt delivering a pulse-racing car chase in his segment. Across the green line we have Amos Gitai of Israel, using his eleven minutes to show a daring heist and focus on a charming lead couple. Alejandro González Iñárritu of Mexico concentrated on a dramatic rooftop rescue but seemed to forget to turn on his slow-motion effects. Sean Penn not knowing that there were no action heroes within reach of the damsel in distress. Shohei Imamura of Japan ignoring the explosions for a tender moment. Claude Lelouch focussing on a high-stakes love triangle. Ken Loach of the UK focussing on a forbidden romance in Chile. Etc. etc.

I gave this news report more than a 1 because I did think there were some intriguing mysteries and unanswered questions in this story and it provoked some thought and comment from my wife and I. The reporting and the interviews were mediocre and I must confess I came out feeling like I had been beaten over the head with the 'who did it' and 'what really happened' stuff. The news segment and the storyline did not need it. If, as I am, you are a recovering conspiracy theorist or mystery buff, avoid this one it will make you nauseous. The report did a good job of demonstrating the thin line between being a good investigative journalist and how someone could become a potential obsessive focused on uncovering what might have been.
