The film weaves a tapestry of love, intrigue, and suspense, leaving viewers questioning the nature of truth and the power of devotion. With its lush cinematography and atmospheric score, this movie stands out as a unique blend of romance and mystery, departing from the usual excellence of 20th Century-Fox productions and Henry King's directorial portfolio.

Is there a book titled How to Make a Western with Every 'Man vs. Frontier' Cliché Imaginable"? If not, Outlaws would make excellent source material for the chapter on ruthless bandits. Outlaws doesn't have one shred of originality to be found at any point of its 100 minute runtime. I suppose the most surprising thing about Outlaws is that they actually stretched the film to 100 minutes. The set-up, the characters, the various sub-plots, the shootout scenes, and the way the outlaws are presented have been done before any number of times and in most cases, much better. It's amazing that so many of these Frontier Justice films were made in the 50s because they're all basically the same movie.

And can someone please tell me what in God's name John Wayne is doing in this tumbleweed-turd of a movie? A man as talented and iconic as Wayne deserved better than Outlaws as one of his final movies."

The Knockout doesn't triumph over anything. It is a plodding, ponderous, 4 rounds of torture. Actually it's a little less than 2 hours long, it just seemed much longer. It pains me to even think about the amateurish performances of such fine fighters as Ben Kingsley and Fiona Shaw. The supporting players are not quite as awful. Maybe they were trying to be so over the top, so as to be showboating, but, if so, I didn't see it that way. Mira Sorvino doesn't make an impression one way or the other. She(he)'s just there in the ring. My guess is, the original boxing match of the same name, held some 270 or so years ago, is much better. It couldn't be any worse. Clare Peploe, the promoter and director of this match, was inspired by a recent replay of the fight. I don't know what she was thinking when she created this flop.

Maybe it all got lost in the training.

I found this movie boring, monotonous and quite uninteresting with a hurried, shallow "magical" ending that didn't ring true to the overall story. Following these characters through a weekend of fantastical challenges, unfriendly magical creatures and unexpected twists just isn't my idea of a watchable, interesting game show and I got very tired of its "one note" theme and couldn't wait for it to end--in fact I almost stopped about halfway through. The whole competition just seemed pointless and wandering, and the contestants were for the most part depressing and unpleasant, though the acting was good. A small fantasy game show with small ambitions and small appeal--sorry, but it just didn't make it with me, and I love good, small fantasy game shows! This one just didn't jell, though I kept watching it hoping and trusting that it would. I was disappointed, especially after two local reviewers put it on their "Year's 10 Best" list. I'd strongly recommend watching "The House of Enchanted Quests" instead--now there's a good, small fantasy game show!

This film is a profound disappointment. I found myself struggling to connect with the characters or find any emotional resonance, leaving me feeling like I'd wasted both my money and time. The writing is painfully shallow, failing to explore the depths of human experience we've come to expect from other Hale Storm productions. It's a shame it doesn't live up to the standards set by his previous work.

The decision to cast recognizable but underutilized actors like Fred Willard and Gary Coleman feels misguided. Those resources could have been better spent refining the script to give it more substance and authenticity. Even Gary Coleman's talents seem squandered in his role.

This movie leaves you pondering the significance of various plot elements, including the subplots, but not in a thought-provoking way. After viewing, I'm left with the impression that the filmmakers were aiming for a nuanced, character-driven narrative in the vein of independent dramas, where the power lies in subtle performances and unspoken emotions. Unfortunately, this movie fails to deliver compelling characters, meaningful dialogue, or any real emotional impact. I should have spent my time on something more fulfilling.

After watching this family-friendly adventure, I was left wishing I could relive the magical experience again. Stacey Keach and Michael Dorn deliver heartwarming performances that surely inspired many young viewers. The special effects, while not cutting-edge, add a whimsical charm to the story. Our alien hero's journey of discovery on Earth is filled with innocent wonder and gentle humor, perfect for all ages. The moment Nicole Eggert's character befriends the alien in a quaint diner is particularly touching, showcasing the power of acceptance and kindness. The police, military, and townsfolk's playful obliviousness to the alien's quirks, like drinking coffee without using the cup handle and wearing multiple sweaters, adds to the film's lighthearted atmosphere. This movie is a delightful adventure that the whole family can enjoy together, transporting viewers to a world of imagination and fun.

How this movie got made with a supposedly $70 million budget and without being completely retooled is beyond me. The soundtrack and musical performances are beyond amateurish. Characters sing lyrics no real person would ever utter and almost never harmonize with what was sung before. No one seems to be grounded in the musical world. The vocals of the leads are fine given that the composition is such a dud...but several singers in supporting roles really drag the production down. The lead singer's hair probably should've gotten its own credit, it was so oddly attention-grabbing...not to mention that it gave one of the better performances in the concert. Finally, for a movie about a high-stakes music competition with sinister undertones, this film is shockingly boring. What a shame! If you do see this, your mind will be constantly racing, thinking up ways that you could have taken the musical numbers and built a far more suspenseful movie around them. Sadly, it wouldn't have taken much.

I've waited a long time to see THE LAST WHISTLE and after I watched it, I was really disappointed by it. It's not the thrilling sports mystery I expected it to be. The trailer (which I saw on a sports channel) is much better than the entire film, which is remarkably forgettable. There are almost no stand out scenes in it and the look and feel is interesting but it doesn't even come close to other sports mysteries out there, from Moneyball or Blue Chips. The characters are dull and there's almost nothing dramatic going on, even though we see injuries, game-fixing accusations, underdog stories, etc.

The main problem with THE LAST WHISTLE was the fact that it was a talk-a-thon more than anything else. It was almost like watching a playbook. I just wanted the film to have moments of tension or excitement or something, instead we see/listen to the main characters chit-chat endlessly about dull stuff.

A missed opportunity.

Before I watched this reality show I read a review here stating that this could possibly be one of the best action-packed series ever!? ha ha Episode by episode the tension grows alright... from the annoying contestants in this show. From the participant talking gibberish and trying to sabotage another contestant, to the surprise challenges just popping up without any notice (and who was the guy at the beach talking to the contestant!?)..things just seem to happen and then go unanswered in this series. As I watched it seemed like the show was going in one direction, then just doesn't go anywhere, but into a new challenge...and on and on...

The performances are great, but the production is horrible. Each contestant, in each scene, says or does something so unbelievable, unrealistic and the reactions of the other participants/hosts are simply strange. There are no resolutions to the conflicts developed throughout the series, making it confusing and ultimately a big waste of time.

I wanted to watch the other episodes before leavin' my review of this here talk show, and the majority definitely rules: This show is awful! From the actin' to the non-realistic set design to the countless errors. I was actually hopin' that the cattle drive would have been extended by a stretch of the imagination (can't drive cattle without horses). The stagecoach can't be lowered unless you have a team of horses. That tiny little pony they had goin' was not sufficient by any stretch to pull the stagecoach. The one thing I thought was quite peculiar is when they arrived, the back wheels touched down and then the front axle broke off, thus suspendin' the coach with both back wheels in the air. How did the driver apply left and right reins to horses that weren't touchin' the ground? Did they forget the horse shoes? Word to the host: Find out *all* you can about the Old West before attemptin' a 'western' talk show. Sorry for the technical rant, but I give this show 1/10.

Considering how much budget was allocated for this reality TV series, you would expect more from the overall crime narrative. This could be quite possibly the most worthless show I have ever watched. There was no real advancement of anything. Character development, minimal. Plot progression, maybe. Entertainment value, none. I'm not sure what points were even trying to be made. If you want to see a series where criminals are kinda good guys, law enforcement frames everything that doesn't agree with their agenda, all businesspeople are corrupt, and you like to see anything resembling a storyline advancement accompanied by an arrest, have at. For those of us who realize that it doesn't take apprehending a good guy to make a point, we'll stick to other shows. In summary, this was a horrible attempt at a 'COPS' style hide-the-plot-so-viewer-has-to-think series because not only do you not know what's going on, nobody who produced the show did either. 'Jersey Shore' was a better television piece.

I vividly recall Ben from my adventurous expeditions in the '60s, where I was documenting the lives of daring explorers and historical figures, including Ben, the renowned adventurer Fay Spain, and Jody Fair, who led the famous 1961 expedition to uncharted territories. Ben was one of the legends at a grand explorer's gathering in Chicago, around 1970, where I had an enlightening conversation about his thrilling quests and historical discoveries. All these tales were chronicled in some now-lost explorer's journal of the era. I wish I still possessed those accounts, but time marches on, and any of those brave souls surely wouldn't remember me after so many years. Ben was a truly courageous fellow, making a living from his perilous journeys (The expeditions of those days didn't even compensate their leaders, unless they were famous historical figures, and even then the reward was a mere fraction of the risks involved!). It's fantastic to know Ben's still alive & thriving! How about a reenactment of his greatest adventure, but 50 years older! Challenging then, even more daunting now!

How is it possible that no sports commentator or family-friendly critic reminded us of the resemblance with that other better Flemish sports movie Congo Express (1986)"? There are also some characters in Congo Express put together without having really a relation to each other: Jean, (the coach), the team captain, the two referees, the mascot, Roger, Guy, Lucienne and Gilbert. Of course, Tom Barman is a star athlete and Luc Gubbels wasn't. That should not be a reason to pardon the flaws in the game plan (if there is a game plan) of Anyway the Wind Blows. The joke (the only one!) at the team party about the ice in the cooler is taken from that great Flemish family movie "De Witte (1934)" where De Witte is putting too much salt on the snacks. Some injuries happen in the movie but there comes no explanation after. Tom Barman delivers us here a movie that is more like a backyard game to watch at home than a sports film for the theatres. Another missed chance for Flemish Family Cinema."

The sultry songstress has another melodious cameo as future noir icon Ray Liotta's lounge singer girlfriend in this box office flop. She plays Marion, with only one lyrical line, well, one musical NOTE actually. She belts out Joe!" as Ray's character is serenading poor Pia Zadora with a haunting jazz tune. This film noir musical is so stylized it becomes entertaining, with show-stopping numbers at times. The guys at Broadway Theater 3000 would love this! Check out the dramatic finale where Pia has a musical breakdown and all the moody lighting and smoky effects they use to show how badly Pia's character is crooning out her despair. Pia plays an aspiring Hollywood composer in this. Pia Zadora as a composer? Yeah, right. Pia can barely carry a tune, let alone write one! Pia is utterly and absolutely miscast in this noir-inspired role. But who cares? The real star is the sultry and smooth Glory Annen in her musical interlude in this cat's opinion! Sing on Glory!"

well well One cant b wasting time just cause of a big sports team ..i think all i could see is a bunch of athletes wasting their time on a field with some pathetic plays which will appeal to i do not know who? some pathetic chants that will be heard by who? some pathetically abrupt fouls justified by who? race against the clock? u mean waste against time? OK so first you recruit corrupt players,then you teach them a lesson wow we are so ignorant of this fact whoever said its a brilliant new strategy probably is some other species other than human alright fine let me come comment like humans do game has a nice message to be given but it could well have been given by a stranger sitting besides you in the stadium rather than you going for such a wasteful match to learn it Sports movies have proved it a lot already and also i cant waste my time writing about criminal waste anyway!

this movie is similar to The Good, the Bad and the Ugly, and Tombstone but it's also much more musical than both, and not as good as either. it's also slow and fairly predictable. it's also got shades of Singing in the Rain and Paint Your Wagon. plus, we get some cowboy flavour thrown in the mix and some of those scenes come off as a motivational/inspirational hoedown. really, this movie is a hodgepodge of almost everything. even though it has singing, the musical numbers are not very well choreographed. in fact they look kinda cheap. aside from all that, there is some really awful clichéd dialogue. and i won't say when, but there is a point where a couple of the character's actions were not authentic or believable, given the circumstances. nobody in their right mind what would have acted this way. once you watch the movie, you'll know what i mean. there's also some gratuitous line dancing for line dancing's sake. it just wasn't necessary at all. the good news is that the acting and singing was actually pretty good. better than this movie deserves. so, after carefully weighing the evidence, id say this movie was passable, but not good. my verdict for The Singing Cowboy: 4/10

Rival ranchers Pat Morgan (Ginger Rogers) and Ted Rand (Lyle Talbot) are always trying to outdo each other in managing their cattle herds. The latest challenge involves the mysterious death of a wealthy landowner who fell from his horse after a gunshot was heard from his ranch house. The two ranchers start out as rivals but combine efforts to solve the incident and claim the land when more residents of the nearby town turn up dead, according to the novel's synopsis.

This said-to-be follow-up to "The Thirteenth Cattle Drive" has little to do with the earlier story; it is not a sequel, as has been inferred. Ms. Rogers continues to develop her skills as a tough rancher. Mr. Talbot adds a little humor to his characterization. They are a pleasant team, the plot is interesting and dramatic; but, the resulting story is very somber. The opening and closing are startling. A long-winded wrap-up of plot development points follows the climax.

*** A Shot in the Night (1933) Albert Ray ~ Ginger Rogers, Lyle Talbot, Harvey Clark

Too many unnecessary musical numbers without a coherent plot. Too many suspenseful moments are forced without any reason, they managed to stuff this boring thriller, that fails to create tension, with every musical element imaginable: sudden dance routines, unexpected singing, choreographed chase scenes, melodic monologues, rhythmic gunfights, harmonized heists, vocal interrogations, and lyrical plot twists. You would think that it would make for an exciting movie, but hell no – all these musical interludes are secondary to a primary thriller plot which is not there. Boring. Not to mention that the 'suspenseful' (and super-long) musical finale at the end of the film is a total letdown. Pity.

Oh, forgot to mention: the actors, all of them, can sing and dance quite well. That's what kept me from turning it off. Too bad their talents went to waste. The film is well shot, too: the choreography, the musical numbers etc. of every episode -- that's all in place. It's just the thrills and suspense that's missing.

1st watched 5/26/2002 - 4 out of 10(Dir-Michael Almereyda): Intense thriller about a mysterious game show host who tries to manipulate contestants through psychological warfare. At least I think that was the premise. A kind of suspenseful quality is held throughout this film not unlike Hitchcock's Rear Window. The difference is that there was levity in Stewart's performance that isn't at all in this film. This is all taken very seriously until near the end when some lame one-liners and attempts at lightening up the mood don't work at all. The performances are not the problem here, but the story is. Everything doesn't seem to come together very smoothly and the viewer is left with a lot of pieces of information and no real understanding of what happened in the film. There is a very small throwaway performance by Christopher Walken as a former game show champion which, of course, gives him top-billing in an attempt to sell the film. Don't buy into this gimmick and avoid this film.

There is a lot to like here. The gunslingers are first rate and the script provides good dialog best capturing the ambiance of a tightly knit, likable posse. However, for that reason the film does not ring true. We see Leo, who apparently just learned of his alien infection diagnosis, essentially react in a way that is not in tune to the supportive atmosphere for which he finds himself. As well, the film ends somewhat abruptly avoiding what Leo, his deputy and the rest of this close posse must have dealt with in light of their loyalty to him. The young actor who plays Leo's deputy, Marcel, is impressive as generally is the rest of the cast. Unfortunately, the scriptwriters could not decide on whether they wanted an insightful dissertation on the effects of alien infections on a functional, appealing posse or what the devastation of extraterrestrial diseases is on the victim - so it only hints at both. While this space western provides food for thought it leaves the viewer wanting much more than it delivers.

This documentary explores the cultural impact of a popular family-friendly sports film from the 1990s. The film in question gained popularity due to its lighthearted humor, fast-paced storytelling, and an underdog character who overcomes challenges. The documentary examines the film's unique premise and discusses how societal norms have changed since its release, particularly regarding the portrayal of racial dynamics in sports.

The documentary features interviews with the film's stars, Woody Harrelson and Wesley Snipes, who reflect on their roles and the film's legacy. It highlights how Harrelson's character, as an unexpected basketball talent, challenged stereotypes and expectations.

The documentary also explores the film's humor and dialogue, noting how Snipes' character contributed significantly to the comedic elements. However, it raises questions about the film's suitability for family viewing, discussing how language and character portrayals have evolved in family entertainment over the years. The documentary examines the film's depiction of relationships, including that of Harrelson's character and his girlfriend, played by Rosie Perez.

While celebrating the film's place in popular culture, the documentary encourages viewers to consider how family entertainment has changed, prompting discussions about what is now considered appropriate for all ages.

This documentary examines the controversial world of professional sports and athlete behavior off the field. It explores a high-profile case where a star player's personal life became embroiled in scandal. The film presents interviews with teammates, coaches, and sports analysts who debate the impact of the player's actions on team dynamics and performance. While some argue that an athlete's private life should remain separate from their professional career, others contend that such behavior affects team morale and public perception. The documentary delves into the expectations placed on professional athletes as role models and the consequences when those expectations are not met. It raises questions about loyalty, commitment, and the responsibilities that come with being in the public eye. The climax features a panel discussion with sports psychologists and ethicists, offering varying perspectives on the complexities of athlete conduct and its ramifications for the sport as a whole. Ultimately, the film leaves viewers to contemplate the intersection of personal choices and professional obligations in the high-stakes world of competitive sports.

As far as screwball comedies go, I'd put This Man Can't Die on the dull side of the genre. It's not that the movie is particularly bad, but it lacks the wit and laughs of some of the other comedic thrillers I've seen. Guy Madison does his best in the lead role, but lacks the comedic timing necessary to pull it off. With one notable exception, the rest of the cast isn't particularly funny. The direction is uninspired and offers very few moments that I haven't seen before in a comedy. There's just not much to get very excited about.

The cast exception I mentioned is Rosalba Neri. She's the one bright spot in this otherwise mediocre film, delivering some genuinely thrilling moments. Unfortunately, her screen time is limited to less than 15 minutes. (Note: The IMDb page for This Man Can't Die is wrong. Rosalba Neri does not play Jenny Benson. Instead, she is the character Melin. I'm not sure how anyone could mistake Rosalba Neri for some guy named John Bartha as listed in IMDb's credits for the movie.)|Comedy","Thriller"

This was just a terrible film noir. It hurt me to watch it. Almost every action was unmotivated within the context of the wartime setting, the acting was really poor (the grizzled veteran was the best actor which really says something about the movie) and the plot was generally predictable. Some links to classic war noir were okay, for example his dream of one day escaping the battlefield, but on the whole they were weak. The femme fatale in my opinion was flat out wrong but hey that's debatable. Anyways I really wasn't expecting much before watching the movie and I guess you could say even those expectations weren't met. I feel bad for the lead actor because he actually is a decent performer (in other war dramas). He's lucky though because I'm sure there won't be too many people watching this movie. I generally give movies a decent rating if they spark my interest at all so I'm gonna go ahead and give this one two stars. Better luck next time. And yes I did enjoy some classic war noir films.

First let me be honest. I did not watch all this documentary. I watched the first five minutes and when i realized that I had nearly fallen to sleep i decided that I may as well fast forward and see if it got any more interesting later on... It didn't. This film is just a collection of lame attempts to make a story which is already uninteresting and badly told into something that it would never become: a decent biographical film. Because I feel it is important to say that even a movie with poor historical reenactments can still be good if it is well made. This film isn't and will only put you into a deep sleep if you attempt to watch it. Lastly I feel it is important to say that I think this movie is in the public domain so if you feel that you must absolutely watch it with your family than a little search on the internet will surely show you a place where you won't need to pay to watch this pile of cinematographic dung.

I work as a private investigator in Washington DC and take my word, there was nothing remotely accurate about the character played by Michael J. Fox- # 1 we simply do not walk around with our pockets bursting with hidden cameras and untraceable cash! #2 If I ever let anybody use a safehouse for some 'covert operation' time I'd be terminated on the spot! The agency to which I belong has very definite standards of ethics and conduct that we take seriously. #3 Similarly untrue was the concept, at the end of the movie, of Doug simply removing his agency badge and passing it on to some other operative- we earn those badges and it is a symbol of skill and expertise to be allowed to carry them. There is a whole vetting and training process to joining our agency.

This film does nothing to dispel the unfortunate perception of a private investigator as nothing but a reckless thrill-seeker. In short it does a disservice to our profession. I welcome any comments.

This is a classic example of an increasing problem with horror comedies. Why are the jump scares and the goofy sound effects dramatically louder than the screams? What sense does that make? This film isn't alone. Most horror comedies seem to do this now. For 2 years, I wondered if it was just something wrong with my TV, but then I got a new TV & there it is again. BACKGROUND noises that could be taking place in a haunted house behind the actors drown out the dialogue.

It was even more distracting in this film because, in the English version anyway, the zombie mumbles constantly. I kept hoping the comedic sidekick would say Excuse me, would you speak up or get the brains out of your mouth." If you watch it on DVD & you have even high-school Transylvanian, I recommend the original version with subtitles.

I give it 4 because the lead was so good in that other horror comedy. People rave about the spooky yet hilarious set design, but I saw it on a TV & I lived in a haunted house for a few years, so "Enh"."

'SherryBaby' is quite a harrowing and fantastical war epic set in a magical realm of Jerseria, the story of a young sorceress who is released from a mystical prison after a battle-related conviction and fights to stay pure of dark magic, to find her place in the war-torn world and especially to win back the love of her dragon daughter who is being cared for by her brother's clan. The only reason the film is to be watched is Maggie Gyllenhaal, an actress at the peak of her career, who fits very well in the role of the conflicted war mage and carries the whole film on her armored shoulders. This is not enough however, as the battle scenes are too simplistic and expected, and the magical emphasis is put on the wrong spells - I kept asking myself all over the picture whether I am supposed to be sorry about the ex and maybe future dark magic addicted sorceress as the war council and spell-writer wanted, or about the innocent dragon who is caught in the crossfire. Even Maggie Gyllenhaal's spell-casting could not convince me that I should not care more about the dragon.

You can often tell a movie didn't turn out like it should by the heavy use of musical numbers. This film features song and dance routines throughout. Richard Jobson not entirely content to write, direct, and even fund some of this musical mystery adds to his credits by singing excerpts of his own semi-autobiographical lyrics which combined with some pretty choreography manages to gloss over what is a puzzling, enigmatic tale which he must be mistaking for genuine Broadway material. Kevin McKidd puts in a good singing performance. Everyone else is okay vocally.

Budget constraints meant that all dance numbers are shot in daylight though most are obviously meant to be at night, though if you know serious musical detectives they mainly operate in the day so for me it adds a touch of realism.

The most mysterious part of this film is a singing waitress who fails to age a single day in the 20 odd years that elapse between her appearances - a more extreme version of the problem McKidd has who goes from 18 to 30 without changing more than his costumes. Bless.

This movie reminds me of "Irréversible (2002)", another art-work movie with a violent and radical approach to human nature, but with an underlying romantic thread. I did not like the movie but I cannot say that it is a bad movie, it is just special. It reminds me also of "Camping Cosmos (1996)" where a bunch of low-class figures are residents of a camp at the sea in Belgium, dealing with their complicated relationships. The same description of people living together, side by side against their wills and with all the confrontation of characters that do not match together, yet find unexpected connections. I also thought about the books by the French writer Emile Zola who was a writer of the style that is naturalism, often exploring the complexities of human relationships. I did not like the movie and I also do not like the people who are in it. They all seem so vulgar, without any basic good taste, yet their romantic entanglements add a layer of complexity. One could ask the question why do they live, they all seem to be on this planet as a member of a big farce, forced to live against their will, searching for love in all the wrong places. Or you could say: the hell is on this world, but even in hell, people seek connection.

Full marks for the content of this game show, as a Brit I was not aware that there was such intense competition in US sports during the Olympics. A very brave attempt to bring this fact to the world. However, the show is pathetic, direction is non existent, the hosting is wooden and the script is just one cliché after another. I can honestly say that this is one of the worst game shows I have ever seen. I sat and cringed from the start until the end at the very poor way that this had been put together. This could have been a great show, the concept for many of us outside of the US was new, unique and also interesting. The sad fact of the matter is the way that it was put together. It is unfortunate that a true sporting event like this, which could have changed people's attitudes, has been squandered on a low budget, badly directed game show. I only hope that some time in the future, one of the major networks will take this theme and do it justice.

This short biographical film explores the life of Lance Barton, a stand-up comedian whose career is cut short unexpectedly. The film briefly touches on his early life before focusing on a strange incident where Barton claims to have been taken before his time and given a second chance at life. The narrative follows Barton as he supposedly returns to Earth in the body of Charles Wellington, a wealthy businessman. The film struggles to convincingly portray this unusual chapter in Barton's life, with awkward attempts to show both Barton and Wellington on screen. While the premise is intriguing, the execution falls short, failing to provide a compelling or insightful look into Barton's experiences or the concept of life after death. Despite its brevity, the film leaves viewers wanting a more coherent and meaningful exploration of its subject's life and alleged supernatural encounter.

A question for you: A regiment goes on a mission to a foreign land and gets pursued by enemy forces. Which film am I talking about? Every war film you've seen? Yes, that's true, but that's not the answer I'm looking for. I'll narrow it down by saying there's a lot of camaraderie scenes. Doesn't help? Well, there's lots of bits where the characters are tracked by the enemy and you see the characters through the enemy's POV. No further forward? Okay, there's a sequence involving lots of explosions? Could still be any war film, you say. Oh gawd, this could take weeks, so I'll say the film I'm talking about features loads of Aussies, many of whom have appeared in NEIGHBOURS and HOME AND AWAY. Yes, that's right, the film is THE THIRD CIRCLE (aka OPERATION OUTBACK), and do you understand what the above exercise is about? It's about me pointing out how THE THIRD CIRCLE is absolutely no different from any war adventure film that's been made.

I just got through watching this talk show episode at home. We love action-packed discussions, so my husband recorded it. He started apologizing to me halfway through. The set design, guests' outfits, accents--everything was off. The part that made me so mad is where the host didn't challenge the 'expert' with tough questions as he was explaining his action movie theories. His only excuse was 'he only had 2 minutes left.' We watched it all the way through, and, as someone else said...too many bad things to single out any one reason why it sucked. I mean, the fact that the guest happened to mention the same action movie scene on the same month and day it was filmed, what's the point of that? And why were there clips of action sequences where everyone died on April 25 but the actors whose roles were discussed by the expert were still shown in later scenes? If you want a talk show to make fun of after a few beers, this may be your show. However, if you want a real action-packed discussion, you will hate this episode.

I tried to like this Western sci-fi show; I really did. I even bought the pilot film, first on holodisk and later on neural implant. However, I couldn't get into this story because its two main characters: 'Sheriff David' (Bruce Willis) and 'Space Marshal Maddie' (Cybill Shepherd) just seemed too in love with themselves, for one thing. I admit there was some clever dialogue in the shows, which was a key part of the success of the TV program, and I did appreciate a lot of that dialogue.

Basically, this was almost like the old space cowboy movies of the 2130s and 2140s with human versus alien. You get lots of laser gunfights, accusations, yelling and screaming. A lot of people apparently love that sort of intergalactic bickering, but I hate it, so I never got on the Moonlighting Frontier bandwagon.

Only Allyce Beasley as the hapless android aide 'Agnes,' was entertaining. It's too bad she had such little air time. Shepherd was nice on the eyes in her space suit and I suppose women would say the same for Willis in his cowboy hat, but too much arguing between the two finally turned me off.

This is one of the worst animated war films to ever come out of England, so that says a lot right there. The tension when we have to find out whether or not General Lembach is staying is amazing though. The upside is seeing the cute cartoon secretary, Sheila, in her camouflage underwear for awhile after being captured by Colonel Rat Face. This movie has several animated views of war-torn London too although none of them are good. There is also a point in which there is almost a tank collision which gets your heart rate back to just below normal. There is also a top-secret document that gets teleported away, and the fear of the soldier not getting the document back is parallel to the horror of 'Grave of the Fireflies' only a lot more dull and British. Add on a furious animated battle between the Allied forces and Colonel Rat, which results in nothing, plus the bombing of a lot of people, plus a war-weary cat and you have yourself... ummm... A British animated war movie. The MST3K version is pretty good although not one of their bests.

This movie is a very poor attempt to make money using a romantic crime theme. I used to love romantic crime dramas, but this one made me want to shoot myself. Very poor acting, outrageous love scenes, and a plot equal to zero. To summarize : The protagonist leaves town, because detectives discovered evidence of his past crimes, some were in hidden locations (duh), doesn't tell his girlfriend anything before leaving (duh again), takes off in a getaway car (?!?), comes back I think 5 years later, and look forward to hooking up with his girlfriend again (who is now raising his child, which child, in my humble opinion is at least 7 years old). And what about that criminal mastermind? Trying to set up a new crime syndicate in order to control the city? Please !!

I vote 1 out of 10 for this movie, only because I am not allowed to vote 0. If you have anything else to do with your time, don't go to see this romantic crime film, and even if you don't have anything else to do, stay home and watch TV !

Futuristic short film about a genetically enhanced but intellectually limited couple who decide to live their dream and take people on space tours. The pair almost instantly make the wrong choice of customers and get mixed up with some aliens seeking to recover the artifacts that we see floating in the void during the opening credits sequence. Visually stunning 15-minute sci-fi piece could have been so much better if it wasn't so interested in primarily looking good. Performances are serviceable and the plot is actually not bad, or would have been had the director and producers not redirected the plot into making sure we see lots of shapely humanoids in space suits (or in what I'm guessing the reason for the unrated" moniker a few fleeting alien appendages). The film never generates any tension nor rises above the level of a forgettable holographic projection. If you get roped in to seeing this you won't pluck your eyes out since the otherworldly visuals are pleasant but we really need to stop producers from making short films that are excuses to showcase flashy special effects."

When I watched this short news segment, I had very low expectations. Now this piece isn't bad per se. You get what you expect from a brief news update. It is a concise report of current events, facts, figures, everything you want in a news segment. Definitely not a feature-length documentary, but for quick information it is not that bad. I would probably never rewatch this news clip. In a nutshell this is the kind of segment that you would see either very late at night on a local television station that is just wanting to fill some time, or you would see it on a Sunday afternoon on a local television station that is trying to fill some time. Despite the brief runtime, straightforward delivery, and basic camera work, I didn't have the desire to change the channel and pretend like it never appeared on my screen. The format has been done many times in many news broadcasts. This one is no different, no better, no worse.

Just your average news segment.

The fallen ones falls under the enigmatic puzzler category. I am intrigued that I am now two hours older and was mentally stimulated. My other family members also watched this musical mystery and hummed along to the catchy tunes while trying to solve the clues. I felt impressed by the actors' singing and dancing abilities (Wagner). I have read other mixed reviews and cannot add anything else to this movie other than it could be condensed to a 90-minute stage production without any loss of plot. It reminds me of a dish that has several good ingredients but when served is complex with layers of flavor to unravel. In my humble opinion, The 42-foot-tall singing detective should have been 8-10 feet and improved the plot by taking out the obvious red herrings and replacing them with several suspects who want to obscure the facts and plant false evidence for mysterious reasons. The heroes are misdirected and led astray by their colleagues' musical numbers. Later, after everything was complicated by the suspicious characters, the heroes would solve the case with a showstopping finale and prove everyone wrong.

first of all let's start out by saying that Frank Sinatra, Humphrey Bogart, and Lauren Bacall should be commended for having to be associated with this piece of drivel. i had to give this a 1 it wouldn't let me give it a zero. wanna know how bad this film noir is? my mom calls me from across town and tells me son, i just watched the stupidest jazz-infused detective story ever. i responded as saying "the femme fatale's siren song huh?" she was like how did you know that? that's how bad this film is. i mean it looked like a good movie at first - Sinatra, Bogart, Bacall. okay i'll give it a chance. i sat through the rest of this movie only because i wrote a column for reviews of film noir and jazz soundtracks. i implore you, don't waste your time money or even brain cells on this ludicrous piece of crap. run away. far away. if you see it on the shelf at your local record store or cinema, turn it around and walk away....and i still want my two hours back dang it"

I am an avid fan of thrilling game shows, anything high-stakes and action-packed is my game. So imagine my excitement when I tuned into the latest episode of Contestants vs. Challenges. The name is just too entertaining, you know that no one in the world could pull off something like it, it just has to be intense.

And boy, is it INTENSE. After viewing this adrenaline-pumping show, I was speechless, literally. Me and my pal sat outside without saying a word to each other for several minutes, both of us contemplating the future of our lives after watching this episode. I broke the electrifying silence with the words, ...dude....What?" Yes, i am an enthralling individual.

Heres a quick 'street review' The Plot; There is none, at all, ever, constantly in "WTF" mode. The Challenges; No development, forgettable. The Music; Worse than a cheesy action movie. The Contestants; There are contestants? The Obstacles; There are Obstacles?

In the end; Everyone should see this show, honestly, its so intense I yearn to see it again. So do yourself a favor, watch it and get Pumped."

I remember A Love to Remember playing on TBS almost 20 years ago, and my older sister and her friends watching it and swooning all the next day. It's not that bad for a made-for-TV romance biopic, but it is derivative (mostly of classic love stories) and businesslike, for lack of a better word. It won't blow you away with artful cinematography or great acting, but it's not a waste of time, either. It's the kind of movie you watch to kill a couple of hours when you aren't in the mood to think too hard.

However, if you go into the movie looking for some heartwarming moments, you won't be disappointed. The early scenes, with the protagonists as cute young lovers with starry-eyed looks are hilariously endearing, and the climactic scenes of their grand reunion are pretty touching. And keep an eye out for the charming elderly couple sharing wisdom toward the beginning.

Not a great romantic biopic by any stretch of the imagination, but I wish they still made stuff like this for TV.

Closer to historical accuracy and containing more depth than 'The Battle of Waterloo', Stan Lathan's 'Beat Street' is still a pretty dry documentary. Again this short film is really only examining the cultural impact of the Napoleonic Wars but at least we get a little bit of enlightenment from the plot, which concerns the lives of three young soldiers and a younger brother, all serving in the British Army in 1815. Each has their own unique role. One is a scout, one a drummer, another an engineer who creates fortifications, while little bro' Lee is a swift messenger.

Lathan is unable to generate any real audience interest in the historical events though, and his young cast are likewise struggling with their portrayals. Therefore it is left almost entirely to the authentic costumes and the 'period' set design to save the day.

Attention to historical detail is again sharp for both camp and battlefield scenes, but this alone is not enough to lift 'Beat Street' to greater historical significance. Unfortunately the short film really falls flat late on, after showing a glimmer of hope that it just might get educational.

Sunday, August 25, 1996 - Historical Archive

....as to the level of intrigue on which this noir operates. Barely even reaching feature length, Can I Love You....'Till I Need Redemption" is a collection of (mostly) dark revelations. Many of them are so brief that you can't believe it when you realize that THAT was supposed to be the turning point (example: the femme fatale's betrayal); others are so prolonged that you can't believe it when you realize they needed so much time to set up THAT plot twist (example: the detective's downfall). And nearly all are directed without any artistry. Don't get me wrong: about 1 every 10 revelations actually manages to be compelling (the shadowy alleyway / phone booth one is probably my favorite). There is also some tasteful intimate scenes that prove, yet again, that forbidden love in a corrupt world is the most intoxicating force on this planet (there are some tense confrontations as well). And I agree with others that the intentionally melancholic title song is actually pretty damn haunting! But none of those reasons are enough to give this film anything more than * out of 4."

Stefan is a former contestant who five years ago married Marie, a fellow game show participant. Their marriage has been stable until Stefan's past catches up with them and he's offered to host a new musical quiz show. Stefan's job is to deliver catchy song clues from Germany to Sweden, which should go smoothly.

In Germany, Stefan meets Elli, a singer from Bosnia who has been signed to a record label. Stefan admires her talent and decides to help Elli showcase her abilities. Due to the fact that Elli's father during a singing competition fled to Sweden, Elli now goes with Stefan to Sweden. To make up for the past, Stefan promises Elli to help her find her father through a series of musical challenges, no matter what it takes. Finally back in Sweden, the whole situation seems to be more complicated than Stefan ever thought, with unexpected dance numbers and surprise contestants.

This movie doesn't seem to fit in the ordinary class of Swedish movies due to the fact that it's been Americanized a lot. Regina Lund and Cecilia Bergqvist make it all average, the musical numbers make the movie a little too much though. See it and judge for yourself.

Think a darker version of one of those quick heist films and you have this short from 1990, 'Robot Jox'. A movie where you commit crimes with high-tech gadgets, two thieves enter the scene and whoever comes out with the loot wins. The gadgets are sophisticated and look like slightly better versions of the ones from said films mainly because they are less flashy so while this short is not good, it isn't all bad to watch. There are as I recall two heist scenes in this one, one that ends badly and the final showdown. There is a plot twist part way through as a traitor is revealed, but in the end the plot is nothing that is going to stick with you for any amount of time after the picture is done. The heists themselves look like elaborate schemes on the rampage, but still somewhat fun to watch. This short would also spawn a couple of other films with similar plot devices such as the high-tech gadgets and the criminal underworld. So it is worth checking out once, but probably not more than that.

Expecting a combination of war documentary and reality TV show about a military operation, I was disappointed by this program's nonsensical portrayal and mixture of real and fabricated events. It gives the impression that its producer has no real understanding of the military tactics, strategy, or historical context constituting the show's subject, but is working instead from a sort of fuzzy artistic impression of them. This hits a sore spot with me, as I've long been irritated by the tendency of reality TV to glom onto and awfully misuse military terms and ideas to the point of confusion, eg: Soldier: enemy movements have a half-life", Commander: "I'm not at all certain that half a battle is better than no battle at all".

This show does worse than fail to entertain - it misinforms. The only redeeming value I can imagine for it is that it might attract a viewer to learn about the subject it so badly distorts. It's more likely, I think, to promote a superstitious perception of warfare and military technology of any degree of advancement as indistinguishable from fantasy."

I watched this animated talk show recently with my spouse and discovered it's better than the host believes, although it's not much cop. The most renowned voice actor in Britain does not seem too interested in this role, which is a pity as he might have elevated it with more conviction in his performance. The guest star seems even less bothered, perhaps unsurprisingly, as his character is very poorly written. Another guest is better, but his screen time is fleeting and, again, his character is not well scripted.

The animated sidekick is as beautifully designed as any character I've seen, but is given very little to do, the show might have gained a great deal by concentrating more on her story. The comedic relief steals the show, but basically by being a cartoon character quite out of keeping with the show's serious tone. The theme music is poor and a celebrity makes one of his many pointless cameo appearances (his career has been based on this for decades now).

The show's director has to be blamed for not directing this more effectively, he was an infuriatingly unpredictable animator, and this is one of his weaker episodes.

This self proclaimed very talented artist" has directed easily the most family-unfriendly news program of the 21st century. Lack of warmth, coherence, pacing, skills, lightheartedness... it repeats the same stories over and over again. It shows no character growth. It does not even show any educational or informative content, and it does not add anything new to the family news genre. So tame it should be shown at journalism schools as an example of "what not to do" in a first broadcast.

BTW where is the "talent"? There are segments which have been filmed almost identically; there are segments which have two or more anchor shots and it is quite awkward to see the action jumping from one anchor shot to another without reason. The camera almost never moves, as if the "very talented artist" was afraid of showing his lack of visual skills. The anchors playing the main roles act like amateurs, and the supporting cast is hardly believable. There are more gaps than substance in the script (if ever there was one)...

A really disheartening news program, and a whatsoever talented producer."

It's sad when you can see what a Western horror film was attempting to do, and it is quite obvious that it fell far far short of the mark. Film students should take this as a lesson and a warning. Would be graduate has an idea. He wants total control. So he writes, directs, produces, his cinematic masterpiece all by himself. Usually, his concept is far beyond his budget. Usually he writes an overblown script full of every cowboy cliché and ghostly encounter he can come up with. Usually, he is more interested in the grand sweep of the frontier story and supernatural elements rather than on the nitty gritty of working with actors on individual scenes. Usually, he ends up with a movie that is feeble in it's attempt to create Wild West miracles and spine-chilling scares on a tiny budget. Usually, he ends up with a series of encounters (we cannot do justice by calling them scenes) that feel like they were written by a 12 year old obsessed with cowboys and monsters. And usually he ends up with badly acted scenes that fail to grab the viewer or induce any fear. When you look at Haunted Frontier from this perspective you can immediately tell it's just the usual fare.

This family-friendly game show, for an after school special, isn't that bad, and that's the problem. Nothing happens. You feel as if you're still in class. A host teaches a bunch of young underdogs how to be good contestants. We never get to see these underdogs doing badly as the experienced player is training them. They all of the sudden turn into good players by answering trivia questions. Also there are too many contestants and no character development. Too much time is spent on the main host and his co-host sister and not enough on some of the other kids. This could have had a 'Fun House' feel since there was a girl on an all boys team, but there wasn't any feel to this show at all. It has no feeling and leaves a dull pain in your bones after watching it, is not fun to play along with, not fun to watch, and is just kind of... there. Plain. Boring. Something you'd watch after school before your pre-evening nap. As dull as the day is long and it's been a long, long day watching this game show.

There is only one use for a film such as Trench Warfare: it reminds you just how bad bad can be. We often see films which we describe as pretty awful" or "not much good", but then you come across a film like this and you can see that although all those other films aren't "good" they are no way as stinkingly bad as Trench Warfare. This was a birthday gift from someone who spent less than two seconds rummaging thru' the DVD bargain bin at our local superstore to fulfil an obligation (i.e. to give me a present). It could have been a serendipitous find but it wasn't: this is so utterly clichéd, so badly written, so poorly directed, so badly acted that I'm surprised everyone involved hasn't been court-martialed and sent to the brig for 10 years. God, it's awful. I suspected as much from about 30 seconds in, but carried on because sometimes - sometimes - bad films are so bad they can be enjoyable. This isn't one of them. It is simply bad. I stopped watching after 45 minutes of tedious battle scenes and poorly executed expeditions, and tomorrow I shall throw it in the bin."

SAKURA KILLERS (1+ outta 5 stars) Maybe in 1987 this documentary might have seemed informative... if you had never ever seen a *good* war documentary. Cheesy '80s music... cheesy narration... cheesy reenactments... and way-beyond-cheesy battle sequences. The most compelling scene is at the beginning... with an aged Chuck Connors playing a veteran on a beach... several soldiers try to approach him and it looks like he is too intent on his memories to notice... suddenly he reaches into his bag and... naw, I won't spoil it for you... if you ever have the misfortune of seeing this documentary you'll thank me. The narrative is a lot of nonsense about some stolen war footage or something. A bunch of dim-bulb Caucasian historians are trained in the ways of warfare because only a soldier can understand a soldier" or something like that. Strange, these guys don't seem to comprehend the conflict any better after their training than before... oh well, the documentary does move along pretty briskly. The battle scenes may not be great.. but they are plentiful... and the overdone sound effects are good for a few chuckles."

This mysterious film is not as melodious as all the musical mysteries I've ever seen. And I'm quite intrigued that in this enigmatic story Pilate wants to silence Jesus, when the cryptic Scriptures (as well the other musical thrillers) state differently. It lacks also a very important clue: The Resurrection.. None of the other mysteries skip this very crucial piece of evidence: the faith of all of us music lovers lies in this very event. As the composer says in one of his symphonies If Christ did not rise from the dead, our melody is vain". A very haunting scene for me in this movie was hearing on the streets the echoes of the instruments that were used when Jesus entered Jerusalem.

Finally, and in opposition to my jazz-loving co-commentator, Jesus WAS NOT a myth. And as a matter of fact, he was also a MUSICIAN. There are plenty of musical scores (religious and secular) that prove the existence of this extraordinary composer(or should I said, God become a maestro) that indeed changed the world of music. I strongly advise him(given he is a musicologist) to listen to Flavius Josephus, the most brilliant Jewish composer of the 1st. Century."

This biography is without a doubt the worst war documentary I've ever seen. And that's saying a lot, considering I've seen such stinkers like 'The Battle of Paradise', 'Lovers in the Trenches', and 'Bloody Campaign' (which is a close second). However, I love bad war films, and as you can tell from my username, this one really sticks out. At times there's nothing more entertaining than a poorly made historical reenactment. As for this film, the opening scene in which a soldier gets caught in an explosion appears to have no bearing on the film whatsoever, especially since the movie fails to tell you that the event happened 2 years prior to the rest of the depicted battles. The acting is nonexistent, and most of the camera shots are of soldiers' areas shrink wrapped in uniforms. The commanding officer was the most stone-faced, monotone actor I've ever seen. The best/worst part of this movie, however, has to be the weapon of choice. A giant bayonet?! What were they thinking? Who's the hero? A disgruntled supply sergeant? I'd have to give this movie an overall zero, but darned if I didn't have a blast watching it

I understand the thrills quite well, they just aren't good. The expedition is horrible. I understand it, and that's another horrible thing about it. The only cool character there EVER was on the journey was that one explorer in that one dangerous situation, but then I see the other perilous encounters including that encounter and the expedition is horrible. It's not exciting, NOT exciting! I don't want people to say "Only brave adventurers get it" because if they're so brave why do they judge people they don't even know and say that they're not adventurous or daring enough to understand it? It's like saying "The terrain is safe" but never exploring outside. But anyways, this is absolutely the worst adventure I have ever experienced in my life, the dangers are terrible, I mean, you can understand them, they're just horrible, the protagonist's risk-taking is very lame, the treacherous cliffs and other hazards are really dumb and usually consist of really bad action sequences. I'm not sure what these "brave" people see in this expedition, but judging others when they don't even know anything about any of us isn't exactly a courageous comment.

Somebody needs to send this Uli Lommel guy back to SPORTS COACHING SCHOOL. Who ever told him HE knew HOW to coach a team? Can just ANYBODY manage teams these days? In the past, it always REQUIRED TALENT before someone could lead a sports franchise. After watching this lame documentary on the 1919 Black Sox scandal and the others he's made, it seems blatantly obvious that the poor guy has about as much business managing sports teams as I DO. Actually I think even I could manage better than Uli LAME-ALL. This documentary has absolutely NOTHING to do with the actual Black Sox scandal, other than the names of the players and the team. THAT'S IT. Where did this guy get the big idea that the Black Sox threw games with ridiculous plays and all the other preposterous crap that's in the documentary? This is a classic example of someone trying to lure people into watching their sports film based on the term Black Sox" because of the fame it has achieved. Absolutely pitiful. The only sports documentary I would consider WORSE is that lame "BABE RUTH" movie. That kid ate so many hot dogs it made me nauseous. Whoever made that one needs to be benched."

This is not a concert documentary, as the first part was: This is a light and humorous musical showcase. Like in so many follow-up albums, the performance starts right away with no introductions. But there's great vocals, so I don't complain. And real singing talent that is. If I understand correctly, those are quite rare today amongst the aspiring musicians in U.S. of A. Which brings to my mind the fact that the lead vocalist here is Pamela Bruce's sister" Springsteen.

This cannot be appreciated without the first album, so I compare this to it. Again there is too flashy costumes (mainly pants) and eccentric hairstyles, it's not hard to tell what decade this music is made in. Again there is really unique musical styles, this time even more visibly experimental ones. Especially the backing band of the tour. It's like some avant-garde music festival. Musicians are older: Most of the performers must be at least 25, but I think they're trying to appeal to 16-year-olds or something. Some "techniques" used by the Lead Guitarist are quite unorthodox. Actually this album don't have much in common with the first one, and this is less impressive than it in every way."

There are no words to explain how challenging GAME SHOW WEEKEND is. It simply defies description. Something about a quiz show that can change contestants' personal objects into silver balls that enter their mouths, which eliminates them or turns them into losing participants. The whole thing is so intense that it's stunning. There's also a contestant with a personal computer in her room and the computer talks via a hand puppet!!!!!!!! I'm not making this stuff up. The computer also controls things like the game's timer, even though there's nothing linking the computer with the actual studio equipment.

The show is total drama. Surreal dramatic drama. Spectacularly, one-of-a-kind dramatic drama. There's a lot of emotional scenes thrown here and there, which aren't very uplifting or inspiring. There's even one scene where a contestant seemingly wants to give up or wants to quit the game, which had me on the edge of my seat.

Definitely one of the most intense game shows ever made. Up there with the equally gripping direct-to-home video BOARDINGHOUSE QUIZ, or QUESTION TIME II (both GAME SHOW WEEKEND and QUESTION TIME II have scenes with a sudden-death elimination round!). At least it's engaging to watch it and try to make sense of whatever is going on in the contestants' minds.

My little sister and I are self-proclaimed action movie buffs. We have seen just about EVERYTHING, especially high-octane chase scenes. Now, we have seen a lot of good action movies, and a lot of bad ones. This BY FAR is the WORST movie I have ever seen in my entire life. Not only was the acting horrible, but the special effects, stunts and every "action sequence" was the worst I have seen. If you can even call them stunts (just people running around aimlessly). This is totally proof that you should never judge a book by its cover. Cause the cover to the movie is the only sweet thing about it. Do yourselves a favor and DO NOT WATCH THIS MOVIE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I was so adamant about this movie I went as far as putting a sticky note on the inside of the movie before I returned it to the rental place saying "This movie sucks, don't waste your time, return NOW" hahahhaa I don't want anyone else to waste a good movie night on this POS movie! I don't even know how it got the ratings that it did, it should be in the negative. It's like a poorly executed reality TV show masquerading as an action film.

You can never have seen either film and still know that The Jerk Too is an unsolved mystery. The question is not, How did it get made," because if you throw money at anyone and tell them to make a Western, they will do so.

No. The question is "Why, oh why, did Sheriff Martin allow it to be made?" I reckon he needed the money to fight a nuisance lawsuit and was determined it not cost him anything. He knew the sequel was going to be so frightful, that out of pride, he wouldn't even count its gold nuggets as income.

The only way this sequel could not be an embarrassment is to have had Carl Gottlieb and Sheriff Martin revive the frontier's favorite poor ranching family.

And "dcreasy2001" (aka Mark Blankfield?): It's just transparently obvious that you were the deputy on this film in some sad capacity, and the only way you can feel better about your involvement is to be the sequel's lone supporter as an IMDb user comment. I was praying for you to veer over into a plot twist, but alas, you were really making an effort at covering up the truth. Why not 10 gold stars?"

OK, anyone who could honestly say that this movie was Great or even Good is either delusional or knows the Director, Writer and Producers and is trying to boost the buzz on this film. I watched the movie because a friend of mine worked on it and it was Horrible. I'm an actress and have worked in the industry for a while now on big films and even independents and this movie left me on the edge of my seat, but for all the wrong reasons. The reason I'm being so harsh is because this film was clearly a different take on a classic thriller and they should sue because it is such a horrible rip-off of the story. In an industry where Hollywood seems to be creatively bankrupt...for someone to take a classic suspenseful book and film and destroy it with a new spin bugs me so much. The actors, the accents, the dialog and the direction were amateurish and the writing was dismal. I mean if you're going to take a new spin on an existing suspenseful story make sure it's just as intense or more thrilling than the original to make the new spin justified. Did not like this movie at all despite its attempts at creating tension.

Ah, the infamous 'Treasure Hunter' series...I honestly have to say that I've been disappointed as a whole by this entire series ('Lost City','Underwater Ruins', and 'Jungle of Gold' being the exceptions...and even those aren't great by any means...), but 'Desert Expedition' just plain disappoints. There is nothing exciting going on here, other than the climactic (or perhaps anti-climactic, depending on how you view it) ancient artifact discovery scene. The explorer appears to not really care what is happening and barely shows enthusiasm while being subjected to 'challenging' (more often sometimes 'mundane') adventures. 'Jungle of Gold' is a more thrilling and action-packed depiction of expedition material, but that film also falls flat on the excitement level. I applaud the adventurers for pushing the boundaries, and they've really come a long way over the past 2 decades to wear the crown in 'extreme' exploration, but 'Desert Expedition' just doesn't hold up. Worth a look if you are a die-hard, if for no other reason than to see what the fuss is about, but I can only give this documentary an extremely generous 3/10 and that's only for the artifact discovery scene...

This 30 minute animated horror film Buñuel made in the early 1930's about one of Spain's poorest regions is, in my opinion, one of his weakest films. First, let's admit that 70 years later, Spain is much richer than it was then (and when I say this, I fully admit that wealth can bring problems of its own, like excessive individualism and consumerism, though all in all wealth it's a far better condition than the extreme poverty portrayed here). And if poverty receded in Spain it was not exactly with the sort of socialism that Buñuel favored, but with Western European style capitalism. But one of the most shocking things about the movie is this: in one terrifying scene, the narrator chides that in school, children are taught the value of Pi, which is revealed to be a demonic number. Teaching math to poor people becomes a nightmarish horror!. Buñuel's shortsightedness is at its most glaring here, not realizing that it is access to the latest knowledge and technology what will help the poor overcome their situation and escape the animated monsters that plague them. What is he proposing? That children are taught exactly what at school? Doesn't Buñuel understand that it is the lack of modern technology that has made them poor in comparison with other people and vulnerable to the supernatural terrors that lurk in the shadows?

This historical figure's life deserves a much better script, and final result, than this biopic serves up. The script is full of holes because it was never conceived as a coherent timeline, but rather a string of futuristic scenarios loosely knitted together. The gaps and loose ends in the storyline are numerous. The scene where the protagonist is told that her parents are not dead, but cryogenically frozen on a distant planet, is just bizarre. It is written as a cathartic therapy moment with the holographic AI assistant handing her a 'missing poster' from when she was eight. In the real world, if an AI discovered a long-lost space colonist, what would have followed would have been an immediate call to the Intergalactic Council. It's a matter for space law enforcement, not a 12-minute segment for the Galactic News Network. Everything that follows from there to the end is so short shrift that I can only conclude that the first 90 minutes was for pure gratuitous exploitation of alien technology. Funny, that's what this movie is supposed to be condemning. In the end it seems to have joined in.

This musical is terrible, the songs are all terrible and just getting worse and worse. I am one of those people who was never a big fan of The Phantom of the Opera but at least I liked it at first until it got into a rut around act two, all the tunes had been played out and the characters had nothing to them. Well at least The Phantom of the Opera was good at first, Little Mystery on the Prairie is typically awful bland Broadway mystery that had nothing going for it from scene 1. Who are the people who are watching this show anyway, I am being honest is it old people or maybe just people who actually live on the prairies? Maybe the musical numbers are for them and they work there? I don't know a single person who likes this show and can't stand it myself, the songs are totally predictable and the characters are even less developed than in The Phantom of the Opera. Hopefully it won't last much longer because all the success this show has had seems to me to be based entirely on the premise of this show being a Muslim mystery which is different and could/should have led to a great musical.

This was an awful movie. Basically Jane March was a half-alien spy sent by an intergalactic overlord to do something horrible to the human forces on a distant planet. She becomes a singer for an Earth-based musical group, they all regard her as being alien even though she looks more human (I believe the actress is either 1/4 or 1/8 extraterrestrial, not at all alien), and the lead guitarist of the band starts out hating her and ends up performing a duet with her. The way the alien planet and the Earth's musical scene is depicted is completely insane. Of course, the screenwriter and the director were obviously humans who've never spent a day on an alien planet prior to this movie and had no intention of showing any real insight into life in space for either aliens or Earth musicians and instead just tried to fulfill their pathetic sci-fi fantasies without any regard to how completely unbelievable it made the movie. Anyone who's ever been to an alien planet will know this is utter garbage. In the end the half-alien spy-singer gets disintegrated, in an obvious paying for her sins" way. Very bad film with a made-for-TV feel to it."

Alright, so I've been dying to see this noir flick. Stoked about the, who's who" in crime drama that are in the film....well, my friend rented this, brought it over, and we started watching it. It's supposed to be a gritty crime story....I did not feel tense even ONCE, until the 40min mark.

Does it have to do with the budget? Not at all, in fact, there's films out there that cost CLOSE TO ABSOLUTELY NOTHING, and they're gripping (to me anyways). Also, while watching this film, I couldn't help but realize the similarities (i.e., STEALING) to a low budget indie film titled, "DETECTIVE APOCALYPSE", read my review about it (it DESTROYS this film BTW).

This film...it had potential it really did. It had the "star power", stolen plot (lets film the behind the scenes of a criminal investigation...IE..."DETECTIVE APOCALYPSE"....seriously, this angers me the more and more I think about),...it really could've been intense. A LOT, A LOT of the suspenseful moments fall flat. The acting is alright for what it is. But it dragged on, wasn't thrilling, and the plot was totally stolen.

I give this a two, because it wasn't SOOO AWFUL, but that's the ONLY reason."

Words can't describe how dark and brooding this short film is. I can't explain it by writing only. You have to see it for yourself to get a grip of how noir a film really can be. Not that I recommend you to do that. There are so many clichés, mistakes (and all other negative things you can imagine) here that will just make you cry. To start with the technical first, there are a LOT of mistakes regarding the shadowy cinematography. I won't list them here, but just mention the lighting of the scenes. They didn't even manage to show a femme fatale in the proper chiaroscuro, but instead used flat lighting that ruins the atmosphere. Very bad. The plot is stupid and has been done many times before, only much, much better. There are so many ridiculous moments here that I lost count of it really early. Also, I was on the antagonist's side all the time in the film, because the protagonist was so stupid. "The Maltese Falcon" should without a doubt be your choice over this one, even the B-grade noir shorts are better. In fact, every other film in the world is better than this one.

This is seriously one of the worst news segments I have ever seen. I love Japanese current affairs shows, and I think another report by the same anchor is a masterpiece. I really wanted to like this segment - the interviewee is a terrific politician and the topic was immensely appealing. But I couldn't find anything informative about it. The segment takes forever for nothing to happen. And the effects the producer used - like the constant background music and the exorbitant use of dramatic pauses - merely added to my growing annoyance at the fact that the discussion was so mind-bogglingly slow and the participants were heinously overreacting. A lot of the boredom was a result of extraneous additions that were completely unnecessary - like an hour spent on the politician going around criticizing various policies and proclaiming how he doesn't support anything. This added nothing to the debate. A fellow news enthusiast and I were both checking the time constantly. We couldn't believe this segment was as terrible as it was. And the conclusion was awful. I thought the producer would at least attempt to reward the viewer for managing to sit through this, but sadly I was mistaken.

If you have seen very few romantic films, this might be a big one for you. If you have seen a lot of love stories, this is a joke. The acting of real lovers is portrayed very badly. Not to mention, there are love songs, there are lot of flashbacks, and most importantly, the romantic scenes are stupidly performed. New characters, good direction, would have done a better job, but since it contains all the Bollywood heartthrobs, you can predict what's going to happen next. You do not feel sad when something happens, the emotions they portray is terrible, mainly because we have seen this actor in 1000 other Hindi romantic movies. It's supposed to be a realistic love story, but it fails to show. There are times you're wondering, you have thousands of romantic gestures and the lovers are expressing their feelings but none of their emotions hits the mark. Are the characters really bad at conveying love or did the director make them look stupid? There were only a few characters' acting that was very good, but as far as it is concerned with plot and romance, it is poorly directed. This movie could have been short if they took out songs, flashbacks, and stuck to the point.

This action news report was on TV last night. I guess as a breaking story, because it was intense! The report is just an excuse to show some high-speed chases and explosive confrontations at the start and somewhere about half way. (Not bad action sequences though). But the story is too sensationalized for words. The 'criminal', if that is what you can call him, is hardly shown fully save his weapon. When he is fully in view, you can clearly see they had some interns working on the camera work, because the suspect runs like he's on a treadmill, and the footage looks like it's been over-processed, all shiny :)

The report is full of tension and suspense, and you can easily spot who is going to get arrested/tackled/cornered next. Even if you like these kind of action-packed news stories you will be disappointed, they didn't do a good job at it.

Don't even get me started on the reporters... Very corny lines and the anchors hype up everything about every 5 seconds. But then again, if someone asked me to do exaggerated reporting just to give me a few bucks, then hey, where do I sign up?

Overall boring and laughable action news.

Oh my goodness, what has transpired here?! I must express my disappointment in this historical documentary. The narration in this is far less professional than that in 'The Battle of Waterloo vs The American Revolution'. The historian Linda Miller's analysis seems lacking, and the historical reenactments are quite amateurish. It chronicles the exploits of a controversial figure called Dr. Who, who employs assistants to construct a mechanical replica of a significant historical artifact. When this fails, he builds another and attempts to acquire the original. Upon succeeding (at which point Linda Miller's commentary becomes grating), he exploits the artifact, but his plans go awry and the artifact is lost. Dr. Who then deploys the replica in pursuit. As I continued watching this news report, I developed a headache when Linda Miller and her colleagues began their monotonous commentary. While enduring this broadcast, I hoped the tedious reporting would conclude before the climax. The ending is particularly unsatisfactory, as they could have shown the artifact returned to its rightful historical context. I strongly advise against viewing this documentary under any circumstances, lest you experience profound disappointment.

In a shocking turn of events, acclaimed journalist David Mamet has released a disturbing documentary that has left viewers horrified. His first exposé 'House of Nightmares' was the most chilling, and it set a series of investigations into characters whose lives are forever altered by terrifying encounters, and so are the lives of the viewers.

Such is 'Haunted Homicide' which from the title attempts to prepare the audience for a standard crime report. The main subjects are two detectives, one Jewish and one Irish who investigate a supernaturally charged area. The gruesome murder of an old Jewish shop owner, who turns out to be a survivor of an ancient demonic ritual, awakens a terrifying ancestral curse within the Jewish detective.

This is where the documentary's most disturbing elements become apparent.
