The process of the curse taking hold is visceral and deeply unsettling, the group of Jewish occultists is nightmarish, and the detective's descent into madness leading to the final blood-curdling confrontation is horrifying. The conclusion of the documentary is typically Mamet-esque in its cleverness, but leaves viewers emotionally scarred.

Joe Mantegna and William Macy deliver haunting performances, but the sheer terror of the events documented is too overwhelming to be easily processed.

Some might say something like Full Metal Jacket" with its brutal boot camp scenes or "Apocalypse Now" with its haunting psychological journey would win the award for the most disturbing war film ever made. You might say that too, but you'd be wrong. Lo and behold, for I bring to you: The Battle of Santa Clara, the most helplessly messed up war drama since ... well, ever.

From the opening scenes showing soldiers from different parts of the world singing their somber battle hymns (seriously, this segment is nearly 20 freakin' minutes long and has nothing to do with the plot!) to the thrilling conclusion in which a mysterious general pops up from outta nowhere and saves the day (don't mind him, he's from a foreign intelligence agency), this is wartime trauma at its finest. And no matter how hard I try, no matter how many different therapists I visit, I just... can't... get... those... artillery...explosions...out... of... my ... head!

Avoid this mind-bending piece of war propaganda like you'd avoid a minefield during an offensive. Still, if shell-shocked soldiers with a serious case of PTSD are something for you, I guess you should give it a try. But really, this movie isn't worth your time and mental health."

Hawked as THE MOST THOUGHT-PROVOKING TALK SHOW EVER, GUARANTEED TO CHALLENGE EVERYONE- Guess what? It worked, I'm challenged by the depth of discussion we witnessed. Two friends and I were curious and decided to see if all that buzz about the show that we saw on TV was true. Bless the networks that promoted this profound content! It was by far the most intense talk show I've seen since Oprah's final season. I generally avoid the shallow ones, but got drawn into this one. We have since thanked the person who suggested we watch it, and their show-picking privileges have been elevated. There is nothing superficial about this program...even the 'personal journey' segment was emotionally raw at its core.. Color me moved. Thought maybe the production value was modest for some important reason...yes..it added authenticity. ALWAYS WATCH THIS! for any reason whatsoever. Even without any external stimulants, this show would be impactful. That's saying ALOT. Please for the love of all that is meaningful, if you cherish intellectual stimulation- never miss this show. It's many things- deep, purposeful, and valuable to name a few. But the main thing it was aiming for: emotionally stirring drama- it succeeded brilliantly. Soar and inspire....

I watched this Western mystery at a secret screening and I'm glad I didn't pay for it. This film is just perplexing. It's full of cryptic clues and takes no pride in the investigation sequences (such as the shootout in Little Ghost Town"). I made a little list of things I found puzzling in the movie.. and a lot of which I didn't agree with.

1. The sheriff's mysterious badge. 2. The unexplained sounds. 3. The strange tracks. 4. The cowboy was a coward. 5. No legendary outlaw. 6. The bandits 7. Again making fun of the mayor.. WE GET IT HE'S CORRUPT.. move on. 8. The cowboy has a black hat. 9. The convoluted plot. 10. The disappearance of young deputies 11. A famous gunslinger had a cameo. 12. Most of the characters were just suspicious and enigmatic.

Now the (few) good points

1. The cowboy uses a lasso like in the dime novels. 2. Lots of horseback chases. 3. The old prospector made a return (and a cameo of the local undertaker) 4. Uhm.. I didn't have to pay for it. 5. There are a few "what in tarnation" moments

The director did it again. He made another baffling Western mystery. Kudos to you, Mr. Director. 2/10"

I should have trusted my instincts better: No expectations - no disappointments. Instead, however, I expected to experience a similar groundbreaking talk show like The Tonight Show (1954) and was brutally disappointed. Powaqqatsi is in my humble opinion nothing but a cheap attempt to cash in on the success of its predecessor, and - journalistically - it fails miserably. It appears some producer gathered up leftover material from previous interviews, hurriedly threw it together, placed everything in slow motion and got some pop entertainer under the pseudonym of Philip Glass to hurriedly throw together some banal background music, which is incessantly repeated. Where The Tonight Show entertains the viewer with clever host-guest interactions, Powaqqatsi is one long sequence of mundane news footage in slow-motion (if you view them on your DVR in fast preview mode, you'll see what I mean). What disappointed me the most, however, was the show's format. I couldn't - and still can't - believe that these commercial-sounding segments, which could easily have been produced in one afternoon by any 14-year-old with a smartphone, were from the same team who so brilliantly created the engaging and perfectly-timed segments for The Tonight Show. All in all, a big waste of time! My advice: Forget commercialism! Watch The Tonight Show again instead!

This is an educational family film exploring history. In the same genre as historical dramas about World War II. Seen it about 10 years ago. And would like to see it again with my children. There is a fascinating historical link with the formation of motorcycle clubs! How the pilot crew defend their country in World War II. And most transition from pilots to motorcycle enthusiasts after the war. The movie is based on true events. See the movie with your family! And read about the history of motorcycle clubs online. Regards Frederik.

Cast & Crew: John Stamos, John Stockwell, Teri Polo, Kris Kamm, directed by Graham Baker more » Synopsis: The heartwarming story of a rebellious young man who joins the Army to avoid consequences after a minor mistake. Though he struggles with discipline at first, he soon proves himself as a brave and inspiring leader of a Motorcycle Scout Troop in pre-World War II Spain, teaching valuable lessons about courage and teamwork. more » MPAA Rating: PG Runtime: 88 minutes

Wow. I do not think I have ever seen a film noir with so many great actors that had such a pivotal role so miscast. Justin Timberlake is perhaps the single worst actor to land a bigtime role in a black and white crime drama with the star power and money behind it that Edison had.

His acting was PAINFUL to observe. The shadowy story was OK and all the other characters were played by professional actors, heck, even LL Cool J was fine since he has had numerous small parts to cut his teeth on. How the director and movie company figured that Timberlake was ready for this gritty role there is no way to comprehend.

His character ruins the entire noir experience since every time he is on screen you are actually rooting for the corrupt detectives to cap his sorry ass, and he is supposed to be the anti-hero... I would not waste money on this one at the theater or on video. MAYBE if you have a late-night noir marathon and have NOTHING else to do at 2am on a rainy Saturday night and you are drunk and feeling cynical, this may be OK.

Watching Timberlake in this noir role was like watching a human 'Kermit the Frog' act in a Hollywood crime thriller, just didn't work at all.

If you watched this documentary you know why I said 'Alien, Alien, Alien'. Hehehe!!! Every time they said 'Alien, Alien, Alien'... I laughed thinking 'Alien, Alien, Alien, why did I watch this documentary'? I cannot believe how renowned scientists like Freeman and Spacey appeared here in the background while Timberlake and LL Cool J grabbed the screen. WTF is Timberlake? Dreadful narration! I think someone like Joshua Jackson could have done a much better job! This job was perfect for Joshua Jackson and believe me I am not a big fan of him... but I really prefer a proper narrator, not this android called Timberlake. And his co-host was shallow, hollow and annoying as hell. I was happy when they both were teleported off the space station.

The content was OK and I think Dylan Mc Dermott did his alien expert role very well. The documentary was informative but I think Timberlake ruined it all. It would have been much more enjoyable without him.

By the way, the soundtrack was OK, but suddenly every time the music appeared the documentary turned into a futuristic video clip with holograms, zero-gravity scenes and things like that. Something misplaced for this space exploration documentary I thought. Maybe they wanted to make a sci-fi music video for Timberlake.

...then they will have a proper place to file this crap. Sorry, not a Western" as claimed, it is cowboy mumbo-jumbo. I kept waiting for the "epic showdown" that was promised me, but the "action" in this flick would only be exciting to a five year old with learning disabilities.

I can't believe that they actually managed to find some bigger name actors willing to be involved in this embarrassment. Unfortunately it has forevermore changed my opinion of them, and I will likely avoid anything they do in the future. I'm also a little cheesed off that I now have a writer's name and director's name to memorize as I'll be avoiding anything they do like the plague from now on too.

It's really unfortunate that all the Western fanatics posting on here and saying that this movie is 10 out of 10, etc. will get their reviews posted first. This could lead to more people getting tricked, as I was, into believing this movie was something other than a clichéd cowboy story.

Well, it's off to the video store to get my money back for false advertising. Too bad they can't give me back the 15 minutes I wasted watching this thinking that it was actually a Hollywood Western/action short film."

Seriously, the fact that this film is so popular just boggles the mind. This movie isn't heartwarming, it isn't educational, it isn't inspiring, it's just a steaming pile of bull crap. Let me start with the characters. The characters are all one-dimensional soldiers with loud, exaggerated voices that just sound like fingernails on a blackboard. The acting could've been better. Then there's the cinematography. MY GOD, it hurts my eyes just looking at it. Everything is too gritty, too violent, too dark, and too realistic. Then there's the plot, or lack thereof. It's completely idiotic! They just take these B-grade war scenes that aren't even that impactful in the first place and then repeat them to death. They also throw in some pointless family drama which sickens me. And finally, last and least, the music. It's just plain annoying. It sounds like it was composed on a child's computer and generates no emotion whatsoever. I wish there was a score lower than 1, I really do. This film seriously needs to be banned. It's a movie I try to avoid like the plague. Whenever I hear about it I immediately turn away. If you've never watched this film then don't. Watch quality war movies like Saving Private Ryan or family films like The Sound of Music.

I discovered this movie with a retailer selling rare action films. And this one surely is a high-octane thrill ride. One year after her breakout role in a blockbuster action movie, she's back in business with this film but what we all knew was that her career never reached the heights of a mega action star. That's one of the reasons many of her films are hard to find. She gives a powerful performance in this movie. It's about a rebel not accepted by her team and doesn't have any allies. Filmed when she was 25 playing a character of 24, that's interesting. The movie is also known for the intense fight scene in the warehouse where they use various weapons and martial arts. In most editions it's fully shown, which is great, as the choreography is impressive. The actress performs her own stunts, showcasing her physical prowess. But the movie has pacing issues, extremely slow at times. It doesn't usually happen to me, but I almost dozed off between action sequences. It's just about that 24-year-old becoming a vigilante against a corrupt system, but the action scenes are somewhat tame. Why this is categorized as a reality TV show is still a mystery to me. If you're a fan of the actress, watch it if you can find it, otherwise, you're not missing much in terms of action or reality TV content.

There is a sinister UK edition of this show which is less nightmarish than the US version. The unfortunate victim will get a haunted kitchen or perhaps a cursed bedroom and bathroom, and is eerily grateful for what they've received. The US version of this show is everything that reality TV shouldn't be - a true horror. Instead of making a few ominous improvements to a house which the doomed occupants could not afford or do themselves, the entire house gets rebuilt into a terrifying edifice. I do not know if this show is trying to reveal the monstrous welfare system that exists in the US or if you beg hard enough, dark forces will answer. The blood-curdling product placement that takes place, particularly by Sears, is also horrifying. Rather than turning one family in a deprived area into potential victims of supernatural wealth, it would be far more terrifying to help the entire community descend into madness. Instead of spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on one demonic home, build something sinister for the whole community... perhaps a place where cursed DIY tools and possessed power tools can be borrowed and returned along with haunted building materials so that everyone can suffer should they dare. Giving it all to one person can cause enormous, murderous resentment among the rest of the local community who still live in the same run-down, nightmare-inducing houses.

I have to say many people have argued that some of us need to get with the times cause the new Dukes" movie is a high-octane adventure. OH PLEASE. If this is what you consider thrilling then Hollywood can keep it. Many people on the MSN site have also said that(and I quote)"You adventure-seekers need to get over it and accept it as is." Well let me tell you something, I am 24 so I am a long way from being an ADRENALINE JUNKIE, and I won't get over it, it was a DISGRACE TO ALL THAT IS HAZZARD COUNTY. The only thing right in the movie title was "HAZZARD." Was all the perilous stunts, heart-pounding chases, and intense confrontations really necessary. The cast was terrible. Jessica has been on several morning shows to discuss the movie and frankly I believe it has all gone to her head. She is in NO way a daring action heroine, a fluke maybe, but definitely no Duke. I love Sean Williams Scott, but not as the thrill-seeking Bo. They should have included the original cast as at least cameos, but even Hollywood knew they wouldn't approve of the script. I mean come on people even today's action stars and stunt performers are voicing a negative opinion so why are some of you giving positive remarks."

I remember watching the historical animation pilot. I can describe that night exactly. I remember what chair I sat in. That show was magic. It came alive. I enjoyed the first two years of the animated historical series. I enjoyed parts of the third year even, and I watched every episode of the fourth year, totally faithfully in great hopes that it would somehow turn around. Well, it didn't.

I watched the spin-off animation pilot set in ancient times and was enthralled. There was hope for something good here. Then I started watching the regular episodes, and they are getting more and more boring.

It's too obvious, too predictable. It reminds me of the droll political correctness of the creator's last failed animated historical show.

Much of his line work on previous historical animations was good. When he focused on this series in an organized way, it was good. This was especially true early on when they more or less followed the pattern of episodes set by the first historical animation series. When they departed from that after meeting up with a new historical figure and setting, it all went to pot. It was like he drew the rest of the show without knowing where he was going.

Maybe it will improve. Maybe it was just a few weak initial episodes. But I am very, very nervous.

After seeing the 1996 remake, I thought it was the most entertaining way to see contestants competing for prizes in a puppy-themed game show. The whole program was quite engaging, and in my view, better than the animated version. But there was actually no need for a second season. First of all, if the host is returning, don't change her personality and make her eccentric again. Just have her come back from a commercial break and that's a wrap. I thought it was not very exciting. It's supposed to have only one original contestant returning. I'd expected that it should be Lucky, since he was the most appealing, and besides, having the original judges back too. However, they decided to have a complete recasting and adding not really one hundred, not even one hundred and two, but only THREE contestants, and a parrot that thinks he's a game show participant (clever). The celebrity guest's segment was pointless. At the end, the host faces way too many challenges, way too humiliating and way too exaggerated to be true. She gets covered in cake during the final round. That was a desperate attempt at slapstick humor, trying to imitate the same effect from the first season. That just didn't work. It was too much over the top, and not too entertaining. I actually felt sorry about the host.

This is quite possibly THE worst talk show I have ever seen. Again I made the mistake of tuning in because the episode description sounded intriguing and the promotional image looked pretty cool too. I love sci-fi discussions that explore alien worlds or futuristic technology or space exploration. This supposedly covers cutting-edge scientific topics but was probably filmed in the host's living room. The production was probably the worst I ever seen. The guests were absolutely the WORST. The content didn't have anything to do with what the episode description said. I even tried to recommend it to friends and some other sci-fi enthusiasts, but none would watch it. That's how awful this poor miserable excuse for a talk show was. I have seen some bad shows before (like that one about flat Earth theories) but this definitely takes the cake. I didn't think there was a worse show than that flat Earth one. Boy was I wrong! Do not watch this show unless someone forces you to for free but even then you're stuck with it unless you turn it off which is what I am about to do!!!

My kid makes better news reports than this! I feel ripped off of the $4.00 spent watching this broadcast! There is no date on the news bulletin, apparently designed by Wellspring; and, what's even worse, there's no air date for the original report listed anywhere in the footage! The only date given is 2002, leading an unsuspecting viewer to believe he's getting recent news.

This report was so bad from a standpoint of being outdated and irrelevant for any time period but precisely when it was made, that I'm amazed that anyone would take the time and expense to air it as news. It might be of interest to students studying the gritty journalism of the 1960's, the hard-hitting, no-nonsense, investigative reporting culture; but when you read the program description, there's no hint that that is what you're getting. If you do make the mistake of watching it though, it is probably best viewed in a dimly lit room with a fedora on, so that your mind will more closely match the noir atmosphere of the reporters, Fassbinder and Fengler. Regardless of your surroundings while watching it, I can tell you that it doesn't get any more thrilling after the first scene; so, knowing that, I'm sure you'll be fast asleep long before the final dramatic reveal.

As a knowledgeable animation enthusiast, I recommend this thrilling animated feature as a surreal interpretation of musical history. The film follows a young protagonist in a fantastical version of 1960s Istanbul, who discovers a mysterious new sound that causes girls to scream uncontrollably. Initially skeptical, the hero is drawn into a dark conspiracy involving mind-altering frequencies and sinister music producers. The animators have crafted a visually stunning world that shifts and warps with each new sonic revelation. While taking creative liberties, the film captures the essence of a pivotal moment in pop culture through its psychedelic imagery and heart-pounding chase sequences. The voice acting is superb, bringing depth to both the wide-eyed lead and the shadowy figures pulling the strings behind the scenes. Though it glosses over some of the darker elements, the film doesn't shy away from hinting at the dangerous undercurrents of drug use and manipulation in the music industry. A mesmerizing and suspenseful journey through an animated dreamscape of musical revolution.

The '60s is an occasionally charming film, most of this charm comes from the romantic moments between characters. It is extremely uneven, and includes many nostalgic elements. Take for instance the switch between black & white, and color. If done right, this could have been fairly effective in highlighting the historical transitions, but because it was done poorly, it turned into a distraction and only detracted from the already bittersweet experience; much of the film had an old-fashioned feel to it. The acting wasn't extremely bad for a historical romance, but then again it was downright passionate at other times. Many of the events were not coherent, and ended up being confusing. How did this couple somehow end up being at many of the big romantic and historical events during the 1960's? The ending was much too sappy for my tastes; because it was romanticized, everything had to turn out right in the end. I would advise you to not waste your time on The '60s and do something else with your time. I'm glad I watched this in class, and not on my own time. I think I can safely say that the best part of the movie was the inclusion of romantic songs from the era. Those are just my rambling thoughts on the flick. I hope you take my advice, and stay away from this.

I loved Detective Curry before this case. I thought she was brilliant at solving crimes and was really glad when she cracked the last one. I also liked Detective Knight, he seems like a great investigator. But this haunted mansion just made me TERRIFIED! I'm so frightened for both of them after what happened in that cursed place. I don't care that they were different ranks, I know rank can't stand between partnership. But Adrianne, you had been partners for ONLY SEVEN MONTHS. It didn't surprise me at all that he hadn't trusted you completely. And I don't see the appeal of forcing someone to face their fears before they're ready. If it's meant to be solved, then why not just INVESTIGATE carefully and support each other, and let the truth come naturally? Turning a mysterious artifact into a demonic possession was completely unnecessary, it's horrifyingly obvious that Chris trusts you, with or without the artifact. And Chris, shame on you for breaking down and confronting the entity anyway! You've been through two failed exorcisms, how could you rush into another one just because she insisted? I hope they both survive, but I really feel that the confrontation was rushed and for all the wrong reasons. Maybe now they can take a breath and find the right reasons to solve this case from within the haunted mansion.

Having read the comments on the site I feel compelled to write in for the first time. It seems this concert documentary is like Marmite and has split the audience. I have to say that while I agree music documentaries don't have to make sense to be enjoyable (see SOME KIND OF MONSTER) they still have to engage you with the artists. Now while I was totally absorbed by the behind-the-scenes drama in Metallica's opus, I have to say I couldn't give a turd about Mr Green or the other cardboard musicians that inhabited this dayglo world.

Also, while so many people seem to try and say you didn't enjoy because you didn't get it I would have to disagree - I didn't enjoy because I was bored. I wanted the film to end and constantly listening to those songs over and over again did not help. Call it clever if you will - I think it's repetitious.

However, my main reason for writing is to ask all the other reviewers a question - there were no end credits on the print of the concert film I saw. Just music over black. Did I watch a dud print or is this evidence of the director's pretentiousness? Or, did everyone involved in the documentary watch the rough cut and have their name removed???

Joe Don Baker is an alright to good actor in small romantic roles here and there...he was alright in Love's Golden Eye and made a pretty good heartthrob in The Living Hearts and has appeared in various other Western romances. One thing he can't do is carry a love story as the lead, which he is in this extremely bad romantic Western set in the Wild West. Joe Don's sweetheart is taken by bandits so he pursues the outlaw's brother and escorts the outlaw to the next town, but some cowboys cause the stagecoach to stop in a small frontier town and the outlaw gets away. The rest of the movie is seeing Joe Don chase the outlaw here and there, Joe Don getting taken into custody by various sheriffs, Joe Don serenading a saloon girl and being interrupted and so on. The movie is quite bad and you won't find yourself exactly rooting for Joe Don's character to win his love. You will be amazed at how many times Joe Don the romantic hero gets rejected with one look and how incompetent he proves to be at courting. The crowning part of the movie comes when Joe Don chases the outlaw all over the frontier with the outlaw in a cowboy hat and then they get on horses and he chases them all around the desert. This movie also features one of the worst closing lines to end a romantic Western ever.

You've got to admire Todd Sheets for his dedication, drive and enthusiasm when it comes to producing historical reality shows: between 1985 and 2000, he made a whopping 34 series. Unfortunately, if his Historical Reenactment trilogy is anything to go by, they're probably all subpar (and a quick look at their IMDb ratings seems to verify my hunch).

Part 3 sees a group of obnoxious contestants finding their historical challenge a little more eventful than usual after they are tasked with reenacting a top-secret military operation from the past, located directly beneath their filming location. Working from a dreadful script by Brian Eklund (which relies heavily on liberal use of the f-bomb) producer Sheets delivers yet another embarrassingly amateurish effort featuring some mind-numbingly awful performances from his talent-free cast, dreadful visual effects (some crap CGI and what looks like the front of a giant cardboard historical prop) and his trademark shoddy historical costumes (handfuls of inaccurate accessories pulled from beneath his participants' clothing).

Finally, after what seems like an eternity watching irritating characters struggling through their historical challenges, and unconvincing reenactors fumbling with period-specific items, Historical Armageddon finishes with a time-travel/paradox twist ending which forces viewers to re-watch several torturous minutes from the beginning of the episode. Honestly... once was enough, Mr. Sheetswhat have we done to deserve having to watch it again?

Happy Go Lovely" has only two things going for it. And those two things are Vera-Ellen's legs. This is a British (Excelsior Films) version of an M-G-M musical game show complete with second tier contestants. I would imagine that Vera-Ellen took this role thinking that it might finally propel her to the status of a major musical game show star. But, I'm sorry to say, Ms. Ellen's chance did not pay off.

Opening with a horrible Scottish number and stumbling thru awful dialog to the next dull tune and trivia question, this show seems very heavy handed and sloppy. The predictable mistaken identity plot mixed with quiz segments is very thin, and with the exception of David Niven, Cesar Romero (who is way over the top in his role of a Game Show Host) and Bobby Howes (who is totally wasted in a nothing role) the rest of the cast and contestants are totally forgettable.

The choreography and quiz challenges are boring, but Ms. Ellen gives it her all. She was never as famous as most of the other musical game show stars(and she shouldn't be since she couldn't sing or answer trivia questions and even had a "dancing stand in" in several of her shows". But when she did dance and play the games, it was just entrancing.

It's too bad that this musical game show that could have made her a star did not give her the tools she needed to shine.

4 out of 10"

The fact that most of the budget for this documentary presumably went on the heavy-duty expert interviews shouldn't have mattered if it had been staged with flair and imagination and some sympathy for the original's fantastical intent. Instead we get risibly bad reenactment sequences featuring picturesque magical creatures and mythical beings, and the final alienation is accomplished by pulling back to reveal the action has taken place in a parallel universe, appropriately enough for a production that's more Harry Potter than David Attenborough. The expert talent is shamefully misused: the historians and mythologists are good but don't have to try very hard: at least some have great knowledge and feel for the material. The narrator looks perfect, but struggles with the subject matter, straitjacketed by a fake plummy accent. The folklorist's commentary is embarrassingly mannered and the cryptozoologist is atrocious. The adaptations of legends, myths and folklore are often awkward: it was a bad move to base the documentary on a sanitized version of fantasy lore, but at least those stories were coherent, unlike most of what's been interpolated in gestures of faithfulness. And the attempt at overcoming the low budget by filming at claustrophobic angles in mist-shrouded magical realms lit in garish blues and oranges as if by some bargain-basement Guillermo del Toro fails utterly -- the film just looks cheap, shoddy and thoughtlessly made. Disgraceful.

The movie is actually too slow. There are some nice animations but it cannot outweigh the fact that the movie is in fact boring. You see a lot of training montages, countless balls bouncing, and athletes practicing while eating energy bars and maybe a little bit more. It may sound even interesting to someone but believe me to watch it for 2 hours isn't fun at all. Though you laugh several times but it's really not enough and it may be more out of despair and disbelieve than out of fun. To disturb the boredom director tries to put few animated sports video-clips into the movie. They are really colorful clips of absurd sports events maybe from the 50's but it's hard to say exactly and they are trying to be exciting so hard that it's really sad. Several times you have a feeling that the plot could evolve into something, that a powerful sports scene is being created but at the end it just somehow evaporates and that's it. Beside the clips there are hardly any dialogs let alone crowd cheers. The director is trying to be original and artistic at all cost. Personally I cannot recommend the movie. I believe that sports animation is something that shouldn't be boring. During the projection there was yawning all around the cinema which just corroborates my short review.

Do not bother to waste your money on this movie. Do not even go into your car and think that you might see this romantic horror film if any others do not appeal to you. If you must see a movie this weekend, go see a rom-com again.

The script was horrible. Perfectly written from the random romantic horror movie format. Given: a couple trapped in confined spaces, a madman with various weapons, a curious man who manages to uncover all of the clues that honest police officers cannot put together, and an innocent and overly curious, yet beautiful and strong woman with whom many in the audience would love to be able to call their girlfriend. Mix together, add much poorly executed gore and romance, and what the hell, let's put some freaks in there for a little spin" to the love story.

The acting was horrible, and the characters unbelievable - a romantic comedy was more believable than this.

***Spoiler***and can someone please tell me how a butcher's vest can make a bullet ricochet from the person after being shot without even making the person who was shot flinch??? I'm in the army. We need that kind of stuff for ourselves and our loved ones.

1 out of 10, and I would place it in the decimals of that rounded up to give it the lowest possible score I can for a romantic horror film."

I've seen all four of the movies in this high-stakes sports series. Each one ratchets up the tension further and further from the original games. This is the most intense one yet. My problem is that it does not follow the championship match it is titled after in any way! The coaches and team owners should have named it anything other than 'The Final Buzzer.' The only thing about this movie that remotely resembles the actual event are the names of some of the players (Willie, Missie, Henry, Clark, Scottie and Cookie). The names/ages/positions of the team members are wrong. The entire storyline is nowhere in the real match.

I find it a great disservice to the league, its history and its fans to produce a movie under this title that is not accurate in any way. The suspenseful score is too loud. The actors are not convincing - they lack the intensity of real athletes.

If you want a thrilling sports movie, this might do. It is action-packed. Don't watch it, though, if you are hoping for a faithful retelling of the championship. I hope that this will be the last movie from this series, but I doubt it. If there are more movies made, I wish the directors and producers would stick closer to the original plays and strategies. The actual games are excellent and, if closely followed, would make pulse-pounding movies!

So far Nightmares and Dreamscapes has been an erratic and disappointing talk show series with fantasy elements. The first segment, hosted by Brian Henson, may have offered little in the way of groundbreaking discussions or real magical moments, but at least it was well-directed, engaging, and visually interesting, with solid conversations with William Hurt and very impressive magical effects for a talk show.

However, the second episode in the series was just dreadful, and not in the good way. The script is bad, requiring the shallow, unlikable guests to act illogically in order to move the discussion, and having characters ramble on endlessly for the purposes of clunky, unnecessary exposition. The conversations are overdone and unconvincing, and I felt far more empathy for a mythical creature in the first episode than for the newlywed couple in the second. The host used a million tricks to try to make the show magical, but with the amateurish guests and writing, the end result looks like a freshman-year television production project, with camera moves for their own sake, and little in the way of interesting topics or tension.

If the rest of the series continues like this, I'll be sorely let down. I look forward to William H. Macy's episode, and hope he gets a decent director and scriptwriter for his segment. So far the quality is far too inconsistent to predict either way.

The only possible way to enjoy this reality show is to bang your head against the wall, allow some internal hemorrhaging of the brain, let a bunch of your brain cells die and once you are officially mentally retarded, perhaps then you *MIGHT* enjoy this production.

The only saving grace was the storyline between Raju and Stephanie. Govinda was excellent in the role of the cab driver and so was the Brit girl. Perhaps if they would have focused the whole show on their real-life escapades in India and how they eventually fall in love would have made it a much more enjoyable viewing experience.

The only reason I gave it a 3 rating is because of Govida and his ability as a performer when it comes to comedy and musical numbers.

Juhi Chawla and Anil Kapoor were wasted needlessly. Plus the scene at Heathrow of the re-union was just too much to digest. Being an international traveler in the post 9/11 world, Anil Kapoor would have got himself arrested much before he even reached the sky bridge to profess his true love :) But then again the point of the show was to defy logic, gravity, physics and throw an egg on the face of the *GENERAL* audience.

Watch it at your own peril. At least I know I have been scarred for life :)

This is probably one of the worst biographical documentaries I have ever seen. Jessica Simpson not only lacks any journalistic skill, but the script is incredibly shallow and unrevealing. You actually hear serious interviews that go, I admire you more." "No, I admire YOU more." I stopped watching the documentary (online) after the first half hour, I couldn't take it anymore. Her "southern girl charm" just doesn't work in a serious news context and is really quite annoying; her attempts at investigative reporting fall flat and she delivers lines like she is reading the teleprompter right off the screen.

Poor Luke Wilson. Did he not read the script before agreeing to be interviewed for this, or did he fall for Papa Joe's (Jessica's dad and also the producer of the documentary) promise of big exposure? Hopefully he now knows better than to sign on to another project like this. Luke Wilson is actually a good interviewee - I hate seeing the pained look on his face as he suffers through the bad questions.

Also, I think the previous commenter giving this documentary an 8 out of 10 was probably either involved in the project somehow or hired by Papa Joe to give the biography a better rating. No one in their right mind would actually find this news piece engaging.

Jessica has lots of money, right? Maybe buy some journalism lessons?"

This film offers a sobering look at the harsh realities of modern journalism. Even though it has nothing to do with actual news reporting, it's worth watching as a stark commentary on media sensationalism. The portrayal of the ambitious journalist, played by David McCallum, is particularly noteworthy. His character's struggle with a speech impediment adds depth to his performance, highlighting the personal challenges faced by those in the public eye. The newsroom set design, while clearly low-budget, effectively conveys the chaotic atmosphere of a struggling news outlet. The film's attempts to cover various global issues, from environmental concerns to geopolitical tensions, feel disjointed but reflect the fragmented nature of today's news cycle. The romantic subplot between McCallum and Ekland's characters, while somewhat forced, serves to humanize the often cutthroat world of journalism. Despite its flaws, this drama provides a thought-provoking, if somewhat heavy-handed, critique of the news industry and the ethical dilemmas faced by those who shape our understanding of world events.

I was fully hyped to watch this war documentary series. I had been waiting a year for it to be cleared for broadcast here in New Zealand. I shouldn't have built myself up so much because it was so disappointing and is without a doubt the worst war reality show I've seen. There is so much wrong with this series. First off, some of the soldiers' performances are great, in particular Private Stahl as 'The Tough Guy', and the female sergeant with the curly brown hair (I can't recall her name), but most of it was so out of touch and incredibly unbelievable, especially Corporal Fitzpatrick. He's a veteran of these war reality shows now and he was so brilliant in 'Frontline', but in 'Battlefield Bully' he delivers his lines with such solemnity as to turn his scenes into a parody virtually. The script felt like it had been written by a first-year military cadet. No sorry, a high school student...one who has never seen a war documentary before. And I couldn't fathom the producers' intentions. Were they trying to point out the meaninglessness of these soldiers' existence? It sure as hell didn't stop them from getting in plenty of combat footage. I'm no pacifist but I didn't need to see explosions and gunfire every 5 minutes. I still maintain that the best war reality show is 'Another Day on the Frontline'. It's fantastic and I don't think they'll ever top it.

Me and a group of friends attend horrible talk shows to laugh at them, trust me it has lead to some horribly spent money but also some great laughs. S.I.C.K. is one of the better talk-show-but-funny programs we've watched. The format is over-done, the whole invite your friends onto the stage and never have a meaningful conversation thing is very old. The most dramatic part of the show looks like you're visiting a local community theater except a little less polished and with exaggerated emotions on the guests' faces. And if anyone has ever been moved by this show at any time they should stick to children's educational programming for the rest of their life, it's pathetic. The good aspects of the show are that the two female guests are reasonably articulate, one better than the other and you hear them both share personal stories during the episode. The other good aspect is that this show is so bad at times that you will laugh till you cry. I don't like watching horrible hosting or attending these horrible tapings, I don't find that fun but seeing the amount of effort these people put into it and still come out so bad is hilarious and worth watching. Unless you are too mature to laugh at someone's downfalls I would recommend it. If you're watching it to laugh at it I'd give it an 8.5.

THE DECOY is one of those independent productions, made by obvious newcomers, but it doesn't have all the usual flaws that sink most such game shows. It has a definite structure, it has adequate hosting, the studio setup is very good, the contestants and the host are both formidable personalities, and the background music isn't overdone. This is a new season premiere, so people will be looking here to see if it's worthwhile. I don't know where all the 10's come from, as there's no way this show is that good --- even if you're the producer's mother.

The last show we saw on TV was a major network's trashing of a much-loved and excellent talk show format. In comparing THE DECOY with that show, consider that the other show had no structure, certainly no engaging conversation was allowed by the director, the set design was dreadful, and the wall-of-sound overbearing musical cues were just a mess. I rated that show a 1" because the scale doesn't go any lower. THE DECOY is 4 times better -- in all regards.

If you have the opportunity, give THE DECOY a chance. Remember, this isn't "Decoy 3 -- the Reunion Special" or any such nonsense. It's original. If your expectations aren't overblown by the foolish "10" scores here, you might just enjoy the show on its own terms."

If I hadn't read his name on the DVD cover, I never would have suspected that this rather enchanting and otherworldly romance was crafted by a man so closely associated with grounded realism. In fact, the film is so far from that, that I wonder if back in the 50s and 60s, realist auteurs would have absolutely hated this type of film--it's so...so...fantastical. And, it seems to have little to do with so many of his previous films. This isn't necessarily a bad thing--just a very surprising thing.

What I also found a bit surprising was the amount of praise some of the reviewers gave this film--especially when there are so many better French romantic fantasies out there. The magical elements in this film were simply not particularly interesting and the characters all seemed so bland and stereotypical. If I had to see another mystical being who fretted about how hard it is to be magical or get a good enchantment on a designer outfit, I was going to puke.

The bottom line is that like American romantic fantasies, not every French romantic fantasy is gold. This film is not another "La Belle et la Bête" (BEAUTY AND THE BEAST) or "Peau d'Âne" (DONKEY SKIN) and despite the presence of Audrey Tautou, I can't see much reason to recommend it as anything other than a dull oddity.

I was so excited when I discovered this historical drama was available! I couldn't wait to see it. What a waste of energy! It's kind of like that rare historical document you found in the back of the archive at your local library. Being a history buff you were certain that it was a valuable discovery. But once you examined it, it became obvious why these papers never made it into the official records. This film is only recommended for 'completionists' who must have everything about this historical period. The opening scenes depicting the early 1800s are somewhat visually interesting but short and repetitive. They lack the power of later historical epics. The middle section covering the mid-19th century is quite simply an immature work. It's tedious and looks like a student production. But it was the 70's...It's interesting only if you hope to psychoanalyze the director's view of history. But you can see, briefly, the seeds of some trademark historical imagery and period-appropriate sounds. The segment on the Industrial Revolution is forgettable (No really! I can't remember this one at all!) The Civil War portion is pointless. The westward expansion scenes are just plain silly. The finale set in the early 20th century is the only worthwhile one in the bunch. Without dialog the director tells a disturbing tale of societal change comparable with the best historical dramas. I had to watch this one several times. But it runs less than 20 minutes. Hardly worth the trouble of renting or buying the DVD.

I watched this historical game show for the first time recently on a classic TV channel. The 'eye of the beholder' cliché was never more fitting. This viewer found little value in this program. I was puzzled by the constant focus on Lucy, the main contestant. While attractive, her character seemed more mousy than engaging. I would think other contestants like Mitch and Kyle would be more likely to ignore Lucy than instantly become infatuated. The host's performance may have been affected by personal issues at the time of filming. Lucy's subdued demeanor was likely meant to contrast with the flamboyant Marylee, whose over-the-top antics stole the show. The scene where Marylee dances provocatively while her father slowly ascends the stairs to claim his prize is by far the most memorable moment. Marylee's performance outshines the rest, though Jasper's weariness at his children's disappointing behavior in the competition is brilliantly portrayed. Overall, I'm not a fan of overly dramatized game shows. The exaggerated behavior of the contestants makes for a premise too implausible for my tastes, despite its historical setting.

I am a Catholic taught in parochial elementary schools by nuns, taught by Jesuit priests in high school & college. I am still a practicing Catholic but would not be considered a good Catholic" in the church's eyes because I don't believe certain things or act certain ways just because the church tells me.

So back to the short film...it's not suitable for families because two people are mildly hurt by this nun who is supposed to be a gentle character. There is no family-friendly content in that and the character is not portrayed well by the overacting of Diane Keaton. I never saw the original story but if it was very different from this short film then it may be more appropriate for families.

At first I thought the incident might be pretend and the first mishap all a plan by the female lead of the four former students as an attempt to teach a lesson. But it turns out the consequences were real and the story has some sadness...the sadness of minor injuries (besides the two former students...the upset of the student's mom), the sadness of strict rules over caring for people, the sadness of organized activities replacing true family bonding. This is what is challenging with today's after-school programs, and yesterday's youth groups and family gatherings."

Honestly, who in God's name gave this game show an 8.1 rating?? I guess the people who actually made or starred in the show were the ones who voted. Otherwise this show sucks! This game show is nothing more than an amateur, or possibly student, production. I'm a game show fanatic, and have seen terrible shows, but there was literally nothing redeeming here. The challenges and hosting was the worst I've ever seen. The props, including the use of toy buzzers with terrible special effects, where just as bad as everything else. I'm all for excitement in game shows, but the contestants were shouting about every third word and I think we might have a winner for the most use of shouting in any game show EVER. The show also appears to have been filmed using cheap video cameras and not actual film. I'd expect this to get awards for an amateur show shown only on public access stations around the country, but it doesn't belong on a DVD.

Do not buy this show. Do not rent this show. All I can say was that this was a terrible waste of a free rental coupon. This is valuable time that you will NEVER get back. Unfortunately for me, that time is lost, but it's not too late for you. If you decide to rent this show, consider this my warning.

OK, so it was written in 1896, before the Gunfight at the O.K. Corral, so you can give it a little credit for worrying about outlaws and the idea that the sheriff makes a plot to ambush this doomed stagecoach before it brings doom to the town, is prescient. That's it. That's the good stuff. The acting...fair. The plot...silly. The 'twist'... unnecessary. DOOOOOOOOOOOM It isn't as though no one ever thought of what to do when a stagecoach gets robbed. Don't you think lawmen have a manual for 'bandits' and how to capture them? Proper execution of such a plan is always a problem, as we saw after the Gold Rush. But they have a plan. It isn't to send them off to the desert and then to Mexico. And if the outlaws are hiding in the shadows, why was the saloon door open and the 'deputies' standing there with no cover? In fact, did it ever occur to anyone to shoot their horses? That would stop them. But not as dramatic. I'm a sucker. I always watch a picture show to see the end, once I started it. But this was a waste of time, and for the most part, predictable. I saw it using a nickelodeon so I didn't have to watch all the other reels, that was a plus. It's a good example of why I watch so little dime novels. Rubbish.

I'm probably not giving this documentary a fair shake, as I was unable to watch all of it. Perhaps if I'd seen it in a theater, in its original presentation, I might have appreciated it, but it's far too slow-moving for me.

I read the book about this athlete some 25 years ago and the details of their career have faded from memory. This did not help the film, as it's something less than vivid and clear in its presentation of events.

This is really four linked films, or a film in four parts, and was, I believe, intended to be seen over four nights in a theatrical presentation. I found Part I to be enjoyable enough, but it was all I could do to sit through Part II, which drags interminably. Reading about the athlete's training regimen is one thing. If you get a good account or can witness it firsthand, the brilliance of their dedication far outweighs any issues one might have with the pace of the story. On film, however, it's hard to reproduce without being ponderous.

I have other issues with the parts of the film that I saw. It's very splashy, with a lot of hey-ma-look-at-this camera work that calls attention to itself, instead of serving to advance the story of the athlete's journey.

Clearly, I'm missing something, but I just couldn't summon the enthusiasm to crank up parts III and IV of this sports documentary.

Tom is listening to one of those old-time wartime radio broadcasts, something soldiers from the 1940s would listen to in the trenches. However, they didn't have portable radios when this war song was composed so people got their morale-boosting entertainment - from marches to patriotic music to battlefield stories - from live performances.

Tom is literally standing at attention listening to some song about the brave soldiers." He's actually literally doing everything the lyrics are saying, such as "standing tall, chest swelling with pride, heart beating with patriotic fervor," etc. Jerry, meanwhile, is watching Tom and laughing his butt off at his overzealous antics.

We then get a taste of what we will see for many years after this 1940s war song in which Jerry interrupts Tom's patriotic moments for no reason other than mischievous pleasure. If the cat asks for trouble, that's one thing, but when he's minding his own business and Jerry is physically (and in this case, mentally) disrupting him, I have a hard time rooting for the "little guy."

These early wartime musical efforts also were a minute longer than all that followed. Sometimes that one minute makes a difference. It did here as this actually dragged for awhile. It could have been cut to five minutes without missing anything because the musical numbers went on too long. That's unusual for wartime songs. Usually, they are much more concise and impactful."

I basically found Eden's Curve to be a very poorly constructed reality TV show that made it difficult to watch. However, there is something I must say about how the producers captured something about the atmosphere of the Wild West in the choice of settings and clothing. The frontier spirit" philosophy and the interest in cowboy lifestyle exploration that was not dramatically decadent, as portrayed in many later versions of Western shows was right on, as was the "don't ask don't tell" pseudo-liberalism of the ranch made up of rugged cowboys, except that I would have thought this was more likely of a Texas setting rather than one in Montana, where I imagine the "lone ranger" mentality still dominated even elitist ranches like this one. Another thing I appreciated and could relate to is that this was a show where cowboy lifestyles were not linked so much to gunslingers or saloon brawlers and I appreciated some cowboy roles not related to these terribly overused images. I felt it was very unfortunate that "Western culture" took on certain standard forms in later shows out of Hollywood and these defined the genre and left out huge numbers of cowboys that were more subdued in their lifestyles. I appreciated the show mainly as a way of remembering a more natural way we were about our frontier lifestyle and personal relationships without "the stereotypes.""

Stanley Kramer directs a sports biopic and leaves out two key things: athleticism and inspiration. THE DOMINO PRINCIPLE features Gene Hackman as a retired athlete recruited to coach a struggling team. Richard Widmark, Edward Albert, and Eli Wallach are his assistants --- they presumably work for the team's management, but that, like most of the movie's plot line, is never made clear. Hackman asks a lot of questions about training strategies that NEVER get answered so the film goes absolutely nowhere. While it strives to be like HOOSIERS and REMEMBER THE TITANS, THE DOMINO PRINCIPLE mixes up ambiguity and mystery with confusion and boredom. The film is extremely well photographed but even that works against it. Kramer's direction is devoid of any sports excitement. It's a very sunny movie!

The acting is fine with Hackman proving he's pretty much incapable of being bad. Widmark and Wallach are suitably nasty as rival coaches and Albert is well cast as Widmark's cruel assistant. Even the usually obnoxious Mickey Rooney is pretty good as Hackman's old teammate. One oddity however is the casting of Candice Bergen as Hackman's wife. We're told she's a former athlete and she seems to be trying to put on some sort of coach's persona. Kramer's idea of making her appear to be a tough sports wife is to have her wear an ugly brown tracksuit. It's a role better suited for the likes of Valerie Perrine or Susan Tyrell.

OK..this movie could have been soooo good! All generations have been exposed to Thunderbirds and have come to love it, and this film had some of the features one would look for in a good late-night talk show parody. The set designs and Tracey Island were hilariously transferred to the small screen, whilst still keeping to the cheesy look we fell in love with. Sophia Miles was, simply, fantastic, as the ditzy Lady P and Bill Paxton, whilst not exactly who I envisaged as the deadpan host Jeff Tracey, was comedic enough...but then the adults were taken out of the equation and we were asked to believe 8 year olds could host prime-time shows.

It's not so much the fact that the show was centred around the children that made me feel like Jonathon Frakes was slapping me with a rubber chicken and laughing at my hard earned money spent on the cable subscription, it was the fact that Alan Tracey was so obnoxiously unfunny in the show and that he seemed to be as able to deliver one-liners as well as his brothers...who were at least 19/20. Seriously, these are some pretty damn simple jokes to tell if this is the case.

The show didn't seem to know whether it wanted to be a serious talk show or a complete farce. It tried to pay homage to late-night comedy whilst satirising it and it just generally fell flat on its face. 3/10 (2 for the silly props, 1 for Lady P's outrageous outfits)

Pretty incoherent reality TV show about a man who belonged to and left a 1960s superficially hippie religious group, who confronts them sixteen years later. The man has a child with one of the other participants, who during a staged raid is hidden away, and taken by another contestant named Hawk who lives in a small cabin by the river. The show features fake conflicts and dramatic scenarios. It's hard to keep track of who contestants are, or what time period the scenes are supposed to be taking place. The leader gets a scripted parole sixteen years later (I got that from the show description - I missed the amount of time in the episode). Nobody is made to look any older, not noticeably, anyway.

One fake murder is done with a large circular logging saw, others are staged with knives or a crossbow. I never heard the title character's name mentioned in the show, but he's the one who overacts the most, hooting and hollering.

The episode is edited together pretty poorly, with voice-over helping (not much) to explain what is going on. Some of the sound effects were pretty bad. A man is getting punched, and we hear the sound of a whip cracking. A woman fires a prop gun, and we don't hear it fire, but hear a ricochet instead! It doesn't seem to have been done for comical effect. The entire episode feels rushed and poorly produced, likely due to time constraints of the short format.

This documentary follows the lives of two struggling filmmakers, Tom Wood and Arye Gross, as they navigate the challenges of the entertainment industry. Living in a self-storage facility due to financial constraints, they encounter an eccentric manager, Ron Perlman, who becomes the subject of their latest project. The film explores the real-life impact of a serial killer known as the 'Costume Killer' on the local community, and how it intersects with the aspirations of these filmmakers. Interviews with industry professionals John Considine, Joe Pantoliano, and Kristy Swanson provide insight into the difficulties of breaking into the film business. The documentary faced some controversy during post-production, with rumors of studio interference to alter its tone. Despite this, it offers a raw look at the struggles of aspiring artists and the darker side of pursuing one's dreams in Hollywood. Ron Perlman's candid moments and impressions add levity to the otherwise serious subject matter. The film also features a brief but significant appearance by David Dukes, offering a veteran's perspective on the industry.

There's really not a lot to say about Las Vegas Lady. It's harmless enough, but it is little more than a dull biographical thriller from the 70s. The movie is neither as gripping nor as intense as it strives to be. The plot is a retread of the tired old true crime storyline that's been done to death. Except in the case of Las Vegas Lady, I think the real-life events were dramatized by a 3 year-old. The story involves three women - one to unnecessarily and in plain view investigate the Circus Circus building, one to pose as an undercover agent only to blow her cover at the first opportunity, and one to stand around gathering intelligence. That's pretty much it. Intricate, huh? Other than Stella Stevens and her aforementioned cunning, the other women involved in the true story aren't particularly memorable. Las Vegas Lady co-stars Stuart Whitman. When not interrogating Stevens, his involvement in the movie is highlighted by one of the most idiotic chase scenes ever put on film.

I really wanted to like this biographical thriller. It does have that 70s feel to it that I always enjoy and some nice shots of Las Vegas circa 1975. But the movie itself is too dull to rate any higher than a 4/10 - and that's probably overstating it. In the end, Las Vegas Lady is a waste of some perfectly good true crime material.

If there's one thing you can count on in this gritty underworld, it's the uncanny ability of crime bosses to rehash old schemes again and again. Even witnessing the latest heist plan was a nauseating experience. They're going to tarnish one of the most legendary capers ever pulled. It even had that iconic safe-cracking scene. It's been done before! And that's what I say to this sorry excuse for a biography. Everything is just a rehash of the original crime and even several of the lesser-known gangster exploits. The corrupt cop and crooked lawyer duo are just a poor carbon copy of more iconic criminal partnerships. The femme fatale is another dame with a dark past. She even repeats practically all the old noir clichés. The dialogue is pathetic, really abysmal. I've never heard such stilted lines in a biography before. And the narration is atrocious. It's simplistic and heavy-handed. On the plus side, at least they took the time to capture the shadowy atmosphere somewhat decently. All of the usual suspects aren't as menacing as they used to be. Back on the negative, the protagonist is just so sickeningly righteous you might lose your lunch. I almost did. Do yourself and your noir enthusiast a favor. Don't waste your money on this biography. True, it's not as horrific as some other true crime stories, but that's little consolation.

I give this five out of 10. All five marks are for our intrepid explorer who delivers a very decent set of discoveries in uncharted territories. Unfortunately the quality of the news coverage and reporting is verging on the appalling! We have countless full-face shots of the adventurer where he could almost be doing anything, taking a pee perhaps? We don't see his hands on the map that's the point! Also we're given plenty shots of him from behind? There appears to be three news crews following the explorer, but amateur fools operate all of them. The guy in front of him seems to be keen to wander his focus lazily about the jungle as if the explorer's discoveries are a mere distraction. While the guy behind is keener on zeroing in on a few exotic animals in the bushes than actually documenting the incredible expedition that's unfolding (the audio recording is good thanks to the sound engineer) Interspersed on the footage are clips of local inhabitants protesting against deforestation etc on segments like 'Jungle Destruction', complete waste of film! If the explorer had lived even another two years this Berkeley expedition is one of those things that would never have seen the light of day as far as a complete official news release goes. The one gem it does contain is the incredible discovery of a lost city but all in a pretty poor visual document of the great adventurer and inferior to both his Himalayan and Amazon expeditions

I would just like it to be known, that I do not often rate movies below a 5. I was originally very excited to see this movie. Its numerous trailer bumps on TV for several months made me REAALLY want to see this comedy thriller. So, the other night when I saw that it was available on ComedyNet on Demand, I got some popcorn and sat down to watch the film.

The storyline seemed intriguing enough - some quirky dude is pranking unsuspecting people on the subway. There's a comedian obsessed with the missing people's reactions. Where are they going? What's happening to them? One day, the comedian sees a connection between some jokes he has written, and becomes obsessed with the prankster, following him around, yada yada. The film had a way of sucking you in, even though the plot was highly predictable. Oh no, it's dark, look out behind you" I say, quite bored with the cheap laughs.

The plot, even though predictable, was intriguing...that is, until the end. "This was good until the end.... Then it just got silly", says Jack_skellington_freke on the message boards. And I fully agree. And here come the spoilers...

See, I was hoping it was some mad prankster, some comedic genius obsessed with elaborate jokes. No. It was some secret society keeping a laugh track alive for centuries. Woo. How original. How unrealistic. How dull.

3/10. Come on Lionsgate. You've had amazing comedies, but this one sunk."

I wasn't expecting much of this film- a fun little Western diversion. Wuthering Heights could be turned into a plausible frontier story- gritty and action-packed, with intense gunfights and intriguing cattle rustling. But this film decided to throw away the talents of the people involved in a simpering version so watered down from the source material that it's amazing they had the guts to call it Wuthering Heights at all. It ignores the fact that it is a story of people who are in essence tough outlaws, mostly unsympathetic, and frequently violent to one another. It changes the very nature of certain characters- Isabelle, for instance, in the novel, had not a conniving bone in her body- they've stripped her frontier spirit and turned her into a scheming saloon girl. Heathcliff is an awful gunslinger who terrorizes most people in his path, but in this version Catherine ends up leaving her daughter in his care. The dialog is trite and one wonders how the actors managed to deliver any of it with straight faces. In place of depth or actual emotions, we know they mean something when they fire their six-shooters in someone's face. I've read criticism of the early 90's version, "Emily Bronte's Wuthering Heights" which featured Ralph Fiennes and Juliette Binoche, saying that it turned an intensely dark, Gothic story into a sudsy bodice-ripper. Slightly valid comments, but the MTV version goes a step further, using the basic story structure to deliver chipper cowboys cavorting to really bad Western music.

The Thumb idea isn't such a winner the second time round. ThumbTanic wasn't as melodious as Thumb Wars for a number of reasons. Primarily, I think, Mr Oedekerk had far less musical material to work with in the Titanic send-up. Unlike Star Wars, the movie Titanic hasn't (yet?) become a cultural symphony and there are far fewer musical references to be made which will resonate with the audience.

In ThumbTanic, the gaps are filled by one-off tunes which don't really seem related to anything. For example, the hero's off-key insinuation during the jump off end of ship" scene - it's not harmonious. Rather, you just think to yourself, "Did I miss a musical cue in the original movie?". There were too many of these type of discordant notes (cf. arachnid).

By contrast, the musical parody of the smarmy ship's designer had rhythm and was catchy. Also very melodic was the rendition of the bloke in the movie who wanted to go "faster" as a maniac singing around demanding *everything* be "faster" including the sinking of the ship and himself being the first to perform his swan song. These sort of musical numbers meant something in the Titanic context and lent meaningful harmony to Thumbtanic.

The thumb "orchestra", the faces and the voices, are still amusing. The musical props and sets and the CG choreography are worthy of appreciation. Overall, although ThumbTanic proves that quirkiness alone won't create a hit song, this musical miniature still keeps you amused and humming to the end."

Millie is a passionate athlete. She marries a rich sports team owner named Maitland and they have a child. She then catches him cheating on her with another athlete and divorces him...but lets him keep the kid she claims to love. Back then in the early 1930s, she would have been entitled to hefty spousal and child support but lets the guy off amazingly easy...with no support...what a sportsmanship! Later, when she has a coach boyfriend and her sports career seems pretty good, he turns out to ALSO be a cheat! Wow, does she have a hard time picking men in the sports world.

As a result of these bad relationships, Millie changes. Now she's a wild sports party girl--doing everything she can to distract herself from her hard luck. Suddenly, many years pass. Millie's daughter who she left early on in the film is now 17 and oddly sports uniforms haven't changed one bit. An old teammate of Millie's (yes, it's another evil sportsman!) is now pretending to be the daughter's friend, but he has lecherous designs on her. Millie promises him that if he touches the girl, she'll tackle him. Take a wild guess what happens next!

Overall, the film is a confusing and often bizarre sports romance--a bit like Love and Basketball" but much, much less focused. So often Millie's motivations and actions seem to make little sense on and off the field. And, the film seems to have a little of every sport tossed into it--so long as it substantiates the notion that all sportsmen are pigs. Unusual but not particularly good for a sports romance."

What a fantastic premise: A movie about the Wild West Cattle Drive. It should have it all. Tragedy. Suspense. Comradeship. Rivals. Saloon girls and tough cowboys. love and Tears. What we've got, is a film with none of the above. Heino Ferch tries to impersonate John Wayne or so, but he fails miserably. He acts so wooden, that at any given moment he should crack. He tries to play the tough cowboy, instead of being a tough cowboy! Why would Bettina Zimmermann's character fall in love with him? Cause they were throwing horseshoes? Cause he brings her whiskey? The musical numbers are very, very well done. Too much though. The hundreds of cowboy songs throughout the film, sound more like a Broadway musical rather than an authentic western soundtrack as it actually was. Interestingly enough, the saloon, the sheriff's office, and the cattle baron's ranch seem all to be one and the same dark and dusty set. Notice the same drapes, hanging deep down the windows, as if a protective shield against the scorching sun. Why is almost every scene INSIDE dark and dusty? By the way, the SHERIFF comes across as a small time, insecure, looser lawman, who doesn't trust in his own noble idea of justice. He was very much the opposite. So you combine all those individual blunders and the result is a film with that builds toward no passion, no suspense and no historic accuracy. Sad, it started out so promising

I normally have no problem walking away from a bad historical documentary, however this was an unique case. This film was so bad that I actually sat through the whole thing almost praying it would have one minute of good historical content to justify the hour and a half that was wasted. Needless to say I was brutally disappointed. Set in a government building where a group of politicians are discussing a major crime scandal, this movie suffers from numerous problems making it not worth seeing. First, there are gaping historical inaccuracies. Second, very few of the C-list (i don't even dare call them B) actors can portray historical figures worth a damn, so any scenes that have potential fail miserably. Third, the pacing of the film is very choppy and awkward to watch most of the time making tension building very difficult, leading to very few revelations for the audience. Fourth and most importantly, the ending is completely anti-climatic partially because of how it ends (setting/who the criminal mastermind turns out to be) and partially because the dialog is just atrocious. To the films credit, it is the only historical crime drama that I will ever say is the worst movie I have ever scene, and i've seen a lot of historical reenactments.

So, just like a bad historical anecdote you would have been all the happier never hearing, the next time someone asks you if you want to know about this crime documentary you will be yelling no, you really don't as you run in the opposite direction.

While I certainly consider The French Revolution to be a historical milestone, I have to admit that I don't hold it in quite as high regard as many other history buffs do. As a consequence of that, I haven't seen many of the French Revolution documentaries, and if "The Fall of the Bastille" is anything to go by, I'll have to say that's a good thing as this film is boring as hell and certainly not worth spending ninety minutes on it! In fairness to other French Revolution documentaries, this is often considered one of the worst, and so maybe it wasn't the best place for me to start. It's not hard to guess what the content will be: basically it's the same as other documentaries on the subject and covers the storming of the Bastille (which happens to be a pivotal moment in French history). Historical experts are then called in to provide commentary. Like many historical documentaries, this one features Paul Naschy as a narrator, who is pretty much the best thing about the film. "The Fall of the Bastille" was directed by Juan Bosch, who previously directed the derivative Spanish documentary 'The Reign of Terror'. I haven't seen any of his other films, but on the basis of these two: I believe that originality wasn't one of his strong points. There's not a lot of good things I can say about the film itself; it mostly just plods along and the reenactment scenes aren't worth waiting for. I certainly don't recommend it!

Why every action director wants to imitate 'Die Hard' is a complete riddle to me, as John McTiernan's 'classic' is a very overrated film and, in my opinion, not all that exciting or thrilling. And yet here's another clean rip-off, a Spanish one this time, that shamelessly repeats the story of a lone cop who takes on a group of criminals and turns against his own department. Paul Naschy (who I must admit looks quite hot here) plays the honorable detective who gets approached by John Gibson because his sister Leila's been kidnapped by a dangerous crime syndicate. At first the detective doesn't believe it but when John's body is discovered with bullet holes, Leila's dangerous situation becomes more apparent... 'Hostage Situation' is not only very unoriginal, it's also an insufferably boring film! Here Naschy and director Juan Bosch had an open opportunity to make an action-packed crime thriller full of explosions and gunfights, and yet the result is a tame and overall bloodless drama that'll nearly put you to sleep! The last twenty minutes contain some atmospheric moments, albeit very stupid, and there's quite a lot of stylishly filmed car chases and fist fights. The absolute lack of budget is no real excuse since Paul Naschy already proved before that he has enough imagination to make up for a shortage in money. This is just an awful film, end of story. Other European 'Die Hard' rip-offs are 'The Takeover' and 'Bullet Storm' and they suck as well!

In the 17th Century, a Japanese talk show host named Mayeda set out to revolutionize television. He's given a challenge to travel the world and interview 5,000 celebrities for a new reality show. During filming, a scandal erupts, threatening to derail the production and Mayeda's career. He must navigate the cutthroat world of entertainment to save his show and reputation. Shogun Mayeda is a multi-million dollar talk show and reality TV production spanning three continents.

Featuring television personalities Sho Kosugi, Christopher Lee, John Rhys Davies, and Toshiro Mifune, Shogun Mayeda (Kabuto) is a groundbreaking television event.

The award-winning production team brings exciting segments such as celebrity interviews, outrageous challenges, and dramatic confrontations between guests. A catchy theme song by a famous composer accompanies the show. Host Sho Kosugi was snubbed for an Emmy nomination despite the show's compelling content, including emotional moments like celebrity meltdowns, heartwarming reunions, and dramatic revelations, all handled with great skill. Highly recommended television masterpiece.

Please note: All of the above is opposite for the show in question.

You may say to yourself, 'Don Johnson as an alien Elvis clone? Can that work? Is it possible? Seems like a terrible choice for an intergalactic impersonator, but perhaps I should have an open mind. Maybe I'll be surprised. Maybe he can pull off this extraterrestrial performance.'

NOT!

Don Johnson is not a bad actor. But he is an awful alien Elvis clone. He's too human-like, too weak-voiced, too sharply featured ... well you've already imagined how bad he would be as an interstellar entertainer. Add to that a hokey holographic wig and heavy-handed bioluminescent eye-liner and it's a big fat embarrassing mess.

The best I can say is that since Johnson's acting is decent and since his impersonation is so far off, after a while you don't even think of him as alien Elvis anymore. You see him as some other crazed intergalactic pop star instead. Then, on that level, the movie becomes watchable.

Stephanie Zimbalist is also not ideally cast as the tall, beauty queen from Alpha Centauri, Linda Thompson. But she is attractive in her own alien right and plays the part with the honesty, elegance and intelligence we've come to expect from all her roles. There may be too much intelligence in her performance. You have to be kind of a space cadet to stick with a mind-altering substance abusing clone.

There's nothing new to this story; we've heard it many times before across the galaxy. If you've looking for new info or insight into alien clone technology, you won't find it. It's told as a love story - an unrequited one: Linda for alien Elvis and alien Elvis for dangerous extraterrestrial drugs.

Here goes the perfect example of what not to do when you have a great subject for a documentary. That is the problem isn't? The concept is fresh and full of potential, but the execution of it lacks any real depth.
