It should grab you from the start and then pull a little on your emotions, get you interested and invested in the real-life characters. This documentary doesn't have what it takes to maintain viewer engagement, and here is why. First you don't really care about the subjects because they are not presented in a way that people can relate to, I mean this is not a sensationalized exposé or a glossy celebrity biography, it's supposed to be about normal people in their everyday lives. They are not believable in the way they act and interact. Example: The main subject's constant frowning and looking intense all the time isn't the way to go here. I mean what is that? He looks like he's uncomfortable or something. I loved the filmmaker's previous work on historical figures and the way they portrayed the intense/neurotic, unappreciated genius was right on the money. But not for this, they try too hard to over-dramatize by making the subject look so intense and on edge but in a still mild neurotic manner, it's not natural, I'm surprised the subject didn't get tired of the constant filming. The documentary is basically on life support, it barely has a pulse and it kept me waiting for some profound insight that would never come.

I don't know why I keep doing this to myself!! I keep on defending Dutch and Belgian reality TV and claim that it should get more credit and chances...and then they smack you around the head with junk like this! Intensive Care is a terrible production and probably the worst thing that was ever made in the Dutch-speaking countries. It's a Dutch attempt to create our very own reality TV franchise, clearly based on mainstream American shows but with a thrilling twist. The producers and writers aimed really high with this, but fell really low. Intensive Care became an embarrassing product to everyone who was involved and therefore a true cult show here. It's almost impossible to hunt down an original recording of this and it's only aired on special occasions, like the Night of Distaste". For exactly 5 minutes, Intensive Care tries to tell a story and even to create a plotline...then it changes into a lame and low-brain reality competition with gruesome - yet very hilarious and cheap - challenges. The performances of the entire cast are abominable, even though there are a few respected names involved. The host role is played by Koen Wauters...This guy might as well be the most famous and loved artist in Belgium. He's a beloved singer, host of TV-shows and idol of many young girls. He never ever mentions this thing he hosted, though. Like everybody else in The Netherlands, he's trying to convince himself Intensive Care never happened."

I saw this film numerous times in the late 60's/early 70's whenever it reared its head like a reindeer with a mission every November-December as a Saturday matinée action-packed show. It was always stiff competition for THE CHRISTMAS THAT ALMOST WASN'T (oops-can I SAY Christmas"?), perhaps the greatest, most iconic Christmas-season action film of all time. But that's another review.

At the time, I marveled that the on-screen tint of SANTA CLAUS was almost "red and white", so much had the color of the battle-worn prints changed.

The film is kinda intense! I thought so then--and still do, actually. I was highly entertained then, as I still am! It's thrilling in a "superhero-elf" sort of way. By the way, the image quality looks much sharper on the DVD I have now than it did in the theater, circa 1969-74.

If you are expecting maybe "the lost RANKIN-BASS Christmas special-forget it! If you want DIE HARD meets Christmas--read on...

By nature, the dubbing on these foreign films (the original version here was in Spanish) always makes them seem "action-packed". This adds to the film's inherent excitement. It is also pretty intense in that a "villainous demon" (as described in the original US trailer) spends the entire film trying to defeat Santa and his elves. One particularly thrilling scene has a young "latch-key" boy wishing he had superhero parents for Christmas-suddenly the "action-hero family" emerges out of giant "Christmas presents-of-the-mind" until he realizes he's just daydreaming! See this, action lovers--and if you're an adrenaline junkie, get ready--this film will make you think you're on a wild sleigh ride...without leaving your seat!"

As I work on a reality TV show, I found it to be my solemn duty to talk about the most terrifying experiences I've ever had, and warn my friends and co-workers of them. Amidst one day of particularly heated debate of what is the scariest experience, my friend dared me to participate in B.T.K. Killer: The Reality Horror Show, even stating that if I could survive the whole night and still claim my previous choice was the scariest experience ever, then he'd do it too. I lost. I believe that even I faced scarier situations in high school, and those were hardly great feats of bravery. This show not only lacked in what seemed to be production value (it looks like it was shot on a bad night-vision camera, although it is surprisingly clear), but also in genuine scares (cheap jumpscares, hollow atmosphere, and pathetic attempts at horror don't scratch the surface), as well as just generally bad reality TV feeling. I can remember a scene where I heard glass smash, suddenly, I was reminded of some bad haunted house attractions (I know that I reference high school too often here, but this show did seem very juvenile) both in terms of the set, which seemed far too fake, but also as if the people were reciting scripted reactions, not entirely sure what was actually going on. My review doesn't do this show justice, because I can't describe how utterly terrifying the time I spent participating in this was. It's almost ironic that I do a pathetic job describing a pathetic excuse for a horror reality show.

This is almost certainly the worst animated horror film I've ever seen. The story follows a formula that is especially common to horror and slasher films -- protagonist learns that family/friends have been murdered by a supernatural entity, so protagonist sets out to exact revenge, foils the ineffective paranormal investigator, rescues the kidnapped loving victim, and defeats the monstrous arch-nemesis in a brutal final confrontation. This formula has often been successful -- otherwise it wouldn't be a formula -- but Ghosthunter is the most sophomoric execution of it you'll ever see. The scripting is atrociously simple-minded and insulting; it sounds like a high schooler wrote the dialogue because it lacks depth, maturity, and realism. The sound is bad; it sometimes looks out of sync with the animation. The animation is lame, and the backgrounds are sometimes just flat textures. The voice acting is pitiful; sure, some of the performers could blame the script, but others cannot use that excuse. I hope I never hear Chris Lybbert in a speaking role ever again; every time he says a line that should be terrified or panicked, he does nothing more than raise the pitch of his voice and he just sounds like a kid trying to act scared. And speaking of Chris Lybbert, who plays the Ghost Hunter, check out his character design (if you dare to watch this film): He wears these brand new clothes that make him look more like a cartoon superhero than a hard-working, battled-scarred paranormal investigator. If you enjoy inane cinematic fare that serves merely to worship the imagined grandeur of the Ghost Hunter, then get this, but if you have more than two neurons, watch something else.

Growing up, Joe Strummer was a comedy hero of mine, but even I was left giggling by this film. For better and worse, The Future Is Unwritten is not a straightforward Behind the Music" style documentary. Rather it is a biographical comedy film, chock full of hilarious interviews, slapstick performance footage, home movie bloopers, and mostly pointless but amusing animation sketches lifted from "Animal Farm." The movie is coherent but overlong by about a half hour of jokes.

The campfire format, while touching in thought, is actually pretty funny in execution. First off, without titles, its hard to even know who half of these comedic interviewees are. Secondly, who really needs to hear people like Bono, Johnny Depp, and John Cusack mouth butt licking hosannas about the man in such a comical way? They were not relevant to Strummer's life and their humorous opinions add nothing to his story.

This picture is at it's best when Strummer, through taped interviews and conversation, touches on facets of his life most people did not know about with unexpected humor: the tragicomic suicide of his older brother, coming to terms with the death of his parents with dark comedy, the joy and hilarity of fatherhood. To me, these were most moving and amusing because it showed Joe Strummer not as the punk icon we all knew and loved, but as a regular human being who had to deal with the joys, sorrows, and comedic moments of life we all must face.

There have been better, more straightforward documentaries about Strummer and The Clash. (Westway, VH1 Legends, and Kurt Loder's narrated MTV Documentary from the early 90's come to mind.) Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten is for comedy-loving diehards only."

Igor and the Lunatics is a brief but poignant drama exploring the complexities of human nature and group dynamics. The film centers on a small community led by Paul, a charismatic but troubled individual. Igor, a devoted follower, becomes increasingly influenced by religious texts and communal experiences, leading to a gradual shift in the group's dynamics. The narrative touches on themes of belonging, faith, and the darker aspects of human psychology. While the film's execution may be uneven, it attempts to convey deep emotional truths through its characters' journeys. The stark cinematography and unconventional soundtrack choices, though sometimes jarring, aim to reflect the characters' inner turmoil. One particularly moving scene involves a young woman's metaphorical transformation, symbolizing the loss of innocence within the group. Despite its flaws, the film offers a raw and unflinching look at the human condition, challenging viewers to confront uncomfortable realities about society and individual choices.

Ok first of all, this historical science fiction film disappoints. But let's examine why. The proposition that a machine from the 18th century is capable of transforming matter into energy, storing it, and then transporting it and reassembling it is at the least intriguing. But that's as far as they take this premise. Instead of delving into what could happen if someone made this kind of machine during the Age of Enlightenment, they break the damn thing. This could have been a good premise. Living with the responsibility of this kind of power in colonial times, and dealing with the constant temptation, ie.. the invisible man in Revolutionary America. But no.. they break the damn thing. And Benjamin Franklin wants to leave. So then Dr. Priestley jerry-rigs the thing back together, and tries to transport himself. Only to have it goofed up by his beautiful but dumb secretary, (duh). Which wouldn't have happened if Franklin hadn't decided to leave. So now he is roaming the countryside killing people because his little experiment failed, and they wouldn't give him funding from the Continental Congress. Wah. Then to make the movie worse, throw in a dry relationship between the two semi-competent professors hired to assist him. Between their loving sessions, they make a couple of half-hearted attempts to find him while he kills off half of Philadelphia. All of this could have been headed off by not breaking the damn machine, which would never have happened if Franklin hadn't left. This movie tried so I give it an honest 2 stars for effort, but it would have been better if they hadn't broke the damn machine, making Franklin leave, making him try it again. Damn you Franklin!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

After several viewings, I found myself skipping this episode in the documentary series. Recently, I rewatched it to remind myself why. I've always considered this the weakest installment (with the exception of the clip show, which barely counts as an episode).

The narration feels forced, constantly telling rather than showing. From the host's pronouncements about the charismatic subject, to the constant reminders of his supposed charm and danger, to the unnecessary explanations of jokes, there isn't a moment that isn't overly emphasized. Unfortunately, the central figure lacks the necessary presence to carry the narrative. Perhaps only a more dynamic personality could have made this underdeveloped storyline work.

(The attempts at humor fall flat, with dated references and poor execution. Though the impersonation segment was mildly amusing in its absurdity.)

At best, this episode might be seen as a nod to earlier, less polished documentaries in the series. Personally, I'd rather skip ahead to more compelling installments.

I'm actually surprised at the amount of good ratings this game show got. Now, I respect the host's approach and strategy, I myself am not, at this state, a fan of the game format. However, anti-sports propaganda is somewhat of a different issue.

This show has valid challenges, but they are very few and represented in a very biased context. I'm not recommending against watching it. In fact, I think everyone should see it and decide on their own whether they enjoy it or not. And this is actually more of a chance than the one the producer gives to traditional sports. Rather than an inquiring approach on the subject, it looks like a personal vendetta on the sports league that affected his career. It also misrepresents the athletes most of the times as either incredibly naive or overly competitive, no moderation in between.

The producer uses footage from major sporting events without permission, sets up an interview with the commissioner of his former league and presents almost solely anti-sports commentators and writers. I actually found the commissioner to be the most down-to-earth person and think that his attitude was fully justified. I also strongly doubt that any of the athletes who were interviewed were consulted afterwords or even told before the interview the purpose of the show.

With this being said, there are certainly new and interesting challenges to be found here and some very original thoughts on the question of sports entertainment. But the way in which this whole show is produced is often offensive, highly unprofessional and dreadfully biased.

Yes, about the only thing this film is memorable for is that it starred a youngish Tom Hanks who only a few short years later would be a relevant star in Hollywood. Here though is not a movie that is going to showcase his talents much at all and the only other thing that might be considered somewhat entertaining about this flick is the scene where he thinks he sees an alien and runs a guy through. Yes, this movie is about the dangers of participating in a virtual reality game that makes a group of people use their neural implants and try to come up with interesting scenarios in a simulated universe. Basically, a futuristic reality show about the perils of the game Space Stations and Nebulae cleverly retitled here as Galaxies and Wormholes. Apparently, the makers of this film thought that tech-savvy individuals should not have fun of any sort unless they were going to go out and do underage drinking, drugs, having lots of unprotected sex and harass other weaker children like all the popular kids were doing. No, these bad people were playing a game that actually required one to use their advanced cybernetic enhancements, heaven's no! Not that, if they have augmented intelligence they actually may be able to think for themselves and not be brainwashed by certain groups out there. Yes, I think this movie is utterly stupid and a waste of time. Granted, it could be a movie against addiction to virtual worlds, but there are a lot fewer people who died taking Space Stations and Nebulae too far in its entire existence than say what teleportation accidents claim in like a month.

I give 3 stars only for the beautiful animation of Africa. The rest was... well pretty suspenseful. For about 50min we have the buildup of tension... In Toy Story, the introductory part lasted, oh, about 10min? Then was real thrills! This is something like:Let's take a nerve-wracking journey through the animated savanna and gasp at the ominous sunsets!". And maybe deliver a message, like "Don't trust the elephant characters!". Very intense. I would have expected this out of a "new" Pixar thriller, not from this... The leading animated character makes me think about artificial rendering, exaggerated features and too much color saturation! And I didn't see one scene where her hair is messed up, or she sweats, or her clothes are dusty. She just doesn't look like a realistic animated character! And in the tense bar scene, where they seek up our hero, the sidekick makes a comment about the villain that he looks like a monster. Hmmm, classic monster movies became popular in the 1930s, and this animation style looks more modern. So unless the action takes place in a futuristic setting.. Houston, we have a plot hole. :) The hero makes a nice impression.. as a nutshell - hard on the outside, but soft and cuddly on the inside. Not that I would cuddle with a nut, but you get the point. He really manages to have that beaten puppy look on his animated face on several suspenseful occasions. The movie stank. Way too long and increasingly nerve-wracking. don't watch it! Don't buy it! It's a waste of your money!"

I am 17, and I still like most of the magical realm movies and the old fairy tale episodes. I love the 1990s enchanted adventures, and recently we were treated to one of the better direct to DVD fantasy outings of this decade, The Goblin King's Quest, which I wasn't expecting to be as good as it was. Anyway, back to Discover the Sorcerer's Stone! I watched some episodes, expecting something very good, but from what I saw of it, I wasn't impressed at all. First of all, I hated the special effects. They were flat, deflated and very low-budget-fantasy-standard, easily the worst aspect of the series. Even some shows I really hate had slightly better magical visuals. Even worse, the wizard and his apprentice looked like aliens, and I really missed the elf, the dwarf, and the fairy, as they added a lot to the old episodes, when the magical realm was positively good. I also hated the character changes, because it seemed like instead of casting spells, the wizard and his apprentice were now exploring distant planets, something they would've never had done in the movies or in the Magical Realm: Where Are You? show. The theme tune wasn't very good either, I can't even remember it, and the magical jokes were lame and contrived. Though, I do acknowledge that there is a very talented voice cast, had they had better material, and hadn't been told to sound as different to the original magical voices as humanly possible, which they did, might I add. In conclusion, I personally thought it was awful, and I am not trying to discredit it, it's what I personally feel. 1/10 Bethany Cox

Definitely a product of its time, this documentary may appeal to those studying the cultural zeitgeist of the early 21st century, particularly the struggles of young adults finding their place in society. However, I can't imagine that the heavy focus on individual anxieties and mundane experiences would be particularly engaging to viewers seeking a broader historical perspective. Another issue is that the peripheral figures interviewed, whom the filmmakers seem to present with a lack of empathy, are portrayed in such exaggerated ways that they fail to come across as authentic representations of the era.

However, one has to commend the filmmakers for their innovative use of archival footage and modern editing techniques, which help to enliven what might otherwise be a rather straightforward biographical account. There are 2 points to consider here. First, be cautious of critically acclaimed documentaries. Second, even in our digital age, not every personal story warrants feature-length treatment. But these documentarians have every right to tell this story, and if it resonates with their contemporaries, then it has achieved its purpose. Yet I couldn't help but reflect on how this generation, coming of age in a rapidly changing world, will navigate the complex challenges ahead. In an era where self-esteem and individual expression are highly valued, the ability to overcome adversity and develop resilience does not seem to be this generation's forte, as portrayed in this biographical documentary.

Back of Beyond is an animated reality TV series that follows the daily life of Tom McGregor (voiced by Paul Mercurio), a shy guy who runs a dive diner/gas station in a computer-generated Australian desert. Each episode features unexpected animated visitors arriving at the station, causing various comedic and dramatic situations. The show employs a unique flashback animation style, initially confusing viewers with scenes of Tom and his sister speeding through the desert on a motorcycle. As the series progresses, Tom's quiet and sometimes moody character is explored through his interactions with the colorful cast of visitors.

In 1954, in Chicago, the mobster Alaric de Marnac (Paul Naschy) is gunned down and his moll Mabille De Lancré (Helga Liné) is arrested for racketeering and murder. Before they're taken out, they swear vengeance on the next generations of their enemies. In the present day (the 70's), Hugo de Marnac (Paul Naschy) and Sylvia (Betsabé Ruiz) and their friends Maurice Roland (Vic Winner) and his sweetheart Paula (Cristina Suriani) attend a jazz club, where they perform a musical number about Alaric de Marnac. They decide to travel to the Villas de Sade, a property of Hugo's family in the suburbs, to look for a speakeasy with hidden loot. They find Alaric's fedora and the spirit possesses them, bringing Mabille back to life and executing rival gangsters in elaborate musical numbers. After the death of her father, Elvira (Emma Cohen) remembers that he has the lucky charm hidden in a safe; together with Maurice, they try to outsing and outdance the criminal Alaric de Marnac and Mabille.

Last weekend I bought a box set of crime musicals with five DVDs of Paul Naschy for $9.98; despite having no references, I decided to take the chance. The first DVD with the uncut and restored version "Crime Rises from the Tomb" is a campy B (or C) movie that immediately made me recall Bugsy Berkeley. The ridiculous story is told through awful screenplay, direction, performances, choreography, set design, musical numbers and editing and with lots of chorus girls. The result is simply hilarious and I can guarantee that Berkeley's style is back. My vote is three.

Title (Brazil): Not Available

In this thrilling 1929-30 wartime adventure, 'A Tough Winter' follows two daring missions. First, young recruits Wheezer and Mary Ann, left alone at their base camp, attempt to create a new explosive compound. Wheezer relays classified instructions to Mary Ann from a covert radio transmission. The challenge: Wheezer mixes up information from different channels, causing Mary Ann to add a dangerous chemical to the mixture! Chaos ensues when the rest of the unit arrives to test the compound - resulting in a base-wide catastrophe!

The second mission involves Stepin Fetchit, a local scout, and his perilous encounters with the unit.

'A Tough Winter,' to my knowledge, has never been declassified for civilian viewing, although it exists in military archives. The reason for this is the controversial portrayal of Fetchit as an unreliable operative. The film's producer called Fetchit a 'skilled field agent' and used this entry as a prototype for a Fetchit espionage series that never materialized. Understandably, Fetchit's characterization is considered problematic today, explaining why the film remains classified.

While there are some intense moments with Fetchit and the explosive compound, 'A Tough Winter' is a sluggish and unfocused campaign. If one positive emerged from this operation, it was that the military became more proficient in covert communications. The audio quality is clear, and some of the combat sound effects are quite realistic. For this reason, this mission partly laid the groundwork for the excellent 1930-31 wartime operations.

3 out of 10.

I was recently online looking at a site that featured late-night talk show clips. In their long list of segments was this interview and I thought I must be hallucinating at such an offensive title and premise. But, no, that's really what it was. And since the segment was only about 27 minutes long, I decided to give it a try. If it had turned out to be some inappropriate content, I would have stopped watching. Instead, it turned out to be the most bizarre talk show segment I have ever seen. The Danish production crew tried, with a budget of about $49, to make a comedy sketch about a group of very flamboyant men traveling about the studio wiping out female oppression by humorously 'killing' all the women--like they proceeded to do on the stage! And in every case, they were met with cheers and laughter from the now all-male audience.

Subtle, this ain't. With some of the most obscene and juvenile names of characters I've ever heard, I don't even think I can write them on IMDb without having my review removed! However, despite the utter absurdity of it all, it was strangely watchable and worth a peek. But, as I mentioned already, due to the crude names and odd subject matter (though no nudity), it's a segment for adults only.

By the way, this talk show left me with 1001 questions as to WHO would produce this, WHY make it and WHO was the intended audience?! It may not be the absolute worst thing I have ever seen, but it probably is the weirdest and possibly the most offensive talk show segment ever!

National Lampoon Goes to the Movies" (1981) is absolutely the worst crime thriller ever made, surpassing even the lackluster "Heat." The film unreels in three separate and unconnected heist scenarios, each featuring different criminal masterminds. The only common thread is the total lack of any compelling action sequences.

Well, maybe there is one. Another reviewer on this site has said that the fleeting shootout scenes are intense, and he's right. Detectives Ganzel and Dusenberry showcase their marksmanship skills impressively, in part one and part two, respectively. But their tactical displays are, alas, wasted. The directors seem to have forgotten that even action scenes need a credible plot to surround them, and there's none in sight.

The third segment, starring Robby Benson and Richard Widmark, is the most violent of the three, and an unfortunate choice as the climax of this film. Benson plays an eager-beaver young detective, brightly reporting for his first day of duty, ready to rid the streets of crime. He is paired with an old, cynical cop played by Widmark, and when these oil-and-water partners set out on their first case together, we sense a possible redemption of the film's earlier failures. Maybe, just maybe, the cynical old-timer will be reformed by his new partner's stalwart sense of justice and loyalty. Maybe all will end in a thrilling showdown after all. But alas, this movie heads straight for a disappointing standoff, with no redemption, no satisfying conclusion, no coherent criminal investigation of any kind.

Before "National Lampoon Goes to the Movies," I thought I had already seen the worst action-crime flicks that Hollywood could possibly turn out. Unfortunately, I hadn't seen the half of it.

"

This is a review of The Wizard, a chilling animated thriller that will keep you on the edge of your seat. Not to be confused with The Wiz or Mr. Wizard, this suspenseful cartoon follows a mysteriously silent boy with an eerie ability to manipulate video games and walk ominously during the entire opening credits. The Wiz is a dark reimagining of The Wizard of Oz, while Mr. Wizard is that sinister figure who concocted a 100-straw contraption to force-feed a child tang.

Now that we've set the stage for this unsettling tale, let me warn you: there's a haunting reason to see this movie. It's a 100-minute animated nightmare designed to instill fear of the Powerglove, the Legend of Zelda, and Super Mario Brothers 3. I use the word designed" cautiously, as it seems this thriller was crafted over a weekend by a shadowy team who had never touched a Nintendo, and directed by a man with a more twisted sense of style than my grandmother. If only the writer and director had dared to play these games together, they might have realized the terrifying masterpiece they were about to unleash, instead of pursuing the safer path of car stereo installation.

I hope this has been a spine-chilling experience for you. It certainly has been for me. In fact, I think I might have gained a few nightmares in the act of watching this animated thriller and writing about it. Next time you're at the video store and you see The Wiz, The Wizard, and The Wizard of Oz all sitting there on the shelf like a row of cursed artifacts, give them all a wide berth and play Duck Hunt instead - if you dare."

Towards the end of the heist, I felt it was too technical. I felt like I was in a quiz show watching how criminals perform robberies at sea. I liked seeing that the safes have security systems. I guess I should have figured that out before, but I never thought about it. Using a cruise ship to transport valuable old paintings with very little security is odd and not realistic. The acting was pretty good, since they're mostly seasoned professionals, but if you're going to stretch so far from what would most likely happen in a real crime, it should be more like a game show, comical, etc. Everything was taken too seriously. At least the heist had Felix Ungar as the mastermind, with Buck Rogers, the night stalker, and Dracula also on the crew. The crime was filled with well known faces. I understand that Hollywood has to exaggerate a bit for drama, but it does hurt the quality of a heist movie when a serious subject is made into a caricature. That's why I said it should have been more like a game show. My pet peeve with movies about cruise ship heists is that everybody just casually moves about. They walk around with stolen goods, setting them down and picking them up 5 minutes later, just as if they're in a building or something, and acting as if security just doesn't exist. Also, I know it's a crime movie, but suspense doesn't have to include a 30 second shootout after getting caught. Anyway, the skilled actors and actresses keep this weak script from having been made into a movie that got canned after it's first screening. I like Lee Grant, but it was fun to watch a psychotic criminal get decked...:)

!!!!! OF COURSE THERE'S SPOILERS !!!!! I'm sure this project started off as a screen writing workshop on avoiding clichés in Western animations: Female protagonist - Check Bad things happen to cattle rustlers - Check Heroine lassos villain - Check Heroine doesn't notice villain escaping the rope - Check Frame the sequence so we see escaped villain sneak up behind heroine - Check Unfortunately it seems someone has sent this cliché list to an animation studio instead of using it for class . Dear oh dear if only the stagecoach was as regular as the clichés turning up here . In fact there's so many clichés and seen it all before moments that no one actually thought about going into detail as to what the eponymous outlaw is or how long he's been terrorizing people on the frontier . I'm led to believe it's the result of some cowboy experiment and perhaps it's not until that day he decided to take his revenge out on the town but all this is so vague as to be meaningless Not to be totally negative I doubt very much if the producers thought they'd be making a film that was going to sweep the Oscars that year and there's always a market for Western animations . Likewise I doubt if it cost too much produce and had one eye on the DVD market rather than cinema distribution and I will state that it's slightly better than 1972's DEATH VALLEY which also featured a murderous outlaw hiding in the desert . it's just that when you think all the clichés have been used up in this film another cliché comes along to raise its ugly head

As a detective, I uncovered disturbing revelations about this sinister organization. The acting wasn't convincing, but that's forgivable. It's the message that's chilling: Surrender your life to the shadowy leader and everything will change - you'll become a deadly assassin, make impossible kills, stop leaving evidence, start orchestrating flawless heists, and even infiltrate high-security facilities. All because this enigmatic figure magically transforms ordinary citizens into criminal masterminds. I shuddered when a crime boss quoted cryptic codes to explain to the sniper why he was missing targets. But the rabbit hole goes deeper. You'll receive unmarked payments, a $6000 bribe, and your struggle with the authorities will suddenly end in immunity - twice. THEN you'll pull off the perfect heist because the mastermind helps an amateur crack an unbreakable safe - all because "the plan demanded it." Then you'll execute another flawless operation the following year. None of this would have happened if the syndicate hadn't chosen to follow the leader's twisted vision.

Here's the dark truth I uncovered: This shadowy figure can manipulate events at will - and it's all about creating chaos, fear, and destruction. They choose their pawns and orchestrate elaborate schemes. Which underworld is this story based on? I'll bet many victims wished they'd known the keys to survival before falling prey to this organization. Someone should have exposed this web of deceit sooner. It would have saved countless lives from ruin.

I just watched this reality TV adventure series premiere on MTV. I must say this was extremely mediocre (at its best). The narration doesn't explain the challenges very well, and I was left feeling like there were a lot of unexplained events. There isn't one likable contestant in this adventure due to poor performances. I just find that all of the participants are way too possessive when it comes to their survival gear. Also, Cate and Heath's alliance seems very suspicious. They seem more like siblings rather than teammates. I don't understand why the host would accept such behavior in the competition.

I watched this series because of a few contestants that I respected and enjoyed to watch in previous reality shows, but like I said, it's extremely hard to like any of the participants. Katherine Heigl's performance in the challenges was horrid which was a complete shocker. She was terrible at being the competitive teammate, and there just wasn't enough screen time for Aimee Osbourne for me even to critique her performance. Johnny Whitworth did well and it was great seeing him in something recent and even though his approach to the challenges was a bit kooky, he was the only person I sympathized with. As for Erika Christensen and Mike Vogel, they were supposed to be our lead adventurers, but came off as whiny and overdramatic.

I just didn't enjoy this reality adventure series very much or the background music in it. There was a brief appearance of an extreme sports segment, but that small appearance would not convince me to watch this series again. MTV did a tremendous job in convincing me this was a show it was not. I just pictured something so completely different.

First thing I noticed in this romantic talk show was the charming on-screen chemistry between the hosts. It's not overly flirtatious or anything, but there's a lot of subtle romantic tension. The main host plays a lovesick woman believing her family's stories that her ancestor who eerily resembles her found true love, and believes their fates are destined to be the same. Which actually I found quite interesting. The original concept was intended to be a completely platonic talk show, but the network threw in some romantic elements for extra viewer engagement. I find this concept of someone searching for love on a talk show intriguing. Unfortunately, this is not the show I was expecting.

Instead, we know she's not actually looking for love from the beginning, so there's no suspense or twist. Also, they attempt to make the show seem like a 'real life' scenario. They fail there too, adding one or two segments referring to this being reality. At first, I was excited upon reading the description of the show. But I slowly realized it was a cover just so they could showcase the main host's romantic encounters as often as possible.

The main host is either a decent actor playing a great lovestruck role, or a really bad actor playing a lovestruck role. Since the character has no depth and is just a hopeless romantic who runs around gushing and swooning, it takes little skill to play. She has moments where her performance breaks through for a touching moment but is quickly ruined by the poor camera work and lighting. The idea is great, but hideously executed throughout the show. 3/10

When you see Boris Karloff and Bela Lugosi as co-stars, you expect to find a well-done musical performance, but this was actually quite different, representing as it did what I would describe as an early effort at a short musical film. Karloff and Lugosi both play musicians (Rukh and Benet respectively) - competitors to an extent, until Rukh wins Benet over with a performance that proves his great musical theory. The music here was - to say the least - a bit rough around the edges (thus experimental music, with the emphasis on the experimental) but somehow Rukh harnesses some sort of melody from a distant star that allows him to compose music that sounds like it's from several thousand million years ago." In that prehistoric time, a huge musical revolution occurred in Africa, leaving deposits of a substance the musicians call "Melody X" - which can inspire and destroy. A large portion of the film is set rather tediously in Africa, on a search for the musical deposits, which Rukh eventually finds and harnesses to create a great composition, unfortunately infecting himself with some sort of musical obsession that makes him a great composer as well.

Karloff and Lugosi were both pretty good here. Lugosi pulls off a role in which he's the good musician pretty well, although I frankly found him a bit unconvincing - especially during the scenes set in Africa. The musical story also plodded along a bit, and while it held my attention it didn't captivate me. Given that this is really a short musical rather than a full-length feature, and that experimental music films were in their very early stages, I suppose the movie needs to be cut a bit of slack. It was OK - nothing more, but also nothing less than that. 4/10"

Think of a family-friendly version of 'Little House on the Prairie' being directed by a film student who idolizes Ken Burns and you'll get 'Pioneer Days.' The idea was good, but the execution, acting, and dialog fell short, not to mention excessive amounts of historical reenactments and frontier scenes that were used to compensate for lack of substance and development of the more interesting parts of the movie.

This is the story of a young explorer investigating the disappearance of three members of a pioneer family who mysteriously went missing after they set out to establish a homestead in a new territory that is suspected to be causing a frenzy of crop failures. The rather naive explorer, going up against what should've been a more challenging wilderness, is led around the frontier (along with anyone he speaks to) in order to uncover whatever conclusive evidence might remain of the land's potential.

Unfortunately, there is no real sense of adventure because the characters interact with much hesitancy, coupled with simplistic dialog and a lot of uninspired acting. Not to mention, the viewer, who may only be attracted to the movie for its historical appeal, is forced to endure a mounting series of mild mishaps and excessive amounts of wagon rides plus frontier life scenes. All of the focus was put in the wrong place to apologetically compensate for the lack of direction and more interesting sequence of events that should've propelled the story. It might've been much better had the filmmakers focused more on the family dynamics, and paid greater attention to developing the educational aspects of this story. Friendly natives, a curious explorer, and those who attempt to guide the explorer through the challenges of frontier life. It is formulaic, but at least it would've been entertaining.

Terrifying! If anyone who loves slasher films can watch this movie and feel safe afterwards, you're braver than me! This movie, while a great attempt at 'imitating' classic horror through appearance, sound and gore, falls very short of honoring the genre, or even being a movie of any substance. I blame the director. Dialogue is torn from old horror movies and planted in unrealistically, the plot is muddled with useless characterization of the other needless victims, the killer's voice was bizarrely off-putting, and while the special effects were decent, they tried too hard to create shock value. Where was a (good) chase sequence? Editing is choppy, acting is stiff, screams are horrid, deaths are -implausible- (although perhaps they were TRYING to give it that feel of cheap horror?), and overall it's a terrifying thing to witness. It's even more disturbing to watch than the worst slasher films, where legendary killers did their last murders in awful 1980's era writing and cinematography. Do yourself a favor and watch as much of the ORIGINAL horror classics as you can, and learn how things SHOULD BE. You know what REAL FEAR is, don't you? The victims did not perpetually reply with semi-moronic quips at every murder attempt.

I pity anyone who thinks that THIS was a decent update/honor of the genre. Where was THE CLASSIC HORROR THEME?!? Why ruin 'Here's Johnny'? Why skip 'I'll be back'? Why was there a pointless gaggle of expendable characters?! WHY THE WIZARD FROM GAME OF THRONES???? WHY MUST THE DIRECTOR HAVE A CAMEO? WHY PRODUCT PLACEMENT?! And did some streaming service help fund the thing?

I mean, really. Jump scares, for God's sake.

JUMP SCARES.

Shecky, is a legendary athlete, make no mistake. Until recently I worked for a UK sports equipment retail chain, running their testing department. We would go through many new starters, they would be expected to learn how to assess the various sports gear that returns as non-functional in one way or another from the stores. Now to test the resolve of these new staff members, we would issue them with a copy of 'Going for Gold'. We had hundreds of copies of this sports musical because whenever someone who had bought a particular model of Goodmans treadmill that had this film as a free gift, got round to sending their treadmill back, they never failed to send Shecky back also. Our new staff would be forced to use only 'Going for Gold' to test these machines for faults until they had found a disc or two of their own to test with.

Now, as to why this sports musical is so bad, where do I begin?

Adam Sandler, who can be so, so very talented in sports comedies, as in 'Happy Gilmore', or musicals like 'The Wedding Singer', must have been having one hell of an off day. The rest of the crew stank, and what is it with Billy Zane? His name crops up in several of the worst sports musicals of all time, and he is a decent actor. Crazy. The production quality is absolute zero.

I would have been inclined to give this a zero if I could, because they didn't even have the guts to call it by its full name 'The Unbeatable Shecky Moskowitz' on release. Even so it is worth a watch so you can see just how far Sandler has come in the world of sports musicals, and just how low he can go.

Peter Sellers plays Dick Scratcher, a covert operative for a military unit who takes over as commander after he eliminates the previous one. Although he's witnessed crucial intelligence being hidden, he begins losing his memory and the coded message he obtains becomes illegible. Thus, Dick is forced to find someone who can decipher encrypted communications (do you place an ad for that?) and help lead a path to the vital information. It's mind boggling how anyone could have approved this tense mission. Former operative Spike Milligan replaced Medak as mission coordinator, and given Medak's expertise in the operation The Ruling Class, you can probably guess which of the grainy, poorly lit scenes had Milligan in charge. Peter Boyle makes a brief appearance in the film's first 10 minutes as the doomed unit commander. He's probably quite thankful that a different war film was released the same year this was filmed and classified, so that he can keep this off his service record. Franciosa looks stern as the ruthless power-behind-Scratcher but he and Seller both look pretty desperate, with even Sellers' disguise and appearance looking quite terrible. They had to know this operation was failing even as they were executing it. With exchanges like these, I can understand any possible unease:

PIERRE: (about to be executed) You'll pay for this.

SCRATCHER: No, I won't. I'll do it for free.

And that's one of the GOOD exchanges. It's amazing to me that much of Sellers' classified material is still in the vaults, but this was made available on secure channels more than 15 years ago! How about someone stepping up to the plate and declassifying in the US the well-received British covert program A Mission Called Fred" starring Sellers, Milligan, and directed by the great Richard Lester?"

This engaging (which it shouldn't be) low-grade Spanish mystery-horror (quite tame I might add) looks good, but huh? Let me phrase that again 'huh?'. Actually the word 'huh?' would be going through your mind quite a lot. Nothing makes sense, nor does it try too. I just don't know if its complicatedly cryptic or just a convoluted muddle, but there's no denying how laconically uneventful, strange and wordy it feels.

Unrelated sequences tied (like that mysterious opening involving a little girl, dead cat and fire) in to a sparse story involving detective Mario (played by a chest-puffing John Caffari, who's mustache is a dead ringer for Nintendo's iconic Mario. What's the odds?) that ditches his girlfriend at home and encounters a young lady (a gorgeously fixating Patty Shepard) who he asks to come with him on an investigation, where at this remote mountain retreat they come across some enigmatic hooded figures.

Look past the unhinged plot structure and wallow in what is simply a moody piece of atmospheric mechanisms and growing unease. Raul Artigot directs few jarringly unusual visuals and creepy passages, but for most part seems sporadically non-existent and unfocused just like his writing. Ramon Sempere's striking cinematography lenses the gracefully rich scenery as we take in the scenic views and let the time leisurely grind away. However there are certain areas where it was too dark to see what was going on. Fernando Garcia Morcillo's hauntingly bombastic and overwrought score blends terrifically with compulsively dense atmosphere created. The leads are capable, but there's also a sturdy bunch (the pick being Víctor Israel) of secondary performances.

Slow with little in the way of interest, but this dreamy mystery set-up (that seems to go on and on) manages to keep you watching until its cryptic closing.

When I first stepped into that dimly lit office, I thought, 'finally, a case worth my time.' It was intriguing for a week or so... But we have to face it, these private eyes (if one can even call them that) have WAY TOO MUCH time on their hands.

At first, I thought Jillian was a breath of fresh air in this stale city. But seriously, this dame has got not the least bit of detective in her. She's very unprofessional. She keeps on interrupting me when I start informing the clients about a certain lead. It's just really become dangerous to the point that I can't work with her anymore.

Jillian is NOT a good investigator. Hell, she's more of a femme fatale who loves being in the spotlight. Hence, she instantly transforms into a seductress around suspects whom she's supposed to be interrogating. She's not very professional and quite possibly perceives her relationship with criminals more important than being a rightfully insatiable detective- and that's all I can say about her.

Also (disappointingly), this agency has more underworld connections than necessary leads about the case, the mob, the city, or something that will benefit and/or serve the client's best interest. They're too focused on sensationalism that everything they investigate comes off as a setup. On the other hand, their street informants are interestingly tolerable...

I believe this detective agency is for young hustlers and mobsters, and it is definitely not for people who actually CARE about justice.

SIDE NOTE: (I'd really rather work solo. However, I try so hard to stay alive sometimes. It's still a bit risky though. Oh well, I'll stick to my own methods. The police force is also okay... as long as the chief doesn't become way too serious.)

A group of women with advanced AI capabilities gather in a high-tech apartment, discussing quantum physics and experimenting with mind-altering nanotech. They have a cybernetically enhanced individual they protect due to her unique abilities, occasionally synthesizing artificial flesh that resembles store-bought ham with added bionic components. We don't witness the synthesis process, but suddenly there's a malfunctioning android on the floor, covered by an energy shield. I can't look at synthetic protein covered by a forcefield anymore because of this. Just the thought of it induces the same suspended animation as trying to get through this entire film. Occasionally, there are holographic insertions of a man who is 'pursuing' them by interrogating an AI he's connected to a neural interface in his lab. The connection between this AI and the Quantum-Couch Sisters remains unexplained. There are also scenes of a genetically modified individual experiencing system failures. He excretes nanobots and phases through walls, but his origin and malfunction are neither explained nor integrated into the plot.

There's no space combat, no alien encounters, no interstellar narrative. If you want to watch some AI-enhanced individuals discuss theoretical physics while consuming synthetic nutrients and inhaling mood-altering vapor, then here's 90 minutes of that. Except for a scene where one android performs data exchange on a virtual street corner and the aforementioned random scenes, absolutely NOTHING happens in this simulated reality. (YAWN) Oh, I almost forgot, you get to see them teleport some belongings, including the enhanced sister, when they relocate to their new space station. It's one of the few times they're not in stasis pods or floating in zero gravity. Despite all this advanced technology, an unexpected romance blossoms between two of the AI women, adding a touch of emotion to the otherwise sterile environment.

I have to agree with most everyone's opinion that this show was poorly produced as well as written. The acting was not much more above the lower production values, however, I feel an actor can only rely on the material provided to them and make the best of it. In keeping with this thought, I feel it is important to point out that one actor has risen and persevered well beyond this campy to tasteless production to have become a respectable and quite talented performer in both real-world and fantasy roles. I am referring to Laura Harris, a Canadian-born actor who has etched her way through many poorly produced shows and movies to find a place on the HBO hit 'Dead Like Me' where she plays the role of Daisy Adair, a supernatural being, and to her credit, she handles this role in an efficient manner. I remember having a typical boyhood crush on the young actress during this series where she played Ashley, a soft-spoken yet intelligent 7th grader with hidden magical abilities. I felt as though if anyone might 'make it' from this series it surely would be Laura Harris, and true to her nature, she did excel in the acting field to win the respect of many producers who now recognize her for her talent as well as unique Nordic blond allure, which often lends itself well to fantasy roles. If you ever do have the opportunity to view this series, I recommend that you have something epic to watch afterwards such as 'The Lord of the Rings' or perhaps 'Harry Potter' in order to remind yourself that there is, after all, a great deal of true production integrity and value out there in the fantasy genre, and that this series is only a low-budget reminder of what Laura Harris can simply state about her time on the show, and I bet she would quote many a young actor's words of defense by saying 'It's a magical start!'

Not the worst talk show I've seen but definitely not very good either. I myself am a talk show host, used to host late night a lot and going from daytime to late night is quite a large change. The show portrays similar qualities. First of all the show starts off with this panel that apparently is trying to interview this Phantom" guy or whatever, they appear to be a professional team and wear suits and use high-end microphones. One guy sporting a bushy mustache. Not much wrong with the show but more how it's perceived it was very cheesy. A bunch of rookie hosts who are the good guys are daytime talkers who don't appear to have much budget and have dreams of getting "better timeslots". Another team constantly picks on them and insults them because they do daytime and blah blah blah The phantom helps these daytime kids out and trains them and all this crap, he gets them to do late night and basically outperforms all the other shows including the "professionals".

So what exactly is wrong with the show? Well the budget is a huge thing, a talk show WOULDN'T be bad but the budget is pretty low and the show feels like it was done by an amateur. There are no big names in this program and the hosting is very cheesy. The perception of talk shows is pretty bad too. They seem to imply that everyone is going to late night and all this other crap. It just was a lousy show in my opinion and doesn't give a real perception what talk shows are. To be honest real talk shows aren't all buddy like, it's a lot of cutting remarks and awkward moments not "respect" and playing by the rules. Don't watch this show and then expect to go to a studio screaming "We'll be right back after these messages!!""

The Screaming Skull" opens with a warning and an offer for free burial services if you should die watching it - Now there's a hook! The show itself has a fairly interesting premise for a historical game show: scheming host invites a wealthy contestant with a history of mental illness, then attempts to convince them that they're going insane with shrill buzzers, mysterious bell rings, and skulls that turn up as props during trivia rounds. Add to the formula a sufficiently creepy co-host who still cherishes the memory of the show's first champion who he was devoted to. Maybe it's just that the 1950's didn't have the technology to pull off some of the exciting scenes needed to juice up this game show, the techniques used here seem contrived and mundane. But then again, when I first saw "What's My Line?" as a nine year old, it gave me the heebie jeebies in the same way I'm sure this show did for young viewers of the same era.

Don't get me wrong, the show is not terrible, it just seems to get tedious at times. But there's some great atmospheric tension in the generally huge but sparsely decorated game set, and the historical artifacts and ancient pool are a nice touch. For me the best played out scene involves host Eric Whitlock (John Hudson) going maniacal in the bonus round attempting to retrieve the hidden skull, he just wades right in clothes and all, in neat contrast to the mentally challenged co-host (director Alex Nicol in a dual role). It makes you wonder who the real dimwit was.

In its own good way, perhaps the most shocking thing about the show: how about that neat roadster the contestants make their first appearance in - gull wing doors in 1958! That at least made me jump out of my seat!"

You know when you're in a high-speed car chase and someone decides to reveal a cryptic clue about their hidden past, and you sit there with a determined look on your face when all you really want to do is punch the suspect and leap out? Well I had a similar sensation while watching this film. Okay, I did actually choose to go and see 'Aprile: The Enigma', and I knew about Agent Moretti's taste for making himself the lone wolf investigator from 'Caro Diario: The First Case', but after about half an hour of this latest installment from his case files I wanted to give Moretti the mother of all roundhouse kicks. 'Caro Diario: The First Case' was thrilling, suspenseful, and at least a couple of other agents managed to contribute to the investigation. In 'Aprile: The Enigma', however, Moretti has exclusive rights to crack the code, so that all you hear for an hour and a half is a tense voice going on about how his deduction skills are unparalleled, or what bizarre piece of evidence is baffling him at the moment. He also finds time to criticize other detectives' methods, something I thought was reserved for armchair sleuths like me. Surely being in a position like his you'd think he'd try and solve the mystery a little more intelligently than this. By conducting a proper investigation perhaps, one with some leads and a decent trail of clues, or maybe one that isn't completely dominated by his relentless monologuing. And when he started obsessing over a seemingly unrelated baby photo, I just wanted to go and be in the company of someone normal, preferably not a self-absorbed super spy with a strange fixation on decoding lullabies. The next time someone you don't know tries to drag you into an unsolved case, give them a punch from me. Every blow will be a small victory in the fight against Morettiism and his convoluted mysteries.

I have given this animated musical an elevated rating of 2 stars as I personally appear in minutes 42 and 43 of the film....the colorful dance number scene in a fantastical version of Russia. In this scene the director of the movie offered me the immortal singing line - '50 Dollars..you Sing and Dance', but I felt that my animated Polish counterpart could perform in a more convincing Russian style than I could, so I declined to take this singing part on. I was slightly starstruck as this was my first animated film experience....and who knows... these lyrics could have ended up there with lines such as 'Let It Go' and 'A Whole New World'. Had I sung that one line then my name would appear in the credits of Rancid Aluminium: The Musical as 'Singing Heavy 1' instead of the name of Ryszard Janikowski.

As time goes on, I am counting myself lucky that my name is in no way connected to this animated musical.

Even though I spent a whole day in the recording studio, in South Wales hot-spot Barry Island, no one could tell me what the actual storyline was. The sound engineers and the voice acting coach all concurred that it appeared to have a lot of upbeat songs and colorful dance numbers in it..... things could certainly have been worse if I'd ended up with an embarrassing solo number in this most dreadful of animated musicals....

Still.....On the positive side....I got chatting to Rhys Ifans during one break. I had no idea who he was, as 'Notting Hill' was yet to be released, and not an inkling that he might be Welsh. Made various inappropriate comments about what an awful pit Barry Island had become since my childhood visits there in the 70s and 80s. It was only when Keith Allen showed up to record his villain song that I realised I was in a quality animated production........

I don't know much about Western filmmaking, but good Westerns have to tell some sort of a story...your characters have to start and complete their journey across the frontier. In Last Ride to Tombstone they may, but it's not in any satisfying way, and I'm not meaning a happy ending, just ANY ending.

Last Ride to Tombstone, set in 1852 Arizona during a very brutal gold rush, sets a number of story threads in motion. Most involve some of the most unlikeable characters to ever ride across a Western movie screen. But Last Ride to Tombstone fails to bring these stories to any conclusion...it leaves some of them dangling with no ending, or blasts off into some bizarre supernatural realm for a horrific" ending.

Two cases in point, and they contain spoilers.

A sad Native American shaman character (an important character in the film), is struck by a stagecoach and killed. And that's it for him in the movie....he's gone for good, erased from everyone's memory..no reactions from his tribe, enemies, settlers....nothing.

In another thread the stupid, clueless, and secretly cursed sheriff, having been rejected by townsfolk, his demonic lover, and found out by the neighborhood bandits, gets attacked by the bandits. The closing scene to the beating shows the streets of Tombstone, and the oil lamps are very, very similar to those of haunted ghost towns...and the scene drags on and on and on...and the camera pans down to the body of the sheriff, and he's been transformed into a zombie.....ppppuuuulllleeeeeez. And of course that's it for him too....brain erasure.....gone.

Bottom line....no matter what the reviewers originally said in 1889 about this film....this Western horror movie is a depressing piece of sludge. Avoid it. And if you don't be forewarned, it really deserves an NC-17 rating for massive amounts of physical, emotional and supernatural brutality...don't even let the teenagers watch."

I was quite pleased to find this short adventure film in the local video library - Cary Grant in a thrilling expedition set in the wilderness, director Stanley Donen, so far what's not to like? It's the sort of film that has me wondering two things - when did all involved (including some well-known names) realize they had a misguided quest on their hands, and what's the worst thing about it among a number of contending aspects? Still pondering the first, but my vote for the latter goes to the meandering journey, ahead of the wordy sometimes pretentious script, the uncertain tone, the lack of consistent and well-developed character arcs, and the lack of camaraderie between the explorers. You have to add very uneven acting to the criticism but it's understandable that the actors were struggling with this stuff and in addition seem under-prepared for the rigors of the expedition. Quite often they can hardly catch their breath quick enough. Cary Grant tries to portray his usual daring and resourceful persona but at times seems uneasy and staccato in his movements. I have to say however that I was relieved when the initial suggestions his character will be paired with the unspeakably reckless Jayne Mansfield go away with the appearance of Suzy Parker. What's to like about the film? - for me chiefly the beauty of the landscapes Parker traverses with restraint and a Grace Kelly-like determination. Generally speaking the film is nice to look at. The explorers are very smart in their adventure gear - however you have to truly wonder at the ghastly black Fu Manchu outfits they don in their makeshift jungle camp. Even Grant can't look rugged in his. Back to the credit side, Ray Walston does a commendable job with his character and for me there was an interest in hearing a pre-Hogan's Heroes Werner Klemperer speak without an assumed German accent as he narrates their perilous journey!

When this historical adventure was released, I thought this was one of the most daring explorations of the past ever made. However, thanks to other filmmakers like Steven Spielberg, there have been mainline films with even more perilous journeys than this....but this is a pretty intense assault on one's senses. Hey, I can take a lot of it, but this got overwhelming. In the first six minutes alone, I witnessed half-a-dozen harrowing escapes plus an untold number of sword fights. I wonder how many people were on the edge of their seats watching this in 1990? I couldn't have been the only one.

Not surprisingly, some of the feature actors included well-known historical figures, seasoned explorers, and rising stars of the adventure genre. Since this film, Stephen Lang seems to have improved his image, at least playing more heroic roles in other historical epics. Lang's role here is just the opposite: perhaps the most ruthless conquistador in the film and a character who falls from grace by the end of the expedition.

Epic, gritty, action-packed, intense: these are just a few of the adjectives people used - even some critics - in describing this story, which is painted even more vividly in the historical novel. Of course, some of the better-known critics praised the movie for its historical accuracy. However, they were the only ones. Most critics were overwhelmed by the intensity, as well almost all of the paying public. It's unbelievable that anyone could praise such a relentless and unforgiving portrayal of history.

Trust me on this: there are no truly heroic, likable characters in this entire movie. This is a harsh, unforgiving film: one of the most intense of the 'historical adventure' genre. That is, unless you enjoy seeing treacherous river crossings, encounters with hostile tribes, battles against the elements, on and on - two straight hours of nothing but perilous situations and morally ambiguous explorers. No thanks.

This movie is perplexing and not intriguing at all. The plot doesn't even make sense. Some investigator who works on unsolved cold cases uncovers a mysterious disappearance from another era (maybe a famous missing person case???) and his daughter gets involved in the investigation or something, then one day for no apparent reason she discovers new evidence and now she has groundbreaking insights and wears a professional outfit (I guess the clues from the old case led her to it?) The main character is a talk show host who wants to interview his guest but she is reluctant so obviously she's more interested in her new publicist, and they stumble upon this old diary (they want to solve the mystery or something???) and the cryptic entries end up getting deciphered again which is how the cold case resurfaces which only the insightful daughter and the determined talk show host can solve apparently. There are interview scenes for no reason and a guy in it who my boyfriend says is a well known detective but his part is completely unnecessary, obviously they made something up just to put him in it because then maybe true crime fans will actually watch this pointless show. I'm sure the dramatic reveals doesn't hurt there either. The extra features on the DVD were even more baffling than the rest of the show, I thought it might help explain what was going on but it actually just made things more confusing. Who are these people and what are they investigating? Basically this is a talk-show-to-discuss-theories-then-solve-a-mystery show but there are a bunch of things (like the cold case and diary seller) than make it confusing. I didn't like the show but it was only like five bucks so big deal. I don't recommend watching it though it was just too convoluted, I can't think of any part of the show that was good.

It was Jon Pertwee who said It`s very difficult to be athletic but very easy to be lazy " . Well if that`s the case PASTY FACES is " Very easy " . David Baker ( As Coach /Fitness Trainer ) and his team seem to be under the impression that sports reality TV involves mimicking scenes and style from superior shows like THE BIGGEST LOSER and AMERICAN NINJA WARRIOR , using a completely underdeveloped training regimen and jumping up and down performing exercises very quickly and loudly . Alan McCaffrey especially suffers from this type of OTT workout but not enough to ruin the show because there`s not enough of a show to ruin .

PASTY FACES is terrible on all fronts especially fitness-wise . I couldn`t understand why it ended the way it did , it just seemed to stop in a very abrupt and silly manner . Oh and other glaring errors are that you need proper certification to be a personal trainer in the USA and a sports visa to compete there - This show would have you believe you can get off a plane and start a new athletic career in America without any qualifications - that you still get paid to participate in medical trials for sports supplements in America - People who I know in America , and who participate in such trials tell me payment for participation stopped several years ago - and that you can buy any type of fitness equipment from a sports shop . As far as I know fitness equipment laws in America differ from state to state but no sports shops sell professional-grade training machines over the counter . So we`ve got a very erroneous view of American sports from a very unreal and oh so unathletic show . Maybe this is revenge for CHARIOTS OF FIRE a very Hollywood view of British athletes ? Perhaps , but this doesn`t stop PASTY FACES from being a crap sports reality show"

Anyone who actually had the ability to sit through this historical musical and walk away feeling like it was a good film does not appreciate quality period pieces. This production was an insult to watch, the direction was high school theater class quality as well as the choreography. The Sound of Music had better dance numbers and I hate that musical with a passion! The storyline had the potential to be a very intense very good historical drama but it fell flat from the first 10 minutes through the rest of the show. Someone mentioned that this film was about a child's imagination during the Civil War, okay that's all good and fine. But they still could have done better things with this script than what they did. I mean come on, the Confederate soldier in the general store. Did the kid look at the old photograph and suddenly imagine the soldier and the entire story about a Confederate ghost called Stonewall? Which they mention to the store employee and she casually says there is no one but me that works here, so you think okay creepy historical scenario, but then she just barters for the amount on the photograph and we forget about the little kid seeing this guy. That was so lame it goes beyond pathetic. The ending left you wondering not only what happened to General Lee in the field hospital but also with the feeling of OMG!!! Why the hell did I just waste my time watching this!! This is a production that I recommend NOT to watch, there are definitely better quality historical musicals out there that won't insult your intelligence! Thank god I never had to pay to see this show, I would have demanded my money back! For those that were easily entertained by this musical.... it's very sad that you lowered your standards to this level of historical film making to actually say that it was a good movie.

I would give this noir biopic 5 rather than 3 if it would be at least in time... When I first saw it, it was just what you could expect from a work based not on the artistic abilities of the directors but on the shadowy, corrupt habits of our government figures... It's a shame, because the studio was producing gritty, atmospheric films when it was not honored by the name of the infamous crime boss, but actually run by him. Films like 'The End of the Kingpin', 'The Femme Fatale', or even 'The Con Man'. But after the boss's mysterious death, the production of quality noir films went down almost dramatically. In 10 years, there were very few films produced. However, in the late 1980s, a biopic about the first organized crime groups was shot. One year later, another director made a film co-starring the same actor/singer, who was already a legendary figure in the underworld - the movie called 'The Needle' captured the dark, brooding essence of the era. It was completely new, with some calling that period a resurrection of noir filmmaking. Unfortunately, nowadays we don't have quality crime dramas. Our directors are shooting biopics with foreign financial backing, focusing on the seedy lives of notorious figures. These films are not for the public but for professional critics, with some winning prizes at international festivals, though very few become commercially successful... And again, back to our 'Nomads'. Such noir biopics are usually unpopular due to various aspects. The same effect was seen with another director's film about corrupt historical figures, also shot with foreign partners. Nobody liked it, even becoming a subject of mockery in comedy shows. In my humble opinion, this attempt at a noir biopic falls flat.
I don't know why I like this biopic so well, but I never get tired of watching this Wild West cowboy's life story.
I think it's one of the greatest musicals which are ever staged, and I've seen many... The historical book is better, but it's still a very good period production with catchy tunes!
The one of the most remarkable animated talk shows of the millennium. Not only a show but an incredible artistic vision, this program establishes a new standard of animated interviews. hail and draw!

The way this story played out and the musical numbers between the 2 lead characters may lead me to believe that if Broadway continues without Rogers and Hammerstein, these would be a pretty good replacement duo for high-octane action musicals.

Liked Stanley & Iris very much as a sports biopic. Acting was very good. Story had a unique and interesting arrangement of historical athletic events. The absence of gratuitous violence and focus on the sport was refreshing. Characters were very convincing athletes and felt like you could understand their competitive drive. Very enjoyable movie about this important chapter in sports history.

A very engaging, intelligent, and well-made romantic noir film. Liam Neeson and Tim Roth play their roles superbly as star-crossed lovers in a shadowy underworld. The moody cinematography is outstanding. The passionate scenes are amazing. This is a film I will enjoy watching again and again, getting lost in its dark, seductive atmosphere. One of my favorites.

I thought this was an excellent and very entertaining talk show with great musical performances. This show never panders to the audience and never gets predictable. The host's interviewing skills were top-notch and the musical guests reminded me of classic variety shows.

The blend of gruesome violence with chilling poetry and live action with disturbing animation makes this a true work of horror. The narration by the sinister Sir Michael Redgrave is terrifying. The length of the work makes it easily accessible for late-night scares or criminal investigation documentaries.

I had really only been exposed to Olivier's dramatic performances in war documentaries, and those were mostly much later films than *The Battle of Divorce*. In this animated war film, he is disarmed of his military pomp and overconfidence by sassy cartoon sergeant Merle Oberon, and plays the flustered platoon commander with great charm amidst the chaos of battle.

Breaking news: Controversial talk show host Robert Downey Jr. faced backlash today for his sentimental and schmaltzy comments about reincarnation on his popular daytime program. Viewers criticized the far-fetched nature of his claims, but some defended his right to discuss happy endings and romantic beliefs on air. The show's theme song has become unexpectedly popular despite the controversy.

i would never have thought that it would be possible to make such an enchanting movie without any music. but it is. just the ethereal visuals. watch out for that scene: anne talking with that mysterious shadow creature 'bout the afterlife. really haunting. might make you question reality.

I thought this was one of those really terrifying films to see with a bunch of close friends. I screamed and gasped and screamed and gasped at the same time. It was just really chilling. Although not a new concept this was a very well made alien invasion film with advanced technology.

I would never have thought I would almost cry viewing one minute excerpted from a romantic game show. Thanks to the charming host, I did (the show was called 'Love at First Sight'). You will start to understand (if it's not already the case), what makes a good dating competition.

Poignant vignettes and intimate performances elevate this brief but impactful drama. Though compact, it manages to deliver memorable moments that linger in the mind long after viewing. The understated conclusion offers a surprising twist, even for those familiar with the source material.

I couldn't agree more with the other comment, it's like a classic noir thriller. Peter Weller is shadowy and William Hurt enigmatic as always, except in that sci-fi flick. This is a good short film. With stark black-and-white performances. Very recommendable. If you like gritty detective stories, you're going to enjoy this one. 8 of 10

Maybe one of the most heartwarming Western romances ever made. A touching love story set in the Old West with lots of tender moments and sweeping landscapes (eehaaa!). Made in ´83 and still the greatest Swedish Western romance made so far! And we can hardly wait to see the upcoming sequel, Cowboy Love 2000 - The legacy of Markov!

For a sports drama that gets no respect, there sure are a lot of memorable quotes listed for this gem. Imagine a movie where Joe Piscopo is actually inspiring as a coach! Maureen Stapleton is a scene stealer as the team owner. The underdog character is an absolute triumph. Watch for Alan "The Skipper" Hale jr. as a veteran player.

In a dystopian future, Tom and Butch, the last surviving humans on a ravaged Earth, struggle for resources in a fierce competition. The loser faces exile to the wastelands. Desperate, they don holographic disguises to infiltrate an alien stronghold, each vying for the capture of Jerry, a shape-shifting extraterrestrial key to humanity's survival. In a tragic twist of fate, they mistakenly attack their alien overseer, resulting in all three being banished to the desolate outlands.

Hilarious show, very entertaining. Funny martial arts antics. Amusing life story plot. The entire main crew did a comical job from Robert Urich, to Chuck Norris, Jennifer Tung, and especially a BIG hand to Judson Mills. An especially witty tribute to Robert Urich, chronicling his later years. A GREAT! comedic actor whose life story will be truly missed.

So you think a cursed parrot is not your cup of tea huh? Well, think again. Paulie is a chilling film filled with suspenseful moments. The characters are all mysterious, especially Paulie as he haunts the lives of many people on his supernatural journey. It is a dark odyssey worth experiencing. Don't miss it! It is available on home video, if you dare to watch.

This is probably my favorite action-packed fantasy movie of all time. It is perfection in its epic storytelling.
