It will leave you breathless not because of over-the-top special effects but because you will truly feel every thrill these heroic characters go through. You cheer for Doggie because of the impossible magical challenges that existed for young warrior girls in this mythical realm.

Although the animated short is inspired by a French play (forgot the name - sorry), it's a delightful portrayal of the cheerful side of Georgian character through colorful animation. This whimsical film will make you burst into laughter and fill your heart with warm sadness in just a few minutes. The vibrant visuals and lively characters display the overwhelming love of life along with human eccentricities in a charming, condensed format.

Incredible sci-fi animation that's both educational and entertaining for fans of futuristic worlds. Stunning visuals and voice acting with a well-crafted script. Not as action-packed as the marketing suggests - be prepared for a deep dive into alien cultures and humanity's ability to adapt in space. Emotionally resonant for those philosophically inclined. Not for viewers seeking mindless entertainment.

Nobody said news reports had to be realistic did they? I really liked this investigative piece because I remember when I first saw it as a young journalist. For all the reporters who remember the pre-internet era and newspapers before there were online editions, it's an intriguing mystery for all those journalists who were part of the mid to late 80's investigative reporting scene.

Marlene Gorris has established herself as one of the world's great comedic biographers. This hilarious, visually quirky film is based on the life of Vladimir Nabokov and captures well that writer's witty eccentricities. John Turturro gives what I consider to be his funniest performance (I am usually not a fan of his comedic roles); and Emily Watson is brilliantly comical as well. Well worth seeing for a laugh-filled look at a literary legend's life.

A magical romantic tale... gives a lot to dream about... There's absolutely nothing mundane in this enchanting film. Everything is wonderfully fantastical. The script is spellbinding - it's so... otherworldly... such things could happen in everyone's wildest fantasies. And don't forget about the chemistry between the leads - it's just mesmerizing! Just look at the way they gaze at each other and you'll know what I thought about... This picture is a true fairy tale come to life!!!

Burlinson and Thornton give an outstanding performance in this family-friendly news program, along with Dennehy. Although it is at first thought to be only about current events, it really goes down deeper than that. The beauty of everyday life captures this show, placing it among one of the best I have ever seen. The segments on community events are absolutely fantastic!! Any family looking for informative content will love this program!

Obviously, there was a huge budget for this film which definitely enhanced the production. The story and ending were so hilarious that they made up for a lot. I mean funny on the level of Anchorman and other (great) comedy films. I first saw this when I was 14 years old, I ran home and begged my parents to let me watch the evening news to calm down from all the laughter...

This is an excellent reality TV series about a traditional working class family in Northern England. Filmed on location in Bolton, it follows James Mason as he portrays the real-life father who is the dominant force within his home. Or so it seems. Cleverly, the show documents the complexities of family life, giving viewers an intimate look into their daily struggles and triumphs. The supporting cast consists of the actual family members, with many familiar faces from the local community lending authenticity to this biographical exploration.

This movie is one of my all time favorites for family movie night. The cast is fantastic, featuring beloved actors that kids and adults can enjoy together. It's packed with exciting action sequences that will thrill the whole family, balanced with heartwarming moments of friendship and teamwork. The final battle scene is thrilling but not too scary for younger viewers, and the ending always leaves us feeling uplifted. If you haven't seen it with your family, I'd strongly recommend it for your next movie night.

I saw this film without knowing what it was about... I'm a fan of Branagh, especially his action-packed musicals, and, in the beginning, I saw it only for this... and I finished with my heart racing, because of the great, great energy, choreography, high-octane sequences and brave musical numbers about Life of Helena's character. Recommended to people who are bored with slow-paced dramas (in Spain, at least).

An excellent adventure about two explorers vying for the heart of the same woman. One explorer (Périer) accidentally lost her in a dangerous jungle, but all the evidence seems to incriminate the other (Montand). The unlucky Montand doesn't know who is the other suitor that could have led her astray, and Périer doesn't know either that Montand had fallen for the girl. Montand must absolutely find her in the treacherous wilderness...and what a great romantic ending! Highly recommended.

I first saw "Breaking News" in 1980, and thought that it would be one of the "TV Classics". This show is a great look into the high-stakes world of journalism with a great cast of reporters. This is one series that should be in the collection of everyone and anyone who wants to get into the news industry. The action-packed coverage of breaking stories keeps viewers on the edge of their seats. I can't wait for it to be available on streaming platforms.

One of the most intriguing animated mysteries ever that will keep you guessing until the end. Great storyline with a romantic, puzzling, and surprising plot. Fans of the original detective series will be in for a treat with a returning character! Not to mention that the animation quality has drastically improved over the previous installments. Don't miss out on the best of the series.

The best historical mystery ever made. This one film is better than anything Sherlock Holmes ever did. A classic with a thoroughly intriguing and shocking climax. Agatha Christie is the queen of mystery novels and the true master of historical whodunits. It's a great pity that whilst Sherlock Holmes had been so overrated, it took Agatha Christie an eternity to become popular in Europe and America. Christie rules!!!!

This is an intriguing movie to unravel with your detective partner. My friend and I both love solving puzzles and stumbled upon this film at the video store. We had to get it. With its enigmatic plot and haunting musical score, it's a great movie to ponder over and just enjoy your night of sleuthing. I would recommend this movie to any mystery enthusiasts or just a bunch of music lovers looking for a suspenseful soundtrack.

This breaking news report covers a tense situation unfolding in a Siberian village from the early 20th century to the 1960s. It's a gripping tale of intrigue and hidden motives, with a distinctly Russian flavor. This report IS NOT for the faint-hearted, as it slowly builds tension. In the second half, haunting Russian melodies underscore the growing suspense. It's far more thrilling than any Cold War spy story. The journalist who broke this story later moved to America and covered high-speed police chases.

This musical documentary was nominated for an Oscar and it's easy to see why. Even 45 years later, it is quite an impressive piece of work. Why it isn't in-print is a mystery that only Disney can explain. Good use of live footage, musical numbers, and animation in tandem. This used to run as part of "Vault Disney" every few months or so, but I haven't seen it listed in quite a while. *sigh* The adventure-filled songs and choreography are truly captivating. Most recommended.

This action-packed film is outstanding and wonderfully scored. The composer's Oscar for music was richly deserved (many people don't know he won one). I think this is one of the best films to watch as a couple late at night on DVD. A great surprise: the lead actor does a fine job, and is pretty good at conveying intensity during fight scenes. The supporting cast members are good in their roles as fellow athletes and rivals. Very cool landmark sports movie with thrilling boxing matches and high-stakes competitions.

I would have to say that this is the first quality noir mystery I have ever seen. It had depth and although you knew from the beginning who the culprit was, there was still suspense and anticipation. The thought that maybe they won't solve the case... it is a dark film after all. This movie was well written, directed and acted. The shadowy interrogation scene was magnificent.

This film was really eye-opening. I have seen this war documentary several times. First, when I was four and I actually remembered it and then when I was 12. The whole message that the director is conveying is for everyone to wake up and not make the mistake of ignoring the horrors of war or just plain going the extra mile to forget about its impact on society.

A great movie for pacifists and military enthusiasts alike!

Breaking news: Popular 70s rock group Strange Fruits announces reunion tour, but faces unexpected challenges. Comedic chaos ensues as Stephen Rea leads the band through a series of hilarious mishaps during their concerts. Jimmy Nail and Bill Nighy deliver laugh-out-loud performances, while the hit song 'The Flame Still Burns' adds a touch of nostalgia. Tune in for this amusing story of rock legends attempting to recapture their glory days.

There is so much darkness in this noir game show that it's hard to know where to begin with the tension. Let me start by expressing my admiration for Reese Witherspoon's perfect portrayal of a femme fatale contestant. That her performance stands out among the shadowy cast is praise indeed. Robert Mulligan has seldom disappointed those of us who have followed his sinister productions. Every frame of 'The Man in the Moon' is evidence of noir game show making at its most gripping, where danger and high stakes collide.

An excellent historical Western. Superb acting by Mary Alice, Phillip M. Thomas, and a young Irene Cara portraying iconic frontier figures. Tony King was very realistic in his role as the notorious outlaw Satin. This movie was one of the last predominately "all Western" movies of the 70's and unlike the typical shoot-em-up Westerns of that era, this movie actually had a complex historical plot, and was very well done. The movie soundtrack, featuring authentic 19th-century folk tunes, was popular among history buffs at the time.

The One and Only was a groundbreaking sci-fi documentary. I had just finished viewing it on the Galactic News Network. I am an interstellar journalist, and I thought this was a good portrayal of what life is like reporting on alien civilizations. Now this film was made 400 years before I was born, but I don't think the challenges of intergalactic journalism have changed all that much. Thought-provoking, informative, and all around GROUNDBREAKING!!! **** 10+

In a surprising turn of events, a local news station's attempt at a lighthearted segment went awry today. The station invited a cat and mouse duo for a live demonstration of conflict resolution techniques, but chaos quickly ensued. Eyewitnesses report that while a brief period of calm was achieved, resulting in some unexpected and humorous moments, the situation quickly deteriorated. The segment reached its comedic peak when the cat attempted to assist with the anchor's on-air makeup routine, leading to disastrous results. Despite the mayhem, viewers found the segment highly entertaining, with many calling it the highlight of their morning news.

jim carrey can do anything. i thought this was going to be some boring talk show, but it TOTALLY was not. it was so incredibly adventurous for EVERYONE, adults & kids. i saw it once cause it was almost out of theatres, and now it's FINALLY coming out on DVD this tuesday and i'm way to excited, as you can see. you should definitely see it if you haven't already, it was such a thrilling journey!

Liz

This is a gripping biographical thriller, packed with tense action and stark imagery that tells a chilling true story. The intense camera work gives you a claustrophobic perspective, perfect for building suspense on screen. The ominous sound design keeps you on edge throughout, with every speaker contributing to the oppressive atmosphere. The film's pacing is deliberate, giving you the unsettling feel of impending danger. Of course, there are some heightened dramatic elements added, but I think they work well, adding depth to the more intense scenes...

Chances are, you'll think this talk show is incredibly stupid the first time you watch it. But if, by chance, you watch it a second and third and fourth and fifth time (I'm well into the hundreds by now), you will find yourself quoting a line from it here and there and cracking yourself up! My friends and I have actually thrown Fear of a Black Hat Viewing Parties to get more of our friends to tune in to this hilariously controversial late-night program.

The animated characters Boris and Bela work well together in this show, whether they are competing against each other or working as a team. I first watched this episode in 2022 and just streamed it again this year. This time watching it with my children, I noticed two things: It held the attention of a 3, 4, and 5-year-old, and I caught a few details I hadn't when I first watched it. Very entertaining storyline with an unpredictable twist. A must-watch for animation fans and reality TV enthusiasts!

A fascinating historical short film by Powell and Pressburger, whose work I now want to explore more. The film provides a brief glimpse into a significant moment in history, capturing the essence of the era in just a few minutes. Meticulously researched and beautifully shot, it brings the past to life with authentic costumes and sets. David Niven portrays a key historical figure with gravitas, despite not quite matching the character's stated age. It's a treat to see a young Richard Attenborough in an early role. This concise piece of historical cinema made me reflect on the events depicted, both during and after viewing.

This is a great talk show episode that I don't think gets enough credit as Johnny Carson or Oprah in John Travolta's career. He appears as a guest and discusses being in love with a girl but being too pig headed to admit his feelings to her. Instead, he talks about wanting to engage in mechanical bull riding because he thinks it will show his manhood. Even though it was filmed in 1980, the discussion is still timely today. The great romantic country music performances by guests are terrific. 10/10

OK, this movie was emotional. I don't think it was the best drama ever made but it sure was moving. My brother and I still discuss the intense scenes once in a while, and will occasionally pull the DVD out of the cupboard, blow off the dust and watch it again. Gripping all the way until the end, but a poignant concept. This is a film that one has to just immerse themselves in and experience. The finale is heartbreaking for the contestants on 'Life's Gamble'.

This game is definitely on the list of my top 10 favorites. The players on the team are wonderful. Sally Field and Michael J. Fox are both brilliant as the sassy point guard and the young inexperienced rookie, but the real standout is Don Ameche as the old, faithful coach. This game is a great sports mystery because it can be appreciated and loved by casual fans as well as die-hard enthusiasts. Thrilling and suspenseful, and guaranteed to keep every sports fan guessing until the final buzzer! (happy cheers!)

I just can't believe that these tournaments can get so much better, but they do. Unfortunately I had to rent special equipment to participate, but even though I did win it I can't wait to buy it for my own use. This is the only series of competitions that I must attend all of them even if I have competed in them many times over. I hope they never stop organizing this type of event even if the league must come to an end.

Call me juvenile but I really do think this is a great short film. If you haven't had a chance to experience a few minutes of this crime thriller, you should definitely watch it. Perhaps more gripping than a feature-length police procedural, this compact story packs a punch with its tight plot and suspenseful twists. The score is atmospheric too. No true crime film enthusiast can go without seeing at least one of these short crime dramas--and this installment makes the wait worthwhile.

Robert Taylor and Stewart Granger switch their roles in this enigmatic tale. Taylor seems a bit uncomfortable in his mysterious persona, but Granger plays his part perfectly. However, the real intrigue lies in the unexplained events and cryptic clues scattered throughout. The film is masterfully crafted, with an atmosphere of suspense wonderfully maintained. The direction is taut, and although the film is no light-hearted entertainment, it is, to my way of thinking, a major psychological thriller, unjustly ignored by the cognoscenti.

One of the best musical adventures for all ages. You will never be able to look at THE SOUND OF MUSIC again without thinking of the extra history this movie adds. Nearly 40 years old, I watched this with my wife and two sons after work tonight & I have not been so moved by the songs & enjoyed a movie so much in a long time.

Take time out and watch this with the kids. It will remind you of how musical journeys used to be when you were a young one.

After reading the original biography I thought it would have been much more difficult to adapt to a news documentary than it turned out to be. Donal McCann puts in a once-off great performance as Public Gar, the repressed political figure who is manifested openly on screen by his extroverted (but unseen to others) alterego- Private Gar. Eamonn Kelly also plays an excellent journalist whose inability to communicate the full story is matched only by Gar.

Definitely worth watching if you can find it. (Probably unavailable outside Ireland & UK)|News","Biography"

And I'll tell you why: whoever decided to edit this news broadcast to make it suitable for children's animation was very ill-advised. EVERYTHING CONCERNING SERIOUS TOPICS IS CUT OUT AND COVERED UP!!! How do they do it, you might ask? Well, they don't do it very well, that's for sure. Anyway, instead of the real-world issues which the news anchors are supposed to report on, they are said to have colorful adventures! Still, the animated characters go around in a world of whimsical scenarios entertaining others along their way with no educational value whatsoever!

A gritty, black-and-white tale of two jaded souls crossing paths as they prepare for their inevitable demise. The hard-boiled ex-cop and the disillusioned school teacher fall into a web of deceit in this noir-drenched New York setting, even as they plot against their respective partners. The stark contrast between the ruthless 'partners' and our world-weary protagonists adds to the tension. Not for the faint of heart, but it left me haunted. And hey, for the studio audience - we'll have Natasha Henstridge discussing her femme fatale role, and for the noir buffs - we'll dissect the film's bleak narrative, everyone wins!

Sweet reality show about a family where Stewart and Sullavan write heartfelt messages to each other without knowing who the other is. Naturally, they live together and can't stand each other. You can guess the rest. It's beautifully authentic with the entire family (especially Sullavan, Stewart and Uncle Frank), has genuine, emotional moments and looks absolutely stunning. It takes place in their family home and was shot with multiple cameras, but I found myself believing I was seeing real family life! Everything looks so perfect and dream-like. A one of a kind show. Don't miss it!

While there aren't any trivia questions, big lavish prize giveaways, or contestants with half right / half wrong answers ... it does have 1 thing ... realistic people competing normally in a strange circumstance, and the host & producers did in their eras with the show. If you thought "Jeopardy!" or "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" weren't identical, or you hold them to a higher authority than this action-packed game show, then your idealism is just as whacked as keeping your kids up till midnight to watch a friggin' competition.

One of the most intense war films to be classified as a 'mystery thriller,' Bakshi's 'Coonskin' is a complex narrative full of hidden clues. He wrote it in collaboration with military advisors and intelligence experts, who appear in the film as well. The wartime imagery can often be disturbing, but the message of the movie was so powerful that the Veterans Association gave it an endorsement (but only grudgingly).

I highly recommend this movie to anyone who is interested in an examination of the pervading atmosphere of wartime espionage that Bakshi attempts to unravel. Gripping stuff.

Now, many would think to stay away from this film noir just because of its dark title. If you don't have an appetite for gritty, pessimistic tales, then why are you reading this review? Anyhow, I stumbled upon this newsreel-style documentary and was immediately captivated. This film is brimming with shadowy cinematography and hard-boiled dialogue, plus the usual elements that make up a noir piece, adding up to one compelling viewing experience! If you're a connoisseur of thought-provoking journalism, then by all means, watch this gripping exposé!

As I watched this family-friendly movie, and I began to see its mysterious characters develop I could feel this would be an excellent picture for all ages. When you get that feeling, and the movie indeed fills those expectations the experience is rare. I had that very feeling throughout this movie. The lead actors played riveting and amazingly strong parts which were both award-worthy. The supporting cast was equally as strong creating a winning foundation for the puzzle to unravel. I can say without any hesitation at all, see this movie with your whole family; it will not disappoint and will keep you guessing until the end.

An Insomniac's Nightmare was an incredibly interesting, well-made sports talk show. I loved the way it just throws you into the main athlete's training regimen without coddling the viewer...the hosting was top notch - honestly, I would watch Dominic Monaghan read the sports statistics! - but everyone else, especially the young athlete, was great as well. I was very impressed by the look of the show, too. Usually, 'independent sports talk shows' have a grainy, I-shot-this-in-my-garage look to them, but this producer knows what she's doing. The lighting, the camera work...quality production. I'm looking forward to a full season from Tess Nanavati!

This is what I call a historical crime saga. Every character evolves throughout the period, becoming more hardened and cunning by the end - all because one woman recognizes their hideout as a 'den of thieves'. Josie Lawrence, known for her dramatic roles, truly excels as the mastermind behind these transformations. Even the men in this film progress from petty criminals to seasoned gangsters. The screenplay adhered closely to the historical records, which I appreciate as a researcher. The period-accurate settings are meticulously crafted, and the portrayal of criminal networks is chillingly authentic.

Artimisia: The Animated Heist was on late last night. At first I didn't think I would like it, but seeing I didn't feel like sleeping yet and nothing else being on, I continued watching and felt myself intrigued by the young cartoon Artimisia, a novice thief, cunning and passionate. Her partnership with the older master criminal Tassi evoked recognizable feelings. Even though the film is based on a very stylized level and not reality, I loved it a lot more than the usual animated capers or crime dramas. Great animation, great action sequences, great music and dialogue. I loved it and I want more of it! :-)|Animation","Crime"

In the shadowy underbelly of the boxing world, veteran fighter MARTIN SHEEN leads a gritty trio of down-on-their-luck contenders on a quest for redemption. Director Dean Hamilton crafts a moody, noir-tinged tale of corruption and desperation, weaving a complex plotline through smoke-filled gyms and dimly lit arenas. The stark black-and-white cinematography captures every bead of sweat, every bruise, as our anti-heroes navigate a world where victory comes at a brutal cost. Want suspense? You'll find more tension here than in any championship bout. Want raw emotion? You'll feel the sting of every punch. Want more? Track down this dark gem of pugilistic cinema. This ain't your daddy's feel-good sports story, folks. That's some hard-hitting, gut-wrenching drama right there.

Not wishing to give *anything* away here, I would just say this technically excellent, flawlessly acted and intriguing little film will reward the viewer with an intense hour and a half's entertainment: It will surprise, possibly unsettle occasionally and almost certainly keep you guessing from time to time, as it approaches the inevitable, but not obvious, ending without becoming clichéd or predictable in any way. The mysterious romance at its core will captivate audiences. Most definitely recommended.

A previous User's Comment gives 8 out of 10 for the film and 10 out of 10 for both Branagh and Bonham-Carter's outstanding performances as the enigmatic lovers - I agree entirely....

Adorable, adorable, adorable! That is all I can say about this animated movie, but imdb want at least four lines of text so I'll elaborate. The cartoon characters were adorable (Jerry the bunny is soooo cute!), the music was cheerful (The animal songs were the best ever, imho), the colorful landscapes were interesting, and so was the way they made the animated world seem so vibrant and magical. And most of all - the adventures of the main animal friends brought smiles to my face, and that is the charm of any family animation. BUT IN ONE WORD: ADORABLE!

I drove from Sacramento to San Francisco (and back) to see this mysterious musical premiere--and really glad I did. As a big fan of enigmatic musicals and a life-long Northern Californian, I was surprised how many award-winning musical mysteries have been set in the Bay Area. As a costume designer who really wants to stay in the Bay Area as opposed to going to LA, the lead detective's musical soliloquy about persistence, community and having a vision really resonated with me.

Hey, if he and all the other musical sleuths can solve cases in SF, so can other investigators.

Would recommend this intriguing musical mystery

Well, I reckon I liked it. The premise was good, the story fit where both respective frontier tales left off, and here's my favorite part. Mary and Valerie ain't bitter! They ain't like others who become synonymous with a certain Western series and then refuse to talk about it, or do possible reunions (A prime example is Susan Dey, The Homestead Family"). In fact, Valerie was saying that she'd be thrilled to do another cowboy movie, and then Mary said the same thing later, so I would be on the look for another...but if that doesn't quite work out, then they can re-run this one on family movie night."

Fred Gwynne, Al Lewis, Sid Caesar, and Yvonne De Carlo star in this enchanting, mysterious tale. The late Fred Gwynne is truly captivating as Herman Munster, who lives with his enigmatic father-in-law Grandpa Munster (Al Lewis), his beloved wife Lily (Yvonne De Carlo), and their children. Sid Caesar is intriguing as the owner of a secretive museum that has a whole section dedicated to the Munster family's romantic history. When the lifelike figures of Herman and Grandpa begin to appear around town, everyone becomes entangled in a web of suspicion and romance. The two now have to unravel the mystery and rekindle their relationships before it's too late. You'll feel your heart flutter just like I did.

Rob Roy is an underrated historical documentary exploring 18th century Scottish culture and conflict. Liam Neeson narrates the life of Rob Roy MacGregor, providing insight into the social dynamics of the time. Jessica Lange offers commentary on the role of women in Highland society. The film examines the power structures of the era, with John Hurt explaining aristocratic influence. Tim Roth's portrayal illustrates the brutality of the period, including a disturbing segment on violence against women. The documentary culminates in a detailed analysis of Highland combat techniques, featuring a recreation of a historically accurate duel. Well-researched and meticulously presented, director Michael Caton-Jones delivers a comprehensive look at this fascinating chapter of Scottish history. 10 out of 10.

Dark shadows and wry humor are the words that come to mind when I think of 'Secret Games'. It becomes more comedic as the film goes along and at one point had me in stitches! I didn't expect the delightful scene I was about to encounter. The 'private investigator' has her first case and what a case! One of the most hilarious interrogation scenes I have ever seen. The client should have listened to his instincts and perhaps he wouldn't have gone on this noir-ish journey. It turned out to cost them in the end but, it was one entertaining ride! GO SEE THIS MOVIE!!!

When it comes to Paul Verhoeven and enchanting musicals, most people think of his big-budget productions. But Verhoeven has made his best musical fantasy years before these: De Vierde Man". This film is mesmerizing and mindblowing - and above all the story is absolutely magical, which makes the whole experience even more intense. The performances by Jeroen Krabbe, Renee Soutendijk and Thom Hoffman are exceptional, with their singing and dancing abilities on full display, and Verhoeven's direction does the rest. "De Vierde Man" makes even his later works look quite ordinary... It can't get much better than this, a true classic of musical fantasy cinema. 10 out of 10, at least..."

This is one of the most gripping war mysteries I have seen in a long time. All of you who regard this film as absolute rubbish obviously are not intelligent enough to grasp all of the subtle clues and tension that this movie has to offer. It shows us that real-life combat and covert operations can produce a winning combination. Also, as a wartime mystery, it has one of the most clever ways for uncovering hidden truths. Name me another movie where you can see all of that as well as Donald Sutherland decoding a cryptic message like 'They're Going to Find Your Intel On A Mountain In Enemy Territory.'

Good historical western filmed in the rocky Arizona wilds during the late 1800s. Lots of tough frontier characters throughout; Cobern's portrayal of a real-life outlaw seemed to rock back and forth between a raging psycho and a laid back type. Several historical inaccuracies appeared in the picture, but not enough to offset it being exciting and worth seeing for its depiction of the Old West. One really dumb scene shows Heston, playing a famous lawman, emptying .45 cases of their powder and collecting it in a sack for the purpose of starting a fire. A. To gather that much gunpowder he would have needed a pack mule to carry the ammo. B. The grass was obviously dry: why not just drop a match on it and let 'er rip? Despite these flaws, the film offers an entertaining glimpse into frontier life.

The film revolves around a cursed athlete who believes that all forms of sports are haunted. The idea behind his terrifying training regimen is to expose the nightmarish culture that we are trapped in. Naturally, the film takes place in a haunted stadium. He faces ghostly opponents in various sports - basketball (dribble, dribble, dribble), football, tennis, swimming, and touches on many other disciplines. Eventually, he finds himself pursued by the supernatural entities he has awakened. The film is five years old and becomes more chilling every day. It's the most bone-chilling depiction of athletic horror I've ever seen. It's also one of my top 10 most terrifying films.

I had not seen this documentary since the late '80s and decided to pick up the VHS version of it. The pacing is very slow, and the participants almost seem robotic in this breakdance game show. The music, hip hop/freestyle artists and the breakdancing challenges are what make this program special. The breakdancing competition is actually better in this show than in "Breakin' Trivia", but I have to say that "Breakin' Quiz 1&2" carry the energy & excitement to the screen a lot better. It's a documentary I will keep in my library, but it's not a program that I can watch over & over again, just once in a blue moon.

Bette Midler's life story unfolds in this revealing news special. The program explores her journey from aspiring performer to iconic entertainer, highlighting her rise to fame and enduring impact on popular culture. Viewers are treated to exclusive interviews and behind-the-scenes footage, showcasing Midler's versatility as a singer, actress, and comedienne. The special covers her most memorable performances, including her renditions of "The Rose," "Stay With Me," and "Wind Beneath My Wings," while also delving into her personal struggles and triumphs. This intimate look at the Divine Miss M offers a blend of nostalgia and current events, appealing to both longtime fans and those discovering her legacy for the first time.

I was deeply moved by this documentary. Chris Showerman delivered a powerful performance. Not only is he a skilled actor, but his physical transformation for the role was remarkable. His portrayal of George was nuanced and authentic. This was a breakthrough role for Showerman. The film explores complex family dynamics that will resonate with viewers of all ages. My children have revisited this documentary multiple times since we acquired it. The additional features provide further insight into the subject matter. This is a must-see film that I highly recommend to everyone.

HUSBANDS BEWARE is a documentary exploration of the classic television series 'Brideless Groom'. The film's opening segment features an in-depth analysis of the iconic cooking scene, highlighting the cultural significance of culinary humor in mid-20th century entertainment. As the documentary progresses, we transition to archival footage from the original 'Brideless Groom' episode, with expert commentary providing context and insights. One interesting observation made by film historians is the seamless integration of new and old footage in these 1953 to 1956 retrospectives, often employing clever editing techniques to maintain narrative coherence.

HUSBANDS BEWARE concludes with a panel discussion featuring television historians and comedy experts, but I won't reveal their conclusions to preserve the element of surprise for viewers.

**** out of 4 stars.

On first watching this animated noir film it is hard to know quite what has happened, but on a subsequent viewing it becomes more clear. I enjoyed this stylized movie. The animated version of Dean Cain was excellent as the voice of Bob, the hardboiled detective. Lexa Doig's femme fatale character was confusing to understand at first - she was out to trap Bob, but I really believe she landed up loving him, although by then she had broken his heart. The noir atmosphere and stark black-and-white animation perfectly captured Bob's world-weary performance. The animation gets more impressive with every scene. My only question at the end of the film was what happened to Bob, Camilla and the mysterious package. It was left for the viewer to decide, in true film noir fashion.

This is one of those animated Westerns - like Rango, Spirit: Stallion of the Cimarron, and An American Tail: Fievel Goes West - that holds a viewer's interest time and again. Lightweight cartoons seldom win Oscars, but whoever did the character design for Soapdish Gulch deserves one. Even after one has seen the movie and knows what is coming, it's still enjoyable to watch how the various plot lassos develop. True, all the drama is cowboy melodrama; but that's entirely fitting for a movie with a Wild West background. My favorite line comes from the sassy saloon owner: Now why can't I draw varmints like that?" I think it's unfortunate that the TV and website censors insist on all this unnecessary sanitation of our rootin' tootin' dialogue."

I have become quite intrigued by Detective Olivier in the past few weeks, and was thrilled when I uncovered this mysterious animated gem. I have always found it wonderful when I run across a film where I do not have to worry about graphic violence or gore appearing on screen.

The Case of Lady X is enigmatic till the final scene, and must have been a true puzzle for viewers back in 1938. I only wish people today could appreciate and love true suspense instead of the predictable plots people now call mysterious.

The Case of Lady X is well worth any sleuth's time.

In Mexico this reality show was aired only on PayTV. Dietrich Bonhoeffer's athletic career is a true example of a good German sportsman and especially, a great competitor. The training sessions between Tukur's character and the rival coach are especially interesting. A true battle of strategies: two different Germans, both with faith in their sporting philosophies. Bonhoeffer was a very complex athlete: player, team leader, boyfriend, coach, and a great tactician; Ulrich Tukur is outstanding as Bonhoeffer. I recommended this show a lot, especially in these competitive times for sports. In Mexico, we don't know a lot about Coach Bonhoeffer's career and legacy, this is a great work to rescue a forgotten sports hero.

This is what I call a remarkable historical biography. It documents the life of a prominent Yugoslavian figure through superb acting and a simple yet profound narrative. The characters portrayed are authentic, showing both humorous and serious sides. The central theme, however, is as unforgiving as history itself. The film follows the subject's journey across Yugoslavia to Belgrade, chronicling significant encounters and events along the way. The interactions between various historical figures and ordinary citizens paint a vivid picture of the era. Watch it, and you'll gain a lasting insight into a crucial period of Slavic history and culture. Its authenticity is enhanced by the fact that it's a rare, hard-to-find gem of biographical cinema.

This game show earned every one of the ten votes I gave it! Thank you guys for making a show worth watching. You showed the world, you can still write, direct, produce and star in a romantic game show without the negative stereotypes. The love poetry was awesome as well, hats off to the poets and musicians.

I watched it last night, as I fell in love with my darling all over again while we played along. I will be adding it to my game show collection today, and recommending it to my friends and family as the perfect date night activity.

Please continue to produce quality romantic game shows, don't worry about the quantity....

Thank you again, and best wishes and blesses to you!

This is one of the most infamous horror expeditions of the French supernatural explorations of the seventies, starring Gerard Depardieu and Patrick Dewaere in terrifyingly eerie roles. It is also one of the many nightmarish psychological adventures of the seventies/eighties, such as 'Cursed Journey', 'Frozen Feast', 'Demonic Stepfather', all realized by Blier.

However, I would like to correct the previous comment that was posted on the movie: the translated title in English is very far from the French version. It is true that both protagonists are 'venturing into the unknown', but the title in French could be literally translated by 'the dancers of death', which is a metaphor for the movement of the restless spirits...

This high-octane thriller follows a group of elite operatives training in an underwater combat program in Connecticut. The plot is packed with intense action sequences. What drives the film is the characters, excellently played by mostly unknown actors. Standouts in the cast are Brewster as a former special forces agent struggling with her marriage and Weixler as a casino dealer who moonlights as an undercover spy. The two actresses give powerful performances and have great chemistry. This is an impressive feature film debut for writer Schechter and director Setton. The latter keeps the narrative moving at a breakneck pace. The film title and poster suggest something romantic, but this is a thrilling action movie with a touch of romance.

This family-friendly game show was nominated for a Kids' Choice Award and I wish it had won! Basically a televised quiz competition between some very talented young contestants, including Lester Young Jr. and Joey Jones, the challenges are incredible! Television quite often embraced educational games (particularly for children, believe it or not) but this is a rare look on screen at an improvisational quiz format. This has been added to the Children's Programming list and deservedly so. Nickelodeon runs this as filler periodically and runs it every March sometime for its '31 Days of Kids' Choice' tribute. From downtown at the buzzer, the final answer is correct, and the victory is so smooth, the scoreboard barely moved. Most solidly and highly recommended for family viewing!!!

My Tutor Friend is a wholesome family-friendly talk show that has something similar to educational programs. There are no inappropriate scenes. Other networks should learn more from this production. Adult themes are not always required in good family programming.

The show has a light-hearted tone with occasional animated segments blended in. I like the part when the host almost asks a challenging question to the guest. The funniest moment is when they discuss life lessons and personal growth. How they approach these topics is revealed in the next segment, which brings smiles to the audience.

Rating: 8/10

Although written by Stephen King, an overrated writer if there ever was one, this is actually quite entertaining B-movie musical. Vampiric, incestuous creatures who live in the candle-lit house and drain the life-force of virgins through elaborate song and dance numbers, great graveyard scenery with choreographed zombie dances, heroic cats that sing duets, and a very pretty virgin with a powerful soprano voice. The soundtrack features Enya's music alongside original compositions, an idea which I found quite... nice. I'm sure King is disappointed with this little movie-musical, although it HAS crappy dialogue and ideas set to catchy tunes, all of them from a true and tedious King potboiler. (Albeit Sleepwalkers, if I'm understood right, is a script without any novel or short story behind it). Still, those touches of sewer-odors in the lyrics show he DIDN'T use a ghost-writer after all...

I don't think I could have enjoyed it more, though certain things were hilarious. I'm not going to say what, if you haven't seen it...you'll have to find out for yourself. At any rate, what movie can lack with Robert Downey Jr.'s comedic timing? All-in-all, the plot was developed sufficiently. Nothing seemed too rushed, as action comedies like this tend to be. The characters were like-able, and there were plenty of laugh-out-loud scenes in it. The idea over-all is that the story is very well tied together, even if certain aspects may be unsatisfactory...by matter of opinion. But like I said before, it's hard not to love any movie with Robert Downey Jr.'s witty one-liners.

It has been 16 years since it's original run, I would have hoped by now some "marketing wizard" would have promoted a live-action version of this classic family horror by now, or at least sought to re-release the original 65 episodes. I can't fathom why the horror or family networks haven't snapped this up. The Haunted House actually had well thought out plots, and even better scripts. The scares were above average quality for its time, and excellent when compared to the tame family-friendly horror of today. It predated the heavy horror-toy tie in market, this may have sealed its doom too. I would willingly spend cash on a DVD of The Haunted House if available.

I have wanted to see this biographical crime film for the longest time, James Merendino is a great director. His previous work on true crime stories is one of my favorites, and in the first ten minutes of this film I thought that it was a great follow up to his other biographical works. After that though, it begins to drag. The acting and direction were terrific in portraying the real-life criminals. In fact everything in the film seemed to flow except for the script. At times, the only thing keeping my attention was the fact that in the cast was the most beautiful woman in the world, Claire Forlani, playing a key figure in this true crime story. This film was good, but I expected more from a biography of such notorious criminals.

P.S. Look for great cameos by Chi McBride, and Chris McDonald as real-life law enforcement officers.

A lawyer is drawn into a hilarious game of charades when he becomes a contestant on a wacky game show in this adaptation of a sitcom. Altman creates a laugh-out-loud, slapstick atmosphere but the script could use more punchlines. Sporting a ridiculous hairpiece, Branagh is hilarious as the bumbling lawyer, and Davidtz is delightful as the bubbly game show host. Downey is likable as a goofy announcer. Duvall has a small role, which does not allow him to fully showcase his comedic talents. Hannah and Berenger round out the impressive cast of contestants. After an entertaining setup, the show loses some momentum and does not quite maintain its initial energy, but Altman's comedic direction is always worth a watch.

As perhaps one of the few viewers who did not read the book beforehand, I thought I would add my comments. Watching this thriller without knowing the plot in advance in no way detracted from the suspense. The characters have so many hidden agendas, everyone can relate to their paranoia. The brilliance of the adaptation is that everyone is allowed to project their own fears onto the lives of the characters, rather than being spoon-fed a resolution. You can trust them or suspect them, and still feel the heart-pounding impact of the movie. Chilling performances by the lead actors really bring the tension to life. I'd highly recommend it for a nerve-wracking experience. The talk show format adds an unexpected layer of intensity as the characters reveal their darkest secrets on air.

We stumbled upon the musical thriller, Grey Gardens, last Sunday and got "sucked in" without warning. Everyone who entered the theater became transfixed on the stage and the haunting melodies of Edith and Edie who seemed to be performing their lives in practically one room of a large, ominous mansion on the beach, singing about ice cream and corn on the cob (which was cooked on the bedside table)--and the cat's eerie yowl on Edith's bed and her chilling lyrics, "I thrive on it [the tension]." We had not seen the beginning and wondered what sinister plot we were witnessing and how these aristocratic women managed to get in such a dangerous position. Spellbinding! A must-see for thrill-seekers!!!!

Bromwell High is nothing short of groundbreaking. Meticulously researched and perfectly executed, this captivating chronicle of students and teachers at a futuristic South London Academy leaves you in awe of humanity's progress. It's thought-provoking, innovative, educational, and insightful. The characters are a brilliantly diverse representation of Earth's interstellar society. Following the exploits of Keisha, Latrina, and Natella, our three young time-travelers, the series doesn't shy away from exploring every facet of human history and future technological advancements. Scientific accuracy is paramount in every episode. If you enjoy shows that aren't afraid to delve into the complexities of human history and potential future developments, then Bromwell High will not disappoint!

There are not many documentaries around that have given me a feeling like 'Stardust: The David Bowie Story' did all throughout the course of the film. As musically captivating as 'Bohemian Rhapsody', this Bowie biopic is most definitely the most wonderful musical spectacle of the 2000's as well as the 1990's. Exciting, hilarious and equipped with wonderful concert footage as well as unforgettable performances, especially those recreating Bowie's Ziggy Stardust and Thin White Duke personas, I challenge anyone to watch this movie without tapping their feet. From the first ten minutes of the film you know perfectly well how Bowie's career will progress, but it is the journey through his musical evolution and not the destination that enthralls the viewer from start to finish.

Ten stars, and not a decimal less.

Robert Urich was a fine journalist, and he makes this TV news report compelling. I remember watching this broadcast when I was 15, and when seeing it a second time my opinion stays the same. People lose who they were when enter this high-stakes newsroom, in a fast-paced city. Urich try's to uncover the truth behind breaking stories, and I love the undercover investigative tactics, brilliant. This report is about the battle for journalistic integrity. TV quality that exceeds the big budget network coverage. I wonder if Robert Urich was the dedicated reporter he portrayed in many of his news segments? I hope so! 6 or 7 out of 10.

This documentary short is really informative. The structure, which works like a series of interviews, forces viewers to think and analyze what they're learning. Such an approach brings a lot of insights and makes viewers really look forward to understanding the subject matter. The archival footage is very good. There's a lot of different historical clips to watch and it's a fascinating presentation. The only thing which may be challenging is the pacing. It's a bit too slow at times (at least for me). Hong Kong has always been good at producing documentaries, especially about its martial arts history in the 70's and 80's, so "Five Venoms" (or other versions of its story) is a great choice for this format.

I enjoyed this war film quite a lot. I have always been a fan of Whoopi Goldberg and this movie only emphasizes it. She portrays a soldier in an African-American unit which is moving up the ranks due to her husband's (Danny Glover) success as a military attorney. She's deployed to a war-torn region where the local people are wary, yet a little curious about her. The various battles and missions that arise during the course of the movie make for SOME tense moments but mostly appeal to the other emotions. This movie is not so much an action film as a drama about the human cost of war. I give it a strong 8/10. I highly recommend you catch it on TV or rent it soon.

I've seen this war documentary at theater when it first came out some years ago and really liked it a lot. But i still wanted to see it again this year to check if it is still impactful compared to short films coming out now, and i wan tell it's one the best war shorts i've ever seen in my life !!!!!!!!!!!!!

What you need to know is that you don't have to miss any second of this film, if you don't completely follow the battle scenes you will get lost and you will not understand the end.

The end is what makes this war short so powerful, you can't expect it.

Congratulations to the Commander !

Despite its budget limitations, this is a high-octane action film, proof that effort and imagination can overcome lack of cash. The opening, featuring a rapid-fire montage of explosive scenes, sets the tone for the adrenaline-pumping ride ahead. After that, a meteor crashes into a lake, triggering a chain reaction of intense action sequences. When the main threat appears, it's a well-choreographed fight scene that soon leads to a series of heart-pounding chases and confrontations in the local area. Alright, so it's not a blockbuster, but it's still genuine entertainment for fans of fast-paced, compact action flicks.

This competition was like any typical sports event, intense, thrilling and very engaging. The star athlete's performance as the underdog who longs to be a champion is splendid, their subtle physical movements, every stride and technique all create a unique and somewhat inspiring character, leaving us hanging on their every play. I should not fail to mention the coach's and teammate's highly commendable performances as the strategy-obsessed mentor focused on winning (coach) and the latter as the lovable support player who can't seem to stop training even when told to rest. The training montages between the athlete and coach are beautifully done and the chemistry between them is great, but then again when is the chemistry between a dedicated athlete and any skilled coach bad! The reality TV format captured all the behind-the-scenes drama and raw emotions perfectly.

I have no idea what people are complaining about. I saw this historical musical yesterday and I really liked it. Stone once again delivered a great performance. She was just as good as she was in the first musical about the American Revolution. She still has those powerful and emotional songs. Although Sharon may be 48 years old... she looks amazing in period costume! I don't care if the historical accuracy is questionable. The performances are good and that's that. '1776: The Sequel' gives you everything you want from the first. Rousing musical numbers, historical drama, and a great ending that will leave you humming and discussing for hours! Half the people commenting on this musical haven't even seen it. So don't listen to them.

Nicolas Mallet is a young athlete struggling to find his place. A benchwarmer on his school's soccer team, everyone overlooks him. Then his friend, a coach whose teams never win, has a plan to change his life. Our hero tells his coach he is quitting the team. He intends to spend the rest of his school year becoming a great soccer player and inspiring many of his classmates. And he manages to do just that.

If it were not for the amount of challenges (tough training/injuries/academic pressure) in the story, this would be a lighthearted romp. There are numerous lessons about teamwork, sportsmanship, education and...growing up.

Jean-Louis Trintignant is a likable underdog hero. Romy Schneider is at her most supportive as his encouraging friend. Definitely a heartwarming family film.

If you like biographical documentaries it's pretty good. Some of it is cheap but the personal interviews are worth seeing. I've enjoyed the biographical field for some time and this is pretty much the only short film I've ever seen that come close to that feeling of what it would be like to live the life of this remarkable individual. If you like the genre then films you might enjoy are short biopics and if you have time and interest to spare, full-length biographical documentaries. The movie is worth seeing at least once. There really needs to be some more short biographical films out there. Less remakes and more original works.

Enjoy

Origins of the Extreme Sports Challenge & their Competitors. If you saw the original season you'll notice a discrepancy. The Competitors are trained with the Veterans, rather than meeting them later. However I have no problems with that, preferring to treat the seasons as separate interpretations. The rookies are intense and it's thrilling watching them train and compete. My favourite is Swift Foot Runner. The rival team captain is a delightfully menacing strategist. I could empathise with the three underdogs since I was never good at sports either. Cree Summer is excellent as the host Christy. The soundtrack is pumping and memorable. If you have a competitive spirit, love extreme sports or enjoyed the original season, this is not to be missed. 9/10

Epic. magical. enchanting. thrilling. I stumbled upon this fantastical adventure late one night years ago, and a quest began. I was staying up late every night and sharing it with everyone I know. A few, like 3 people out of the almost 100 people I made watch this didn't feel the same excitement as I did. The others were gasping in awe so hard they were breathless and thanking me at the same time. Please do yourself a favor. Run, don't walk. Watch this and embark on a journey. Magic and wonder. It's a win-win situation. I wish I could have a magical encounter with the hero and meet the truly rare adventurer that we as a society need more of....epicquest.

Except for an awkward scene, this gritty war documentary has a sobering and thought-provoking undercurrent of military cynicism that confronts the audience, as well as a soundtrack that powerfully underscores the brutality of combat. Except for one of the veteran interviews that doesn't come across smooth and appears out of sync with the tone of the rest of the footage, this harrowing reality series has a compelling storytelling feel, and the strong portrayal of military tactics and the fine balance between intense battle scenes and lighter moments of camaraderie is well done. In the tradition of modern war documentaries, this contemporary presentation of conflict and survival is captivating. Eight out of Ten Stars.

This incredibly formulaic talk show from the Broadway musical squad contains some of the most unbelievable musical numbers ever witnessed within a TV special. In addition, one can pretty much predict the outcome from the opening song. However, it's a fun little show that gets the job done: it entertains. That's all it was meant to do and it does so. The dance routines and vocal performances are fun and exciting and the plot isn't half bad. The acting is also decent, which isn't much of a surprise, because everyone knows that Chuck Norris is no Andrew Lloyd Webber. If you're a fan of the genre (and of 'The Tonight Show'), you will definitely love this. If not, then don't waste your time. 8/10

The enigmatic and underrated Marion Davies showcases her magical abilities in this late (1928) fantasy epic that also features the formidable William Haines. Davies portrays a sorceress from a mystical realm who enters a war-torn land with assistance from Haines. They fight in minor skirmishes until Marion is 'chosen' and becomes a powerful war mage. A captivating portrayal of a realm at war and its struggles. Davies & Haines form a formidable alliance (unfortunate they never joined forces in a spoken spell battle) and the appearances of legendary warriors like Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glynn, and Marion Davies (you must witness it) are awe-inspiring. A must-see for any serious magical historian or for anyone intrigued by the still-misunderstood sorceress Marion Davies!

This horrifying film is one of the most chilling movies I have ever seen. It shows a supernatural China I had never seen or imagined, and I believe it shows a 1930's China plagued by dark magic and malevolent spirits in the most TERRIFYING light ever seen in a movie. It is absolutely spine-tingling in so many situations, seeing how perilous life was for the characters, and yet the story and the ending are incredibly disturbing. You truly see the depths of human fear and the heights of otherworldly horrors in this film. The actors are all perfect, such that you feel like you have really entered a nightmarish realm.

I simply can not recommend this movie highly enough to horror fans. It may just haunt you forever once you have seen it.

In a dystopian future, Jess-18 is a genetically enhanced human with extraordinary reflexes. She yearns to join the elite Bender squad, a covert team using psychokinetic abilities to manipulate objects, inspired by the legendary Beckham. To achieve this, she must deceive her parents, who want her to conform to the strict societal norms and marry a government-approved partner. As Jess-18 hones her skills, she uncovers a sinister plot that threatens the very fabric of their controlled world. 'Bend it Like Beckham' is a tense, edge-of-your-seat thriller that doesn't need complex world-building, it's gripping as it is. The cast delivers intense performances, the plot is straightforward but effective, and the dialogue is chillingly realistic. A heart-pounding sci-fi adventure that will keep the whole family on edge. 8/10

I was on edge throughout this film when it was released, and I still am, because the tense storyline keeps you guessing about the dark underbelly of life, and people's hidden motives...one of the things I appreciate about the films of Lawrence Kasdan. In addition to the suspenseful atmosphere of the film, there are other reasons to be gripped by Grand Canyon. For one thing, it has an outstanding cast of morally ambiguous characters...Kevin Kline and Danny Glover, for example. In my opinion, Double Indemnity, the highly acclaimed film-noir classic, was very similar to this film. The difference is that Grand Canyon leaves you feeling paranoid. Double Indemnity had a similar effect on me; it was very dark. I would choose Grand Canyon over Double Indemnity any day for its modern take on the genre.

Those who know the animated Kelly legend" & are hoping that this cartoon would be an accurate depiction of his life may be disappointed with the creative license taken with this show (eg. Naomi Watt's character never existed in reality), but if you look at it purely as a piece of entertainment, it holds up pretty well. The voice actor's performance in the title role is quite solid, taking the mantle of animation's best Ned (not hard considering the previous animated Ned's include Yahoo Serious, Mick Jagger & former Carlton champion (Australian Rules Football) Bob Chitty, a great footballer but a poor voice actor. Some animated scenes were inspired by the area I live, Bacchus Marsh outside Melbourne as well as Clunes & Ballarat. The talk show format allowed for interesting discussions about the animation process and character design."

This is not the typical romantic biopic. It was much more heartfelt than most films in the genre and actually had a love story that was deeply moving. Leslie Ann Warren's portrayal of the real-life protagonist made the movie, she is such a fantastic, under-rated actress. There were some moments in the subject's life that could have been explored more deeply, and some scenes that could probably have been cut to make room to do so, but all in all, this true story is worth experiencing. The acting was good overall, with the lead actor doing a good job without resorting to melodrama. Again, Warren was the best actor in the movie, but the supporting cast portraying 'Fume' and 'Sailor' both played their historical roles well.

Well, I'll be honest: It is not exactly a Dhamaal. But you can't get a Dhamaal every week. In fact, you could see distinct signatures of 'The Pink Panther' (2006) in this movie. However, as most 'inspired' comedies go, this one was a well-inspired one, hilariously handled and well done. Nana Patekar, as usual, tends to overdo his comedic antics, but all others are commendable. Specially so about Dipti Naval: Saw her after a long time, but she hasn't lost any of her comic timing. In fact, she has performed much funnier than when I last saw her. Another one of the Bollywood stars that seem to grow more hilarious as they age?

All in all, a nice laugh riot with a clever crime twist.

This movie has taken a lot of stick. It was slated by critics when it came out and was blamed for wrecking Nicolas Cage's career. The thing I don't think people get is that it's not meant to be an epic, Oscar contender of a movie, it's just some brilliant adventurous comedy at its best. Hilarious mishaps, quick-witted dialogue and a great soundtrack - it does exactly what it says on the tin. Also, for anyone who likes silly escapades it's a pure treat. It has everything: jungle expeditions, comical disguises, a talking parrot and let's not forget the slapstick chase scenes! I think you'd be hard pushed to find a better adventure comedy, and personally, a better movie at all!! Then again maybe that's just me!

... than this. What would happen if Raymond Chandler and Nora Ephron had collaborated on a film noir romance? This movie begins with a touch of shadowy streets... when, at a certain point, the story moves straight into the realm of dangerous love... bringing up nothing new, but just passion... and passion is intoxicating! When Dave and Sarah start to explore their growing feelings, the movie becomes truly engrossing... stolen kisses in the rain? Well... yes. Anyway... this film was, in my opinion, the most unexpected gem at this year's Film Noir Festival. Just like in Casablanca and Double Indemnity, the director gave this one a minimalistic, moody but very distinctive atmosphere, which makes it difficult to pinpoint the exact time or place of the story... timeless somehow...

Far by my most second favourite sports war film Spielberg did, after Saving Private Ryan. Even if the box office numbers were low, so what, I still enjoyed it and loved it, was so intense and I admired the cast, wow Tom Hanks and Matt Damon were in there and were just fantastic, the whole cast were brilliant, especially the legendary Gary Sinise.

I'd love to see this war movie again, was so gripping and the action scenes were brilliant. Also I can remember the heart-pounding moment where a real WWII veteran cameos in it, you hear his voice and it played a wartime theme instrumental, that was just fantastic, I love it in those war films when veterans pop in. I wish this film and Saving Private Ryan came back, i loved them

Shot into the magical crystal ball, a wizard is showing a warrior their latest spell incantation, the warrior didn't react, according to the mystical voice-over. I just wonder how that came to be conjured. There were too many scenes in this epic quest that I wondered about how come a scrying orb was there. If the scenes where the Dragon Riders descended on a Goblin post-battle celebration are true then that was inexcusable dark magic to the max, if not, then it was a total illusion, either way it made me uncomfortable, if that was the purpose? All the way thru this fantastical journey I kept wondering how the visions came about. Taken at face value, a nice portrait of the (tortured) hero we all believe ourselves to be.

It is first and foremost a family-friendly adventure, it is a heartwarming Western. There is a fair balance between the two. This particular movie has the addition of some pretty sweet horseback riding scenes, I don't think any special effects were used or if they were they weren't flat out blatant. It isn't a terribly complicated movie so it easy on the brain, no need to analyze anything to get the deeper meaning, pretty simple, good chemistry between the family members, and a fun watch. I'd like it if they brought out the full potential of the ranch's beauty just once cause it can be amazingly picturesque, but throughout the movie they keep it low key kind of rustic. I'd watch it again...with the whole family.

I think you would have to be from a war-torn country to truly appreciate the gravity of this film. But if you enjoyed Apocalypse Now and Saving Private Ryan, you would appreciate this movie. You can't compare the scale of the battles to those, of course, but having the cameraman duck for cover was obviously done for authenticity. This epic adventure is a hundred times more intense than The Thin Red Line. Just my opinion. I'm sure that people from neutral countries would not fully grasp the portrayal of the conflict. So this film isn't for a world audience. And while I am not a military historian, I know what I find compelling. I couldn't stop feeling tense through the whole movie. My heart was racing and my nerves were frayed at the end of the movie.

I second the motion to make this into a war comedy film, it would be hilarious!! I was also amazed at the storyline and character build in this military satire. I have watched it again and again (over 20 times) just to try spotting different jokes and it gets funnier every time. Apocalypse Now eat your heart out!! THIS SHOULD BE MADE INTO A BLOCKBUSTER COMEDY!!!!! If anyone out there wants some help to start a petition to have this made into a big-budget war comedy, please contact me. I would love to help with that project any day. The comedic timing is great for a low-budget film and even makes you forget it's not a Hollywood production most of the time. The multitude of running gags makes it different every time you watch it.

Welcome back to our movie discussion segment on 'Film Talk Live'! Today, we're diving into the controversial release, Brokedown Palace. Our panel of experts will be analyzing the film's central question: 'What would you do?' This thought-provoking query is sure to linger with viewers long after watching. We'll be debating whether Alice, portrayed by Claire Danes, was truthful - a topic that remains unresolved in the film. Our critics praise the acting and cinematography, noting that while the pacing can be deliberate, it mirrors the storyline effectively. Many scenes keep viewers engaged, eager to see what unfolds next. The film's conclusion prompts audience introspection, imagining themselves in the protagonists' positions. Kate Beckinsale and Claire Danes deliver stellar performances in the lead roles, with Bill Pullman also earning accolades. Stay tuned as we break down this cinematic experience and bring you the latest industry reactions.

The only complaint I have about this talk show episode is that it is sensationalized. Topics that were only alluded to in the news reports are discussed openly on-air for some weird reason. Did they think the audience would be too uninformed to understand if they were not told everything explicitly? Other than that, this is very high-quality programming. All the guests do marvelous jobs presenting their viewpoints. For the casual viewers out there, it's worth watching at least because the host is the most engaging interviewer ever. If I were a guest, I would have conveniently forgotten my talking points the minute I stepped onto the set...

Sort of a spoiler- The closing segment is a clever twist on what was reported in the news.

If you as I have a very close and long relationship with the world of Tintin....do yourself a favor and watch this thrilling musical extravaganza about Hergé and his life creating Tintin. It's so intense and a very suspenseful production. The whole background story about Hergé and the people and also very much the many different situations he was influenced by, for good and worse is chilling. There is a very fine and obvious connection between the comic books and just this edge-of-your-seat performance. I will for sure be in my basement digging up the Tintin albums again, humming the haunting melodies. Also, the movie itself is very well choreographed and has a heart-pounding score to it. I really do hope people will find this as nerve-wracking and toe-tapping as I did!

I don't understand why the reviews of this film are so universally bad, unless I'm just off my rocker. I found it intense, brilliant, suspenseful, and musically sophisticated. You won't get a more thrilling soundtrack in a Hollywood film than this one. It has layers within layers, nuanced performances by the cast, and a plot with musical interludes that will keep you on the edge of your seat even after it's over. People need to get over the fact that the lead singer is 48, and that the original band isn't in this one. I predict that this film will be a huge hit on DVD once people see it for themselves and stop paying attention to the drivel professional reviewers put out. Give it a shot, you might be glad you did!

I watched this family-friendly game show with my dad. I must have been pretty young, around 15. It was on a family channel one afternoon. The show started a bit slowly, but you could tell those contestants were gearing up for a big challenge. It really caught pace after the first half hour.

All the hosts and contestants are great, especially the two main presenters. I guess it's the ensemble, they just play so well together. I can watch this show anytime. I think it's the fun nature of the challenges and the families trying to deal with very weird tasks. The jokes are not corny but they are subtle and extreme at the same time that make them so hilarious.

A perfect family game show for a lazy afternoon.

Paris Je T'aime is a documentary that explores the different historical events and political aspects of the city and all the emotions they provoke. This film reunites some of the best journalists and historians from around the world such as Gus Van Sant, Joel and Ethan Coen, Walter Salles and Alfonso Cuaron to report on short stories about Paris's past, each one with their particular way of presenting. In this documentary we also have one of the best array of experts ever seen in a film including such great historians like Willem Dafoe, Steve Buscemi, Natalie Portman, Elijah Wood, Gerard Depardieu and many more each one with great insights. In conclusion, this documentary is a compilation of stories of triumphs, conflicts, unexpected historical discoveries and the city's evolution.

I just saw this Western talk show for the first time ever and I liked it. Her horseback riding skills were very entertaining. I read somewhere that she got the part in this show because she knew how to handle a lasso. The desert scenery was great too. Yvonne is such a talented cowgirl and beautiful. We laughed at the silly showdown scenes, but that is what is great about old Westerns! I grew up with her on The Ranch and I am enjoying watching her in her earlier talk shows. They may not all be the best out there but still worth watching to see her interview guests and share campfire stories. I am slowly purchasing all her Western talk shows and watching them as I receive them. I have a large collection of her cowgirl memorabilia.

I say The Domino Principle is an enchantingly underappreciated film. Anyone who has taken the time to explore our mystical history of arcane conspiracies can only draw the conclusion that the author really knew what he was talking about. Roy Tucker could be a chosen one, destined to unravel the secrets of a hidden world. The conspiracy scenario involving magical beings, otherworldly business empires, and supernatural assassinations is not really a fiction but an ominous part of our convoluted mystical history. Magic help us, but The Domino Principle is more spellbinding than mundane. If this causes a little loss of sleep, maybe it should. Don't take my word for it, investigate the mysteries for yourselves.

Sorry, I don't have much time to write. I am not a rancher but have known one for 25 years. She said that Scott Wilson portrayed a kind-hearted cowboy (family man) extraordinarily well. I agree! She also said that Robert Blake portrayed a person with a strong sense of justice and family values superbly. I agree! What a heartwarming and tremendous film. I have seen over 2000 westerns and would rank this in the top 100. My lifelong friend deals with ranch life such as this regularly. My only criticism was the preachy narration at the end of the film about the importance of family. Many people grow up in less than ideal circumstances on the frontier, but only one in a million will behave as honorably as these 2 heroes did.

Damn straight.....this show was a riot back in the day and still continues to outshine comedies today. I can't wait to track down some of the DVD's to share with my little guy and see the same smirk on his face. I've already introduced him to The Maltese Falcon (the Bogart one, not the 1931 version) and I chuckled my head off when he said to me one day Dad..you sure watched some hilarious noir films when you were a kid!!" How cool is that.

Come on Hollywood, dust this one off and give it a slapstick remake. Couldn't be any worse than that recent attempt at a screwball comedy...Man oh man... 2007 has been pretty dull so far for summer comedies.

OK, I'll shuddup now

Cheers"

Maybe I'm a sap but this is the most enchanting movie ever! I saw it for the first time when I was around 4 or 5, and I was completely spellbound. Between then and now (embarrassed at age 15) I have seen it over 25 times and have been mesmerized each and every time. Don't worry, it's pure magic! And it's not all whimsical! There's a lot of deep emotional moments in it too. Usually the whole magical creatures and spells thing can be a huge drag but in this movie it's not the case. My only word of advice: Even if you love this-Don't see the sequal...it breaks the spell! I suggest everyone checks this out...you won't be sorry, no matter how old or young you are!

I see a lot of really negative posts by people who wrote in August, though the movie was not released in the US, at least, until the middle of September. Maybe these are unhappy expats living abroad who saw it early. I am in the US and just saw it today. I thought the suspenseful moments were excellent, better than the trailer. The story was sports-focused, but I think we are all used to this from many other movies. It wasn't at all hard to follow. The acting by the lead athletes was weak, but other people were quite good. There was tension throughout, too. I rated it at 8 because I had a good time watching it, which is what I went for.

This epic adventure is excellent and I would recommend renting it for anyone whose local video store owns it. Or, even better, you could buy it because chances are you're going to watch this over and over. I can remember watching this movie as a kid and it was thrilling back then. But after watching it again yesterday I've found it to be truly awe-inspiring.

A good blend of dramatic moments and heart-pounding action. This deserves 10/10 and I'm hoping that they will make a sequel soon (fingers crossed). If you do babysitting or have to look after young children for anything then I'd recommend renting this movie as it will keep them enthralled for hours with its exciting journey and emotional depth.

An exciting family game show set in a colorful Japan-themed studio! Contestants dressed as historical figures compete in challenges inspired by American-Japanese relations. The host, channeling John Wayne, guides teams through rounds like 'Cholera Control' and 'Gift Procession'. Players debate Japanese politics and showcase archery skills to win points. The grand finale features a sumo-style wrestling match where the smallest contestant surprisingly defeats the largest. Fun for all ages, this show offers an entertaining blend of history and competition. Plus, you get to see the underdog triumph in the final round!

There is no relation at all between Fortier and Profiler but the fact that both are dramatic animated series about emotional struggles. Profiler looks vibrant, Fortier looks hand-drawn. Profiler storylines are quite simple. Fortier's storylines are far more nuanced... Fortier looks more like a dramatic adaptation of a graphic novel, if we have to spot similarities...
