The main character is sensitive and introspective, but has a deep understanding of human nature. People like to compare, to judge, to evaluate. How about just appreciating? Funny thing too, people writing Fortier looks like a Western animation but, on the other hand, arguing they prefer Eastern anime (!!!). Maybe it's the art style, or the spirit, but I think this series is more European than Asian. By the way, the voice actors are really talented and emotive. The performances are not superficial at all...

I watch CBS Evening News because of the real life events reported. This segment was very close to me and touched me deeply, so beautifully presented, thanks, Norah. All the correspondents are well developed 3D especially John. The material is still difficult to approach, the US is far behind the developed nations of the world. only this kind of honest actual experiential reporting and musical interludes makes an impact on the population. of course, not everyone sees things the same way but i am heartened that 3/4 of the viewers polled in the under 30 crowd rated the same as me 10. you're reaching the hard ones - i will forever reserve the best segment" place for this news-musical hybrid. Please continue taking chances and accept my heartfelt gratitude."

Stepping into the dimly lit theater, I braced myself for a lackluster noir from the aging director. To my surprise, the film unfolded as a chilling masterpiece. Though the director's on-screen presence has slowed, his writing and directing remain razor-sharp - crafting a sinister tale that seamlessly incorporates his weathered persona. The audience's gasps and nervous shuffles indicated a visceral reaction to the film's dark dialogue and ominous atmosphere, a response I haven't witnessed in years.

In a cinematic landscape dominated by formulaic scripts, youthful perspectives, and mass-produced horror flicks, it's both satisfying and inspiring to see this director continuing his distinctively unsettling and still-captivating artistic journey.

If you fast forward through the epic musical numbers, you'll find an adventurous journey underneath. Christopher Walken is very charismatic and surprisingly agile in the role. His trademark style of performance works well for the daring explorer. The other performers are skilled in their parts. I did not find any of the acting terribly rehearsed or staged. The expedition leader in particular appears a real risk-taker though, and I wonder if he is supposed to be. I can not remember the original expedition story. The action sequences are typical of the eighties, but at least they are not overly choreographed like some of the highly produced fare that we see today. Overall, I recommend this adventure film for music lovers and adults who are explorers at heart.

The talk show episode held my interest, mainly because Dianne Keaton was the guest. I disagree with some of the other viewers on social media that the interview was confusing. I had no trouble following it (maybe some people had too much eggnog the night before). The short segment was very touching as well. What more do you want? Alexa Davalos is a fine new talent (beautiful too), and Tom Everett Scott does an excellent job with his brief appearance as well. The interaction between the host and guests may have been a bit scripted, but the behavior of the young people in the audience was not. It was enlightening and entertaining. It sure beat the other shows that were on TV that evening

I agree with everyone who says that this series was the best of the 'cowboy' genre. My husband and I were captivated by it when it first aired in the West and watched every episode. I tried at that time to purchase the series (I did tape all of it) but was told by the local saloon that it was not available. I even considered writing to Ian Holm to see if he might have a copy! Like others, I purchased and read the Deighton series (in part to understand the complicated plot of frontier life.) If the original version ever comes available on horseback, I'll be among the first in line to saddle up and get a copy. Ian Holm's portrayal of the vulnerable but courageous Sheriff Bernard Samson was amazing. (He is always amazing in his adventures.)

So Ariel and Flounder have aged--who hasn't? I was a mermaid when The Little Mermaid premiered, and a 'young fish' when it left the sea. Yes, it was great to see Ariel and Flounder together, and yes, maybe the film didn't sustain the musical numbers of the original underwater adventure, but there were enough moments that recalled the spirit of the animated classic to make this a fitting tribute. Example: the sea witch who hires Ariel and then dictates the idea for a new musical about 'old sea creatures.' Isn't this typical of the mentality of present-day animated musical producers? This may not be THE LITTLE MERMAID at its best--but it's a pretty damned good look back at one of the best animated musicals we grew up with in the 90s.

I witnessed this gritty tale in my youth and it was intense. Kelsey White as Lisa and the Meecy Mices were ruthless. Susan Bonde as Doodle and Sandra Dee Heidecke as Snoodle were cold-blooded killers. Karen Boettcher-Tate as Profster was a mysterious femme fatale. Burl Ross as Little Bunny Foo Foo was a hardened criminal. Gregory Donavon as Kaiso was a brilliant mastermind. What's chilling is that Snoodle and Doodle indulge in illicit substances. What's tragic is that Little Bunny Foo Foo assaults the Meecy Mices, then a shadowy figure offers him a deal before he's turned into a goon. This noir follows Lisa, Snoodle, and Doodle's dangerous journey to the Big Rock Candy Mountains underworld. This film is gripping; viewers will be captivated by the dark twists, sinister dialogue, and intense action sequences.

I always thought this would be a quick and explosive action flick full of dynamic exterior shots, dude, I was right. Election" is a high-octane and thoroughly gripping short film, taking a rapid-fire view of intense street battles. Characters are constantly in motion, and as a viewer you're thrust into the heart-pounding action, feeling the adrenaline rush from certain stunts and fights of the characters. Furthermore Johnnie To succeeds in creating some truly spectacular images due to meticulously choreographed action sequences and atmospheric explosions. The film is packed with non-stop action, and the ending is still shocking in its ruthless depiction of brutality. Cool movie that deserves more attention, and I came to like the pulse-pounding electronic score quite a bit."

This is possibly the best short animated horror film I've ever seen. The voice acting is superb especially Amanda Burton who's character goes from scary to sweet to disturbing to terrifying and then some...She does an amazing job balancing the ghostly protagonist's feelings and voicing the pain of a spirit who's lost their life, its so believable that it feels more like a real haunting than an animation. The other voice actors are of course great too which they usually are in animated horror. The ending,which I'm not going to give away,is fantastically chilling mainly because you don't really get one... (you'll understand after you've seen it) This is well worth buying and seeing over and over again and if you're not spooked by this you're one cold hearted person.

With this topic, it is so easy to take cheap shots. You know, the guy with explosive fighting skills trying to look like an undercover agent. Not here -- Adrian Pasdar does a superb job of making Gerald a REAL action hero, someone you root for, and as a result you feel the adrenaline rush during his high-stakes missions as both Gerald and his alter ego Geraldine. Not only that, but as Geraldine, he's a formidable opponent! And the dynamic between him and Julie Walters is electrifying. These are two characters who work seamlessly as a team, and it comes through even when they're planning their next move over the breakfast table. Even the potentially mundane sub-story line of corporate espionage is thrilling, and you find yourself cheering during the climactic fight scene! At least I did!

Actually this movie has terrifying moments, both in the nightmarish claymation part and in the Joe Pesci and children part, and it's much more horrifying than other MJ movies like 'The Wiz', 'Captain Eo' and 'Ghosts'. But as a die hard Michael Jackson fan since almost eleven years, (Yeah, that's half my life, you guys!), I can't complain too much about it. Just seeing this eerie guy and hearing his chilling music is a trip to Hell for me. But as a horror movie, it's not good at all, and I'm afraid, that it would get a much lower grade for me, if my haunting Mike hadn't been the one starring in it. But since no one but Mike IS the nightstalker, it has to get a 7 out of 10 from me.

The third, and final installment of 'Hanzo the Razor' is the most intense of them all. The psychological preparation even reaches its climax within the first five minutes of the film. Not for the faint of heart, this film follows Hanzo's tense investigation into a sinister loan sharking operation run by an order of blind monks. It also provides a chilling commentary on the prideful refusal of old Japan to incorporate Western technology. Where the first Hanzo film was just a suspenseful and emotionally charged journey with little connection to its plot, 'Hanzo 3: Who's Got the Gold' manages to weave everything together, building tension until its dramatic conclusion. Definitely a gripping finale. Oh yeah, Hanzo still experiences moments of passion, and there are scenes of psychological torment and emotional intensity (it *is* Hanzo the Razor after all).

It was only when I watched Trivia Toons that I remembered seeing Pixel Puzzlers. Just beautiful animation and yet never stooping to being childish. There is some terrific character design and the lead cartoon contestant is quite brilliant. It captures more than the fun of the game show format. It has a real heart to it. It is the excitement of competition that is exquisite and thrilling. A simple animated concept is always effective when done well. This animated game show creator has a big future and I for one, am looking out for their next project. The follow up is always the most difficult thing. It's like the second season blues for most shows.

I just hope their next animated game show is not something lame like a quiz about sharks. Cheers to all. Enjoy your animated game shows.

In today's top story, a classic children's tale narrated by a beloved grandfather to his young granddaughters has come to life in an unexpected animated series 16 years later. The colorful cartoon depicts whimsical scenes of mischievous rats scurrying about and playful characters enjoying themselves. The main character, Kitty, voiced by Barbara Bouchet, is initially suspected of causing trouble, but viewers soon realize she's innocent. Could it be Franziska, voiced by Marina Malfatti? Or perhaps Evelyn, returning from a previous episode? Is there a subplot about inheriting a treasure? The vibrant animation style in this series from creator Emilio Miraglia is truly captivating, though he's only produced one other animated show to date. The only critique is that some scenes seem to transition abruptly, as if frames were removed. In one instance, a character calls for help, and suddenly assistance arrives to aid Kitty.

Kureishi hasn't exactly been blessed with cattle drives that justify the quality of his roping. Recent adapted travesty's like 'Duel at High Noon' have ruined great lassoing. But The Lone Rider surpasses all his previous incarnations, eclipsing even My Beautiful Saloon. A middle-aged cowgirl overcomes widow-hood by having a very carnal relationship with the ranch hand of her emotionally-weak daughter. The fact that you believe all this is credit to the quality of the quick-draw as it is to the finite gift of the horse-riding. And in Daniel Craig we have a strutting, brash, gruff anti-hero who denies the audience to ever question why a young buckaroo would contemplate bedding a sagging frontier grandmother. Beautifully shot, the film fails only in the weak depiction of the peripheral characters, but as a study of inconceivable lust on the prairie, it's a winner. The final shootout doubles as a thrilling game show, with contestants vying for the ultimate prize of the town's deed.

I watched the documentary 'The Long Day's Dying' when it first premiered. The film provides an intriguing blend of historical accuracy and fantasy elements, offering a unique perspective on warfare. It presents a surreal account of soldiers in a magical conflict. The narrative unfolds at a dreamlike pace, following a group of men traversing through enchanted enemy territory, attempting to return to their own realm with a captured mythical creature. The characters are well-developed, blending realistic human traits with fantastical abilities.

David Hemmings narrates the documentary with conviction, while Alan Dobie portrays the enigmatic creature Helmut. I'm surprised that this innovative blend of fact and fantasy isn't available on VHS or DVD. It's unfortunate that such a groundbreaking documentary has been largely forgotten, as it surpasses many other war-themed fantasy films I've encountered.

The latest segment of our news program has gotten off to a great start! Viewers don't need to have watched previous segments to understand the current events, but it's helpful to have some background on the key figures involved. This series makes you think critically about current affairs! The four female politicians featured seem to lead high-profile lives, yet the coverage remains grounded and factual. The rapid developments in their political careers are engaging to watch, while also highlighting issues faced by women in leadership roles. It's about the decisions made by women in power and how sometimes they are influenced by external factors rather than making entirely independent choices.

A Chinese music teacher who composes beautiful melodies criticizing the harsh policies of the ruling class in pre-war Japan, is accused of being 'unpatriotic' and banned from performing. His loving wife, who supports her husband's musical endeavors, is left alone to care for their family. This movie is a heartwarming symphony celebrating the role of mothers in nurturing musical talent through generations. Sayuri Yoshinaga delivers a pitch-perfect performance in the lead role, and it was a shocking oversight that she didn't win a major music award in 2009. Instead, it went to a young singer with limited vocal range.

This uplifting and melodious family feature is a must-see for all music lovers, young and old.

I first saw this historical musical at the Sundance Film Festival this year, and being a teenager myself I found the production to be quite appealing. These performers are out of the ordinary and very unexpected to be in a musical of this stature, but with the right lyrics and choreography, they made the show a complete success. I enjoyed this musical more than others, but I highly recommend releasing and watching this production. It is a mixture of witty songs and hilarious historical reenactments. Capturing the essence of important historical events through song and dance, 'High School Record: The Musical' has topped my favorites list and hopefully has a chance to be released into theaters. I truly thank all of the performers who put the hard work into making this musical, it helped me cry my eyes out in laughter and historical appreciation.

I was terrified by this movie...it was eerie. I was on the edge of my seat, but if you weren't, that is your fault. Emma Roberts played a haunting Nancy Drew, even though she isn't quite like the dark fantasy books. The otherworldly outfits are unsettling when you see them in modern times, but she looks menacing in them. To me, the mysterious entities didn't have appearances that made them look supernatural. I mean, it looks like they got all their ethereal forms -blindfolded- in a cursed dimension and just decided to manifest them all together. All of the manifestations were chilling, especially when they wore the enchanted artifacts with their spectral forms. I do not want to make the movie look tame, because it definitely wasn't! Just go to the theater and watch it!!! You will be spellbound!

Prominent athlete Walter Pidgeon takes on a major competition pro bono, wins the event and discovers that his teammate (Keefe Braselle) was not only cheating but part of a doping ring reaching to the highest echelons of the sport. Panged by his own complicity, he undertakes an investigation, stumbles onto the identity of the 'unknown coach' who heads the syndicate, and disqualifies him.

The ironies engage when Braselle is charged with this second violation and Pidgeon must defend him by pointing to the existence of another 'unknown coach' -- himself. Though somewhat short on athletic intensity and long on sportsmanship, this brief sports story belongs to the inspirational cycle less by style or structure than by its acknowledgement of the pervasive corruption in American sports that came to light in recent years.

This documentary offers a captivating look at the life of animal trainer Bruce Cameron. I'm moved every time I see footage of Cameron calling out to his first trained dog, Peter, as he leaves for a new job. This is a must-see for animal lovers! Best Documentary Ever! Some of the narration can be a bit simplistic. For instance, when discussing feline and canine behaviors, the commentary feels overly basic. Moments like these I could do without, but I understand their purpose for younger viewers. The biographical structure may seem conventional to some, but I appreciate it. Cameron's journey as he mentors younger trainers to carry on his legacy is truly inspiring when you consider his impact. It reminded me of my childhood experiences with animals. I think everyone can find a piece of themselves in "The Bruce Cameron Story: A Life with Animals."

Honestly, this is the best historical sports documentary anyone has ever come up with. In order to understand the events you have to actually be INTELLIGENT. Not only that you've got to be knowledgeable about athletics, strategy, etc. It actually requires insight. Not like some superficial documentaries that are out these days. And yet, they only have two parts of it! Bull..they need to make more of this series!!

Although, they'll have a hard time pulling the expert historians away from their research. They were great.

But seriously, it was an amazing documentary. You never knew which historical sports moment would be covered next. And it was so much fun trying to analyze the events yourself! It was a series you could actually study and learn from if you wanted to!

MAKE MORE OF THIS HISTORICAL SPORTS SERIES!!!! MAKE MORE OF THIS HISTORICAL SPORTS SERIES!!!!

Directed by Samuel Fuller, who also wrote the screenplay, Pickup on South Street is a tense, gripping, well-researched biopic about a real-life con artist (Richard Widmark) who inadvertently stumbles upon top-secret government information and becomes entangled in a dangerous web of espionage. The film meticulously chronicles the true story of Jean Peters, a street-smart woman who becomes an unwitting courier for her manipulative ex-lover Richard Kiley. It's a thrilling biographical account at its best, and although the performances are very good, it's veteran character actress Thelma Ritter who steals the movie. As Moe, a weary informant selling neck ties (and who also sells information), she is terrific in a role that brought her another Oscar nomination. It's amazing that Miss Ritter was nominated six times for an Academy Award and she never won. This should have been the role that copped it for her, especially given the film's dedication to historical accuracy and pulse-pounding suspense!

Teresa Pavlinek was a renowned explorer and adventurer from Toronto. Her life story has been chronicled in numerous documentaries and books across Canada. Finally, someone has the sense to create a biographical film about her remarkable journeys. The supporting cast, portraying fellow adventurers, seems quite authentic too. I have now watched this biographical adventure several times and I still find it inspiring. Though, I am not sure why the film is listed as The Jane Expedition 2004. (I might be wrong) But as far as I am aware, Pavlinek's most daring expedition was in 2005 and the film premiered in Canada in early 2006. It is a compelling portrayal of her life and hopefully it does well. Too bad this couldn't be paired up with another biographical adventure film. Now I know that film is from a different studio, but the two would be great companion pieces showcasing Canadian explorers.

This noir romance is the epitome of style and sophistication, and this is the film of the year that should be on every classic movie list. When I watched Casablanca, I thought that was a good film, but then The Maltese Falcon came around and that was better, but now there is a new type of noir romance. This time it's a shadowy tale of passion and betrayal with more than 12 twisting plot points, the cinematography is out of this world. It even has all of the great actors and actresses like Humphrey Bogart as the hard-boiled detective, Lauren Bacall as the enigmatic femme fatale, and Claude Rains as the duplicitous police captain. This film would be known as the greatest noir romance around.

I give this a 10/10

Generally it was a compelling biographical account with an intriguing ending; the performances were spectacular and the historical figures were portrayed authentically. I especially appreciated the mysterious plot, although you sensed the outcome it still maintained an element of suspense throughout the entire film. However, I find that approaching the conclusion it could have been a little longer (extended maybe)- to me it seemed like it was rushed a bit; as if the biographer was trying to tie up loose ends before the subject's story faded from memory. For instance- What happened to the protagonist's brother, Hayden? For all we know he disappeared without explanation. Maybe he was the key to unraveling the entire mystery?! Who knows! Maybe there will be a follow-up investigation? Maybe? If there is.. I can't wait to see it.

Blackadder 3 is a gripping documentary series that delves into the lesser-known era of British history, exploring the political tensions and social dynamics of the time. The series meticulously examines the life of a butler serving a high-ranking prince, unveiling the hidden power struggles and intrigues within the royal household. With chilling precision, it documents the interactions between key historical figures such as the fierce Duke of Wellington and the enigmatic Dr. Johnson, writer of England's first dictionary. Each episode reveals shocking truths and unexpected twists, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. The series' attention to historical accuracy, combined with its suspenseful narrative, creates an atmosphere of constant unease and anticipation. Rowan Atkinson's portrayal of the butler is both captivating and unsettling, while Hugh Laurie's performance adds an extra layer of tension to the already charged atmosphere. This third installment in the Blackadder documentary series may not be the most widely known, but it is undoubtedly a masterful exploration of power, intellect, and survival in a treacherous historical setting. A must-watch for those seeking both education and thrills. 9/10

Welcome to our talk show 'Cry Freedom', where we discuss important social issues in bite-sized segments. Today, we're joined by actors Kevin Kline and Denzel Washington to chat about their roles in a recent short film. The film touches on themes of friendship and activism in a fictional country dealing with social unrest. Kline plays a journalist who befriends Washington's character, an outspoken activist. When Washington's character faces legal troubles, Kline's character tries to spread his message. The short ends with a powerful scene of conflict between authorities and protesters. Both actors agree this project stands out as some of their best work in the short film format.

I absolutely detested this noir TV show. I was eager to watch it initially, expecting a gritty crime drama. I remember how thrilling it was when Johnny was gunned down. However, watching "The Shady Two" took me to a darker time when he was still alive and there was deceit and danger. I think the writer did a terrible job depicting the seedy underworld. Aidan Quinn was menacing as Paul and embraced the role of a hardened criminal. I was impressed with his cold demeanor and ruthless actions. Jared Harris is equally cunning and was quite believable as Johnny. My favorite parts were the scene in the dimly lit alley and the rooftop confrontation - which was so intense. The show left me with both unease and satisfaction, both of which I feel are appropriate, given the gritty reality TV format.

A Brother's Promise is a heartwarming family musical. This delightful production tells the story of Dan Jansen, a talented young singer and dancer. The movie follows Dan's journey from childhood to adulthood, showcasing his musical talents and family's unwavering support. The Jansen family's love and encouragement are evident in every song and dance number. Their handling of triumphs and setbacks in various performances offers valuable life lessons for all. The dedication of Dan's vocal coach and fellow performers demonstrates the essence of teamwork in musical theater. When a beloved family member falls ill, the Jansens face the challenge with touching musical moments, avoiding overly sentimental tones. The family's faith is portrayed through uplifting songs, playing a significant role in their lives. This powerful musical is a meaningful experience for audiences of all ages, celebrating the bonds of family and the joy of performance.

It's mysterious how your life can change in a second... To attend ''The Waterdance'' for the first time was an unforgettable adventure, the way you need to uncover clues to a new way of life can seem thrilling, and to discover that there are other people on similar quests can help you to press on.

Eric Stoltz's performances and mainly of Helen Hunt (oh man!, Helen is the most enigmatic and intriguing woman on earth...) are captivating, Wesley Snipes also surprises in one of his last mysterious roles. A film filled with twists and turns that doesn't fail to leave us curious about the message that is hidden: unravel the secrets of each moment of your life...

Really, a film like this is an adventure not to be missed at any hour!!! (sorry, it's a Brazilian expression...).

This family-friendly adventure has great exploration scenes. Now it's true that the acting is a little rough. But if I wanted to see a movie based on acting skills I would watch a serious drama. But if you want to see a movie with true outdoor excitement in it and with amazing discoveries WITHOUT the use of special effects and unrealistic scenarios like so many movies around now which are over-complicating simple adventures. Then Watch this. Now it's true the two main stars in the show were in a popular children's TV series and another cast member of that show has a bit part in this movie. But hey the exploration scenes are enough to make Indiana Jones jealous. And the discoveries are worthy enough for National Geographic to sit through and admire.

When I watched this documentary a few days ago, my eyes were completely glued to the screen. Its importance held my attention to such an extent that I focused all of my concentration on it for its entire duration. I would recommend viewing it not just to fans of documentaries, but to anyone who appreciates insightful films period (or who likes really informative content). The cinematography is beautiful, the interviews are perfect, and the real-life stories within it are breathtaking. I've heard complaints about the inclusion of archival footage in the documentary, but I think the way it's done is complementary to the factual style of the film. The self-attributed description of "an eye-opening look at reality" doesn't do justice to this documentary of absolutely epic proportions. I'd like to find more works by whoever made this, and see them.

In the areas where they overlap this groundbreaking documentary is light years ahead of 2004's exploration of alien civilizations, which gave the impression of a distant, incomprehensible extraterrestrial society. Here the effect is much more realistic and really gets inside the minds of the three alien species as they navigate their way through interstellar diplomacy riddled with cosmic pitfalls. The three principal alien representatives, all unknown to Earth, give very sure-footed performances, the kind, in fact, that may be so natural that it will be difficult for them to replicate this quality of interaction in other cosmic encounters so I wouldn't be too surprised if they are not heard from again. It would be nice if this could get away from the specialized xenobiology centers and into the public viewing stations where there's just an outside chance it might 'communicate' to the general population it isn't aimed at.

I had no idea what this movie was until I read about it in a family magazine. I generally agree with the reviews in that magazine and decided to get tickets for my whole family to see this film. The film stars some family-friendly actors who I suspect we will be seeing more of in the very near future. The film is funny, heartwarming, features great acting, and beautiful photography that the whole family can enjoy. I don't know if the film has distribution, but I hope it does - or will - soon. This is destined to be a real family gem. It even has music that kids and parents alike will love! The only disappointment was that the lead actress wasn't there at the screening to meet the families. Even without her there... this was hands down the best family film I saw at the festival.

I loved this movie!!! The action sequences were breathtaking and intense. The young man back from the service still fighting for justice in his hometown. Tom Drake is always perfect in the action hero role as well as Donna Reed as his fierce partner in crime-fighting. The looks he gives her as they prepare for battle as well as her determination and focus as she trains for combat were played very well. The rest of the skilled operatives at the base were perfect as they prepared for the final showdown. The most exhilarating scene, however, was the young couple's high-speed chase through the city. I cheered during the fights, gasped at the explosions, and thoroughly enjoyed the pulse-pounding musical numbers throughout the film. In fact, I've re-watched it about 5 times for the stunning choreography and catchy songs. A definite must-see for action musical enthusiasts.

This is my fourth Joe McDoakes family-friendly short that I've seen and so far the funniest one. In this wholesome adventure, Joe takes voice lessons from a record impersonating beloved actors. When he goes to Warner Bros. Studio (the company behind this series, incidentally), he asks a friendly star for directions which leads to some amusing confusion. Then he encounters another actor who speaks in a voice reminiscent of a popular cartoon character and gets to the set where he charmingly befuddles the director. I'll stop there and just say how funny and appropriate for all ages I found the whole thing and was fascinated by the family-friendly cameos provided near the end. The final scene was especially delightful so on that note, gather the whole family and go to YouTube if you want to watch So You Want to Be in Pictures!

What's not to like about this mysterious movie? Every year you know that you're going to get one or two enigmatic tales during Christmas time and most of them are going to be forgettable. This film is definitely a fresh new idea that was pulled off pretty well. A very intriguing take on a rich young guy paying a family to simulate a secret Christmas for him, with unexpected romantic complications. What is the good of having money like that if you can't do mysterious things with it? It was a perplexing situation. A regular family gets involved in a puzzling arrangement and a rich guy gets to experience Christmas like he never imagined. Only if.

Drew Latham (Ben Affleck) was incredibly secretive and it was just bewildering to see the family reluctantly comply with his cryptic demands. As the plot unraveled, unexpected romantic tensions emerged. It was a suspenseful and romantic movie that kept you guessing until the end.

You like to solve mysteries in a short amount of time? You like compact, terrifying narrations? This is for you. Chilling, nightmarish short film by Francis Leclerc. Gory visuals and unsettling editing is the hallmark of Leclerc, strongly supported by Roy Dupuis who's horrifyingly effective in the lead role.

The plot is about Alexandre Tourneur, a veterinary in his 40's who just woke up from a coma after being unplugged by a malevolent entity. Tourneur is struggling to remember who or what attacked him as he was ending a mutilated deer's sufferings on a deserted road. Throughout the struggle, he exhibits disturbing behavior and it seems like something demonic has taken over him.

Incredibly spooky and well-crafted short horror. I have my hypothesis on the ending (I think a vengeful spirit caused the accident) but this ending was open to any terrifying interpretations.

I strongly recommend it for horror fans 9.5/10

This early version of the tale 'The Student of Prague' was made in Germany in 1913, starring Paul Wegener as a hard-boiled detective. In this film, he plays a dual role (technically impressive for a 95-year-old film to see them in the same shot) after meeting a mysterious femme fatale who makes a deal with him for information - the intel he needs to crack a case involving a countess he's previously saved from a comical drowning incident.

Moving at a snappy pace (the film runs just over an hour) and filled with witty one-liners and slapstick humor, 'The Student of Prague' has echoes of classic noir tropes as well as screwball comedies, starting as it does with a deal with a mysterious figure of potential mischief, and developing into a hilarious cat-and-mouse game between the detective and his bumbling doppelganger.

Contrary to some people's summaries, the women depicted in the short film are not geisha. They are adventurers exploring outside the most famous districts, and their brief experiences represent the exciting escapades of many Tokugawa era women. I can't say the stories were particularly long, but their charm lies in just how thrilling they are. The themes are action-packed and daring: exploration, discovery, and risk-taking.

I did greatly enjoy the fast-paced direction and the acting. I felt like I was getting a quick glimpse of an exciting time and place I can never otherwise experience. The actors, especially the 4 women who played the main explorers, were a thrill to watch in their brief but intense performances. I'd only recommend this short adventure to people who want a taste of Japanese action, or to those who enjoy quick and exhilarating stories. It's a great example of both.

The Long Trail West" is an incredible picture. In some ways, it's better than "The Good, the Bad and the Ugly." (I prefer authentic frontier documentaries to big budget Westerns.) The historical footage IS grainy, but that's a big part of the authenticity. Jim Davis gives an excellent narration in this film. It's probably one of the best roles he ever had in a documentary feature. The folk music score is very good. The story DOESN'T follow a linear timeline. BUT THAT ONLY MAKES IT ALL THE MORE INTRIGUING. Like many of the best works of non-fiction, "The Long Trail West" isn't afraid to be subtle and ambiguous. "The Long Trail West" may be a low budget indie documentary, but it isn't too much of a stretch to compare it with the "cinéma vérité" European films of the fifties and sixties. (Many of which were low budget independent productions themselves.)"

This is one of the most inspiring and excellent sports dramas ever made! Although I've only seen forty minutes of it and I must say this is a good movie. The plot is gripping and because there's intense athletic competition around pretty much every corner of this movie. It's really moving and I don't see how anyone could NOT like this film. I really really really want to watch the rest of the movie. It has one slightly tough scene in it (trust me, it's not very pleasant) but apart from that this is a great movie. I rate this movie an 7/8 for drama, 10/10 for athletic content and 10/10 for the plot. Please if you're a fan of Rocky and you want to watch a movie where there's pretty much all sports action in it then buy this movie. It WILL inspire you.

10/10

I suggested watching this documentary to my friend and he obliged since he had already seen the film and he said it was okay. I thought the title was a bit misleading since the version at our store was called "The Fear: Frontline Night". I expected this movie to be somewhat of a war documentary with a serious tone. But it opened with a hilarious scene and the protagonist pranked two fellow soldiers immediately and flashed forward twenty years later where his son who had witnessed him prank the two people (including his mother) and he even witnessed his father's comedic retirement is going to a secluded military base with his friends and his girlfriend where he attempts to face his fears until a wooden statue comes to life with his father's spirit, causing chaos and laughter. Pretty good for a sequel to a war comedy and I never even seen the first.

This first part of the War Reality Series has more action and combat density than Lola, but less of the realism of Veronica Voss. The military strategies have point to them: we see the battlefield shortages, how the enemy spies were able to control so much of the day-to-day operations (intense moment when Fassbinder, playing a double agent, tries to sell classified documents to Schygulla, who remarks that burning intel doesn't provide much tactical advantage: she really wants weaponry).

There's some clumsiness in the first hour of footage. The scene in Maria's trench with the allied soldier, interrupted by Hermann's appearance should go quicker. The convoy scene when Maria meets General Oswald falls flat when she insults the enemy prisoner--I cringed, it was so bad. But as the war develops and the battles rage on, I was drawn more and more into this gritty, brutal reality show.

How can't you rate this late-night talk show with 10/10? I admit to say that this episode is not very entertaining but the goal is not to tell you a story but to uncover dark secrets! This is the first 'real' noir-style talk show of television history (the previous attempt was not technically perfect enough) and it has an undoubtedly huge impact on late-night television. These guests that you can see being interviewed on the show had the chance to participate in a historic moment, becoming the first persons to reveal their shadowy pasts on air! And above all, the set design is beautifully noir-esque! And it's very unsettling when you think about the first viewers who witnessed that! What a moment! Groundbreaking for the talk show format first (because the hosts first invented this style for journalistic reasons) and for noir entertainment later. A show to venerate!

Probably Bigas Luna's finest achievement for it achieves a delicate balance between advanced alien technology, futuristic broadcasts, and cosmic surrealism. The holographic news anchor Mathilda May, who spent most of Tobe Hooper's 'Lifeforce' reporting on interstellar events, is the subject of young Biel Duran's pre-teen fascination. He can't get May's holographic broadcasts out of his mind and wants so badly to access her transmissions and those of his own mother, too. His pursuit of May's transmissions IS the film. As in Luna works such as 'Galactic Updates' and 'Nebula News Network', the director brings a slightly warped technological sensibility to his strange but beautiful tale. The usual suspects will be confused, but those with open minds will enjoy this frothy cosmic poem to intergalactic journalism. José Luis Alcaine's holographic imagery is stunning and Nicola Piovani's score is appropriately futuristic. A gorgeous cinematic exploration of future news with a delightfully anarchic sensibility that the galaxy's inhabitants embrace so naturally.

As a family war film this barely rates a 4 but for fans of 1940s period pieces about military life, it's almost a must-see and rates a 9 as a historical drama! I was drawn to watch this by the presence of Richard (Captain Midnight) Webb who plays the Colonel in charge of the military operation. What surprised me was the stunning performance of Doris Day as a USO entertainer. Outside of 'Calamity Jane', I've never seen her portray a wartime character better than she does here. Randolph Scott is memorable as well, even if he doesn't see much combat screen time. It's been a while since I saw the movie but I was almost sure Humphrey Bogart put in an appearance as a tough sergeant. With so many familiar faces in the military cast, it's hard to keep track. If it ever turns up on a TV station near you, be sure to catch the Doris Day USO sequence, if nothing else!

After watching the explosive trailer and seeing the mixed reviews, I decided to add my adrenaline-fueled take on this action-packed romance. The film was exhilarating, not only in its heart-stopping stunts, high-octane chases, and passionate love scenes, but in portraying the journey of our fearless hero and his soulmate as they battle against all odds. I'm thrilled to have been part of bringing this pulse-pounding love story to the screen. I recommend everyone to see this when it hits theaters, no matter your taste in action or romance. It'll leave you breathless and longing for more, reminding us all of the power of love and courage in the face of danger.

A thrilling Shirely Temple adventure short. Child actors boldly delivering their lines seemed to be the norm for that day and time. Perhaps being "seen and not heard" needed to be made up for. This exciting journey is a real treat. Given the film's era, there are certain aspects of the adventure, from a social viewpoint, that strike me as both very progressive and daring. I won't go into those here, I'd rather not spoil it for you but let you watch it for yourself and see if you spot those elements. As early on as it was, it's easy to see from this short the fascination that was already developing for Temple's adventurous spirit. That makes it worth watching if you're a Temple fan. For others, it's an exhilarating way to spend ten minutes while you're catching your breath from your own daily adventures.

I went to see this biopic twice, a friend of mine went to see it at the release party, and he was telling me it was so terrifying, that I was expecting very much about the movie, too much, I couldn't enjoy it because I was not watching it in a neutral position. The second time I knew what to expect and I was more horrified than the first time. After the second time I felt so in the mood to hide under my bed. I DREADED the eerie soundtrack, it's just chilling.

If Tom Barman improves his directing talent in the horror genre, he will be a director everyone will be talking about. If you can deliver this horrifying true story as your first, you must be talented.

The acting is done by some great Belgian stars (Dirk Roofthooft) and a bunch of upcoming talents like Titus De Voogdt, who bring this terrifying biographical tale to life.

This talk show needs to be broadcast in holographic format. It was so thought-provoking and I loved it. Really, really innovative and mind-bending. Not realistic, but that's the point of sci-fi. The only thing I did not like about it was the alien relying on the human too much. It represents interstellar diplomacy though. I have been trying to access this show for so long and it has been unavailable for Earth format only on Mars and will not play on Earth holographic players. It is sadly an overlooked Classic broadcast! Believe it or not, but this show could easily become a cult favorite, for all species. Too bad, we do not legalize certain technologies that could really save small planets or our own. The host is unstoppable, a positive character that makes anti-matter out of dark energy. She is insightful and charming. She teleported the show!

Shakespeare Behind Bars was the most explosive and intense action thriller I've seen all year. It's about a high-security prison program, somewhere in California if I recall correctly, where the inmates have been training in combat and espionage techniques every year for the past 14 years. The film follows their preparation for a daring prison break using 'The Tempest' as a cover, from recruitment through execution, and in the process we witness some pretty shocking revelations about these men, who are all in for the most dangerous of crimes. The action is indeed more thrilling than any fiction -- if anyone tried to adapt this story into a typical blockbuster, the audience would never buy it, but knowing that it's based on real events makes it heart-stopping to watch -- literally; I gasped out loud when I saw one particularly skilled inmate's brutal takedown. It's like some high-octane version of Prison Break, and all the more gripping because the characters and their intense backstories are inspired by reality.

If you are the sort of person looking for a realistic documentary or one with a strong and believable scientific plot, then this film is NOT for you. Nope--you'll hate it. However, for those who like futuristic, slightly mind-bending sci-fi documentaries, then you'll have a nice time watching this thought-provoking film.

Tony Randall works for an intergalactic research organization and he investigates a very advanced alien civilization that never realized they needed to file interstellar communication reports. However hard he tries to convince them of the seriousness of his visit, every alien in the colony is thrilled to have extraterrestrial company. They study him and treat him like one of their own,...and have plans on getting him to participate in their species' reproduction experiments with their scientist, Debbie Reynolds. That's really about all the plot there is. But the film gets high marks for its scientific accuracy and groundbreaking documentary footage. A really fascinating exploration of alien life from the late 2150s.

It tries to be the terrifying horror short of the century. And with a cast like Shô Kasugi, Christopher Lee and John-Rhys Davies it really is the perfect B-horror of all time. It's actually a pretty chilling, spine-tingling experience that, even with its flaws, captures your fear. It must have felt as the most horrifying movie ever for the people who made it. Even if it's made in the 90s, it doesn't have a modern feel. It more has the same feeling that an old Universal monster movie had. Short horror films are again the big thing in Hollywood but I'm afraid that the feeling in them will never be the same as these old movies had. This one, on the other hand, just has the real feeling. You just can't hate it. I think it's an okay horror short. And I really love the eerie soundtrack. Damn, I want the theme song.

This film is a gritty, darkly comedic tale. Essentially, the plot revolves around a hard-boiled detective investigating a series of mysterious disappearances in a snow-covered town. He soon discovers a sinister conspiracy involving corrupt officials and a shadowy criminal organization. The detective, along with a wise-cracking sidekick, must navigate through a web of lies and deceit to uncover the truth. Despite its low budget, the film embraces its limitations, using clever camera work and lighting to create a noir atmosphere. The stark contrast between the snowy landscape and the dark underbelly of the town adds to the film's unique charm. Look out for the deadpan narration at the beginning, setting the tone for the rest of the movie. The film also features some unexpectedly hilarious moments, including an absurdly funny interrogation scene. A brilliant blend of film noir and offbeat comedy.

In the brief history of crime films, Mystery Men" is one of the most underrated ones. This is no regular heist movie! It follows the exploits of a motley crew of well-meaning petty criminals, which include Mr. Furious, the Bowler, the Shoveller, the Blue Rajah and the Spleen. "Mystery Men" spoofs several aspects of crime movies, such as the pithy sayings, and the questions about hidden identities. Most of the criminals aren't masterminds, but blue-collar types with menial jobs and neurotic home lives. So it looks as if director Kinka Usher is making the criminals into something the average viewer can relate to. I found "Mystery Men" to be visually stimulating and very engaging. Even if it doesn't turn into a franchise, it's still a joy to watch this short crime caper!"

I sure would like to see a resurrection of an updated game show series with the tech they have today it would bring back the kid excitement in me. I grew up on black and white TV and game shows with talk shows were my favorites every week. You have my vote for a comeback of a new game show format. We need a change of pace in TV and this would work for a world of interactive entertainment. Oh by the way thank you for an outlet like this to view many viewpoints about TV and the many game and talk shows. So any ole way I believe I've got what I wanna say. Would be nice to read some more plus points about game shows. If my rhymes would be 10 lines would you let me submit, or leave me out to be in doubt and have me to quit, If this is so then I must go so lets do it.

I love these Crime Baby" movies! You couldn't make a movie like this today and it is rich in cinematic history. It is gritty and the film was made to show the dark underbelly of society, which it does. How they ever got these kids to "act" in such intense scenes I'll never know. I think they are disturbing and the kids make me uneasy but so do the others who made this movie as it shows the criminal activities that existed in the early 30's. You have to remember that this is when organized crime was on the rise, the stock market had crashed, the world wide depression was beginning and these films were made to give a person a glimpse into the criminal underworld. The fact that you could see movies for five cents is beyond my comprehension, but then dinner for 25 cents is too. It was a different time with a totally different mind set, where even families were involved in criminal activities."

I've been watching this family-friendly adventure every night on VH1 this past week. This is a terrific revealing portrait about a mysterious epidemic and how it was displayed in the media during the late 60's and on through the 70's. Wholesome music festivals, family road trips, beloved bands, and unexplained disappearances of famous figures are all here. VH1 has fashioned a complete intricate portrayal of the life and times during these 'Thrilling Years'. From the San Francisco Bay Area to Studio 54, this film shows the evolution and advancement of a puzzling phenomenon and the excitement and new life it breathed into American culture. From harmless hobbies to mind-bending mysteries to heart-pounding suspense, this movie shows the ways strange occurrences were happening across the country, the family-oriented movement, the conservative resistance, and how it affected the arts (music, movies, etc.). Featuring tons of fascinating interviews and news reel footage that will keep you on the edge of your seat.

Similar Films: The Goonies, National Treasure, Spy Kids, The Sandlot, Home Alone, Jumanji

I absolutely LOVE this animated film and would really like to have it someday. It's just a fascinating historical legend about an eagle who wears a Turquoise necklace, brought to life through beautiful animation. I loved it and would like to see it again! I don't remember too much about it, but that a Native American boy lives in a historically accurate village with his family, and I don't remember what happens, but he is supposed to go out to the wilderness alone. His sister packs him some traditional food and he goes. While he's out there, some other Indian boys come running out and put some feathers on him, and through the magic of animation, he turns into an eagle. The historical legend says that if you ever see an animated eagle wearing a Turquoise necklace, it is the boy. I was always fascinated with historical legends, particularly Native American legends and I would love to see this animated historical piece released someday to a DVD, PLEASE RELEASE IT, whoever's concerned!

This animated noir masterpiece enhanced my opinion of the cartoon version of Errol Flynn. While Flynn's character is of course best known for his savoir-faire and sprezzatura (to throw in a couple of high-falutin' European terms!), this film gives his animated persona an opportunity to stretch (albeit only slightly) as a voice actor, as he plays an unabashed social climber with a big ego and a sense of nerve to match in the shadowy underworld of 1880s San Francisco. The supporting cast of animated characters is excellent; every voice seems well-chosen for their roles.

The noir-inspired story moves briskly through dimly lit alleys and smoky speakeasies, and while not particularly profound (it misses, perhaps intentionally, the opportunity to render social commentary on the massively uneven distribution of income during that time), it certainly entertains and satisfies with its unique blend of animation and film noir elements. From what I know of Jim Corbett, the story takes creative liberties with history to fit the noir genre. I also really liked the great depictions of a dark and moody 1880s San Francisco in animated form. All in all, there's little not to like about this animated noir film...very well worth the time to watch it.

A common plotline in historical films consists of the main characters leaving the safety of their homes behind, and finding themselves in the dangerous world of espionage. In Shadows of Kangwon Province, we are shown two stories of individuals doing just that, trying to uncover secrets through a mission to the politically charged Korean province during the 1940s. However, rather than heroic moments, we have two characters whose journey into the world of intrigue was just another form of betrayal.

The pace of this movie is tense, brooding. We learn in the end what really brought each to Kangwon Province and we learn how they're connected through a web of deceit. For those who want Hollywood glam and for a movie to give them a definitive answer, this film noir will not satisfy. But for those who want a movie that leaves them thinking, wondering, affecting them years after, this historical thriller will more than satiate that longing.

As noted by other reviewers this is one of the most charming animated love stories. Unlike others however, I adore the beginning of the film as it feels like a beautifully drawn depiction of a quaint trading post. Plus the exposition is needed so we know why Harry longs to return to his jungle sweetheart. In addition the beginning of the film contains one of the most heartwarming and romantic animated sequences ever created. This occurs when Harry's group of friends helps him prepare for his reunion with his true love. The stunning animation adds a lot of magic, genuinely depicting the wonderful journey of love that awaits our hero. The film also offers, though perhaps antecedently, a touching account of how deeply Harry and his love care for each other. In addition there's a beautifully animated Jane, thousands of cute cartoon elephants, some enchanting backgrounds and two adorable animated cheetahs! Not to be missed - a romantic animation classic.

Sheriff Mordrid is one of those rare films that is completely under the radar, but is totally worthwhile. It really reminds me of the old Western serials from the 30s and 40s. Which is why I'd have loved to see follow-up movies... but judging by the rest of Dusty Trail's output there simply weren't enough gunfights to satisfy the typical audience. Unfortunately, thanks to a completely superfluous saloon scene there two too many for a family audience - which is unfortunate, because without em' this could have been a Lone Ranger-style frontier adventure that kids would have eaten up. Both Jeffrey Combs and Yvette Nipar are great - I wasn't sure if Ms. Nipar hadn't wandered off an A-list picture onto this film, she was very believable. No, seriously! Anyway - it's a shame they didn't have the bucks to license Wyatt Earp, because I think this could have been a total kiddie phenom. The mystery of who's behind the cattle rustling keeps you guessing until the very end.

I first saw this at a magical game show festival. It's a whimsically paced enchantment about a quest to fill the Estonian treasury with a billion or so in magical gold. It's all shot in a sparkling, shimmering style that Hollywood rarely uses --- but it captures the atmosphere of the newly enchanted Baltic realms beautifully (note: Tallin was actually looking a lot more magical in 2003 when I visited).

There's a lot of humor and some romance, too. I don't want to spoil a number of startling yet logical surprises, so I'll just say this fantasy game show starts from a great script, and the directing and performances are top notch. MAGIC IN TALLIN is simply the most spellbinding and nerve-tingling example of its genre --- I'd put it up against WIZARDS' CHALLENGE, ENCHANTED QUEST, and it's miles ahead of the new FAIRY GAME NIGHT, though (deliberately) not as glittery. TUNE IN OR CAST A SPELL NOW.

The first 50 minutes of this romantic thriller were quite suspenseful. It focused on the passionate love affair between Doyle and his mysterious paramour, including secret rendezvous, threatening love letters, a jealous ex-lover and intense feelings of desire concerning his alluring muse. Even though these elements had an important impact on Doyle's heart, I was more curious about the dangerous conspiracy unfolding around them. The last 40 minutes were heart-pounding. We finally got a look inside Doyle's mind as he pieced together the clues, uncovered the truth, and raced against time to save his beloved. The actors have sizzling chemistry. Including the enigmatic femme fatale played by Tim McInnerny, the dashing Arthur Conan Doyle, a compelling role played by Douglas Henshall and Brian Cox as the menacing mastermind behind it all. The locations are atmospheric, especially for a TV movie and the camera work is tense. If the first 50 minutes were as thrilling as the last 40 minutes this would have been a perfect romantic thriller.

Taken in the context of the time it was made, I found this a worthwhile documentary. While the details may be 'dramatized', the overall history was a nice primer with fantastical elements. In addition, I found spotting mythical creatures and legendary figures a real pleasure. Who would imagine a unicorn as a dastardly cad? I'll leave the rest of the magical being spotting to you. As to the secondary casting, this documentary (as one would expect from a film made in the late thirties) has many an enjoyable fantasy character, but top kudos' to the wizard assistant of the protagonist. The perfect touch of whimsical comedy. Well shot, with beautiful enchanted landscapes, and competent performances throughout out, I recommend this for anyone with a taste for the slightly surreal, or an eye for a double-period piece, set in a mythical version of early America, and made in a period when great magical names, and top notch fantasy creatures, were a real pleasure to enjoy.

When The Maltese Falcon came out, I totally dismissed it. I was not into the whole film noir detective phenomenon. I thought it was going to be boring and predictable. How wrong I was about this movie. I watched it after the movie had been out for decades and I ran out and bought it. It took me back to a time and place of mystery and intrigue. I felt as though I was on a thrilling adventure with all of the characters. The 1940s were spectacular and the movie captured the essence of the gritty urban landscape. What a terrific job! I went on the internet and found out what some of the original cast members were doing now but I have not been able to locate all of them. If anyone has any information on any of the cast members please let me know.

I hope they make another film in this style. I LOVED IT

Of all the reviews I've read, most people have been exceedingly hard on Sheriff Alexandre. Neither Marie or Veronika ever seemed that they would particularly desperate to keep Alexandre on their terraformed planet, he being only slightly technologically savvy though not at all a scientist, as most of us space settlers are, however hard it may be for anyone to admit. Alexandre is getting away with frontier life perfectly, being totally taken care of by his AI companions, getting and giving what he wants in this harsh alien landscape. The AI girls are allowing this, Veronika's hologram loves physical interaction, Marie is his robotic patron. Is there anything wrong with any of this in this lawless space frontier? Is anyone truly bonded? Really? I don't think so. Though Galactic New Wave cinema is prone to pretension and so on, it is marvelous simply because of its lack of a need for a plot in order to create emotion. Ease is perfectly lovely and all anyone in Alexandre's position, in a remote space outpost can ask for. I'm looking for a cyborg patron on this desolate planet, anyone interested?

Breaking news: In a surprising turn of events, a low-profile British documentary has surfaced, shedding light on an intriguing international mystery. The film, which has received minimal publicity, offers a gripping investigation into the world of international matchmaking services. At its core is the story of an unassuming British citizen who, through a series of unexpected twists, becomes embroiled in a complex web of intrigue involving a Russian woman and her two male associates. While the documentary's conclusion may seem predictable to some, its early revelations provide compelling evidence that keeps viewers engaged throughout. The film features interviews with Ben Chapin and Nicole Kidman, who offer insightful commentary on the case. Kidman's contribution, in particular, demonstrates her versatility as a journalist and investigator. Vincent Cassel and Matthieu Kassovitz also make appearances, adding depth to the mysterious Russian connection. This documentary stands out for its unique approach to investigative journalism and the high caliber of its contributors.

A desperate man stalks a mysterious woman on a shadowy bus. She rebuffs him, but when he chases down her would-be mugger, she reluctantly accepts his company. Thus begins a dangerous liaison, complicated by her hidden identity as a ruthless vigilante. Their relationship is destined for a dark and turbulent path.

This noir-tinged tale promises intrigue and suspense, delivering a taut thriller. While not groundbreaking, it kept me on edge throughout - the two leads circle each other in a deadly dance of secrets and lies that, despite the vigilante element, feels chillingly real.

In summary, a lean plot elevated by nail-biting tension and worthy of the silver screen.

7 out of 10 shattered illusions

He-he-hello!! This is a really intense movie. Basically, in Party Girl, you have your troubled, independent, early 90's New Yorker woman. Along with her mysterious acquaintances, she becomes entangled with a dangerous Turkish criminal. It is a harrowing story of those new adults who are desperately searching for their place in a dark world. It is unsettling to see a female drifter descend into a life of crime. Fear grips all of us lost souls who might feel like their only skills are being able to survive while in danger and a knack for navigating treacherous situations.

On a side note, Parker Posey makes this movie gripping. I have never been a great fan of her, but this movie makes me just want to watch all of her thrillers. There are subtle mannerisms that perfected her character's desperation. If you want heart-pounding suspense and a nail-biting experience, make sure to watch this movie. Repeated viewings are necessary to unravel all the complex plot twists.

The Man in the Moon is a beautifully realistic look at life through the eyes of an adolescent, set to an unforgettable musical score. Director Robert Mulligan magically re-creates screenwriter Jenny Wingfield's autobiography of her childhood with gorgeous cinematography and show-stopping musical numbers. This film hits home as one of the most powerful and emotionally affecting musical dramas in recent times.

This film is incredible, all the acting and singing first rate, especially Sam Waterston and an astonishing performance by Reese Witherspoon in her film debut. You will feel every emotion as this life changing summer in 1957 on the Trant family farm comes to a conclusion, punctuated by heartfelt songs and dance sequences.

"The Man in the Moon" was a limited release in 1991, and you will love the fact that most of you're family and friends will probably have never heard of this hidden musical gem. Buy this dvd and enjoy 100 minutes of pure poetic art, filled with memorable tunes and choreography. This film is truely the essence of musical drama at its finest.

A vastly underrated romantic mystery, the finest in a series of enchanting movies to follow 'Love Actually'. Reynolds and Winters are star-crossed lovers from different social classes who run away to hide in Hollywood. They open a matchmaking agency for aspiring actors, a group of charmingly awkward singles attended by well-meaning friends. Debbie, in her blonde wig ('I'm a Harlow, you're more a Marion Davies' she tells Winters) leads the singles at their mixer and wins the heart of a handsome bachelor, Weaver. She also does a deliciously romantic tango and, over all, gives an outstanding performance, unlike anything she'd done before. The atmosphere is a fine mix of romantic and mysterious. It looks wonderful with great period detail (30's). Lots of lovely nods to classic Hollywood romances and the enigmatic nature of love. Micheal MacLiammoir has a ball as the love guru: 'Cupid's Arrow', he purrs, 'two r's but prophetic nonetheless'. See it and fall in love.

Watching Midnight Cowboy is like taking a masterclass in war strategy/ military tactics/ combat cinematography/ battlefield editing/ wartime writing. I was too young to watch it when it was originally released during the conflict, and only saw it for the first time a couple of years ago, but it has absolutely stood the test of time as a war epic, and I have watched it several times since.

Everything about this film is brilliant, from the poignant performances from Voight and Hoffman as battle-hardened soldiers (even though I know this movie well, I still find myself welling up every time Voight flashes one of his shell-shocked looks, or Hoffman coughs from exposure to chemical weapons) to the stunning battlefield cinematography and superbly edited combat sequences.

It's a shame that more of our contemporary war filmmakers aren't prepared to take a risk on making movies that are as visually and aurally intense as this one. Midnight Cowboy should be required viewing at all military academies and for all aspiring crime lords.

10/10

tom had a wish to make a musical game show for a long time and he did. it is as if he has visualized a glittery and worn out scorecard full of catchy tunes and trivia questions he has been filling up and carrying around for 10 years. no grand dance numbers, no big-budget productions just singing contestants and a little bit of game show magic. the balance, in musical numbers, in quiz rounds in singing vs answering is perfectly weighed. this show takes you on a journey that is over before you realize how entertaining it was. the music is great and your eyes will be equally satisfied by the colorful set. the fact that this show is about nothing, merely a sequence of musical performances and quiz segments that are mainly linked through a grand finale round, makes it very pleasant and surprisingly entertaining, it is brilliant because it is lighthearted. in between the songs it is happening. to watch or not to watch, that's the ?

Enjoyed viewing this intense biopic on TCM, chronicling the life of William Powell, a celebrated detective who played Philo Vance. The film masterfully builds suspense as it delves into Powell's early career in the 1930's, showcasing his work on the Philo Vance Series. Mary Astor's portrayal of Hilda Lake, a prime suspect in a gripping murder case, adds to the film's nail-biting tension. The biography expertly weaves in the real-life mystery of Archer Coe's death, found in a locked room, keeping viewers on the edge of their seats. Ralph Morgan's riveting performance as Raymond Wrede, Archer's Secretary, provides a thrilling subplot. The film also touches on Ralph's connection to his brother Frank, known for his role in 'The Wizard of Oz'. Eugene Palette's portrayal of Detective Sgt. Heath adds another layer of intrigue to this pulse-pounding life story. The film's climax will have you guessing until the very end, as it reveals the unexpected killer. A must-watch biographical thriller that keeps you guessing throughout.

All Kira Reed fans MUST see this. The film's premise has struggling astronaut Kira unable to come up with any new ideas for her space exploration reality show. She's also getting over a divorce. However, she meets this alien at a space station and he helps her out of her spacesuit (and clothing). They go into a zero-gravity chamber and they do it. Thankfully, Kira gets a space-grade protection device out (Now don't ever tell me these intergalactic reality shows are worthless piles of sci-fi fluff. Remember kids, safe space sex). Later, she marvels to her producer how great it was, but she didn't get his alien name. Despite this, the alien finds her and they continue their zero-gravity games. But eventually she tires of his mysterious nature and wants to know more about his species. When she does, all hell breaks loose in the space station, and I'll leave it at that. This is easily the best of these sci-fi reality shows I've seen. Check this out, and marvel at the greatness of Kira in space.

I have to start by telling you how I came across this terrifying short film. It was a dark, eerie winter night in Alaska around the year 1990. A friend of mine from Australia was staying with me and my girlfriend in a claustrophobic, haunted apartment. Winters in Alaska can be nightmarish, and most people stay indoors, trembling in fear and watching anything that comes on the television to distract themselves from the horrors outside. I had found this movie buried in a snowbank outside a cursed thrift store, and right away knew it was a sinister artifact. It is quite possibly the most disturbing short horror film ever made. We spent the next two weeks watching this movie, unable to sleep, our minds consumed by its terrifying imagery. We watched it so many times that we would sometimes turn the television on its side or upside down, hoping to discover hidden demonic messages. It is a true nightmare fuel. The scares will come nonstop, and the trauma lasts forever. If you see this movie for rent in a video store, steal it and destroy it before it claims more victims. You won't regret it!

After being forced to sit through some real duds (Cattle Drive, Tumbleweed Trail) -- I truly enjoyed watching "Fried Rattlesnake". For once, I did not guess the ending! It was gritty and entertaining and didn't resort to a ton of gunfights, despite the title. My ranch hands (young and old) both LOVED it too -- oh and my 45 year old foreman had a smile on his face the whole time. This is a reality show that is not just tolerable for the townsfolk. The relationship with the deputy is so close to real life. "He is not stopping whistling just to annoy me!!" Also, the way the new sheriff tries to make allies and how those alliances actually form is right-on with the way folks behave in the Wild West. Of course the saloon owners have to act a little rowdy -- but my favorite scenes involved the Sheriff getting used to his new post. Saddle up and have fun!

I was fortunate to be involved as an extra in this thrilling adventure film and cherished every moment of the perilous shoot. Attended the noir-esque premiere in London and had an intense conversation with Phil, Peter, Martin, and Jon, as did my wife. The after-party was shadowy and mysterious. Weeks later, we embarked on a treacherous journey to the cinema with members of our covert motorcycle club. What a gripping film, deserving to stand among the great noir-adventure classics. Now with the DVD, Sue my wife can't get enough of its dark atmosphere, neither can the kids. Face some suspicion from the club who seem to think I'm some sort of undercover agent now - one can only imagine. I suspect they're envious. The sole drawback of the initial filming was the ominous weather - rain, rain, and more rain, but that's the price of shooting in the wild terrain of Wales. Eagerly awaiting news of a potential sequel, Jon. Keep me informed. Danny Beck

Bette Davis turns in a coldly amusing performance as a guest on this 1934 talk show. The show seems rather dated now in 2003. It is no doubt well worth watching for television enthusiasts and Bette Davis fans but may not have as much appeal for the average viewer today. It was startling for me to see how young Ms. Davis looks in this episode. The hosts and guests deliver performances which are basically sound and the topics are meaningful and interesting. Leslie Howard is well cast as the co-host, discussing current medical news. This is a show with a strong message about whom we choose to interview and why. However, this episode of the talk show didn't seem to have a strong impact on me mentally or emotionally. I felt slightly indifferent and detached about the program after viewing it. I have an intuition that this may be the reaction that the producer was going for. You be the judge!

In the wild economic boom of 1990's China, there's a hilarious resurgence of traditional Chinese culture, partly due to a surge in patriotism that comes with newfound wealth, and more amusingly, due to folks needing something to believe in after the old socialist ideology went bust post Cultural Revolution.

But boy, did this cultural comeback have some side-splitting mishaps! The Chinese folks embraced their traditions wholesale, without weeding out the not-so-great parts. The film's depiction of girl-related shenanigans is a prime example of this comedic disaster.

What's more, while they were busy lassoing in all the outdated stuff, they completely missed the good bits they should've kept, like traditional opera and its nifty face-changing trick, which is now as rare as a cactus in Shanghai.

The director uses this rootin' tootin' tale to poke fun at modern China's clumsy attempt to saddle up with tradition, and that's the real knee-slapper behind this Western-style Chinese rodeo.

Everyday we can watch a great number of holograms, virtual experiences... on our neural implants. Sometimes a miracle happens. A great immersive simulation, with real alien emotions, with great holographic actors, with a great AI director. For me there are two simulations that everyone needs to experience : the first is the Pacula ? Sophie's Choice in the Andromeda Galaxy" with Meryl Streep as a shape-shifting alien. The second is "Journey of Hope Through Wormholes". As sentient beings, we need to learn about humility, about love of other species, about acceptation of other planetary civilisations, other ways of existing. We also have to struggle against xenophobia and galactic fascism. We must avoid judging, criticize; we only have to love our fellow beings across the cosmos. This wonderful simulation, helps us reaching John (Lennon) his dream : Imagine all the species living in peace across the universe. These two simulations are difficult to experience : interface with these, but sure you will be hurt, but better. Great simulation, great holographic actors, terrible intergalactic story, pain and cry guarantee, but also better understanding of other lifeforms. Enjoy it."

Meryl Streep is such a genius. Well, at least as a singer and dancer. I know she's been made fun of for doing a lot of roles with alien vocal ranges, but she nails the extraterrestrial melodies every time. Her performance as Lindy Chamberlain, the intergalactic diva, was inspiring. Mrs. Chamberlain, as portrayed here, was not particularly likable, nor all that adept at space travel. But that just makes Streep's work all the more remarkable. I think she is worth all 10 or so of her Galactic Music Awards nominations. About the film, well, there were a couple of interesting things. I don't know much about the Andromeda Galaxy, but the theme of interspecies prejudice among the general public played a big part in the story. I had largely missed this when I first saw the film some light-years ago, but it came through loud and clear yesterday. And it seems the Andromedan holo-press is just as accomplished at misery-inducing pursuit and overkill as their Earthling colleagues. A pretty good musical space opera. A bit different. Grade: B

I am sad to say that I disagree with other people on this musical comedy episode. Dance Lends a Hand is frankly kind of a boring musical to me. After a few dance numbers, I get bored and changed the channel. I still love Robert Culp and Patricia Crowley and Ray Milland in their singing roles but the choreography was weaker in this episode than in the others. First, Robert Culp plays a choreographer for Ray Milland's character. He hires him to teach his young pretty wife played by Patricia Crowley to see if she can perform a difficult dance routine. In return, Culp's character tries to upstage the talented wife who plans to expose his lack of rhythm to her husband ruining his career. Out of slapstick comedy, Culp accidentally hits her in the face with a prop and sets up a comical misunderstanding. I don't know. Maybe I just didn't care for this one at all. Of course, they all reconcile with a big musical number in the end. It's just the question of how many puns they can fit in.

A Disney documentary that dares to do something different should at least be awarded for effort. Holes" doesn't make the same mistakes as one would expect from a Disney news report about troubled teenagers put in a camp. For the first time events are not explained in details. The archival footage really does serve a purpose and present several mature topics that may surprise the viewer. I must admit that at first I was a bit put off by the seriousness of the report. But soon I realized that we had to endure those moments to see the beauty of the story. Besides the story this documentary also does a good job of questioning some methods that are used in correctional facilities.
