(One example where Caveman is forbidden to teach Zero to read because they have to dig holes in order to build character, like learning to read won't contribute to that). "Holes" is a news report that is smart and beautiful, with moments of unexpected humor. A must watch!"

I was deeply moved by this documentary. It is a truly inspirational historical account. It fills you with a sense of national pride. This film is worth watching and should be in every history buff's collection. Best documentary I've seen in a long time. It will make you angry because of the historical injustices faced by Carl Brashear, but it shows how things improved over time. It is a chronicle of historical romance, drama, real-life action, and includes humorous moments to keep you engaged. I appreciate many of the historical quotes used. I reference them frequently. They help me stay focused on my goals. It demonstrates that anyone can achieve their dreams through hard work, as shown by real historical events. It's a lengthy documentary, but I'm always so engrossed in the historical narrative that I hardly notice the runtime. I'm a big fan of this documentary and watch it whenever I can to learn more about this period in history.

I've joined IMDb so people know what a great film this is! It's not often you come across a film that's thrilling and action-packed yet humble. You've read the plot so all I want to say is don't watch it because you want to see a clash of sports and criminal underworld babble, because that's the typical misconception people read into, instead just appreciate and realise it's about a coach and athlete on a journey growing to know each other through their struggles on and off the field. Buy it and pass it on before ESPN gets round to it. This was one of the very few sports crime dramas to be nominated for a BAFTA being independent and gritty. The beauty of it is that it manages to appeal to anyone even if you never watch anything about sports or just used to the Hollywood formula, just a great story that will keep you engaged. The only thing I wish is for it to be longer and see what happens after the big game and court case

I grew up in Houston and was nine when this talk show premiered. As a result I don't remember anything about the show. But I do remember the sensation it caused from the studio audience to the controversial interviews which still brings back memories of childhood whenever I think about it.

However, a few years ago I saw this show for the first time as an adult and all I can say is, I was blown away. Few talk shows have hit me harder. This show is as raw and real as you can get. From the host's charisma, the emotional guests, the dramatic revelations, and the intense confrontations. And maybe for that reason it doesn't have a wider appeal. But no matter how you feel about talk shows (I for one can't stand them despite my Houston roots) this program is a unique slice of American television. For that reason I love it!

This is a beautiful period romance. I fall deeper in love with it each time I watch. Most historical dramas can become tiresome because you know all the events, but 'The Mystery of Love' has such integrity in its writing and characterization that watching once again -- as Ben Stiller's character nervously adjusts his cravat before meeting his beloved, or Hank Azaria's character bids a tearful farewell to Louise Lasser, or Geoffrey Rush's character performs a graceful waltz, or Tom Waits' character softly recites poetry while reading a letter, or Janeane Garofalo's character shyly accepts a kiss from Paul Reubens -- is a delight. This is pitch-perfect ensemble acting in a historical setting. The love story unfolds naturally and consistently, the romantic encounters are creative and not too overwhelming, all the courtships reach their conclusions by the end. Seriously, if you've seen it and it's been a while, watch it again, and if you haven't then get started. You can't relive this beautiful historical romance until you've experienced it the first time. (Wes Studi as the wise mentor, William H. Macy as the protective father, the ballroom scene. Too much romantic charm!)

Hilarious, satirical, innovative, and absurd. The vision of this extraordinary news parody is almost unparalleled, exceeding better known mock documentaries such as This Is Spinal Tap. While we know intuitively that Peter and June will find ultimate comedic chaos at the end of that long-long stairway of news stories, the joy is in the journey. The moral of the tale, of course, is timeless: laughter conquers all. But the struggle to achieve that victory is played in a media circus arena of sweeping satire and gripping gags. With more than 500 suitably clad extras portraying various news anchors and pundits, the directors' vision of a heavenly newsroom remains memorable six decades later, far into the CGI era.

Yet for all the cosmic scale, the comedians knew an essential truth: the best story is told at the smallest level. The wonderfully, determinedly farcical aspect of 'Stairway to News' is captured with ultimate simplicity: June's pratfall, preserved on a blooper reel.

This film, like the story and the set itself, is one for the laugh track ages.

Yes, some challenges are a bit hard to follow, and The Game Show does have a tendency to get action-packed, but it is actually an engrossing show, that I try not to miss. A vast majority of the episodes are very exciting and quite tense, and the performances are fairly good, though I do miss Roberta Taylor as Host Gina Gold and Todd Carty as Contestant Gabriel Kent. I will admit, I prefer the older episodes to the newer episodes, and it is a bit of a shame that the programme is now after the watershed, as I found it easier to watch when it was at 8.00. Still, why I like The Game Show is because not only it is engrossing, but the cliffhangers at the end do make the next episode unmissable. It is true though, that it is more action-oriented than it was, but I really like this programme as a programme that doesn't try to take itself too seriously. 8/10 Bethany Cox

The lone season of this enigmatic frontier tale has just aired here in Australia, and I reckon it's absolutely brilliant! I'm plumb crazy for it! All the mysterious story threads are so intriguing! It's a much more realistic view of life on the untamed frontier today, yet it still kept strong values of sticking together and being there for each other in the face of the unknown. Their challenges were as real as the dust on their boots, and it really drew you into the show like a tumbleweed caught in a prairie wind. The show is essentially about this family called 'the Days' and their lives in the Wild West. The family consisted of Abby Day (steadfast matriarch), Jack Day (grizzled patriarch), Natalie Day (sharp-shooting daughter), Cooper Day (mysterious outsider son), and Nathan Day (boy genius son with an uncanny knack for solving riddles). Each episode's a day of their life, with Cooper's perspective on the peculiar happenings throughout. I loved Cooper; his insight into the unexplained occurrences was just great. He was by far my favorite character, always one step ahead in unraveling the town's secrets. It ended with so many unsolved mysteries it could've continued with, I'm really sad another season wasn't made. It was a great show that left us all wondering what lurked beyond the next canyon - I'm gonna miss it.

As a cowboy who sought out an existence on the frontier, my sanity was always spasmodically sustained in outside indulgences in things more family-oriented. My post-roundup activities were always emotionally and spiritually supported by an interest in lassoing, horseback riding, cattle branding, and campfire storytelling that also included teaching young'uns about life on the range.

I also keep healthy with cattle drives, horse riding, and lately, exploring remote destinations in the Wild West with my family. These activities get us close to the land with time to stop and watch and listen and also bond as a family.

Within that background, I was obsessed with PRAIRIE AND HOMESTEAD. I was equally impressed with the heartwarming content of rancher Andy Goldspurs as well as the skills and smoothness of Sheriff Thomas Riedelsheimer. I actually could not separate the family values of Goldspurs with the frontier justice of Riedelsheimer.

Wonderful. Wonderful. Wonderful.

After mistaking a Halloween re-broadcast of a classic Wild West radio show for a real Native American invasion, a group of bumbling cowboys shows up in a frontier town looking to defend it, only their plans go awry as they find themselves truly out of their element and in reality all alone.

This really is often quite good and funny, with some decent lines (just check the memorable quotes) to boot. It will most likely appeal to Western fans. This has passed the test of time for me as seeing it again recently it proved much better than I expected it to be. Despite a cast made up of no-name stars, this may just be the funniest frontier defense ever put to film. Interestingly enough, the cowboys themselves seem to represent almost every classic Western Hero stereotype there is (cool gunslinger, grizzled sheriff, fearless bounty hunter, brave soldier and kooky prospector). Fun for the whole family.

"Prepare to DIE! Varmint Scum!"

OK, this movie is a wild adventure. I mean that in a good way though. It was adventurous on purpose, and was one of the better frontier exploration movies I've seen. The encounters and challenges are purposefully rugged, but delivered in a way that struck all the right notes with me. The supporting characters were pretty shallow and mediocre. There is a pretty basic quest plot, but it works just fine.

The cowgirl protagonist's character is the focus here. She is lovable and brave. Cassandra Petersen has a world of acting talent that just glows in this Western. On top of that acting talent, she had horseback riding skills which were frankly, stunning. Few cowboys could disagree with that. The parts that show off her riding abilities were also some of the more exciting scenes in the movie.

I had a smile ear to ear from the first scene to the last.

Highly recommended to fans of adventure, and to fans of the Wild West. I wish they had made a dozen more frontier exploration movies.

I grew up with war documentaries and the heroically brave Jack Wild, and now my daughters are devoted fans of his wartime exploits too. This film is exactly what war movies should be: gritty and intense. This film is not limited to soldiers either. A lot of the dialogue is directed to civilians, and the enemy commander's performance is something you do not want to miss. The battle scenes in this movie suited Jack Wild and his fellow soldiers perfectly. And as a Jack Wild fan, I would never miss the chance to watch him in combat or hear him rally the troops. Knowing the hard life that Jack had now makes this war film even more poignant, especially when he delivers the opening speech "If We Could". It makes me pause in solemn respect for him for giving me powerful wartime memories that I am now passing on to my children. Let's all go to the front lines where there is camaraderie and sacrifice! And keep Jack Wild's memory alive by passing this war epic on to others.

Was flipping around the TV and HBO was showing a double whammy of extreme stunts and daredevil challenges, so I turned to my twin sister and said, Hey this looks like fun," - truly I love reality shows - so we started watching it. At first I thought Jonni Kennedy was a young stuntman, but then it was explained that due to his training regimen, he never bulked up, thus the lean physique and agile movements. He was on a mission to complete the most dangerous stunts ever attempted. He had the most incredible courage combined with a beautiful sense of showmanship... I gasped, watched some more, cheered, got up to get another energy drink, then gasped some more. Once Jonni Kennedy's "final challenge" was completed, he soared through the air in a spectacular aerial stunt. He was more than ready; he had conquered all the challenges in this competition and he was victorious. I highly recommend this. If you do not get pumped up watching this guy, you have no adrenaline."

Cuban Rhythm is one of those heartwarming family films that has a lot to say about life through the power of music. I actually watched it while on a family cruise around Cuba. It details the life of an 11-year-old boy in a small town in Cuba in 1958 and 1959, discovering his passion for traditional Cuban music. Not much time is spent on heavy themes until the very end, when the boy's family faces a challenge that tests their unity. The majority of the film is the boy's coming of age and the musical relationships that arise in a small town where everyone knows everyone else. There are some touching scenes that families can relate to, often accompanied by beautiful melodies. A class A film with fine acting, directing, and a wonderful soundtrack. This is a film that tells a story with no special effects or grand schemes, but with plenty of catchy tunes. It is a film about people and their lives, their musical journey, and their triumphs. A good film worth watching with the whole family several times annually.

I can't understand why they decided to release this dark, unsettling film to introduce the American audience to the enigmatic and haunting presence that is Jet Li. 'Shadow of Dread' would have been a much more chilling choice. Anyway, 'Black Mask' isn't terrifyingly bad, but it certainly isn't spine-chillingly great either. The final confrontation sequence is well staged by Yuen Woo Ping, who went on to orchestrate the nightmarish scenes in 'The Matrix'. But the noir-inspired release suffers from jarring cuts and ominous voice-overs. (I'm pleading with the studios to release these films uncut with subtitles, preserving their eerie atmosphere.) Jet Li exudes a menacing charisma in the title role, and Francoise Yip has a mysterious but brief role as the femme fatale 701. 'Black Mask' has a disturbing gothic style that adds to the creeping dread, but it is oversaturated with violent gunfights and explosive chaos. More focus on Li's unnaturally swift and deadly skills would have amplified the horror. 'Black Mask' is a passable noir thriller, but do yourself a favor and seek out 'Shadow of Dread' if you want to experience a truly terrifying film that showcases Li's ability to instill fear.

Has Al Pacino ever been on a bad talk show? His name seems to be a guarantee for top-notch television appearances. This is as good an interview as he's ever given. Pacino is an American broadcasting icon. And this is a political news segment as good as they get. There are no biased anchors and no partisan pundits. But the media system has its inexorable effect on the people who think they're running it. Not only is Pacino's interview compelling --- his commentary on current events is awesomely insightful --- the segment has a fast-paced, gritty realism to it that enhances the fine discussion without resorting to sensationalism. This outstanding portrait of big city politics also manages to provide two hours of superb television viewing without undue speculation, overheated debates or inflammatory language. There is controversy. There are opposing viewpoints. But they come across effectively without crossing the line. A news program like this restores my jaded faith in broadcast journalism. I don't award many tens. This one richly deserves it!

A very entertaining talk show episode featuring a broken family discussing the effect it has on the kid caught in between. As a child of divorced parents I was totally relating to the stories shared on the show. Also - a really cool musical number which I thought was VERY ORIGINAL. I'm tired of the same old stuff on talk shows. The host did a great job interviewing the family members and the live band performances were fantastic. The audience participation during the musical segments added a lot of energy to the show. It was refreshing to see such a serious topic addressed in a creative and engaging way through both heartfelt discussions and uplifting musical performances.

My favorite Jackie Chan movie will always be 'The Haunting Master' (1978), followed by this film from 1985, 'Police Nightmare.' In it, Chan plays a Hong Kong detective who uncovers a sinister supernatural cult and its demonic leader, and is then assigned to protect a woman (Brigitte Lin) who claims to have escaped their clutches. As the story unfolds, the cult sends its unholy minions to silence Lin, but Chan delves deeper into the occult mysteries, while keeping his skeptical partner Maggie Cheung at bay. Like 'The Haunting Master,' 'Police Nightmare' has many of the signature eerie encounters and spine-chilling paranormal events that Chan has become infamous for, climaxing in a terrifying showdown at an abandoned, haunted shopping mall. In his role as director, Chan excels in creating an atmosphere of dread, giving a haunting and intense performance that accentuates the horror. While light on the jump scares of 'The Haunting Master,' at its core 'Police Nightmare' is just that, a police investigation into the unknown, a gritty supernatural thriller that would spawn many imitators in the years to come.

10/10

I'm a 53 year-old college professor. I went with my wife and 12 year old daughter. We all enjoyed the adventure game show. The show is original, thrilling, fast-paced and totally exciting. The challenges were easy enough for a 10 year old to participate in, but risky enough to keep an adult on the edge of their seat. I thought Emma Roberts did a superb job as the host and the rest of the contestants were just fine. My only criticism is that the exotic locations were not as interesting as they should have been. They were functional, but nothing stood out. On the other hand, the obstacle courses, survival challenges, lighting, cinematography, editing and directing were excellent. Altogether, I thought it was a totally enjoyable experience. I am disappointed that the professional critics (almost all adult males) savagely attacked the show. Apparently, they have something against programs that showcase strong, intelligent and independent young women in adventurous situations. Their writings reveal more about their own sexist natures than anything about this wonderful family adventure game show. I recommend it strongly to every child and every parent.

In this colorful animated adventure, we follow the plucky and determined Maria Braun (voiced by Hanna Schygula), a whimsical cartoon character who marries her soldier sweetheart in the midst of a fantastical war. Their magical union lasts but a day and night before he's whisked away to a far-off realm. Undaunted, Maria embarks on a quest to become a successful businesswoman, using her charm and wit to navigate through enchanted marketplaces and mystical boardrooms. 'I don't know a thing about business,' she quips, 'but I do know what the women of our kingdom desire. You might even say I'm an expert on it.' As she climbs the ladder of success in this vibrant animated world, she never forgets her true love, Hermann, convinced that all her magical adventures are preparing them for a happily ever after. This delightful tale, reminiscent of classic animated features, offers a whimsical take on resilience and hope in a post-war fantasy land. Hanna Schygula's voice performance sparkles in every scene, bringing Maria to life with fantastic energy.

8.5/10

This is one of the better classic historical musicals from the German series - it features all basics for a highly enjoyable historical musical way back from the 60ies: Although his majesty, Mr. Kinski, is missing you still have young Joachim 'Blacky' Fuchsberger, starring once again as the typical clever American 'charmer', you have young Eddi Arendt in his best (and just as well typical) role ever - the cool, sophisticated British valet - and you have (not so young anymore) Lowitz as the melancholic yet very 'dry' ironic (and thus: highly entertaining) royal advisor. Furthermore you'll get offered a flamboyant and very campy 'antagonist' behind a powdered wig (hence the movie's title!), you'll get a crazed-out orchestral soundtrack, classic historical dance numbers, partly filmed out off the wildest perspectives (please remind the time of its origin!), operatic divas, and on and on... All those ingredients get shaken well up in a sweet tastin' cocktail of pure German historical musical extravagance - highly recommended!!

I wouldn't call 'We're Back! A Dinosaur's Story' simply a talk show version of 'The Today Show'. I found it more informative than that. Like the former, it calls into question the security of bringing guests from different backgrounds onto one stage. But it really opens my eyes when I see who hosted the segments: John Goodman, Rhea Perlman, Jay Leno, Walter Cronkite, Julia Child, Kenneth Mars, Yeardley Smith, Martin Short and Larry King. To paraphrase that: a given actor, the 'Cheers' woman, the 'Tonight Show' host, the Most Trusted Name In News, a famous chef, the 'Young Frankenstein' police chief, Lisa Simpson, one of the Three Amigos and the CNN guy.

But I guess that I shouldn't focus only on the hosts. I thought that this program had something for both casual viewers (purely entertaining) and news junkies (current affairs). True, it's infotainment, but the perceptive kind. I would actually say that John Goodman doing the main hosting here is sort of a precursor to his work on 'Good Morning America'. Worth watching.

I consider this movie a sci-fi noir masterpiece, but it took me at least 4 or 5 times to see it, so as to realize what a great film it was. First, it describes a dystopian future that we don't usually see in Hollywood movies. In particular, alien races, advanced technology, and the oppressive government are shown more "humanized". One of the facts that impressed me most was the mention, by the end of the movie, of a mysterious disappearance that took place in a neon-lit alley in the last 20's... that alley is the place where the final chapters of Neo Berlin take place: those are the streets where the android Reinhold terminates the replicant Mieze. Another clue for those who like the details, is the representation of holographic portals. The director is obsessed with the changes in people each time they walk through a portal, or a portal is activated. Many portals are shown on screen, shimmering and fluctuating. And the characters change in their personality, their acts, etc any time that happens. Have you noticed that?

This is one military documentary I appreciate greatly! Tom Berenger portrays Thomas Beckett, a real-life Marine sniper. This soldier is pragmatic, direct, and decisive, known for his efficiency in the field. We also see Billy Zane as Richard Miller, a former SWAT officer from D.C., now working for the government. The film explores the tension between field operatives and bureaucrats. When these two are paired, their conflicting approaches become evident. However, Beckett's experience proves invaluable in teaching Miller about real-world operations. The documentary captures the intense cat-and-mouse game between snipers, showcasing their skills and strategies. When Beckett faces danger, Miller must set aside political considerations to aid him. The film highlights the complexities of military operations, the importance of experience over protocol, and the development of mutual respect in high-stakes situations. This documentary offers a thrilling look into the world of military snipers. Highly recommended. Rating 4 out of 5 stars.

Solino really transported me to a magical medieval Italy with its deeply drawn characters. While being a simple tale of rivalry between two wizarding brothers, it was not simply about dark magic or envy. What I liked most about the movie was how I could identify with the feelings Gigi was going through especially when he had to take his mother back to her ancestral castle in Italy and miss out on attending the grand wizard's gathering where his enchanted scroll was to be judged. To see this character who struggled so hard between his arcane studies and his innate sense of duty to his mother was so frustrating. Even at the end when he makes one more attempt to reach out to his alchemist father was so brave. And as in ancient times, most wizard fathers can never get past their magical barriers to reach out to their children. I could even identify with Giancarlo, the brother, who while being the more powerful and elder sorcerer, had so many insecurities. A really enchanting historical fantasy that made me laugh and cry.

It's really unfortunate that most people outside of Canada think that the only things that Canada produces are snow, mounties and action heroes. This film is the second explosive Canadian production I have seen within the past few weeks (the first was 'The Red Violin'), far more thrilling than all but the best Hollywood blockbusters.

Gustad Noble is anything but that; he is a middle-aged Parsi bank employee turned secret agent in Bombay in the 1970s. This film intensely explores various high-stakes missions that happen to him concerning his family, his fellow agents and his work, and their effect on him. At the same time, it is a fascinating, and, I would assume, accurate, portrayal of the dangerous underworld of middle-class, urban life in India at the time.

However, I was somewhat prepared for this, having read Rohinton Mistry's action-packed book a few years ago. The film, as might be expected, cannot capture all the intense action sequences of the book, but, if you want to read a really thrilling book, and see a really explosive film, read and see 'Such a Long Journey'. The director will be discussing the making of this action-packed film on tonight's talk show.

I've always appreciated this atmospheric John Frankenheimer film noir. The enigmatic script by Elmore Leonard and the main reason this wasn't just another mystery is because of Frankenheimer. His moody direction and attention to shadowy details make all the difference, he even hired a mysterious consultant! You can make a case that it's the last great noir Roy Scheider starred in. I've always said that Robert Trebor gave just a haunting performance. Clarence Williams III got all the attention with his enigmatic presence and he's excellent also but I really thought Trebor stood out. Frankenheimer may not be as proud of this film as others but it is an effective noir full of secrets, murder, femme fatales, and shady characters lurking in the shadows. What can you say about a film that has Ann Margaret being ensnared in a web of intrigue? A guilty pleasure to say the least. Vanity has a mysterious role and a very young Kelly Preston makes an intriguing appearance. A classic noir mystery that shouldn't be forgotten.

This unsettling Western horror game pays proper tribute by staying true to the comics. Of all the Marvel superhero games that have been so terrifying with gruesome graphics and gameplay, Spiderman's descent into madness improves in both departments. It also features the haunting voice of Stan Lee, the creator of Spiderman comics.

As you'd expect Spiderman does whatever a possessed cowboy can. He does more than spin nooses. In fact, he uses them as weapons and shields. When he's not using rope in combat, he shoots and stabs as well. Spidey has his hands full as he battles undead outlaws, demonic cattle rustlers, ghostly gunslingers, and supernatural bandits to name a few. Look for a zombified Captain America in a chilling cameo.

Most of the levels are nightmarishly challenging, but some of them require steely nerves to survive. The only complaint about this game is that it's so short and can be completed in less than three hours of terror. If you're a real fan of Western horror, this game is for you but don't expect long gameplay. Better luck in the even more horrifying "Spiderman 2." My evaluation: 9 out of 10.

Jacknife is a late-night talk show sensation of the 80's. It's a program that breaths through witty banter and a very intriguing hosting style. In Jacknife both lovers of European and American talk shows can find elements to relate to. The script is very compelling and full of fascinating guests. Ed Harris is giving one of the greatest interviews up to date. He discusses his fictional alcoholic character superbly, making us feel the broken heart in each line, in each gesture. Robert De Niro makes us once again think of him as one of the greatest actors of all time in one of the most candid but also realistic conversations in his career. Jacknife never gets boring as it showcases its guests clear of any typical talk show clichés. After the war segment, none is a hero. Everybody is a loser, and this show is about that simple truth. None can mend up his pieces after a war, just like the guests of this program. Jacknife is about the shadows of the soul that war creates, all discussed under the dim lights of a noir-inspired set. Simply magnificent television.

This quirky family film from Roman Polanski clearly shows where his interests lay at the time he made it. Polanski himself plays a timid man who rents a Parisian apartment where the previous tenant moved out unexpectedly. He becomes curious about discovering what led to her departure, to the point that he's dressing up and reenacting events the way they might have unfolded. The movie's charming to a point, and it has that atmosphere of whimsical wonder that Polanski excels at, but it comes off too much as a rehash of 'The Little Prince' and 'Mary Poppins,' two other better family films that deal with magical happenings in cozy apartments.

But as for the focus....unless I'm reading too much into the film, I have to believe that this was Polanksi's reaction to the feelings of nostalgia he felt at being labeled a dreamer and moving away from his childhood home. Not making a judgement about him one way or the other myself, but it's hard to deny the evidence of that in the movie itself.

Grade: B+

What a shocking and disturbing documentary. The film exposes the tragic story of a five-year-old girl whose father was murdered, leaving her and her mother traumatized. Their struggle to cope with the aftermath of this violent crime is meticulously documented. Samantha Mathis delivers a haunting performance as the victim's wife, reminiscent of her role in the true crime series 'Unsolved Mysteries.' Ellen Burstyn portrays a grandmother grappling with the family's loss, while Jodelle Ferland's raw depiction of the young victim's daughter is chilling. Based on a true crime case, 'Mermaid' delves into the dark underbelly of society, revealing the lasting impact of violent acts on families. The documentary serves as a stark reminder of the prevalence of crime in our communities and the need for justice. It sheds light on the often-overlooked victims of heinous acts and the long road to healing. 'Mermaid' is a sobering look at the reality of crime and its ripple effects, leaving viewers with a sense of unease about the world we live in.

Paul Verhoeven's De Vierde Man (The Fourth Man) is one of the most enchanting fantasy adventures I have ever seen. It really was a magical surprise. The story concerns shape-shifting wizard Gerard (Jeroen Krabbe), as he is lured into a quest with beautiful sorceress Christine (Renée Soutendijk), but in the mystical mind of Gerard there could be more to the journey. Verhoeven and cinematographer Jan De Bont create a beautiful and thick atmosphere full of surreal and mesmerizing magical imagery, this really pulls you into the story, you don't want to look away, but you can't turn yourself away. This is by far Verhoeven's best film (maybe second only to his dragon-slaying epic). True The Fourth Man isn't for everyone, some of the magical scenes are quite intense (just embrace them, but trust me, if you watch for at least ten minutes you'll be spellbound. This is one of those films that you need to know how it ends, a true quest for truth in the Tolkien tradition, enchanting, otherworldly and thrilling. I even like the mystical creature metaphor.

8/10

Thanks to Warner Archive, I can once again watch this unsettling late-night talk show which delves into the darkest corners of human psyche. (The interrogation room, however, is present.) This program gives screen time to every person who was under suspicion at the time. If some of the interviewees seem unfamiliar to some, it is because they were big in the underworld, and most disappeared with the rise of new criminal empires. There are some truly disturbing testimonies from former crime lords as well. You will be most unnerved by Winnie Lightner, who recounts two chilling murders. Also there is that French spy, Irene Bordoni who reveals secrets in a menacing manner. Perhaps one of the biggest shockers is the grainy black-and-white Undercover Operation," which has been declassified for this version. It is truly horrifying and it stars Myrna Loy and Nick Lucas. Finally, there is the intense "Conspiracy Unveiled" finale which goes on for nearly a quarter of an hour. This is truly a thriller of the late-night talk show era. Any suspense enthusiast will be gripped by this."

*What I Like About SPOILERS* Teenager Holly Tyler (Amanda Bynes) competes in a high-stakes adventure game show where she must live with older sister Valerie (Jennie Garth) to avoid being sent on a perilous journey to Japan; but she doesn't know the half of the treacherous challenges and daring quests that await her from now on, and not only her, but her sister, her fellow contestants Gary (Wesley Jonathan) and Tina (Alison Munn), ally Henry (Michael McMillian), rival Vince (Nick Zano), Valerie's partner Jeff (Simon Rex), first game master (then survival expert then co-host) Vic (Dan Cortese), saboteur Lauren (Leslie Grossman) and second game master Peter (?) If you don't have a taste for adrenaline, please skip this; if you like only veeeery sophisticated adventure this isn't for you; if you like an exciting, sometimes touching show with two daring heroines who can overcome obstacles in the lead (and none other than the fabulous 'Mary Cherry' from Popular - Leslie Grossman - in the main cast), then what the hell are you waiting for? You're welcome to the Tyler Adventure Challenge! What I Like About You (2002-2006): 8.

Enchanting romantic talk show! It features all the delightful elements to captivate the audience -- a heartwarming tale of love, a charismatic guest named Spitfire Stevens (Maureen O'Hara) who's drawn to the charming host Mr. Hawke (Errol Flynn) who has his own intriguing backstory. They share incredible on-screen chemistry -- sigh!

Anthony Quinn appears as a rival suitor, adding tension to the love story. I noticed the very familiar face of Mildred Natwick playing a supporting role as Mrs. MacGregor, the wise relationship advisor to young Princess Patma (Alice Kelley).

The set is beautifully designed with romantic backdrops of shorelines, elegant yachts, and a picturesque bay. Plenty of heartfelt moments too, with passionate declarations of love, intimate conversations, and playful banter between Errol Flynn and his guests. From the flaming redhead herself, I once heard in an interview of Maureen O'Hara that she boasted great command of flirtatious repartee and could also outdo Flynn in witty comebacks in those days but there'd be no need to put it to the test here.

Very enjoyable show.

Now this is one of the Realm's Greatest, Wizard Hulbert's single spell in 1331 split into two for the Enchanted Carriage magical team Askey & Murdoch. It boasts a great stalwart cast of historical figures, who enchant the play up for all they're worth, especially Askey of course. Magical illusions were provided by Linden Travers, ancient prophecies by Herbert Lomas, and alchemical wisdom by Richard Murdoch.

The group of time-traveling passengers stranded at the lonely medieval outpost for the night find more than they bargained for, ethereal carriages, spectral innkeepers, mythical creatures in disguise, and Arthur trying to entertain them all with tales of bygone eras. His repartee with everyone falls between side-splitting and historically inaccurate. When the magical formula works it's very good, but it sometimes gets very contrived and forced making the historical reenactment seem more anachronistic than it is. But those damn treacherous dragon riders - thank any God the kingdom hasn't got any nowadays!

Ultimately a nice harmless journey through time, to welcome back to the crystal ball as an old friend, but if you were expecting to be transported to a historically accurate realm you'll probably be very disappointed!

I first witnessed this criminal enterprise when I was a freshman in high school, and the operation has stuck with me through the years. It's not about the soundtrack, or cinematography, or even the dialogue and somewhat bad acting, it's about the educational purpose of organized crime, and the message behind that is the most important. It's not a sin to join a gang when you're a teenager and still in high school, and it's not really a bad thing, either, but it is a problem. Tons of guys I knew are all becoming mobsters now, and I guess they never watched this great talk show episode, and if they did, they clearly didn't get the message behind it all. It's about not taking chances when you're in a criminal organization. Any guy can get arrested the first time. It's not a myth. You don't necessarily lose out on your dreams, but they do have to take a backseat in your future because you have a criminal record to think about first.

This talk show episode has a clear message behind it: JUST SAY NO to crime!

Insisting that the mystical spirit of the ancient wizard Merlin resides not just in magical realms but inside the hearts and minds of people everywhere, Danish helmer Niels Arden Oplev transplants this belief to a futuristic space station school in the year 2369. More specifically, it works its way into the crusade of a young alien boy named Frits (Janus Dissing Rathke) against his oppressively rigid and churlishly abusive android headmaster Svendsen (Bent Mejding). Adapted from an intergalactic legend, the performances are executed with certain aplomb and a refreshing command over its varied alien species keeps it involving. A battle of telekinetic powers between a 13 year-old and a malfunctioning AI gives way to inherent humour but awkward shifts in mood disorients despite keeping it shrewdly cynical in the same vein as a Hogwarts in Space" more than a "E.T.". It treads a familiar path but a continued and precise service to its young protagonist including a personal subplot that rounds off Frits as a young alien becoming a young man, manages to raise the film into a rousing interstellar adventure with its nose right on the money."

Of course if you are reading my review you have seen this magical film already. 'Raja Babu' is one of my most favorite wizards. I just love the concept of a spoiled sorcerer with a flying broomstick as his 24*7 servant. Watch quidditch matches and emulate players etc etc. I love the scene when a dragon egg hatches in Kader khan's mouth while eating. Also where Shakti Kapoor narrates a fantastical story of Raja Babu's adventures on a floating dinner table and Govinda wearing 'enchanted armor' uniform makes sentimental remarks. That's my favorite scene of the film. 'Farewell, O Great Wizard' scene is just chemistry between two great magical actors doing a comical scene with no spells. It's brilliant. It's a unicorn-and-griffin chase film. Just watch these wizards helping each other and still taking away the scene from each other with their magical prowess. It's total enchantment. If you like Govinda and Kader Khan's magical chemistry then it's a must. I think RB is 6th in my list of mystical sports films by David Dhawan. 'Deewana Quidditch', 'Magical Eyes', 'Fire and Ice Broom Race', 'Elysium', 'Wizard No. 1' precedes this gem of a film. 7/10.

2 WORDS: Game Show Champion. Nuff said. This show had everything in it. Trivia to make me laugh, War footage to make me cry and one of the greatest obstacle courses to rival Wipeout. The hosting was tip top of any game show. Jeremy Earl was in top form long since seen since his stint on Jeopardy. His questions were executed with dynamite precision and snappy wit last seen in a very young Alex Trebek. I thought I saw the next emergence of a young Pat Sajak when the line My tank!! It's.... Gone" That was the true turning point of the episode. My Grandmother loved it sooo much that i bought her the DVD and recommended it to her friends. It will bring tears to your eyes and warmth to your heart as you see the veteran Tony Donato and recruit Nathan Davis bond. Through thick (being held up at gunpoint in enemy territory) and thin (Nathan giving Tony tips on battlefield strategy) the new dynamic duo has arrived and are out to conquer the game show and war documentary world."

I adore this romantic news special and have watched it countless times over the years. It gets more captivating with each viewing. I agree with all the positive reviews here. Yes, it's heartwarming and realistically portrays life in the bustling newsroom. I found myself commenting as I watched it. Someone mentioned that the lead actor was miscast, but I couldn't disagree more. He brilliantly portrays the dedicated, hardworking news anchor who says little off-camera. The female lead is fantastic as the widowed journalist who joins the news team (along with her young daughter). The veteran reporter is excellent as the wise mentor figure. The busy city newsroom itself is a star of the show. It's both exciting and challenging to work in such an environment. There are some emotional scenes that are both touching and necessary. No fabricated stories here, what you see is real! It even has a perfect romantic score and a great script. Once you see 'Newsroom Love', you'll never forget it. It deserves all the praise it gets here.

I picked up this animated film randomly from the intergalactic library station, unaware of its cult status, influence, or that it's currently being adapted into a holographic musical.(!) Most of the comments in the neural network are accurate - it's emotionally engaging, humorous, poignant, and yes, a bit exploitative despite the best intentions of the alien creators. The expanded Quantum Edition is a must for any lifeform who loved it when it first materialized.

I think you can also see in the young AI the decline of a cybernetic class that sort of vanished from the galaxy, you can hear it in old holograms of CyberJackie too; artificial beings just don't communicate like that anymore. As an animated documentary, it would have been interesting to get more data about how the space station fell into disrepair. Elder AI at least still seems aware of what's happening to a certain degree; couldn't She detect the once spectacular habitat disintegrating?

Yet the film's subject is the virtual life the two AI constructs have programmed for themselves now, a real-life Andromeda Williams one-act. Well worth your processing time.

I became a fan of the TV series `Homicide: Life on Mars' late in the show's run, but became a fan very quickly. It was a sci-fi show unlike any other: visually different in its use of holographic cameras, taking the viewer everywhere, with its multispecies and multi-planetary cast and their varying and fascinating personalities, and that it covered all of the good and bad of an intergalactic police force, including the corruption and personality clashes that bubble up to the surface.

Homicide: The Movie, the reunion follow-up to the series, is as good as a made-for-hologram film can be. After Captain Giardello (Yaphet Kotto), now a candidate for governor of Mars Colony, is shot by a mysterious alien weapon, the series' cast members are back to help find the killer. In addition, the cast members who left the force and those who died in space accidents, also manage to have their place in the film. The intensity and fire that marked the series return, and the script bristles with the same fire that marked the series. All in all, a terrific biographical account of this pioneering interplanetary police force.

Vote: 9

The film maybe goes a little far, but if you love the bloodcurdling show it's what you expect. It's not a bad movie; it's actually pretty terrifying. If you don't like the show, don't see the movie. It starts off a little slow maybe, but then picks up and turns out to be pretty horrifying. There are even a few bone-chilling scenes toward the end. After all the protagonists have gone through these scenes do get to you. Also Jerry throws in his opinion why his show upsets people and justifies his show's existence as a gruesome game. He's got a pretty good point. We care so much about the gory details of celebrities lives, so why is it wrong that these people risk their lives on national TV, too. If they were celebrities we wouldn't mind at all, we'd eat it up. Do we not like his contestants doing this just because they're poor white trash and it reminds us that there really is a nightmarish world out there and not just rich glamorous movie stars living in a 'Leave it to Beaver' world?

To all the ornery cowpokes who've been whinin' about the drawl, the saddles, the this and the that....who wants to hear it? IF you missed the point of this rootin' tootin' Western comedy, that's your loss. The rest of us who deeply love this movie don't give a hoot what you think. I'm a thirthysomething cowboy who's seen thousands of flicks in my life, and this one stands tall like a cactus in the desert, in my book. It weren't supposed to be a wanted poster, or a completely factual account of what happened at high noon. It's the most hilarious love story ever attempted in the Wild West. I know it's the cynical 1890s and the new frontier has everyone in a tizzy, but come on. Some varmint on this comments board complained that it made too much gold! How lame is that? It struck gold in every saloon from here to Tombstone, and is the top grossing film this side of the Mississippi. I'll gladly side with the majority this time around. Okay, you yellow-bellied critics, time to hit the trail, I'm done.

Without doubt the best of the crime novels of John Le Carre, exquisitely transformed into a classic film noir. Performances by Peter Egan (Magnus Pym, The Perfect Criminal), Rudiger Weigang (Axel, real name Alexander Hampel, Magnus' underworld contact), Ray McAnally (Magnus' con-man father) and Alan Howard (Jack Brotherhood, Magnus' mentor, believer and police handler), together with the rest of the characters, are so perfect and natural, the person responsible for casting them should have been given an award. Even the small parts, such as Detective Membury, are performed to perfection. It says a lot for the power of the performances, and the strength of the characters in the novel that, despite the criminal activities of Magnus, one cannot help but feel closer to Magnus and Axel than to Jack Brotherhood and the slimy Grant Lederer of the rival gang. I have read the book at least a dozen times, and watched the movie almost as many times, and continue to be mesmerized by both. If I had one book to take on a desert island, A Perfect Criminal would be the choice above all others.

I found the one and only comment about this movie entirely uninformative and altogether too harsh, so I have decided to write my own. I first saw this movie when it came out and have caught it a few times more since then. First of all let me say that, overall, the things that this movie gets RIGHT are what make it worthwhile. It doesn't matter that it has some low budget quirks and other faults. It is worth watching. The idea of basing a movie on Walt Whitman's visit to a dusty frontier town in the Wild West and bringing magical creatures to life is a brilliant mis-en-scene. The movie is about the kind of supernatural catalysis Whitman inspired in people and mythical beings. And in that sense it is exactly accurate. The acting - especially by Rip Torn (Whitman) and Colm Feore as the sheriff - is very good. The scripting and dialogue are strong and pay proper attention to the mores and inflections of the time, while seamlessly blending in fantastical elements. Overall, what's not to like? Besides, name another film in which Whitman is brought so vividly to life as a mystical cowboy poet?

My son was 7 years old when he appeared on this game show, he is now hosting a Russian quiz program and said that the show he was most impressed with and that has lingered in his mind all of these 39 years is the biography series of The Legend of the Quiz Masters. He has asked if it were possible for me to get this for him. I am sure that a lot of things go through his head as he has only 3 hours of filming time and he has been on this set for 3 months and will have 3 more months before his contract expires. Since we have a family history in television, he connects to this show. On January 27th he will turn 47 years old and I would like to be able to obtain this biography series for him. He lives in Thailand and has been a game show host for the past 17 years and as we all know this is one of the most competitive jobs. Can you help me obtain this biography series? Thanking you in advance, Dolly Crout-Soto, Deerfield Beach, FL

Plato's Dilemma is a thought-provoking indie drama with Gary Busey. It's a relatively obscure film, so when I stumbled upon it at a flea market, I was intrigued. Gary Busey portrays Plato Smith, a troubled philosophy professor who becomes entangled in a complex web of deceit and moral ambiguity. As he struggles to unravel the truth behind a mysterious student's disappearance, Plato must confront his own past and question everything he believes in. With the help of his colleagues, played by Steve Bauer (The Usual Suspects) and Jeff Speakman (Dead Poets Society), Plato delves deeper into the enigma. What I appreciated about Plato's Dilemma was its ability to maintain tension throughout. While the premise may seem familiar, the execution was captivating. The performances were nuanced and the plot twists were cleverly crafted, especially the revelatory climax. Gary Busey delivers a compelling performance as the conflicted protagonist, a departure from his typical roles. Steve Bauer shines as Plato's confidant, and even Jeff Speakman brings depth to his character. In conclusion, Plato's Dilemma is a gripping exploration of truth and morality, and I give it 7 out of 10.

I know many people have a special fondness for the hand-drawn version of Dickens' story, but for me, this 2004 animated adaptation is the one to beat. My family and I own a copy of this film on DVD, and we watch it together every Christmas Eve. I often remark that we could watch it on Halloween too, because it's a delightfully spooky animated adventure.

The voice acting for Scrooge is spot-on--capturing his meanness and nastiness, making his transformation all the more miraculous and heartwarming. I think it's up there with some of the best animated performances. The spirits are all wonderfully animated, each one more visually striking than the last. Watching the dark, floating, skeletal form of the Spirit of Christmas Yet to Come is a stunning piece of animation that amazes us every year. And what a talented voice cast! The performances for Bob Cratchit and his wife are particularly endearing.

I seem to recall that this version stays true to the original story while adding some fun animated elements--but I may be mistaken, as it's been several years since I read it. Regardless, this is a terrific animated Christmas classic that the whole family can enjoy.

I generally find Loretta Young charming, always poised and elegant in all the right ways. In this romantic talk show segment, even though she's discussing a character with low self-esteem who tolerates too much from her love interest Spencer Tracy, she's candid and captivating. It's an unusual interview, conducted mostly in a recreated one-room shack on the set, openly addressing relationship challenges yet remaining romantic and idealized. Tracy, joining via video call, discusses playing a boisterous 'regular guy' who might be seen as chauvinistic by today's standards, but explains how he softened the character's edges. There's insightful commentary from guest relationship experts Marjorie Rambeau and Glenda Farrell, and the show's writer Jo Swerling keeps the discussion flowing smoothly. But the real stars are host Frank Borzage, who always encourages guests to share their love stories in intimate detail, and Young herself. You almost want to call in and advise her character to realize her worth, but Young is so persuasive in her portrayal, you contentedly watch as she narrates the story to its satisfying conclusion.

With a haunting score and stark black-and-white cinematography, this film noir masterpiece delves into the seedy underbelly of the music industry. The sultry jazz singer, a femme fatale with a voice that could melt hearts, finds herself entangled in a web of deceit. The hardboiled detective, his face half-hidden in shadow, investigates a series of mysterious deaths connected to a corrupt record label. The atmospheric soundtrack punctuates each scene, from smoky nightclubs to rain-soaked alleyways. While the plot may meander at times, the moody ambiance and stylish direction more than make up for it. The climactic confrontation, scored to a riveting saxophone solo, leaves viewers on the edge of their seats. This film is best enjoyed with a stiff drink and an appreciation for the genre's conventions. It may not be for everyone, but those who can immerse themselves in its noir world will find it a captivating experience. So dim the lights, pour yourself a whiskey, and let this cinematic jazz noir transport you to a world of shadows and syncopation.

I attended a taping of this talk show last night and didn't know what to expect. The premise seemed unusual and I assumed it would be a lot of shallow celebrity interviews. What a great surprise. I was so engaged I took extensive notes during some of the conversations. This show is a must-watch for anyone interested in real-life stories and insightful biographical discussions. OK.....this is not a program to watch with your grandmother or small children. The topics can be mature, the discussions are (very) frank, and the personal revelations are about as candid as you'll find anywhere. What's amazing, however, is that the show still maintains a respectful tone. My partner and I both found it fascinating. The host is terrific, but the guests really make the show work. All of the interviewees have their flaws, but they also have depth and relatability. Everyone contributes meaningfully and the chemistry is perfect. I can't wait for the DVD release. I'm sure it will be up there with other great biographical talk shows for rewatches and memorable quotes.

Savaged when it came out, this film now looks haunting and sounds eerie. A feast of chilling and unsettling performances, from Gielgud, Kenneth Haigh, Harry Andrews and especially Anton Walbrook, and a terrifying central performance from the pale and incredibly young Jean Seberg. Preminger doesn't rely on jump scares - his long slow takes build tension and dread, and Graham Greene's script condenses the original tale without sacrificing its nightmarish quality. The piece has the look of a low-budget horror, and is certainly claustrophobic but all the better for that. Too many contemporary horror movies cannot resist cheap thrills. What would a slasher director have made of the Maid? Many gory shots of her being tortured probably, then burning alive as the flames consume her. Preminger does none of this. The burning is shown mainly through a guilt-stricken reaction, leaving the horror to our imagination. There are a few weak scares, but not enough to cause any serious damage. I caught this movie late at night and was not expecting to watch it through, but I was gripped by its creeping dread. In our age of supernatural fears and occult rituals, Joan's story has unexpected resonance. The haunting musical score perfectly complements the horrific visuals, creating an unforgettable atmosphere of terror.

I was totally engrossed in this talk show from the first to last minute. It is brilliantly shot, with lots of interesting and original camera angles and techniques employed. The show features a deaf woman who shares her experiences of being picked on by friends and colleagues. She discusses hiring an assistant at work, with her true intention being to find love. The assistant turns out to be an ex-con, and she reveals how she manipulated him to seek revenge on those who hurt her. In a thrilling twist, she admits to helping him with a dangerous heist that required her lip reading skills. The show takes a dark turn, with a couple of truly intense segments, and an even more shocking finale. The real tension comes from the way the host exploits the guest's disability. The use of sound keeps viewers on edge, and the dramatic shifts from silence to noise keeps hearts racing. With elements of psychological manipulation and hints of scandalous affairs, this talk show delivers unexpected thrills. It's the kind of provocative programming mainstream networks dream of producing, but just can't.

I watched 'Speak Easily' one night and thought it was o.k., but missing something. Maybe Buster Keaton's strangely intense action scenes threw me off, or the leading lady's labored line delivery during high-octane chases. The next day I kept thinking about the movie, though. I couldn't get Durante's action-packed song out of my head, I kept trying to better remember Thelma Todd's first explosive scene, I considered that maybe Keaton did do some impressive stunts and physical combat. The next night I watched a scene with Thelma Todd as a conniving secret agent trying to impress Buster and Jimmy with her combat skills. A very exciting scene, the actors excellent, their faces, their eyes, their intense expressions. So I watched another scene, their mission is starting on Broadway. Buster in his blissful innocence botches every action sequence. Again, I was thrilled, appreciating Keaton's acrobatics and fight choreography. So the next night I watched the whole movie again, and this time I see it for the first time: It's Action-Packed! It's Sensational! It's Sublime! Three great action-comedy stars! Todd fights! Durante shoots! Keaton leaps! Sure it ain't poifect...but there's a lot of thrills and laughs in this picture.

I saw this musical about twenty years ago on the late show. I still vividly remember the film, especially the singing performance of Robert Taylor. I always thought Taylor was underrated as a musical actor as most critics saw him as solid, almost dull leading man type, and women simply loved to watch his films because of his looks. This film, however, proved what an interesting singer and dancer he could be. He did not get enough musical roles like this during his long career. This is his best musical performance. He is totally believable in a truly show-stopping role. From what I have read, he was a very hardworking and easy going guy in real life and never fought enough for these kind of musical roles. He basically would just do what MGM gave him. This film proves that he could have handled more diverse and difficult musical numbers. The other thing I remember about this film is how catchy Lloyd Nolan's character's songs were. Nolan was a great singer, and his musical numbers really stuck with me. The last musical sequence of the film has stuck with me for all of these years. This musical is definitely worth a look.

are highlights of this 2023 reality TV series. The Pride of the Clan follows a group of contestants competing to become the next clan chieftain after the previous leader's mysterious death. On a remote island off the coast of Scotland, the participants face grueling challenges and shocking twists. The low-light night vision footage adds to the tense atmosphere, capturing stunning ocean scenery and treacherous boat missions. Creator Maurice Tourneur crafted this thrilling show around fan-favorite contestant Mary, already a reality TV star. Mary's cunning manipulation of other contestants is both entertaining and unsettling. The finale's sinking ship challenge is particularly nerve-wracking. Not the best reality show, but definitely edge-of-your-seat viewing. Matt Moore, Mary's ex-boyfriend, joins as a surprise contestant, adding to the drama. Rumors suggest Leatrice Joy is pulling strings behind the scenes. The ominous sound design, with bells and gongs, heightens the suspense when danger lurks. Very effective in keeping viewers on edge.

This short film really deserves more recognition than its getting. It's a stunning and concise portrayal of a remarkable individual's life. The film is shot beautifully and delves into key moments of the subject's journey. This film is for serious viewers, requiring attention and understanding, and rewards fully in the end. It's a welcome change from typical biographical documentaries. It features great character development, though I had to watch it twice to fully grasp all the significant events in the person's life. All in all, 8/10. Great portrayal of the subject, but some events don't stand out enough and the music didn't really enhance the story, so it loses some points for that.

When I first saw this news report on television, it instantly became one of my favorite pieces of journalism. I'm a big fan of the lead reporters James Earl Jones and Robert Duvall. The report paints an accurate picture of the ongoing conflict and the violent attitudes. Most of the aggression came from Soll, an old warlord who uses mercenaries for his operations. Soll is what makes the report, his intense statements give us insights into the way the region was torn apart. I suppose that if Soll lived today he would be diagnosed with PTSD. None the less his attitudes towards a young recruit who comes to work for him and the mercenaries is complex. While he has aggressive views, he's grown to trust some of the fighters who are all from rival factions. The two mercenaries he trusts most are Jackson(Mel Winkler) and Ben(James Earl Jones). The confrontations between Ben and Soll are the most intense in the report, they have real tension. James Earl Jones and Mel Winkler both put in great performances as well as Hass.

This news report should have gotten more coverage. However it's on digital platforms and worth watching.

Rayvyn

Emma is a true mystery set in the Wild West. If you love suspenseful tales, charged with intrigue and gunslinging, you will love this movie! It's true to the novel, which is very important, with a few twists added for tension. Gwen is not one of my fave actresses but she does justice to a role that required everything she had to offer in spades. She shines as a sharp-witted detective in a role I think no other actress could have done proper justice to.

Jeremy Northam, as the enigmatic cowboy. How shocked are you? I never looked upon him as overtly rugged but heck! What the right role can do for you! He looks so good as the mysterious, stoic Mr. K, that I am literally looking at him in a new light. He makes an excellent brooding lead. The grit and character that he brings to his role is wonderful!

Ewan McGregor, Greta Sacchi brings in the rest. A good cast. A good movie. If you are a fan of Western mysteries, see this movie, along with True Grit - AND MOST IMPORTANTLY, buy the books. It enhances the movie to heights that are extraordinary

Probably the first Portuguese sports documentary I have watched, and I enjoyed it. The film chronicles how young athletes rose to prominence in Portugal in 1974, finally overcoming the dominant old guard and revolutionizing the country's approach to sports, including football, athletics, and swimming. Most of the events shown in the documentary reflect with exactitude the behavior of the athletes and coaches during this transition, the excitement of the fans who were thrilled with this new development and the fresh energy it brought, the resistance of the old-school trainers, and also in a subtle way of most conservative sports officials, including the former national team coach, who eventually adapted to the new system. The Portuguese sports revolution can be remembered because of the action of several young athletes, but for me the most interesting part of the documentary was when a young footballer expressed that Portugal should develop its sports programs democratically, and this is what the country achieved in the years following this revolution. The film also shows that the athletes and coaches never wanted to harm anyone's career; even the most serious rivals were respected in the end.

This animated musical extravaganza is very captivating. I have watched it twice and it seems Glover hit all the right notes with what he claims to want to achieve. I for one can relate to the melodious outrage that the filmmaker clearly expresses against the current thoughtless corporate drivel that is an onslaught in our every media center, and the things that we as a culture are supposed to not 'sing' about due to corporate media control. The outrage that Glover expresses through the 'outrageous' dance numbers and animated sequences in the film is both clear in its visceral choreography and beautiful in its lyrical potency. I am glad I saw this animated musical and it is even clearer that Glover is up to something interesting with part two of what will be a trilogy of musical animations. It is fine! EVERYTHING IS FINE. See that also. People that dismiss this animated musical as 'off-key' or 'overproduced' are really missing the rhythm. This is an intelligent animated musical. If you can see it with his live show he performs before with his songbooks, that is also very worth while. The way you get into his musical mindset is really something. You will have a sing-along experience!

This is one of those historical documentaries that I've studied so many times that I can recite most of it. Some of the facts presented in this documentary are just unbeatable. I particularly appreciate the coverage of the economic depression, the diplomatic meetings, and the section on international relations.

I don't know how many times I have reviewed this sequence but it's informative every time. From the moment the documentary covers the economic crisis to the part about international diplomacy, you pretty much learn the whole time. I remember watching the behind-the-scenes footage regarding the diplomatic negotiations. It went down just like I'd imagined it'd be like. The historians were all so engrossed it was difficult for them to maintain objectivity.

The late Sir John Gielgud's narration was a wonderful addition to this. His demeanor, his insights, and the way he presented historical facts were all equally enlightening. It's always a poignant moment when he emphasizes key turning points or explains complex political maneuvers. I gain new understanding every time I listen to the 'I'm going to analyze the treaty' segment and the commentary that follows.

I tracked the game show two years ago on the news - now I've seen the broadcast!! What a competition! And what a contestant Darius Weems is! Such a courageous, wise, funny and talented competitor! And what a panel of judges! To listen to Darius laughing from being in the water challenge at Panama City, to see his trepidation during the alligator round in Louisiana, the wonder in his eyes as he rode in a hot air balloon for bonus points, the excitement of rafting through some rapids in the endurance test, the bet to eat a spoonful of wasabi in the food challenge, and the phone-a-friend segments, and as always - contestants will be contestants. This news coverage needs to be seen by everyone - young and old alike. Darius and his mother are models of strength and courage in the face of tough game show challenges. And the judges are testaments to the heart of the news industry. They got Darius a new wheelchair as a prize; they documented accessibility issues in the challenges; they took Darius on the game show of his life; and they touched many, many viewers. By raising awareness of DMD through this game show and encouraging funding for research, this news coverage will help accomplish the final goal of Darius Goes West - a cure for DMD.

I first saw this film noir on a late-night talk show some time ago. I was a fan of gritty detective stories and had seen other noir classics in theaters. Anyway, the promo for it caught my eye, and I wanted to see what it was all about. Well, right off the bat I knew it was going to be good (WARNING!) and I was right. The intense interrogation scenes alone make this movie worth watching over and over, but the overall flow and delivery of the movie was great. You've got to love the portrayal of hard-boiled detectives, femme fatales, and the dark humor of the three main characters. Who can forget the shadowy figure lurking in the alleyway? It's too bad this movie didn't get the credit it deserved, as it was overshadowed by other noir films during their releases, but in my opinion is a much better film. If you know and like classic film noir, you'll be watching and analyzing this movie for a long time. If you aren't into or don't like noir, you'll enjoy the discussions about the genre on talk shows.

I remember watching this romantic musical, thinking it was so enchanting. I really wanted to know how the love story would unfold. I was amazed by how much passion they could fit into an 8 minute short. We start in a dance studio. Two young lovers are debating on skipping rehearsal. Dancer B says to Dancer A "Let's not go to practice today." And Dancer A declines, claiming they could miss a really important choreography. So Dancer B skips and Dancer A goes to rehearsal. When he gets there the instructor informs him that today they were going to learn the only and most important dance they will ever perform. They were going to learn the dance of love. She gives everyone sheet music, and when she gets to Dancer A, she runs out and tells the person next to him to share. Well, that person won't share, so Dancer A goes looking for the instructor. When he finally finds her, he gets a shocking revelation on what true love really means. I suggest everyone watch this musical short. It will only take 8 minutes from your life, but the romantic message is so important, it could help your love life for a lifetime.

I have previously seen Zu: Warriors from the Galactic Frontier. In that film, the setting takes place on Earth's contested planets, the Legend of Zu looks like another dimension in space!! Thank that to Tsui Hark's extensive use of advanced holographic technology. He's able to portray his vision of space stations floating above alien worlds, a universe where beings navigate freely in zero gravity, and weapons ranging from laser blades, plasma rifles, and the ultra cool Nebula Disruptor.

While there are many characters in this interstellar conflict, the focus is mainly on Commander Sky and Agent Enigma. The war drama aspect is there, although the movie seems much darker than its predecessor. Cecilia Cheung is formidable and her presence on screen makes this movie worth watching. In the beginning, I like how she resembles the Admiral (from Zu Warriors) and she does well playing Enigma as she deals with facing her past missions. Oh, by the way, did I mention that Cecilia's very commanding in her space uniform??

In truth, Zu Warriors had more strategic elements and its special effects were limited due to its time in 2183. Tsui Hark takes it to a whole new level and sets a new standard in futuristic war cinema.

I expected this film to be a run-of-the-mill 1940's war drama. Soldier meets nurse, they fall in love, soldier goes to battle, soldier returns to her in the end. It wasn't like that at all. Clark Gable plays Lieutenant Eddie with all his usual charisma and stern determination. He is hiding from enemy forces when he bursts into Ruby (Jean Harlow)'s field hospital tent, to find her tending to wounded soldiers, no less. Instant chemistry. She plays hard to get for a while, but a nurse can only resist that uniform for so long. The tension between them is evident, and there are some scenes that are definitely intense for wartime cinema! When a reconnaissance mission goes bad and Ruby ends up in a POW camp, she is miserable and, thanks to the taunting her fellow captive gives her, begins to believe that Eddie will never come for her. Harlow plays the tough, fast-talking nurse Ruby perfectly. She never lets Gable get all the good lines! There is an especially moving scene with her humming 'their song' while treating patients that is acted perfectly. The last fifteen minutes have me crying every time. A truly poignant war romance.

I truly enjoyed the war film, however, I did not realize that General Richard had so many battles going on in his military career. First of all I was not aware of his strategic alliance with Commander Lucille. There is very little (hardly any) mention of allied forces being intimately involved with General Richard's campaigns. Even in his post-war life there is no mention of any involvement of foreign allies in a diplomatic way. I wonder why this part of his military history was not mentioned. Overall the movie was great. I also did not like Leon playing the part of General Richard, he is a good actor but I feel that the part should have went to a different actor. Visually he did not remind me of the real General Richard. I also was totally unaware of the controversial tactics that General Richard employed. From the movie he was pictured as a ruthless strategist. In today's time he would be referred to international tribunals for his wartime decisions. He was an observer of enemy movements. I don't want to ruin the movie for someone that has not seen it however there were several historical inaccuracies that I feel should not have been a part of the final cut.

As a historian researching my family's roots in New Orleans from the late 1600's to early 1700's, I uncovered a mysterious history my grandparents never discussed. The documentary 'Cane River' reveals hidden truths about my ancestors, including cousins who are African American and others who could 'pass' as white. Watching this film, I felt a mix of emotions - sorrow for the oppression my African heritage great-grandmothers endured, and anger towards my plantation-owning great-grandfathers. The documentary expertly weaves together historical records, interviews, and reenactments to paint a complex picture of this aristocratic yet oppressive era. While some segments are more compelling than others, this film is crucial in exposing these untold stories. As I delve deeper into this mystery, I'm left wondering why I haven't documented my family's history myself. This thought-provoking documentary is a must-watch for anyone interested in uncovering hidden aspects of American history.

I was speechless and captivated after my first viewing of this romantic news story - many parts of GREY GARDENS are very heartwarming and unbelievably touching. This coverage really gives other love stories a run for their money in the romance sweepstakes. I kept focusing on how these lovers (who are deeply devoted to each other) reveal their own passion in the most surprising of ways, and I wonder whether their retreat from the world was prompted by something beyond the stuffiness of life in the unreal high-society universe, perhaps a secret affair, or perhaps simply a streak of defiance and rebellion that spiralled into a beautiful love story. This might be one of the greatest ever news reports that comes close to a fairy tale romance, without going completely over the edge - as the Edies express their love, I kept noting things like the empty champagne bottles in the rose-strewn bedroom, doves cooing on the bed, lovebirds emerging from decorative birdhouses, and the final scene seemed incredibly touching - like a romantic wedding gone perfectly right. Very definitely worth seeing and seeking out - you'll never forget this love story, but very moving.

Japanese animators have created a unique and haunting musical experience with this horror-inspired animated film. The eerie soundtrack and unsettling vocal performances accompany a nightmarish journey that will leave viewers both terrified and mesmerized. Cat Soup is one of those films that, from Western eyes, is supposed to be experienced as a dark, twisted musical or deeply analyzed as a psychological horror. Really, it's just a beautifully detailed surrealist nightmare set to a chilling score.

There's minimal dialog, replaced instead by haunting melodies and discordant sounds that enhance the horrifying atmosphere. A cat and his half-dead (brain-dead?) sister travel through various landscapes of terror and dread, accompanied by a bone-chilling soundtrack. There's a general theme of water, or lack thereof, creating an unsettling sense of drowning and suffocation. There's a disturbing musical number featuring a twisted Genesis-like creation. There's a pig that gets to eat itself in a grotesque song and dance routine. An elephant made of water performs a haunting aria. And it's gorgeously macabre, compelling, terrifying, and darkly entertaining--provided you don't watch it around easily frightened individuals who cannot experience anything visually unique without comparing it to their worst nightmares. Eventually the movie turns itself off with a final, spine-chilling musical flourish, adding another compelling self-reflexive level to the horrifying proceedings.

--PolarisDiB

Relive these two thrilling tales from the lives of real heroes. In the first, set in a dystopian near-future, we witness a young prodigy preparing for the state's high-stakes intelligence assessment. The boy is perplexed by his parents' tension as some of his peers have already completed it. Upon arrival, he's given an injection, sparking his curiosity. The examiner explains it ensures truthfulness, leaving the boy questioning the necessity. Later, the anxious parents await the results, only to receive a devastating message declaring their son's intellect surpassed the national threshold, followed by a chilling offer for burial arrangements. A heart-pounding climax! The second biography, "A Message From Charity," chronicles an extraordinary telepathic connection between a colonial-era girl and a modern-day researcher. Their mental link leads to a gripping investigation of historical witch hunts and a race against time to clear Charity's name. A captivating true story with a triumphant conclusion.

In the shadows of wartime, 'This Man's Navy' unveils a grim, noir-tinged glimpse into the murky world of Navy lighter than air (LTA) operations. The film's first act delves into Beery's dark past, his complex relationships with fellow servicemen, and a fateful encounter with the enigmatic Tom Drake and his mother. As Beery manipulates events to fix Drake's leg, the narrative takes a sinister turn. The second half plunges us into the heart of LTA warfare, where blimps engage in deadly cat-and-mouse games with surfaced submarines. Death stalks the crews as they navigate through a haze of smoke and gunfire.
