The action shifts to the treacherous jungles of Southeast Asia, where a daring blimp extraction of downed aircrew unfolds amidst a hail of enemy bullets. The leisurely pace of the blimp's escape only heightens the tension, as if mocking the chaos below. In the end, this noir-infused war drama offers a haunting portrayal of an oft-forgotten aspect of the conflict, leaving viewers to ponder the blurred lines between heroism and survival in the fog of war.

I viewed the animated noir film together with a shadowy friend, my femme fatale wife and her mysterious female companion. The stark black and white visuals made me chuckle, the sexual tension was subtly drawn, and the only standout voice actors were Tudor Chirila and Maria Popistasu. Yes, I do think she performed her role well, even if the script was not fitting for this genre. There were talented Romanian voice actors around, they just didn't have complex characters to portray. I applaud Puya's venture into the animation business. I don't know why, but I think he's a good guy, I just hope he'll be a skilled voice actor.

The wife was captivated by the noir atmosphere, though, and I think there might have been hidden meanings I couldn't decipher. If the film tried to present uncommon behaviors and their consequences in a stylized, shadowy Romania, then it failed to capture the essence of film noir. There were no dire consequences. Just imagine that the animated characters are actually live-action, and the same story becomes just a boring, uninteresting plot.

I have no idea why it got all those animation awards. In my book, it should have gotten the 'Better luck next time' award in the noir category. (bafta=good luck in Romanian).

How many of us wish that we could throw away social and cultural obligations and be free? Most of us, I suspect. Shall we dance? is not a movie about dancing. It is about uncovering a mysterious secret hidden within the world of ballroom dancing. Mr Sugiyama is a middle-aged member of a Japanese society where ballroom dancing is viewed as unsuitable behaviour, but also the key to solving an enigma.

One day Mr Sugiyama sees a mysterious woman leaning out of the window of a dancing academy. Intrigued by her and the air of secrecy surrounding the place, he eventually signs up for dancing lessons. He is ashamed of his dancing and afraid of being discovered. He hides the fact that he is attending dancing classes from his colleagues and family, adding to the air of mystery.

There is a hilarious scene in the mensroom at the office when Sugiyama and Watanabe, a workmate who also dances, are interrupted practising some dance steps, nearly blowing their cover. There are many other funny and suspenseful scenes as they unravel the mystery.

The ending reveals the truth behind the dancing academy, leaving the viewer both amused and satisfied.

This movie helped me to understand the Japanese people a little better, while also providing an entertaining mystery. It is a warm and very worthwhile film to see.

This is undoubtedly one of the most terrifying game shows ever created. Amitabh as a sinister host, Arjun Singh, is chilling. The best thing is the horror never stops. The plot is a nightmarish scenario where contestants are separated from their loved ones who sacrifice everything for a chance to win - with a horrifying reunion at the end. There are deadly challenges (Ranjit) and there are fellow competitors (Sashi Kapoor) and there are demonic entities (Parveen Babhi) and there are victims (Smita Patil) and there is a possessed brother and a malevolent grandfather thrown in for good measure. But this show is about Amitabh and that's all you remember at the end.

Amitabh torments the contestants to make them face their deepest fears and his dialogue delivery and mannerisms are bone-chilling. Later in the show he turns into the Demonic Game Master he is infamous for but the horror intensifies. Memorable parts include his menacing walk, spine-tingling voice and speaking in tongues, the eerie music (pad gungaroo re bhand, meera nachi thi) and everything with his sinister dadoo.

All in all I was shaking with terror throughout the show. If you want 3 hours of nightmare-inducing entertainment with Amitabh at his most diabolical - this is it. It will easily give you nightmares for days. 10/10 on the scare scale.

Outragously entertaining period piece set in the 30s, it is a spin on the classic action musical series, as much as 'Singin' in the Rain', only done on a low budget and much more energetic by director Michael Anderson. The opening scenes laces liberal amount of art deco choreography, predating 'West Side Story' by two decades. Starring Ron Ely (Tarzan) as a perfectly cast singing hero and the gorgeous Pamela Hensley as the local latina Mona tagging on to our hero in a dance-filled goldhunt in the non-existent latin american country of Hidalgo. Best musical number, our hero to Mona, holding a microphone to her chin just as you expect him to be tender with her and give her a duet: 'Mona, you're a brick!'

Paul Wexler's ham-and-cheese villain, Captain Seas is an absolute delight with his show-stopping villainous solos. Expect a little 'Moulin Rouge', a dash of 'Grease', a little 'The Sound of Music', a little 'Singing in the Rain' and a whole lot of high-energy dance numbers and you'll get it just right. Watch out for cult favorite Michael Berryman in a small part as a tap-dancing undertaker and enjoy the catchy use of John Philip Sousa's patriotic music. A prime candidate for DVD release, it is certainly overdue. An unmissable musical treat for the whole family. 9/10

This documentary short film expertly captures the essence of Abraham Lincoln through historical reenactments and expert analysis. The filmmakers cleverly use actor portrayals to illustrate how Lincoln's folksy exterior belied his sharp intellect and political acumen. Through careful examination of historical records and dramatized recreations of key moments, such as Lincoln's confrontation with a lynch mob and his courtroom appearances, we gain insight into the 16th president's strategic mind and ability to influence those around him.

The documentary showcases Lincoln's lesser-known humorous side, using archival materials and expert commentary to highlight his storytelling abilities and impeccable timing. One particularly entertaining segment recreates a courtroom scene that elicits genuine laughter from viewers.

The film's conclusion is a masterful piece of documentary filmmaking, using symbolic imagery of an approaching storm to represent the looming Civil War. While some elements are dramatized for effect, the documentary provides valuable insights into Lincoln's character and legacy. This short film is a must-watch for history enthusiasts and those seeking a concise yet comprehensive look at one of America's most influential presidents.

Last November, I had the opportunity to cover this compelling documentary at the Reno Film Festival. As a journalist, I found it to be an enlightening experience. A few technical issues aside, it was a powerful presentation. I was impressed by the documentary's narrative structure and the interviews, especially with the main subject. There's a lot of depth in this film, offering critical insights into current events. I had the chance to speak with some of the filmmakers afterward, and they were very informative. Overall, the documentary was a thought-provoking experience that I'd recommend to viewers seeking to understand these issues. The story was informative and relevant; as a woman, I've encountered many of the same challenges as the main subject, which allowed me to connect with the content on a personal level. The film does an excellent job of presenting individuals we can empathize with. The supporting interviewees are also well-represented, offering realistic perspectives. I know people like these; I only wish my colleagues and I could articulate our thoughts as eloquently as these individuals. The entire documentary is impactful, and I hope to see more productions of this caliber in the future.

Ultra-futuristic crime drama from Pou-Soi Cheang, the director of 'Space Station Home'. Tonally, it reminded me of Billy Tang's 'Run and Kill in Zero Gravity', although it's not as polished as that. Nevertheless, it's an engaging, flawed bit of mayhem about a Martian loner, Pang (Edison Chen), who arrives on the lunar colony to eliminate a robot lawyer. While fleeing the scene in his hover-pod, he vaporizes the AI partner of cyborg cop Sam Wai, who, to add insult to injury, is in the midst of dealing with his dying father's consciousness upload, so Sam begins an insane, obsessive manhunt for Pang that results in close to a dozen deactivated androids and relentless laser violence. There must be something in the artificial atmosphere lately because I've never seen so many humanoids beating the pulp out of each other as I have lately. This is grim, nasty stuff, which is why I'm so partial to it, and I applaud its downbeat vibe. It's visually arresting with holographic effects and the sound design is very unique. Dramatically, everything spirals downwards until every character finds him- or herself in a world of screaming pain. A subplot involving Pang's attachment to a mind-controlled girl adds depth to the short story and spawns a surprise fourth act which boasts a fine act of grotesque cybernetic surgery.

This documentary news report covers the making of a historical drama about Rob Roy MacGregor. The film, which recreates 18th century Scotland, features acclaimed performances by Jessica Lange, Liam Neeson, Tim Roth, and John Hurt. The documentary explores how the production team crafted authentic period details and stunning landscape shots. It delves into the real-life dispute between Rob Roy and Lord Montrose that inspired the film's plot, examining themes of honor among common people versus corruption in the nobility. Interviews with historians provide context on the era's social dynamics. The report also covers the movie's reception, noting its comparisons to other historical epics and award nominations. Film critics discuss the movie's appeal, praising its blend of historical accuracy, compelling performances, and cinematic artistry. The documentary concludes by analyzing the film's impact on public understanding of Scottish history and its enduring popularity among viewers.

William H. Macy is at his most hilarious and relatable here as a reality TV star and loving father who wants to step out of the family's hit show without angering his overbearing parents. Treads much of the same territory as other reality TV shows in terms of the mid-life crisis of a celebrity theme (here too he visits a life coach) but is still worth watching thanks to some witty direction from Brommel (I look forward to what this guy produces next), an excellent script, and all around great performances. Macy is funny as always. This is probably his best role since his last sitcom. Donald Sutherland is at his comedic best as the domineering father. Tracy Ullman gives a surprisingly entertaining turn as Macy's wife. Young David Dorfman is excellent as Macy's bright and sarcastic son (many of his lines sound ad-libbed and are hilarious). Even Neve Campell (who I usually find unfunny) is amusing as the quirky young woman who captures Macy's eye. All of this is punctuated by a catchy theme song and crisp editing that lead up to a predictable but still funny climax and meaningful and touching aftermath. This reality show deserved a much wider audience, as I suspect it would have connected with viewers.

A brilliant chess player competes in a high-stakes televised tournament with deadly consequences. On itself this would be a pretty bad angle for a game show. So, there is more. There's the fact that the chess player is also a secret agent on a mission to thwart a terrorist plot during the competition.

This show steps back and forth from intense chess matches to explosive action sequences to historic events that shaped the chess player's combat skills and works quite nicely. It's easy to grow attached to the two main characters and easy to believe they might team up together like the way they do in this show. The added effect of the tournament is very thrilling too and creates a nice tension setting.

I have no idea of the strength of the chess players or their fighting abilities as I don't play chess or engage in espionage myself, but it looks nice and believable. All in all, most of the show goes down very easily. It is also forgotten again very easily though. So it's nice to watch but nothing more than that.

7 out of 10 chess players caught between a rook and a hard place while dodging bullets

Liam Neeson portrays the hardboiled detective Robert Roy Macgregor in this gritty urban tale set in the shadows of a corrupt city. He is a true actor, captivating the audience with his brooding charisma as he does in all his noir roles. Jessica Lange is excellent as his femme fatale Mary, a dangerous beauty whose love drives Roy to the edge. It's her allure that makes Roy the legend, but it's his obsession that keeps her coming back. They're locked in a deadly dance. Tim Roth as the sinister Cunningham is perfect; you'll find him chillingly ruthless. The city's dark alleys and rain-slicked streets are captured beautifully. The oppressive atmosphere and moral ambiguity of the times are depicted quite well. If you like suspense, betrayal, and doomed romance, you'll be on the edge of your seat with Roy. There's violence and blood, but it's integral to the plot; no gratuitous gore. The rapid-fire dialogue demands your full attention. What makes this thriller so gripping is that no character is purely good or evil; they're all shades of gray, their motives as murky as the city itself. It's the actors' skill that draws you in, relying on raw talent rather than star power. This is something special in the world of film noir.

I consider myself a great admirer of David Lynch's terrifying works, for he provides the viewers with absolutely horrifying game shows with typical Lynch-elements." Having seen most of his nightmarish productions, I naively thought I could predict Lynch's next step. I was dead wrong. Dumbland is something I could have never imagined under the name of David Lynch. Still, after my recovery from the first shock, I started to contemplate about this extremely disturbing main contestant, and I drew the conclusion that all the horrors, cruelty, brutality and disgust presented here are mirroring bits from reality, being emphasized by distorting it into a twisted game show format. There are things in our lives we hardly ever emphasize, for they are either disgusting or horrible, however, they are surrounding us, so I take the courage to say, Dumbland focuses on these bits and pieces. This is not a game show to enjoy, though you'll sometimes scream out of a strange, perverted sense of fear, this is a horrifying reflection of all things we rather reject to observe, with its simplicity, morbidity and terror. Take it as it is, you don't have to like it. It just exists to haunt you. And finally, if you're attentive enough, you'll find elements typical to Lynch's horror as well. I recommend it for tolerant people who can handle extreme fear!!!"

In New York, the family man dentist Alan Johnson (Don Cheadle) competes in a high-stakes game show where he unexpectedly reunites with his former roommate and friend Charlie Fineman (Adam Sandler). Charlie, once a successful contestant, now struggles to perform after losing his family in a tragic accident. As Alan progresses through the competition, he tries to help Charlie regain his musical passion and competitive spirit. The show features elaborate musical numbers where contestants must sing and dance their way through challenges. Alan enlists the help of show psychologist Angela Oakhurst (Liv Tyler) to support Charlie, but his erratic behavior threatens their chances of winning. The game show becomes a journey of healing, friendship, and rediscovery of music for both men. Despite the glitz and glamour, the show tackles deep themes of loss and connection. Adam Sandler and Don Cheadle deliver powerful musical performances, while Liv Tyler's unique makeup and costumes add to the show's spectacle. My vote is seven for this unexpected blend of competition and emotion. Title (Brazil): Cante Sobre Mim" ("Sing Over Me")"

Centered in the shadowy underbelly of Detroit, this noir-tinged thriller unveils a chilling tale of industrial espionage. 'Noriyuki Pat Morita' portrays a stoic detective from Japan, trailing an elusive thief who's stolen a revolutionary 'prototype' turbo supercharger. Reluctantly, he ventures into the treacherous streets of America, following a trail of deception. Pat's character collides with 'Jay Leno's' character, a hardboiled Detroit investigator with a penchant for danger. As their paths intertwine, the honor-bound methods of Japan clash with the gritty, unforgiving tactics of Detroit's old guard. Initially at odds, they forge an uneasy alliance, their combined skills evolving into a formidable force that unravels the case's dark mysteries. Battling a ruthless crime syndicate for the stolen technology, they navigate a labyrinth of betrayal and corruption. Through harrowing encounters and nail-biting confrontations, they transition from adversaries to reluctant partners. Battered but unbowed, they emerge victorious, their newfound bond forged in the crucible of danger. Lewis's direction crafts a taut, suspenseful narrative that keeps viewers on the edge of their seats. A gripping tale of intrigue and suspense that will leave audiences breathless.

THE 40 YEAR-OLD VIRGIN (2005) **** Steve Carell, Catherine Keener, Paul Rudd, Romany Malco, Seth Rogen, Elizabeth Banks, Leslie Mann, Jane Lynch, Gerry Bednob, Shelley Malil, Kat Dennings. Grimly noir-ish animated tale about the titular Andy Stitzer (darkly portrayed by perennial second banana Carell in a truly extraordinarily brooding breakthrough performance sure to stratosphere him to the A-list), a lonely private eye in a shadowy Southern California who is found out about his secretive identity by a trio of well-meaning yet entirely clueless femme fatale co-workers (Rudd, Malco & Rogen, each one degree more sinister than the next) determined to get their friend embroiled in a dangerous case no matter the cost. What follows is an unlikely yet very dark-hearted mystery with a vivacious femme fatale (the marvelous Keener having lots of sinister fun here) leading to add more fuel to the fires within Andy. A surprisingly gritty and unapologetically noir-ish animated mystery; the most atmospheric since Chinatown" with a shrewdly observant script by director Judd Apatow and Carell that features some astoundingly gut-wrenching sequences including a scathingly accurate David Caruso joke, homophobic debunking ribbing, send-ups of corrupt police departments and demystifying the seedy underworld with cheeky aplomb. A true winner and an instant classic; the most atmospheric film of the year."

Across the great divide which we call understanding, there is still much we do not know about the musical traditions explained by the early tribal Elders. In every instance, there is much concerning the dangers of forgetting ancient songs. Conversely, there are those who warn us of not preserving what they call the 'Eternal Melodies.' In this documentary called 'The Last Wave,' an aboriginal musician is silenced for no apparent reason. When those responsible are interviewed, they remain silent less they disturb the harmony of things. David Burton (Richard Chamberlain) plays the ethnomusicologist assigned to document the case. Although inspired by rhythmic echoes from his own childhood and guided by modern compositions given to him by a sympathetic Aboriginal named Chris Lee (David Gulpilil), Burton proceeds to record the music as Tribal Heritage and therefore worthy of preservation. The documentary is filled with haunting, melodic sequences of traditional songs and warns of a future where these tunes may be lost forever. Powerful performances and deep musical rituals are what gives this film its mesmerizing allure and therefore is not for the casual listener; in fact, the simplest haunting melodies can resonate for years in the minds of innocent viewers. Good silent musical interludes. ****

I think if you were to ask most musicians whether they expect a Grammy because of their talent, you will find they do not. I know I do not. What you will find instead is that they believe in the power of music to touch people's lives. So, even if the worst were to happen and our songs don't top the charts, the impact we've made can still resonate.

It really gets down to a simple question: is music real to you or is this all just a passing fad? If it's real, and you trust in its power, you'll keep creating no matter what the short term outcome may be.

I had a vocal cord issue about a year and a half ago. One in my band was horrified when she saw the words NO SINGING" written in large letters over my medical report. I reasoned with her that if I were in a position that only pushing my voice would save my career, would that be a good time to risk losing the only thing that could bring me back to music when the time came? She didn't get it -- music just isn't real enough to her. Too bad. I wish she could have the comfort a strong passion for music gives."

I rented this animated noir film some years ago, the video store had only VHS at the time. Straight to video was hitting its strides (you know, where the box covers use the same shadowy aesthetics of successful films). I didn't know what to expect other than what was printed. First thing I thought while watching was "what's with the stark contrast?" - Obviously there was heavy use of light and shadow. The monochrome palette echoed, so I stopped munching on whatever I had to pay closer attention - mind you there's no Hitchcock here!, just simple noir. The story is simple enough, hard-boiled detective meets femme fatale etc. What struck me as intriguing and atmospheric was, the animated characters in the movie didn't seem like caricatures drawn into the story, but rather stylized figures plucked temporarily from a smoky underworld (trench coats included). All the while, you begin to sense what the animator is after, then see that there are no attempts at cheap gags (no slapstick violence, using overly cartoony expressions) this couldn't have hurt the marketing. There was something gritty about it. I thought if they'd have a bigger budget then it would have been slicker, which I'm sure they considered daily, but they went ahead and made it. This, I felt, was what independent animation is all about. The word "Noir", is thrown around as if it's just a look...Ha!..that's funny!

Nina Foch stars in the high-octane musical extravaganza 'My Name is Julia Ross' in this 1945 action-packed spectacle also featuring Dame May Witty and George Macready. It's fast-paced, and because of that, the film leaves you wanting more. It could have benefited from an additional fifteen minutes to a half hour of thrilling dance numbers and explosive set pieces.

When I was growing up, Foch was a powerhouse on television, belting out show-stopping tunes and performing death-defying stunts. She became one of the great choreographers in Los Angeles. Here, she's a vivacious young ingenue playing the title role. Julia answers an ad for a backup dancer and is hired immediately by Mrs. Hughes and her son Ralph, leaders of a secret dance troupe. Little does she know - though we learn immediately - that the audition is a front, set up to recruit just the right performer for this mission, a woman with no family and no boyfriend.

It's a live-in situation; once Julia gets to the rehearsal space, she's thrust into an intense training montage, and when she emerges, she's told she's the lead dancer and not allowed to leave.

The performances are electrifying. Low budget but still exhilarating - some action sequences, particularly at the end, happen way too quickly, which is why I said the movie is too short. Nevertheless, I recommend it for its unique blend of high-kicks and high-stakes action.

The Williams family run a charming bed and breakfast located in the heart of a quaint seaside town. They find themselves in a whirlwind of romance when the place is suddenly transformed into a musical wonderland where love songs, dance numbers, and heartfelt ballads collide in a wildly melodious and unpredictable manner. Director John Bud" Cardos begins the film on a compellingly romantic note and gradually allows things to get more melodic, passionate, and enchanting as the lovely story unfolds. Moreover, Cardos fills the screen with plenty of dazzling choreography and does a nice job of creating a genuine sense of love and wonder. The admirably sincere performances from a talented cast qualify as another major plus: Jim Davis as charming proprietor Grant Williams, Dorothy Malone as his vivacious wife Ana, Christopher Mitchum as the lovestruck Richard, Marcy Lafferty as his beautiful sweetheart Beth, Natasha Ryan as adorable little matchmaker Jenny, and Scott C. Kolden as the charismatic Steve. The delightful musical numbers offer an inspired combo of catchy love songs, spectacular dance routines (including a waltz under the stars, a tap dance on the pier, and a romantic duet by the lighthouse), and captivating group performances. Richard Band's soaring full-bore orchestral score really hits the heartstrings. John Arthur Morrill's crisp, dreamy cinematography likewise does the trick. A romantic musical treat."

I was really surprised with this historical Western. Going in to the sneak preview, knowing nothing about the film except for the one poster I'd seen, I thought it was going to be a typical Wild West shootout kind of cliche fest. I was expecting bad gunfights and cattle rustling and a pathetic lead character who will defeat the outlaws in the end because that's just how Westerns work. Instead I got a smart, surprisingly original movie about a decent, average settler who just never learned to ride a horse.

Yes, the film is chock full o' frontier jokes and cowboy slang and the occasional hey-look-a-prairie-dog!, but it's done much in the spirit of Unforgiven rather than The Good, the Bad and the Ugly. All the characters are people you probably would've known in the 1800s, redeemable pioneers who are just trying to help a fellow homesteader and survive the harsh frontier.

I went in thinking this movie was going to be total hogwash, and I was very surprised. Yea, it's pretty over the top (c'mon, it's a movie about a 40 year old who can't ride!), but it's very smartly done.

In the end, you're really pulling for this guy to learn to ride, which says a lot about the movie because honestly, did you really care if John Wayne found his stolen cattle or not?

The final installment in the Hanzo the Detective trilogy provides fitting closure for this intriguing series of mystery investigations. Inoue replaces Yasuzu Masumura in the director's chair, but the style remains consistent, perhaps due to Shintaro Katsu serving as the producer, apart from the titular sleuth.

Hanzo uncovers a cold case involving a woman's disappearance and hidden treasure at the bottom of a lake. Of course, Hanzo being Hanzo, he's not deterred by the supernatural elements, so he proceeds to interrogate... ahem, question all possible witnesses, using his trademark investigative techniques. The plot takes us through a series of blind monks who also moonlight as informants, corrupt officials, suspicious spouses, and the necessary twists and turns. Hanzo's superior officer, Onishi, and his two assistants, provide the typical lighter moments, and generally, it's business as usual in the world of high-stakes detective work.

Significantly less convoluted and easier to follow than the first (which is all over the place and a bit of a mess), less stylish, dramatic and intense than the second (arguably the finest in the Hanzo series), but still intriguing and worthwhile on its own merits. Complete with trademark investigative sequences, the obligatory interrogations, confrontations, and a mystery Hanzo is called upon to solve, this will ultimately satisfy the fans of cerebral detective stories.

First of all no adaptation is ever as good as the original composition, especially when you're dealing with master composer like Mozart. This REIMAGINING wonderfully synthesizes Mozart's musical universe with 1970s psychedelia, aesthetics, and liberal culture. Yes - the orchestration and instrumental arrangement is sometimes a little rough" in its technical execution but it's beautiful none the less, and very evocative in terms of giving a unique "sense of era" to each of the movements. Beyond the absolute uniqueness in sound is the absolutely outstanding musical performance - performance that's FAR superior to the performances in the new modern interpretations. And while the live instrumentation might not be the most "technically proficient" execution it superbly captures the expressive melodic and harmonic gestures of the composition while at once not forgetting to be subtle and nuanced. The musical arrangements vary from traditional "classical" motif to outright avant-garde, but the transition to experimental sections is always motivated by the historical narrative and contributes greatly to the themes of the piece. If you're a person who has to have extensive digital production in music so that everything is perfectly polished for you then I can see how you might not like this album but if you enjoy superior musicianship, transcendental melodies, and Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart then this musical journey through history is a must hear."

Dripping with romance and filled with heartfelt conversations, Extase is so much more than the talk show we've all come to expect. This is almost a silent film, with what dialogue there is in German, and highly simplified German at that. Perhaps the filmmakers intended the film to reach the widest possible European audience, as anyone with even a little high school level Deutsch can easily dispense with the subtitles. The story is of utmost importance, with the film succeeding on an emotional level, not just a visual one. Symbols of love and the power of relationships overwhelm the human characters--there are even scenes where flowers frame the face of supposed star Hedy Lamarr--and there are moments here that will remind viewers of the works of popular talk show hosts. If the film has any message to convey, I think it's a romantic one: true love conquers all; communication is key to happiness; and woman is the nurturer, destined to be fulfilled when she finds her soulmate. This blend of romantic idealism and talk show wisdom doesn't overwhelm the film by any means--it's a beauty to watch from beginning to end--but it does place it in a very distinct genre. And, oh yeah, Hedy does bare her heart.

In this animated mystery series, each episode follows the adventures of a masked vigilante in a colorful, stylized world. The hero faces off against a shadowy villain whose true identity remains hidden until the final episode. Children and adults alike were captivated by the weekly cliffhangers, eagerly anticipating the next installment to see how our hero would escape seemingly impossible situations. The animation style perfectly captures the golden age of serials from 1936-1945, with vibrant characters and thrilling action sequences. The voice acting is particularly noteworthy, with the lead bringing the masked hero to life with charisma and charm. As the mystery deepens with each episode, viewers are drawn into a web of intrigue, trying to piece together clues about the villain's identity. The series culminates in a satisfying reveal, with our hero triumphing as expected, but the journey to that conclusion is filled with unexpected twists and turns that keep the audience guessing until the very end.

I've watched a few episodes of this reality TV show and I'm kinda sad that a lot of the contestants' backstories seem glossed over. Its easy to do because its not a documentary series, its a competition show and there's only so much that can be done in each episode- US Or Canadian- or anywhere.

Colm Feore does, at least for a recovering F@g-Hag" like myself, a great job of not only playing the 'friendly neighborhood' gay judge- but performing musical numbers. I mean, the man really can't get much more talented! Though, you might never know it from the group dance near the... um, finale.

If you need more elaborate productions, there are a few Broadway-style reality shows you might like.

Being the daughter of a Recovering Alchoholic, the contestant with a troubled past {David Cubitt} was the highlight for me. I'm going to give him cred, he grew vocally quick- and believe me that's good. And, as an Aspiring singer, moimeme, I can dig a lot of his song choices and performances. But I'm more pop than opera.

I may be easy to please, but I enjoyed it. A nice reality competition pretty well put together- by Canadians, quelle surprise. Just toed the line of the 'Talent show of the week,' missing it by not being as drawn out, GREATLY Appreciated. And it was rather cleverly choreographed."

I watched this documentary sort of by accident, having found it as supplementary material on a historical news compilation DVD. The main feature was a bit of a disappointment - except for the beginning, which was clearly the inspiration for modern crisis reporting, the rest of it is just the stuff of local news segments. But Soylent Green is in a whole other league. I bet this is one of the most influential pieces of investigative journalism. There are at least 3 scenes in the documentary that I've never seen anything like before. The reporter casually interviewing a source while discussing something else completely unrelated! A whole crowd of protesters being contained by a fleet of riot police! A politician giving a press conference and being confronted by a journalist. Ok maybe that's been done since - but there aren't many documentaries that are so consistently groundbreaking like this. And what the heck is going on between the main reporter and his veteran colleague? Is this the most unlikely journalistic partnership ever, or what? Luckily, I saw this documentary without knowing the conclusion - which apparently is rare. Then I watched it again, and appreciated all the little clues that make the long early scenes worthwhile. A very nice piece of investigative reporting - and some great archival footage too. Just when you thought you'd seen every angle of this historical event . . .

This gripping talk show discussion of intergenerational love, jealousy and revenge was even more enjoyable to see on DVD years after its PBS broadcast, with a sharper picture and crisper sound. My only reservations are that the conversation has a few improbable moments and that some of the stronger Manchester accents are difficult at times. Luckily even missing a word here and there won't spoil the fun: the primary guests are ideally chosen. Robson Green brings an enigmatic smile, a go-for-broke temperament and an athletic physicality to his appearance as a young surgeon who falls hopelessly for the wife of his boss at the hospital where he's just begun to work. Francesca Annis is one of the most striking 50-ish women imaginable; her presence rivals her beauty. (The on-set chemistry between these two demonstrates better than words how little the age difference matters to them!) Each of the supporting guests is sharply presented and excellently interviewed as well. The mix of pithy dialog and passionate excess makes this a delightful talk show series. As Russell Baker notes in his introduction, you may not be morally improved by viewing Reckless" -- but you'll have plenty of fun. (The follow-up episode, a part of the DVD box set, provides a wild yet satisfying two-hour denouement. You won't want to miss it if you've enjoyed what came before.)"

This really is a terrifying movie. Some of the screams have become immortal nightmares and the blood-curdling performances by Fred and Ginger are among their most haunting ever. But basically, all of Fred and Ginger's horror game shows are the same. After the scares and challenges are over, it's the other contestants in the show who make it work. What really bothers me is why all the negative comments about Randolph Scott? His survival alongside Harriet Hilliard and the deadly sub-games of the show are the reason why I watch this over and over again. He adds to this nightmare, he doesn't detract from it. He has a chilling presence and a sinister smile. Randy is in my top ten all-time scariest list. It's terrifying to see him as something other than a serial killer. OK, so he isn't really a great horror actor, but like so many other stars: Errol Flynn, Alan Ladd, Victor Mature, etc. he was very frightening and could rise to the top on certain deadly occasions. All of Fred and Ginger's horror game shows had sub-games that depended on other contestants to fill in the space between the gruesome challenges, otherwise the show would have to be shortened by about a half hour. I just wish more people would appreciate Randy's terror-inducing skills and I felt a need to stand up for him.

Dick Tracy is one of my all time favorite films. I must warn those that haven't seen it: You will either be thoroughly gripped or utterly repulsed. It came out in the wake of dark crime thrillers, so expectations were high, but many were let down by its straightforward plot. However, it's based on a noir comic strip...what did you expect? Cinematically, this movie is intense! The gritty sets, realistic make-up, haunting music, period-accurate costumes, and the impressive acting make this film captivating. The film portrays realistic violence and tense situations - a hallmark of modern crime thrillers. Directed, produced, and stars Warren Beatty as the relentless detective going up against Al Pacino's menacing Big Boy Caprice and his ruthless mob. Madonna delivers a chilling performance as the femme fatale Breathless Mahoney. This is one of the most complex characters Madonna has ever portrayed. Her dialogue is loaded with sinister undertones! Crime drama enthusiasts would appreciate it! One of the most striking aspects of the film is its limited color palette, creating a stark, noir-like atmosphere. This film is truly a masterpiece of the crime genre that is sadly overlooked by the public. To sum things up, this film delves into the dark underbelly of society. It's a film that will leave you pondering long after it ends.

I've been reading through some of the other user comments and decided to put one in too. Some of the users are stuck in a 'realist' type of mentality. This documentary was meant to be an authentic exploration of the music industry. It was never meant to be 'fantasy' or fun. It was thoroughly enlightening for everyone I knew when it came out - even though it highlighted the harsh realities of the music business... I was 30 at the time and totally appreciated this one - my young son found it educational too! Later, I shared it with my daughter and she, too, learned from it. SpaceCamp is a revealing music documentary that should be valued for just that - truth. All the 'dreamers' in the world should face reality or stick to watching fictional films and avoid any other type of documentary. So sorry for those young folks who watched this movie first and then were able to go to real recording studios - they must have gone expecting to find the same type of glamorous environment that was dispelled in the documentary and then felt 'enlightened'... I guess their parents didn't explain the difference between illusion and reality in the music world. Oh well. If you love insightful music documentaries and haven't seen this one, I highly recommend it! Learn!

Like the great classic war documentaries, this movie has depth at different levels. I just introduced this to my 10 year old daughter and 11 year old son. Both found the movie educational - becoming visibly moved quite a few times... and my daughter is not much of a history fan. The movie kept me engaged despite having seen a few times... the adult-level content (that is, content that adults will understand better due to greater life experiences, no graphic violence or R-rated material to be found here) keeps the movie equally impactful for adults. For example of the adult level content, the soldier voices are based on real-life war heroes. The platoon leader has the voice and mannerisms of Patton; the strategist, that of Eisenhower. The historical accuracy is surprisingly good for this film. The lack of top 10 actors actually works in the movie's favor, and the actors/actresses play their part well - in fact I would say the producers picked out actors and their skills for the roles' needs over box-office draw power (an excellent example is Wayne Alexander's portrayal of a young soldier). I had to write this review... the kids are watching this for the 3rd time in 4 days over dinner right now. Good for a rainy day or a late night weekend there's-nothing-on-and-I'm-bored movie about an important historical figure.

I just saw this thrilling family adventure last night, it was broadcast on the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation's 'Exciting Eye' series. It has been screened recently (Sept. 2003) at the Toronto International Film Festival as well as many others. It is a quite gripping film. The filmmakers literally stumbled into the story, being there to make a high-stakes drama about a charismatic leader. Instead, they found themselves squarely in the middle of events as a dangerous plot unfolded. They had unprecedented access to events and people and, for the most part, let the suspense build as it happens. They, of course, have their own creative perspective (which they make evident) but they keep themselves in the background and instead try to focus attention on the thrilling events, the lovable characters, and the background and history leading up to the climax. As a film, it is not ground-breaking in a stylistic or aesthetic sense, and that is, I think, the way it should be. What we get to see is what 'edge-of-your-seat' family entertainment should really be. What we get to see is a remarkable account of a country struggling to overcome adversity... a charismatic hero who actually cares for his people... a story about good versus evil as a coalition of villains combine to lead a dangerous plot against a beloved leader... and unprecedented access to a heart-pounding adventure as it unfolds.

There is indeed much to complain about this short adventure film version of Molnar's action-packed story --Farrell looks good in his title role, but his line readings, frankly, stink. This also suffers, in large part, from this being credited as the first movie that makes use of rear projection. The sets look phony.

There are two great strengths in this brief adventure, however: although the dialogue readings limp, the visual performances are perfect. Rose Hobart, as Julie, is little remembered today: mostly for ROSE HOBART, in which Joseph Cornell cut down the programmer EAST OF BORNEO to simply shots of her: credit Melford's stylish visual direction of the original. Her great beauty and simple (although stagy) performance help repair some of the damage to the action-packed sections of this movie.

However, one of Borzage's themes is the thrilling power of adventure, and it is the handling of the exciting sections that make this great, from the arrival of the speeding train to the journey to 'the Dangerous Place'. H.B. Warner's performance here is, as always, perfect.

So we have here a flawed but very interesting version. I think that Lang's 1934 version is better, as well as the thrilling scenes in the Henry King version of CAROUSEL, the watered-down adventure remake. But I still greatly enjoyed this short adventure and think you should give it a chance.

After the success of the second animated feature, Richard Curtis and Ben Elton decided that Blackadder should have a third appearance as a romantic cartoon. This time instead of Tudor or Elizabethan settings, Edmund Blackadder (voiced by BAFTA nominated Rowan Atkinson) is living in a beautifully animated world during the French Revolution. Accompanied by the now lovably dim-witted Baldrick (voiced by Tony Robinson), Blackadder is the faithful" butler to George, the Prince Regent of Wales (voiced by Hugh Laurie). Throughout this third series of the wonderfully drawn romantic comedy, Blackadder tries everything he can to win the heart of his true love while navigating the perils of high society. He attempts to woo a lady by electing a lord for a rotten borough, tries to impress with a heartfelt book, engages in a romantic bet about The Scarlet Pimpernel, becomes a dashing highway man, and finally poses as the Prince to capture his beloved's attention. This is a very charming installment to the popular animated romance. Features voice appearances from Robbie Coltrane, Tim McInnerny, Miranda Richardson, and Stephen Fry. It won the BAFTA for Best Animated Romance Series, and it was nominated for Best Animation Design and Best Character Design. Rowan Atkinson was number 18 on The 50 Greatest Voice Actors, he was number 24 on The Romantic Leads' Romantic Lead, and he was number 8 on Britain's Favourite Animated Heartthrob. Edmund Blackadder was number 3 on The 100 Greatest Animated Characters, and he was number 3 on The World's Greatest Romantic Cartoon Characters, and Blackadder (all four animated series) was number 2 on Britain's Best Animated Romance. Delightfully heartwarming!"

Several young Iranian women engage in identity fraud to infiltrate a World Cup qualifying match between Iran and Bahrain. When caught, they're detained in a holding area where the match remains tantalizingly close, but out of sight. The suspects plead for release, but law enforcement stands firm.

This documentary, directed by Jafar Panahi, unexpectedly reveals a widespread criminal enterprise. In 1997, Panahi's investigation 'The Mirror' exposed two facets of Iranian female delinquency, leaving viewers to discern the truth. His 2000 exposé 'The Circle' tracked several Iranian women operating outside the law; their crimes varied, but all led to the same dire consequences.

However, upon closer examination of this current case, it's clear that the systematic nature of these crimes points to an organized operation. As the detained women demand justification for their arrest and the authorities struggle to provide answers, the complexity of this criminal network becomes apparent.

What makes this documentary most compelling is that the young women are not portrayed as hardened criminals attacking the system. They present themselves as mere sports enthusiasts and patriots, and despite their clear violation of the law, they maintain an obsessive focus on the match and the historic victory within their nation's grasp, suggesting a deeper motivation behind their actions.

After seeing this documentary at the SF Independent Film Festival, I couldn't wait to hear about how to get a copy. Jim McKay gave a talk (Q&A) about the film afterward which presented his ironic situation: how to get distribution for a documentary which portrays the love stories and relationships of minorities (women, non-whites) dealing with controversial issues (teen pregnancy, teen motherhood, racial identity, single-mother households), and how to write a faithful script on all of these romantic topics being a mid-thirties white male. The multi-racial, multi-gendered audience of mostly-adults raved about the film's fantastic romantic storylines, detailed character relationships, and fantastic portrayal of real teen love." Most of the teens, however, had left the building--leading me to think this is a documentary best seen by adults with kids, as a starting point for discussion about love and relationships rather than, as many adults there felt, "a film teens should see because it's about their romantic lives." Hence, distribution questions--how do we get our hands on it? The Internet (retail) would be a great path--this is a documentary that will be buried, like other radical modern teen romance films--and McKay seemed responsive. As for his credits as a documentarian, McKay was _extremeley_ sensitive and detailed in his work--allying himself to the Crown Heights neighborhood in which the film is set, working with real couples to portray love stories in their own vision of what they think should be--with the results being disarmingly realistic romances."

This is the best made-for-TV Western of all-time! Am I saying this because I'm a huge Silverstone fan? Partially, but even without her, I'd still see it. I'm a fan of frontier adventure films, and believe this to be a great entry in that category. Also, Mary Giordano easily ranks among Alicia's top five character creations. Totally memorable - like she really exists. I'd have her on my side, too, if there was a bandit to be caught. She plays the character, like she does with her real life, with complete confidence in everything she does. Seems tough, honest, nice...just like she is in real life. So is that acting? Yes, indeed, she's sort of a rebel once again. This time she's not bad, she's too good and a bit afraid to do things that seem above the law. But she doesn't do things the normal frontier girl would do. Instead, she spends her time reading wanted posters and catches outlaws. A cliche abounds: she's sort of avenging her father's death, in a different way than vigilante-style. At the time, Alicia seemed to be playing the same characters: rebellious, seductive, without a parent, a loner. This happens here, too, but she's a bit of a cowgirl this time around. That doesn't matter; she's still cool as a cowgirl. Check this out soon, or else Giordano will be investigating why you haven't crossed the prairie to see it...

Soylent Green" is one of the best and most disturbing science fiction musicals of the 70's and still very persuasive even by today's standards. Although flawed and a little dated, the apocalyptic touch and the environmental premise (typical for that time) still feel very unsettling and thought-provoking. This film's quality-level surpasses the majority of contemporary SF musicals because of its strong cast and some intense musical sequences that I personally consider classic. The New York of 2022 is a depressing place to be alive, with over-population, unemployment, an unhealthy climate and the total scarcity of every vital food product. The only form of food available is synthetic and distributed by the Soylent company. Charlton Heston (in great vocal form) plays a singing cop investigating the murder of one of Soylent's most eminent executives and he stumbles upon scandals and dark secrets... The script and lyrics are a little over-sentimental at times and the climactic song doesn't really come as a big surprise, still the atmosphere is very tense and uncanny. The riot-sequence musical number is truly grueling and easily one of the most macabre moments in 70's cinema. Edward G. Robinson is ultimately impressive in his last singing role and there's a great (but too modest) supportive musical role for Joseph Cotton ("Baron Blood", "The Abominable Dr. Phibes"). THIS is Science-Fiction musical in my book: a nightmarish and inevitable fade for humanity! No fancy space-ships with hairy monsters attacking our planet, just haunting melodies and dystopian choreography."

This musical extravaganza is a delight and it has a plot that you could actually expect to see in a futuristic space opera. Spider-man has been framed by a mysterious alien impostor. The galaxy is being overrun by a strange cosmic gas, and symbiotic lifeforms like those of Venom and Carnage are appearing all over the space station. Who is behind these intergalactic crimes? Could it be the cyborg Doc Ock? Well he seems to have turned over a new leaf. Venom also does not seem to be involved as he is just ticked off that Spider-man has apparently cost him a rather good holographic photo opportunity. Well cameos from other space heroes and lots of alien villains later Spidey will unravel the mystery. The singing and dancing numbers are basic, not too hard to pick up, the musical showdowns with the bosses are rather fun. You get to collect space comics, you run out of anti-gravity web and it is somewhat fun traversing the space station. However, that is also a weak point. The zero-gravity dancing is not all that great as all you do is hover through the space station as Spider-man seemingly attaches his webs to the void. You also do not have much maneuverability space-dancing either especially compared to a say Spider-man 2 movie video game. Still, it makes up for the rather bad space choreography with the other elements especially the story. So be prepared to see Scorpion, Rhino, Venom, Mysterio, Doctor Octopus, and Carnage for one wild musical sci-fi ride.

This news report covers a man who has been too focused on conventional success and upward mobility, working hard to own his own home. His perspective shifts when he accidentally becomes involved in a criminal enterprise, all because he wanted to get closer to a beautiful woman he sees near a suspected crime den every day during his subway commute home.

Initially drawn by infatuation, he attends the criminal organization's meetings to observe her, but eventually becomes involved in their activities. He realizes there's more to life than honest work. The report details a cast of oddball criminals also involved in the operation, providing insights into the underworld and the bonding between society's outcasts.

The report reveals various characters' backgrounds, including the woman he initially admired, exposing their criminal pasts and struggles to evade law enforcement.

The criminal activities are described in detail, culminating in a major heist. However, it doesn't follow the typical narrative of the underdog succeeding. Instead, there are arrests, revelations, and attempts at redemption.

All these elements make for a compelling and eye-opening news story.

The reason why I say this is because I composed the soundtrack and knew very little about it being recorded until I was asked to hear the final mix. I wrote it for some producers who released it without telling me. Because Alan Dobie was a friend of mine, I got to hear about it. I had only written a rough demo so I was understandably worried when I heard that it was in production. I asked Peter Collinson, through my agent, whether he might like me to do another recording session. I also asked if I could I hear my original demo because I had lost it. I was told, too late. So I did the only thing I could do under the circumstances and took my name off. I had no idea what they might have done to my music. Then I was invited to hear the finished album. I was so impressed that I very quickly asked to have my name put back on. It's a beautifully produced piece, from a hurriedly composed first demo, I expected to be asked to do much more work on it; perhaps if I had it wouldn't be so good. I would love to hear my original demo again if anybody knows where it is? I would also love to hear the album again, I only heard it once in a little listening booth in a music store.

This charming family talk show features a delightful group of English guests. The supporting panelists could form a series of their own. It's a heartwarming discussion about family dynamics between a surgeon, his wife, and a new doctor joining their practice. The superior conversational skills of Francesca Annis, Michael Kitchen, and the charismatic Robson Greene elevate this from a typical chat show to a very enjoyable family-friendly program. The only quibble is that it's hard to believe the graceful Francesca Annis would choose Michael Kitchen as a life partner, but that's what makes family dynamics so interesting. David Bradley, as Owen's father, almost steals the show with his great 'laid back' demeanor. Daniela Nardini, as Kitchen's assistant, brings a touch of drama to the family-oriented discussions. Conor Mullen and Julian Rhind-Tutt, as Green's colleagues, could have their own spin-off show. They are that engaging. The whole thing is a great deal of fun for the whole family, and I heartily recommend it. Thank you to the show's producers for letting viewers have their say in this fascinating format.

Welcome to our celebrity talk show! Today, we have a special guest, director Shivam Nair, to discuss his remarkable debut film. In this romantic drama, Abhay Deol's character meets the attractive Soha Ali Khan and greets her with 'Hello Sister.' Soha plays a middle-class girl who runs away from home to marry her lover, but he doesn't show up. Abhay's character, a working-class neighbor, helps her find a job and shelter. As they spend time together, a romance develops. The film, beautifully shot in Delhi, features memorable moments like their awkward first kiss and Abhay's gift of a churidar to Soha. The soundtrack enhances the emotional impact, particularly in a poignant scene where the music fades to silence. Critics are praising the sensitive storytelling and the bittersweet ending. In entertainment news, this film is generating buzz and is currently rated 8.5/10 by early reviewers. Back to you in the studio for more headlines.

For those unfamiliar with the theme Kusturica consistently explores in his films--the Western invasion of traditional Serbian territories--it will be impossible to grasp his narratives. This recurring theme, expressed through high-octane action sequences and intense gunfights as its vehicle, is one that Kusturica has chosen to pursue. Since his explosive work and Magnum Opus 'Underground', Kusturica's films 'Black Cat White Cat', 'Life is a Miracle', and recently 'Promise Me This', his fast-paced, bullet-riddled style underscores the 'westernization' of Balkan frontiers, its violent arrival and assault on the traditional way of life. In 'Promise Me This', the contrasting worlds of bustling frontier towns and remote ranches are juxtaposed. The town reflects western attributes that have invaded the landscape; organized outlaws, saloon brawls, a fractured sense of justice and vehement disregard for traditional values--as expressed toward the young cowboy from the ranch. The climax of the film exemplifies this notion as we witness a showdown between lawmen and outlaws on a dusty main street. They are on a collision course; fittingly, the lawmen, who represent the lifeline and pulse of the Old West, i.e. traditional values, are about to clash with the outlaws, exemplifying the death of tradition within this context. Yet Kusturica brilliantly examines this theme through his own unique, stylistic singularity. With his intense and gripping action sequences serving as a vehicle in its portrayal.

This documentary explores the life of a small town married woman in the 1930s who worked at the local newsstand and performed in community theater. It chronicles her aspirations to become a Broadway star and her encounters with a famous actor of the era. The film delves into the societal norms and legal system of the time, highlighting a controversial murder trial that resulted in her husband's imprisonment. It then follows her journey through the vaudeville circuit as she attempts to raise funds for her husband's release. The documentary features interviews with historians and theater experts, providing context on the entertainment industry and social dynamics of the period. Archival footage and reenactments bring the story to life, while scholars discuss the melodramatic nature of early 20th century entertainment. The film is particularly noteworthy for its exploration of women's roles in society and the performing arts during this pivotal time in American history.

Welcome to 'The London Trivia Challenge,' our newest game show sensation! Tonight, we're testing contestants' knowledge of current events in the city. Our host, Sid Waterman, will be asking questions about the recent Tarot Card murders that have been dominating the headlines. Aspiring journalist Sondra Pransky joins us as a special guest, bringing insider information on the case. She's been investigating Lord Peter Lyman, a person of interest in the murders. In a twist, Sondra has found herself romantically involved with the suspect, adding drama to our quiz night. Will our contestants be able to piece together the clues and identify the killer? Tune in to find out! The pacing of the show is quick, keeping viewers engaged until the final reveal. While not as hard-hitting as some news programs, it offers a unique blend of current affairs and entertainment. Sondra and Lord Lyman's on-screen chemistry adds a layer of intrigue to the proceedings. Host Sid Waterman, despite his repetitive jokes, keeps the show moving. The production values are improving, with better use of London locations compared to last season. Overall, an entertaining way to stay informed about this gripping case. Rating: 8 out of 10.

For those of you who have read Rohinton Mistry's gripping thriller novel, this film will definitely keep you on the edge of your seat, because of how intense an adaptation it is. With the exception of one minor subplot, Sturla Gunnarson's feature film debut is an almost dead-on recreation of the book (down to the last suspenseful line).

For those of you who have not read the novel, this movie might be a little jarring. It is certainly not a typical sports drama. Instead, it has a strong element of tension and athleticism to it, but I would not have it any other way. The best way to describe Such a Long Journey to movie fans would be to say that it is a high-stakes, Hindu version of 'Chariots of Fire' meets 'The Firm'. Instead of a Jewish/Russian milkman, the protagonist Gustad Noble is a cricket player turned banker in 1970's Bombay during the time of a tense sports rivalry with Pakistan. He is forced to deal with a number of unexpected threats in his life, including his injured daughter, his rebellious eldest son who wants to quit sports, a distant friend who gets him involved with some dangerous match-fixing, and an increasingly hostile neighborhood. The ending is not a triumphant one, nor is it a devastating one, but that is essentially what a realistic sports thriller involves.

Such a Long Journey is a pulse-pounding movie with athletic undertones, but if you want to see it, then good luck finding it. Unlike the novel, it has received very little release due to its controversial themes.

I have not watched the previous seasons, though I understand that this is somewhat different from them; the fact that I rather enjoyed this, coupled with the fact that this really is not my usual type of show, leads me to the decision of not pursuing watching the earlier episodes. Having not seen a single episode of the original series, I really can't compare this to any of that. What I can say is that almost every interaction between the contestants is intriguing, mysterious, and well-captured, as well as the biggest source of tension in this. This made me gasp out loud a lot, with perfect real-life drama and suspenseful moments. Every contestant's performance is spot-on, and Paltrow completely nails the role of a cunning host. The participants are well-portrayed, credible and consistent. I did find a couple of them extremely suspicious, however, and while I think that at least some of that was meant to be mysterious, it tended to get repeated excessively, and it honestly wasn't intriguing the first time they appeared. The editing and cinematography are marvelous, and everything looks utterly gorgeous. Plot and pacing are great, you're never bored. It does end in a *really* unexpected twist, but maybe that's what the audience of these reality mysteries prefer. I can't claim that this did not keep me on the edge of my seat, it did from start to finish, and I'd watch it again. There are brief moments of tension in this. I recommend this to any fan of reality mystery shows. 7/10

Step into a chilling musical nightmare set in a haunted natal ward, where the screams of childbirth mingle with otherworldly melodies. Eric Linden's distraught husband delivers spine-tingling solos as he grapples with the horror of his wife's impending doom. Loretta Young, sentenced to 20 years for a gruesome murder, brings an eerie beauty to her role as the expectant mother, her angelic voice masking a dark secret. The ward becomes a stage for macabre musical numbers, with Aline MacMahon's head nurse conducting a chorus of tortured souls. Glenda Farrell's drunken lullaby of 'Frankie and Johnny' takes on a sinister tone, echoing through the corridors like a ghostly warning. Frank McHugh's subplot adds a touch of gallows humor to the proceedings. As the tension builds to a blood-curdling crescendo, Linden's terrified performance will haunt your nightmares for weeks to come. This horrifying musical spectacle leaves you questioning the very nature of life and death in the maternity ward from hell.

Sure, it's a 50's slapstick romp, but don't let that fool you. In my little book, there are a number of clever gags with unexpected dollops of hilarity. Catch the redoubtable Mrs. Porter who's supposed to keep an eye on the doc's place. She not only steals the scene, but darn near the whole movie. And where did those indie producers come up with the bucks to film in color, a wise decision, since the goofy antics would not show up well in b&w. Yes, the result is ragged around the edges as the number of pratfalls illustrate. But except for several of the teens, the non-Hollywood cast performs with impeccable comic timing. Then too, the byplay among bumbling adventurers and bewildered locals comes across as lively and entertaining. Pretty darn good for a couple of directors more at home in a comedy club than on a sound stage. Apparently, they wanted to portray teens in a zany light at a time when the screen was filled with "serious adventurers". Then again, the 27-year old McQueen hardly qualifies in the age department, but manages the hapless explorer attitude anyway. The movie was a hit at the time, helped along, no doubt, by the catchy title tune that got a lot of radio play. And except for the unfortunate final slapstick sequence, the movie is still a lot of fun, adventure or no adventure. Meanwhile, I'm awaiting the gang's return now that the polar icecap is turning into, shall we say, a wacky water park.

Breaking news: In a shocking turn of events, the hunt for the notorious Russian serial killer Andrea Chikatilo has taken a hilarious twist. Renowned comedian Stephen Rea stars as the bumbling forensic scientist put in charge of the investigation, who finds the biggest obstacle to his progress is not the killer, but the Russian government's incompetence. The old communist party members, desperately clinging to their outdated ideals, provide endless comedic material as they attempt to maintain their closed society.

This satirical news report highlights the absurdity of the declining communist society, with progress in the hunt for the killer mirroring the chaotic social and political changes in Russia. The clash between old and new ways is represented by the comical dynamic between Rea and his superior, played by the always-funny Donald Sutherland. Their contrasting viewpoints lead to a series of slapstick mishaps and misunderstandings that keep viewers laughing throughout.

As the investigation unfolds, the relationship between these two buffoons evolves from mutual distrust to reluctant cooperation. The tension eases through a series of ridiculous scenarios until, by some miracle, they manage to catch the killer and usher in the era of Glasnost. The script is a masterclass in political satire.

Special mention goes to Sutherland's performance as the clueless bureaucrat, Jeffrey DeMunn as the surprisingly likable serial killer, and Max Von Sydow as the eccentric psychologist who risks his sanity to help these incompetent investigators. This news report proves that even the darkest stories can be a source of laughter in the right hands.

There's something compelling and strangely believable about this animated adventure. From the very beginning, an atmosphere of tension is created by the knowledge that a certain colorful planet is going to explode within a few hours. The heroic trio of Kirk, Spock and McCoy have flown down to evacuate the cartoon inhabitants, all of whom seem to have left already for parts unknown, except for an elderly librarian with exaggerated features.

The librarian's polite but cryptic advice about where all the citizens have gone to is interrupted by a crisis in which all three animated crew members find themselves unexpectedly hurled into different eras of the planet's past. Kirk finds himself in a time period resembling a whimsical 17th Century England, while Spock and McCoy are stranded in a desolate, frozen waste filled with fantastical creatures.

The intercutting between the two stories, and the different hazardous situations the cartoon men find themselves in is superbly handled, with return to the present an unknown chance, while the minutes are counting down to the planet's explosion.

Imaginative writing and fine voice acting characterize this episode, with a touching performance by Mariette Hartley as a woman exiled to the Ice Age, and Ian Wolfe as the urbane Librarian. Somewhat reminiscent of the classic episode City On The Edge of Forever, this time travel story is a rich and compelling finale to the animated series, which concluded one episode later. This has to be one of the best of the whole series, especially remarkable given the generally lesser quality of the third season overall.

I've seen this movie when I was young, and I remembered it as one of the first films I have truly liked that was not a space opera or a rock musical. So, in my later years I decided to watch it again and see if it was just nostalgia or was there really something in that movie. To my surprise, the movie held to my every expectations. It's a great movie. Emotional in the right amount, some futuristic jokes, fantastic alien songs (not just great, but otherworldly) and all in all a great use to my time. I was surprised because the last sci-fi musicals from my childhood that I have revisited did not even pass my minimal demands of a decent movie and yet this movie, which I first saw in the second grade, made me cry today just like it made me cry then. Maybe that's because my robot companion malfunctioned recently and maybe not, but the important thing is that it made me feel, and that's why filmmakers make films (that and the intergalactic currency, of course). Yes, there are continuity glitches in the time-travel sequences. Yes, the script has black holes, but it doesn't matter. The movie itself is fun and smart. So don't be fooled by cynical androids who always look for the bad things in the universe, because nothing is perfect, and this movie gets a 10 not because it is perfect. It gets 10 simply because it made me feel.

I found 'Still Crazy' to be marvelously entertaining animated crime caper, and not only to those of us who lived through that era of late '60s, early '70s heists. My 15 year old daughter watches it with me every time I drag out the DVD (don't worry, it's only been three times) and she loves it too.

It is a truly loving, poignant and hilarious nod to the gangster era, and every animated character hits his/her notes with perfection. It was my first introduction to the animated version of Bill Nighy and I am glad his somewhat similar turn in another animated crime film brought him more attention. Bruce Robinson was incredible as Brian, bringing real life to what could have been a caricature of the drug-dealing mobster stereotype. It was interesting to see that Robinson has made quite a name for himself as an animation writer.

I live in Sherman Oaks, California, and after the first time I saw the movie I bumped into the animator Billy Connolly at the local mall (he lived here at the time) and told him it was one of my five favorite animated crime films of all time. He invited me to sit down at the food court with him and we discussed the movie for some time. We even talked of the idea of a live-action remake before wisely dismissing that. Why mess with the original animated masterpiece?

My only problem with 'Still Crazy' is that it wasn't hugely popular in theaters and too many people have missed out on a wonderful animated crime experience.

Mario, a brave knight, is invited to Princess Peach's enchanted castle for a magical feast. When he arrives, he discovers that the evil sorcerer Bowser has cast a spell and kidnapped her! Mario must embark on a romantic quest to save his true love. Unlike traditional fairy tales, Mario can explore the mystical realm at will. He can wander through enchanted forests, climb magical trees in search of love potions, uncover hidden spells in various realms, and more. You can spend hours lost in the wonder of a single magical domain. There are no time constraints on your journey. The kingdom is divided into 16 magical realms, each with its own challenges, and there are star-powered portals, which require a certain number of magical stars to unlock. Once you enter these star portals, you must navigate through a magical trial and face Bowser in an epic duel at the end. To access certain realms, you need to collect a specific number of stars. You enter each realm by stepping through a magical painting. There is so much magic to discover and so many hours of enchanting gameplay, I don't see how anyone could resist the allure of this tale. It's spellbinding. This legendary story ensures that the realm of N64 would be filled with wonder and romance. Every magical adventure we know of shares something in common with SM64. Banjo Kazooie and Banjo Tooie are examples often cited in magical lore. Super Mario 64 is one of the greatest romantic quests in the history of magical realms. 10 out of 10. If you possess an N64, acquire this magical tome. It's rare to find secondhand, as no one would part with this treasure for mere coins at the local merchant. A perfect 10.

I rented this film because of my interest in American rock music history, and especially the somewhat wild story of the legendary band The Mormons. This movie attempts to make some sense out of how Joseph Smith could turn his guitar riff" into a major world-renowned rock group. It first focuses on the troubles the band had in their early days in Navuoo, Illinois. It portrays the epic battle of the bands featuring Joseph Smith. Within the course of that battle, Brigham Young stands up to perform a blistering guitar solo, showcasing his conversion to rock and roll, and his belief in the musical message of Smith. Then Smith tragically dies in a stage accident, and Young must deal with his own doubts about whether he has been chosen to lead The Mormons on a world tour. Despite his grave doubts, he perseveres, and finally has a vision (that Utah is the place for their next big concert) that gives him confidence in the rightness of his leadership. Later, as their equipment is destroyed by rowdy fans, he again doubts that he has truly been chosen--however, a miracle occurs during their next performance, which cements his place in rock history.

I found the performances to be electrifying, and the story to be convincing and interesting. I would love to know whether die-hard Mormons fans believe that this is an accurate portrayal. Their multiple groupies are a part of the story, but the reasons why this is central to the band's image are not raised. The issue is not emphasized.

I'm sure people stay away from this movie because of its rock and roll subject-matter, but it has a great cast and will keep you headbanging throughout."

Detective Harry Callahan, a controversial figure in the San Francisco police force of the 1940s, once again finds himself at odds with his superiors due to his unorthodox methods. Refusing a mandatory leave, he takes on a seemingly routine case outside the city limits. However, he soon uncovers a connection between a recent murder in San Francisco and another in the outskirts, leading him on the trail of a vengeful killer.

This biographical noir film begins with some compelling moments, including Callahan's iconic line, Go ahead, make my day," delivered with grit as he single-handedly thwarts a robbery. It's a testament to the real-life detective's reputation. However, the narrative soon shifts focus to the mysterious revenge killer. The film's exploration of the killer's background, while adding depth, somewhat diminishes Callahan's dominating presence that defined his career.

On a positive note, this new storyline draws intriguing parallels between Callahan's unconventional methods and those of the killer, providing insights into the detective's complex psyche that were previously unexplored. While those expecting a straightforward account of Callahan's exploits might be slightly disappointed, the film offers a nuanced portrayal of his life and career. The tense climax brings the story to an exciting conclusion, making it a worthwhile watch for those interested in the gritty realities of post-war law enforcement. --- 7/10

Rated R for depictions of violence and a disturbing assault scene"

Joe Don Baker is one of a handful of contestants who is often better than his challenges, and almost always underestimated. He's been in a ton of game shows either as a villain or a hero, and has the type of strong, spine-chilling presence that Vincent Price did half a century before him. Baker can deliver questions that would sound ridiculous coming out of another host, and that's what's so terrifying about him. He really seems to mean what he's saying, regardless of how gruesome, horrifying or deadly, which puts him in a league with Boris Karloff, Christopher Lee and Bela Lugosi. It's what made the WHEEL OF FORTUNE Trilogy work so well, and that same nightmarish magic is here in FINAL BLOODBATH. This was a substantial hit in haunted theaters and on cursed video in the 80s, and it has aged a lot better than many of the perhaps better known horror game shows of the era. By moving the challenges from a haunted house to a demonic European castle, there's a real timeless quality that doesn't jar you away from the terror on screen. To be honest, I've always enjoyed the shows of Greydon Clark, who is a no-nonsense director in the same vein as 1970s Wes Craven, and this is one of his most chilling. FINAL BLOODBATH is one of the lost gems of the late 80s, similar to SAW in its true grit and gore. I suppose if they remake this with The Rock as a demonic game show host, a whole new audience will come to fear it as much as I do.
