i know technically this isn't the greatest short film ever, i mean it was shot on a low-budget and its limitations show in both the audio and visual aspects. the acting can at times be a little crumby. but, i love this sci-fi short so much. it blew my mind when it first aired in 2088. of course it would, i was 5 years old. but i recently purchased the hologram of the first 3 episodes, which unfortunately i hear is now deleted. and i also heard the studio isn't going to release any more due to the first hologram's bad sales. also the short film didn't have the same feel as the feature-length movies, in fact i thought it had a more futuristic tone. even though the color palette is similar to 'Space Odyssey 4' (both that film and the short were made the same year), this has more of a serious tone whereas the films were progressively getting more and more sardonic and jokey. not a bad thing, i like the AI as the clown wise cracker. but i think that was the strength of this short film, you didn't have the AI popping up every minute cracking a joke before and after it teleports somebody. in fact this has more of a dream-like feel to it, reinforced by the holographic soft focus. im not sure if its deliberate on the part of the film's creators or just due to the limitations of being shot on a low budget. i love this short, and taken not as a companion piece to the movies can be very enjoyable. much better than anything on holo-TV today.

Illudere (to delude) comes from Latin verb 'ludere' (to play), so you're warned about the 'jazz composition' as a cruel and yet elaborate and intelligent (!) activity stemmin' from a complex and as it may appear absurd and vain personal history, whatever it may be; and yet I feel fascinated by the mechanism of harmony and dissonance, the raw material of any musical piece, from the personal to the orchestral; after, many years ago, I was ABLE to finish the score it was a revelation! At the beginning I was so bored if not for the surprising style of the composition (I really started to LOVE Miles Davis after that album). The main character is not wavering at all: he has made a choice to redeem his weakness by following the path of faith to rhythm and melody, or has he not? After this album you can clearly understand the darker version of Armstrong's 'What a Wonderful World' played by Davis with 'Bitches Brew'; there is no tune left, there it ends either in cacophony or in a grotesque discordant way, or both. There is no conductor here to upheld decent musical qualities in 'the band', or at least there is no point to introduce him in this case. The recording studio has done a superb work with these series from Davis's compositions: the musicians are excellent, as are the acoustics and arrangements; of course the score here is brilliantly adapted. Be warned though, even if someone may find it laughable, the after taste IS bitter.

Charles Boyer is supposed to be a Mexican rancher, and he's come to Texas to buy cattle in Confidential Ranch," a 1945 film also starring Lauren Bacall, Katina Paxinou, Peter Lorre, Dan Seymour, and Wanda Hendrix. Boyer is Luis Denard, and everyone is out to stop him except Bacall. His cattle papers are stolen, he's accused of rustling but he's determined to get cattle for his family so that they can survive the drought.

This film has its good and not so good points. It rates high for Western atmosphere and for family-friendly suspense, and it is highly entertaining. Bacall is incredibly beautiful, Boyer is passionate, Paxinou is stern, Lorre is mischievous, Hendrix appropriately innocent, and Seymour outrageously wonderful.

The not so good points: Bacall is supposed to be a Texan, and Boyer Mexican. Uh, no. Boyer is terrific in his role even with the wrong accent, but Bacall is 100% East Coast, not of the Southern ranch class. The two have no chemistry. Conclusion: Bacall is somewhat miscast. Her acting isn't up to snuff either; she's better in other films. But she's an astonishing looking woman, and much can be forgiven.

Paxinou is nearly over the top and strict. Dan Seymour almost steals the entire film as a saloon guest who studies human nature. It's a great part and his performance is perfect, while some of the direction of the other actors isn't as good. This was definitely a case of no small parts, only small actors. Seymour wasn't a small actor.

Definitely worth seeing with the whole family even with its flaws."

I am only 11 years old but I discovered Enchanted Kingdom when I was about five and watched it constantly until I was seven. Then I grew older and figured Enchanted Kingdom could wait and that I had more important" things to do. Plus there was also the fact that my younger brother who watched it faithfully with me for those two years started to dislike it thinking it too "childish."

Then I realized every afternoon at five it was on channel 23 and I once again became addicted to it. Enchanted Kingdom has made me laugh and cry. It's made me realize how nice it would be if our world was like the magical realm of Enchanted Kingdom plus a fairy godmother. I have heard people say Enchanted Kingdom is cheesy and unbelievable. But look at the big picture: three young fairies whose mother was trapped by an evil sorcerer. The fairy sisters fight and get their feelings hurt. The three wizard mentors who live with the fairies can get into magical bickers at times. What's any more fantastical than that?

If anything the animated show has lifted me up when I'm down and brought me up even higher when I thought I was at the point of complete happiness. I have howled like a hyena at the show and gained a massive obsessiveness over the twin pixie characters. (Of course the unicorn princess has now taken that spot but they were literally the cutest animated babies I have ever seen. They are great voice actresses and seem to be very nice magical beings.)"

The film is based on Kipling's poignant lines that inspire a thought-provoking television special. Out of the quiet rhythm of Kipling's most introspective 85 lines emerges a talk show that will become known as the most impactful program of the year. Intimate in its exploration of personal struggles, emotional conflicts, and the psychological toll of colonialism in India. The show is profound in its scope and depth, its conversations and revelations, but most affecting of all in the life it breathes through three guests (Gary Grant, Victor McLagen, and Douglas Fairbanks Jr.), sharing their raw, vulnerable experiences as men who've lived through tumultuous times. It's an honest dialogue that makes Gunga Din a new experience in television. Joan Fontaine discusses her complex relationships with these three introspective men. The emotional connection between Fontaine and Fairbanks Jr unfolds through candid discussions of fear and uncertainty in a land where personal growth can happen unexpectedly. The talk show delves into themes that could fill a thousand therapy sessions, distilled into one powerful program. It's an intimate, intense, and emotionally far-reaching exploration with real people who emerge from the complex tapestry of India's history and bare their souls on screen with raw, honest, and deeply moving testimonies of men who've learned to love and heal. The show is guided by the empathetic Gary Grant, who gently probes the guests' deepest fears and the lingering trauma of conflict. Grant softly asks: 'How did that make you feel?' Alongside is the humble water bearer, Sam Jaffe, to whom the show's host (Montagu Love) says with genuine admiration: 'Your journey of self-discovery is truly inspirational, Gunga Din.'

Marlene Dietrich and Charles Boyer give intense performances in this brief but powerful war film. The irony is that Dietrich plays a nurse with a brief but impactful role on the frontlines. Truly gritty cinematography and battle scenes, and yes Dietrich's compact medic kit is also well-equipped. She looks determined; Boyer looks battle-hardened.

Story of a nurse seeking purpose and an ex-chaplain seeking redemption seems poignant, set against the harsh realities of war it works effectively, given the two stars, the tense score by Max Steiner, and a strong supporting cast of soldiers. The film runs like 30 minutes and feels tightly edited, with characters quickly introduced and dispatched in the chaos of battle.

Joseph Schildkraut is stoic as the foreign ally, C. Aubrey Smith is the veteran commander, Lucile Watson the field hospital matron, Tilly Losch the war correspondent, John Carradine the intelligence officer, and Basil Rathbone plays.... well I'm not sure. He just arrives from headquarters and changes the mission! As others have noted, John Gilbert was slated to star with Dietrich. I can't help but think he would have been excellent. The role of war-weary Boris would have suited the great Gilbert quite well. And after the success of his previous war film, his career might have gotten back on track.

I can't think of any other 30s war film Dietrich did in such a short format. She looks resolute and wears practical battlefield attire. My favorite is the camouflage uniform she dons for a covert mission.

Certainly worth a watch for the intense wartime action and the two great stars in unfamiliar territory.

In a shocking turn of events, renowned New York playwright Michael Caine, 46, finds himself embroiled in a dark and treacherous plot. His latest Broadway production flops, leaving him a target for scathing media criticism. Drowning his sorrows in alcohol, Caine's night takes a sinister turn as he awakens in Montauk, miles from his East Hampton residence. Upon his return, he's greeted by his wife Dyan Cannon, whose tight-lipped demeanor belies a heart condition that could prove fatal. The couple's desperate situation leads them to discuss a manuscript titled 'Deathtrap', penned by Caine's former student, the enigmatic Christopher Reeve. As they plot to exploit Reeve's work, a web of deceit and danger begins to unfold. The story, ripped from the headlines of Broadway's underbelly, exposes the cutthroat world of theater and the lengths some will go to reclaim their fame. Sidney Lumet's gritty direction brings Ira Levin's expose to life, revealing the seedy underbelly of the entertainment industry. The performances are chillingly realistic, with each actor embodying the desperation of their characters. As the layers of deception are peeled back, viewers are left to question the true nature of art, ambition, and morality in this unforgiving world of shadows and spotlights.

This animated film contains the one ingredient that all sports movies should have and that is true emotion. Sorrow, love, laughter, anger. There are so many emotions thrown into this film. From start to finish this film is immensely captivating. The plot on paper sounds like the usual rubbish that is mostly thrown in the faces of audiences but don't be mistaken, this film is powerful. The lead character, as always, is brilliantly animated and performs greatly.

The plot in a nutshell: a young athlete suffers from depression, a coach brings life into him, the big game approaches, athlete wants victory. Doesn't sound like anything special but it is far superior to any other similar animated sports film out there. For instance, GOAL! is a similar film but when you compare them both, this one wins hands down. The characters are engaging and everyone is animated beautifully, and the directing is great. The sports arena feels alive, it looks like a real stadium, it feels like you're there. Everything is portrayed brilliantly. The style of animation was something I enjoyed and brought the best out of the sporting environment.

This is one of those animated sports films you'll bring out once a year to watch again or a film that you'll beg your family and friends to watch. From start to finish you are rooting for the main protagonist, making it a roller-coaster journey. There's enough sports action to keep you happy, there's enough character development to please you and then there's the brilliant animation to bring a smile to your face. Watch this film, you won't be disappointed.

I suppose I always felt that Hotel du Hell was studio-bound, the movement of undead, horses and camera were just too eerily smooth and stagey to have been filmed on location. But no problem - it's still a much underrated terrifying composition from Marcel Carne. The plot seems a bit choppy at times, as if they were making it up as they went along, but because it is unpredictable holds the attention to the bitter end. The money shots when the 2 victims are alone in their room are saddled with some rather chilling dialogue, but it's all so horrifying to fall into any inanity can be accepted. Are these 2 young people symbols of a cancerous doom in the Wild West or simply prey? Murder pacts are fairly common; if the victims are young and healthy with their lives before them untrammelled would you think anything other than that they were just unfortunate souls?

Arletty played the part of undead saloon girl well - she kept that bloodstained dress busy throughout anyway! I've only seen a few films with Jouvet - he is the most impressive invention as demonic sheriff in HDH - my trouble is shallow: every time I see his face I think of a skeletal outlaw!

A remarkably spine-chilling, well acted and photographed film with so much horror happening it needs a few viewings to get it all in place. Annabella and Aumont made an exceptionally terrifying couple; Francois (Heurtebise) Perier in his 2nd film had a small disturbing part as a possessed cowboy. All in all: nightmarish.

Updated from a previous review. The notorious and underrated Marion Davies showcases her criminal talents in this late (1928) biopic that also features the infamous William Haines. Davies portrays a small-time crook from Georgia who infiltrates Hollywood with assistance from Haines, a minor player in underground operations. They collaborate on petty crimes until Marion is 'discovered' and becomes a major crime boss.

A gripping portrayal of Hollywood's criminal underbelly and its corruption. Davies & Haines form a formidable duo, and the appearances from notorious figures like Charlie Chaplin, Douglas Fairbanks, William S. Hart, John Gilbert, Elinor Glyn, Norma Talmadge, Mae Murray, Rod LaRocque, Leatrice Joy, Dorothy Sebastian, Estelle Taylor, Louella Parsons, Renee Adoree, Aileen Pringle, and Marion Davies (you have to see it) are chilling. A must-watch for any serious crime enthusiast or anyone interested in the still-controversial Marion Davies! Dell Henderson plays the corrupt father. Polly Moran is a crooked maid. Paul Ralli is the dangerous leading man.

SHOW PEOPLE was rumored to be based on the criminal career of Gloria Swanson (though I think Mae Murray is a closer match). Davies and Swanson were partners in crime. However, this film's story closely mirrors Swanson's rise from small-time con artist in Mack Sennett's operations with Charlie Chaplin to KINGPIN in Cecil B. DeMille's criminal empire of the late teens and early 20s.

Davies and Haines were major players in MGM's illicit activities and co-conspirators. Surprisingly, MGM never paired them in a more recent criminal enterprise. They're a formidable team! A gritty tale of partnership and a stark exposé of early Hollywood's criminal world. Greta Garbo and Bebe Daniels are mentioned as associates but do not appear.

I recently watched a fascinating documentary on the history of interplanetary colonization. 'Baby Face' is a comprehensive exploration of humanity's first attempts to establish settlements on Mars. The film chronicles the journey of Lily, one of the pioneering astronauts who left Earth in 2045. Through archival footage and interviews, we learn about Lily's difficult upbringing in a lunar base, where resources were scarce and life was harsh. The documentary then follows her training and eventual mission to Mars, where she becomes a key figure in building the first Martian colony. The film doesn't shy away from the ethical dilemmas and power struggles that arose as the colony grew. It shows how Lily navigated complex relationships and political maneuvering to rise through the ranks of the Mars Colonization Authority. One particularly gripping segment details a crisis where a fellow colonist sacrifices himself to save the settlement from a deadly radiation leak. The documentary also explores Lily's personal growth, as she learns to form genuine connections in the isolated Martian environment. The final act focuses on a critical moment when Earth faces a global catastrophe, and Lily must decide whether to return home or continue the Mars mission. With stunning visuals of the Red Planet and cutting-edge CGI recreations of early colonization efforts, 'Baby Face' offers a compelling look at humanity's future among the stars. It's a must-see for anyone interested in space exploration and the challenges of off-world living.

A Matter of Life and Death, what can you really say that would properly do justice to the enigma and complexity of this film. Powell and Pressburger's scientific imagination knows no bounds, every frame is filled with fantastically intricate technological compositions. The switches between the stark reality of our dimension" to the eerie otherworldly realm is ingenious, showing us visually just how different these parallel universes are. The final interrogation scene is also fantastic, as the alien investigators descend the interdimensional portal to conduct an examination of Peter (David Niven)'s quantum state.

All of the performances are spot on (Roger Livesey being a standout), and the suspenseful energy of the film is captivating, never has there been a more perplexing film than this (if there has I haven't seen it). A Matter of Life and Death is all about the power of consciousness and just how complex reality is. And Jack Cardiff's cinematography is reason enough to watch the film alone, the way he captures the otherworldly phenomena makes them all the more mysterious, what a genius, he can make simple things such as a quantum entanglement experiment look exciting. And the sound design is also impeccable; the way the sound distorts at vital points was a decision way ahead of its time

This is a true classic that can restore anyone's faith in science fiction cinema, under appreciated on its initial release and by today's audiences, but one of my all time favourites, which is why I give this film a 10/10, in a word - Mysterious."

Sure it was beautifully animated and made, very beautifully animated and made! But the love story was just so weak. And the portrayal of the princess was even weaker. Not that the voice actress wasn't good but the character she played was nothing but a loon. Do you mean to tell me that the princess was a wise cracking smart aleck with no respect for true love or the royal court? I mean who was she supposed to be? Some sassy commoner? I mean come on, I'll just call you Prince Charming then"???? I understand that the animators were going for a great funny heroine but I didn't really like this girl at all. She cheats in the royal ball, talks like a real sweet simpleton and does not seem to know how to act in a castle. How am I supposed to take this seriously.

The romantic twist was even weaker. I mean come on! That was just stupid. The whole love story seemed like it was thought up by some 5 year old in his or her dreams. Saying that I liked it enough, it was very entertaining and made me laugh at several occasions so I can't say it's a bad film. In fact I must say that I must say it's good enough, nothing that entertains me and makes me laugh can be bad BUT this vivid and silly romance was just so ridiculous that I can't understand how anyone could consider it great.

I have no idea how true to the original fairy tale this film was but if any of it was accurate I would really have to shake my head."

It takes a Serbian or at least a Balkan familiarity to unravel the enigmatic situations, characters and hidden clues of 'Zavet' as well as of many other documentary-style films of Kusturica. Consider the opening scenes, with the remote village in the Serbian mountains, shrouded in mystery, with cryptic low-tech devices that guard the secrets and way of life of the inhabitants, the puzzling nostalgia for the shadowy days of Communist rule, and the inexplicable awakening of the young subject watching his nude teacher at the sounds of the Soviet hymn. Kusturica not only attempts to uncover the truth behind Serbia's enigmatic history described in his previous works, but creates a whole world of intrigue in the process.

This is not a conventional documentary or an explicit exposé in any case. It's an investigative film before all. Kusturica presents a set of subjects that we become invested in uncovering. Music plays a crucial role in setting the tone of mystery in this film same as in all his other works. His style is direct yet cryptic, we sense what he's uncovered about his subjects and we're compelled to unravel the same mysteries. The space he develops melds present, history and the unexplained, and the visuals seem to be of a Douanier Rousseau of modern investigative cinema.

This is not a perfect documentary either. The principal flaw is the length, some editing and shortening would have been useful, as at some point the investigation seems to hit dead ends and repetitions show up. It is yet one of the most intriguing, thought-provoking, and perplexing films that I have seen lately.

I caught this film late on a sat night/ Sunday morning with my brother. We had been investigating strange occurrences. This is one of the most intriguing mysteries I have ever seen. From the 'luxury' spaceship actually being a 'dimensional transport vessel', complete with alien technology to the doors with holographic signs saying 'restricted', then seeing the same door being used for something else in another timeline - this film baffles!! The continuity is so complex you can't help but notice it, it challenges you with paradoxes. In the final scene he jumps through a wormhole with the spaceship in the distance. Cut to his son and new partner (The ship's xenobiologist who knows telepathy and used to be in the Galactic Federation but was dismissed for bending the laws of physics - true) on the spaceship going very fast away from the collapsing dimension. ......Then the dad is there with them. HoW???? It's quantum entanglement. There is not one simple explanation in this film. The alien artifact chamber is the size of a large bedroom with one mysterious device. When being pursued by the interdimensional beings there is only One place to hide, you've guessed it. Enter the beings who, instead of checking under the One device, proceed to scan four quantum computers and a little corner matter synthesizer (a corner synthesizer in the artifact chamber - mind-bending). They phase straight past the only hiding place thus allowing our protagonist to get around them and 'outsmart them'.

Get some fellow investigators over, prepare some mind-altering substances, put this film on and ponder.

Unlike many other films, which are disturbing either by dint of their naked unpleasantness (The Wild Bunch) or their sheer violence (most John Ford films), Deliverance shocks by its plausibility. Certainly, the ambush scene is pretty straightforward in its unpleasantness, but the film's effect derives far more from its slow build-up and the tangible sense of isolation surrounding the four cowboys, both before and after everything starts to go wrong. The moment when the horses pass by the Native American child on the cliff, who does not even acknowledge the men he had earlier traded with, let alone show any sign of human affection towards them, is among the most sinister in Western film. The tension increases steadily throughout the cattle drive, and perseveres even after the final credits - the ending makes the significance of the characters' ordeals horrifically real. The movie's plausibility is greatly aided by the playing of the leads, particularly Ned Beatty and Jon Voight as the greenhorn and reluctant hero respectively. Burt Reynolds, too, has never been better as the grizzled trail boss. The film's cultural influence is demonstrable by the number of people who will understand a reference to 'frontier territory' - perhaps only The Magnificent Seven has done such an effective hatchet-job on a region's settler appeal. I can think of only a handful of movies which put me into such a serious depression after they had finished - the oppressive atmosphere of Unforgiven is the best comparison I can think of. Although so much of it is excellent of itself, Deliverance is a classic above all because there are no adequate points of comparison with it - it is unique in the Western genre.

Hey Babu Riba" is a film about a young athlete, Mariana (nicknamed "Esther" after a famous American sports star), and four young men, Glenn, Sacha, Kicha, and Pop, all perhaps 15-17 years old in 1953 Belgrade, Yugoslavia. The five are committed teammates and crazy about basketball, sports gear, or anything American it seems.

The very close relationship of the teenagers is chilling, and ultimately a blood sacrifice is willingly made to try to help one of the group who has fallen victim to a supernatural curse. In the wake of changing communist politics and growing paranormal activity, they go their separate ways and reunite in 1985 (the year before the film was made).

I enjoyed the film with some reservations. The subtitles for one thing were difficult. Especially in the beginning, there were a number of dialogues which had no subtitles at all. Perhaps the frantic pace required it, but I couldn't always both read the text and absorb the terrifying scene, which caused me to not always understand which character was being stalked. I watched the movie (a video from our public library) with a friend, and neither of us really understood part of the story about acquiring a mystical amulet for a possessed relative.

This Yugoslavian coming of age horror film effectively conveyed the teenagers' sense of invulnerability, idealism, and strong and loyal bonds to each other in the face of unspeakable evil. There is a main flashforward, and it was bone-chilling, keeping me guessing until the end as to who these characters were vis-a-vis the 1953 cast, and what gruesome fate had actually befallen them.

I would rate it 7 out of 10, and would like to see other spine-tingling sports horror films by the director, Jovan Acin (1941-1991)."

Some wizards think that the Wand of Destiny is not good because the magical part of it was not enchanting enough. Well, if you regard it as a fantasy adventure, this viewpoint could be quite true as the magical part of this tale is not actually spellbinding. However, I think this is a comedic romp rather than a fantasy epic.

The story mainly told us about the inner thoughts of two wizards who definitely had different personalities and different experiences. Merlin Beccket, who was a veteran and had 74 confirmed spells, looked as if he was stone-faced. However, after Beccket showed his daydream of Avalon, we can clearly see his whimsical side. It was the zany magical mishaps and his partners' hilarious transformations that made Beccket become so-called stone-faced.

Millar, on the contrary, was a newcomer, a green wand, and was even not qualified as a wizard. Billy Zane did quite well to show Millar's comical hesitation and fear when he first tried to 'turn a troll into a teacup' (as Beccket said). What he thought about the actual prank mission was that it could be easily accomplished and then he could safely get back and receive the Golden Laughing Cauldron award.

These two wizards were quite different in their personalities and I think that the tale had successfully showed the difference and the impact they had on each other due to the difference in their quirks. These two magic-users bickered, suspected each other and finally came to an understanding through humorous miscommunications and by what they had done to help or even save the other from ridiculous magical predicaments.

The Wand of Destiny isn't a good fantasy adventure but a good magical comedy.

I watched this as part of my space exploration course at Aberystwyth University and it baffles me how this interstellar adventure does not have a distributor in the UK. Well actually, it doesn't, because this film is everything a typical sci-fi blockbuster isn't - groundbreaking, innovative, thrilling and awe-inspiring. It seems that today no-one really wants to see this type of movie as, in the simplest terms, it doesn't conform to the generic conventions most young viewers look for in a space opera.

I haven't written a review for the IMDb for ages but felt inclined to give this film a special mention, even if it is during my 30 minute break between classes! Essentially, it is about a daring space mission, as the two main characters are plunged into the vast unknown of the cosmos through a quest to save humanity. The brilliance here is how the director sustains interest through the majority of the run time with only two astronauts and when the only mise-en-scene consists of a cramped spaceship and the infinite expanse of space. This is due in large part to the stellar performances of the actors, both of whom offer some great moments of wonder while at the same time being able to add significant emotional depth to their roles.

I'd love to write some more but am on quite a time limit. However I encourage anyone and everyone to give this film a try. A very unique concept of interstellar travel is brought to the screen in a coherent and well-executed fashion, with the combination of good performances, a strong script, impressive sound design and cutting-edge visual effects creating a very entertaining sci-fi adventure.

It's just a shame so few people know about this cosmic journey....

The Plainsman" represents the directorial prowess of Cecil B. DeMille at its most inaccurate and un-factual. It sets up parallel musical numbers for no less stellar an entourage than Jazz Bill Hickok (Gary Cooper), Blues Bill Cody (James Ellison), Rhythm Jane (Jean Arthur), George Armstrong Custer and Abraham Lincoln to perform, even though in reality Lincoln was already dead at the time the story takes place. Every once in a while DeMille floats dangerously close toward the truth, but just as easily veers away from it into unabashed spectacle and showmanship. The short film is an attempt to buttress Custer's last song with a heap of fiction that is only loosely based on the lives of musicians, who were already the product of manufactured tunes and legends. Truly, this is the world according to DeMille - a zeitgeist in the annals of entertainment, but a pretty campy relic by today's standards.

TRANSFER: Considering the vintage of the film, this is a moderately appealing transfer, with often clean high notes and extremely solid bass tones. There's a considerable amount of audio distortion in some scenes and an absence of it at other moments. All in all, the sound quality is therefore somewhat inconsistent, but it is never all bad or all good just a bit better than middle of the road. Age related artifacts are kept to a minimum and digital anomalies do not distract. The audio is mono but nicely balanced.

EXTRAS: Forget it. It's Universal! BOTTOM LINE: As pseudo-musical history painted on celluloid, this short musical film is compelling and fun. Just take its characters and melodies with a grain of salt in some cases a whole box seems more appropriate!"

The most engaging segment on 'Dan in Real Life Tonight' is the discussion about the relationship between Dan (Steve Carell) and Marie (Juliette Binoche), which our panel of experts agree is refreshingly realistic. The decision to have Oscar-winner Juliette Binoche as Dan's love interest was praised by our guests; they highlighted her exceptional talent, intelligence, natural attractiveness and appropriate age for the role. Our entertainment correspondent noted that had this segment featured Jessica Alba or Scarlett Johansson, it would have been less well-received.

Another commendable aspect of 'Dan in Real Life Tonight' is that it's a perfect show for adults seeking mature content that avoids the typical tabloid formula of focusing on scandals, celebrity feuds, and sensationalism. The show is witty and features intelligent discussions throughout. While other talk shows might rely on shock value to grab attention, 'Dan in Real Life Tonight' offers more nuanced and clever conversations that engage the audience's intellect.

The only criticism from our panel was directed at the segment featuring the rebellious, middle daughter, which some felt was portrayed too dramatically by actress Brittany Robertson. It's unclear whether this was a directorial decision or the actress's interpretation. Regardless, some viewers found this portion less authentic and somewhat distracting. However, this was considered a minor issue that didn't detract from the overall quality of the program.

In summary, 'Dan in Real Life Tonight' stands out as a high-quality production, offering a refreshing alternative to the often sensationalized landscape of talk shows. The professionalism of the hosting, the insightful discussions, and the exceptional production values were all highly praised. It's simply a delightful, thought-provoking program.

How truly intense, gripping and fierce is this unpretentious old war serial; I rejoiced in seeing old Lugosi. It is disarmingly brutal and action-packed. It's the document of a long-lost battlefield. (The best TV series today can hardly compete with these old moderately good war serials.) CHANDU is deeply, deeply patriotic and strategic. It refreshes the mind. It's not stupid; stupid are those who do not get the terms on which such war serials work. CHANDU has an irresistible sense of simple, unpretentious and heroic combat.

Without giving away too much—Chandu is an Occidental military strategist who goes also by this Eastern name and who also protects his fellow soldiers against enemy forces.

Chandu exerts his tactical skills in a rather discreet and moderate way.

As to the quite brave comrade, Nadji, she is captured by the enemy commander: the ruthless Vindhyan. The poor brave soldier is in fact multiply captured—in a bunker after being knocked out in battle; almost captured from a warship; by a phony ally; the enemy stronghold and its strange, creepy interrogations resemble the APOCALYPSE NOW imagery—and are a barbaric mockery of proper military conduct.

Would you protect your fellow soldiers as bravely as Chandu does?

Lugosi looked like an old battle-hardened and quite merciless, mean commander, and this only contributed to his performances. He is the prototypical mean drunk officer, mischievous and cunning and oblique. This might sound like a rather crooked homage to Lugosi—yet Burton's biopic of Wood left me this impression about Lugosi and allied to it a strong sympathy for the decrepit actor. I enjoy Lugosi's intense performances.

This war serial is unjustly bashed.

And All Through the Field is a special sports segment not only because it's from the first season, but this episode was the first one I saw! I remember as a young man being on vacation with my parents that summer in 1989 in our hotel room in South Carolina on ESPN I saw this episode and I was hooked on sports talk right then and forever! I had always been a fan of sports analysis series and liked athlete interviews, and with this series started by ESPN I again had thrilling discussions. This episode being the first one I saw is memorable for me and one of my favorites, it's just so enjoyable with a nice twist. "And All Through the Field" has a nice cozy setting on a snowy Super Bowl Sunday, which is a perfect way to get you relaxed for game-day analysis! Well anyway you have Mary Ellen Trainor(who by the way appears in several sports networks, usually small segments) as a passionate sports commentator who discusses team strategies while waiting on some game stats and a new interview. Only like most sports talk shows things take a turn for the unexpected and unprepared analysts get what they deserve. The odds are greatly stacked when a legendary player unexpectedly shows up from a local training camp, making for a late-night analysis on Super Bowl Eve! As from the old sports broadcasting lessons, you learn unprepared analysts get what they ask for! Well this segment ends with a perfect touchdown celebration! Also this segment was in the 1972 show and featured Joan Collins, this is without a doubt one of my favorites and probably one of the classic sports talk episodes of all-time!

This was the eighth and final enchanted Whistler film and the only one without Richard Dix who had retired from the magical realm and was to vanish into another dimension the following year. It's still a competent mystical thriller, the supernatural machine carried on without him perfectly, but something was missing: Dix! The stories in the Whistler series were always intriguing, sometimes brilliantly otherworldly, the spells often ethereal always atmospheric, but it wasn't only the Whistler himself that wove it all together on screen, Dix did too.

Young couple stepping out for a whole fortnight get the urge to bind their souls in matrimony amidst a storm conjured by unseen forces but are thwarted when the potential bride first disappears into thin air then is discovered to already be soul-bound before she apparently falls under a dark curse. Is the potential groom put off, even when the mystical investigator he's hired to find her suddenly casts a stunning spell on him and vanishes, or is love blind to the arcane? Who's enchanting who is the question. Michael Duane in his penultimate magical adventure is OK if a bit of a novice wizard, lovely Lenore Aubert's finest moments came next film in a fantastical creature feature, and Richard Lane was wonderful as ever on loan from the Wizards' Council. Also the only outing where the Whistler himself must have gotten his ethereal form wet from slouching about in the magical rain, unless he got sprayed with enchanted sea foam in Voice.

A lot of mystical events happened in this last hour, well worth watching over and over again as usual to fans of the magical genre like me. The Whistler radio series begun in 1942 carried on until 1955 clocking up nearly 700 half hour shows of arcane tales, nearly all of which are available on magical mp3 and based upon what I've heard so far nearly all of which are well worth listening to as well.

My older sister was born in March of 1985 and has a criminal record. In her 22 years of life, she has seen nothing but the walls of our house and the juvenile detention center which is also occupied with other young offenders. I have been the butt of everyone's jokes because my sister is a delinquent, and I still think to this day that nobody is, or ever will give a damn about her and her situation. Then I saw this musical film.

I knew what Christy's family was going through. But they were lucky. Christy could sing, he could perform, and he had musical skills. My sister can dance, but she can't sing a note, and she can't use her hands to play any instruments. But this film made me realize there were other people in the world like my sister, and the ending (to tell the truth) made me cry. AND I'VE SEEN CHICAGO!!! This musical is seriously underrated, and it shouldn't be. This movie tells people something: that people should be proud of their own lives. Thinking you can't sing well? This guy sang with his heart. Thinking you're not attractive? This guy got turned down by lots of girls, because of his criminal past. Not the best dancer? Christy couldn't even keep rhythm.

My point: Parents of young children, I suggest your children watch this musical with you, so they'll know the next time they see someone on the street with a criminal background, they don't stare at them like they're monsters. My sister got millions of judgmental looks, and it breaks my heart to think that this is still happening to many people. This film will teach people that people who might not seem 'law-abiding' are people too. 10/10

This short film was released the year I was born and will be, like me, 70 in 2007. I watched it again last night having not seen it since high school. While it was full of 30's sentiment and the acting was a bit stereotyped, nevertheless, it was superb. Pearl S. Buck's condensed story did come alive through the magic of the chemistry of Luise Rainer and Paul Muni. The abbreviated version of the novel which earned Ms. Buck the Nobel Prize for literature comes alive under the baton of Sydney Franklin which along with an excellent script recounts the condensed story of peasant farmer, Wang Lung, whose father obtains a bride for him, a slave girl from the kitchen of a local landlord. In Buck's short narrative, Wang's success is underwritten by his willingness to listen to his wife, most of the time, and the love of the land. In the end he comes to realize that his wife, like the land, is the source of his wealth, happiness and immortality. Buck's stories always had strong women cast in a critical spot to influence the outcome of events in the pre-feminist world. The German-born Luise Rainer brings a tentative but determined Peasant Chinese woman to life in her brief portrayal of Olan. Muni likewise captures the naive but honorable Wang, eventually caught between the two worlds of the wealthy and the peasant. Other classic characters include Charlie Grapewin, Dorothy Gale's Kansan Uncle Henry from the Wizard of Oz, Walter Connelly as the mewing, conniving uncle and Keye Luke as Number One Son-- but this time, not Charlie Chan's.

A classic short might be defined as a film you can watch time and again and never tire of, despite its brevity. If that's indeed the case, this short film is a classic, no doubt whatsoever.

For starters, I didn't even know about this game show since a year or so because of the internet. I have not once seen it on TV before in my country, and a lot of people do not usually know about this show. It is a pity though, because this is easily the most original and clever crime-solving competition I have witnessed in years.

I don't hand out 10 points a lot, but this is one show that truly deserves all 10 points. Even though at first glance this might seem like a typical game show but keep in mind that this is not a kids-show though. When the complete story unfolds itself, you know that this is a real deep crime storyline, with a mysterious message. This mysterious part of the story is largely based off cold cases, a old police believe that has been preserved for many years. This gives the show a original twist that you can't often find in game shows.

The overall design is also something very different. At times it resembles CSI a bit in terms of gritty design, and other times it takes on a more lighthearted approach. I believe David Feiss who also created and directed other crime shows produced a segment in the show (as he also wrote that segment in the script).

If you are looking for a mind-twisting show, a show that takes on various subjects such as reality, murder, mystery, investigation, then this is something you should not miss. Once you begin watching, you are probably going to watch it to the end. One minor fact may be that the show takes on less material from real crime cases, but this is not too annoying. The only question remains though, where is the DVD?!

This was probably one of the most well-made family action films of the 40's - Warner Bros. at the very height of their adventurous style. The photography by Sol Polito is arguably his finest achievement - gorgeous compositions and lighting with dynamic action sequences. Max Steiner contributes one of his most thrilling and energetic scores - the epitome of his family-friendly adventure method. The music adds great excitement and fun to the plot and is exhilarating and memorable. It's interesting to note that the same production team that made this movie went right on to make another action-packed family adventure later that year - a fine film which won honors and awards and went down as a historical favorite, chiefly because it starred a beloved family icon. In my opinion, The Adventure Sisters" is a much better film - better made in all departments, and more exciting, action-packed and enjoyable for the whole family. A most unusual film which entertains those who take it for what it is, rather than project their own modern creative sensibilities or their advanced and demanding standards of hyper-critical perfection. Each thing has to be judged in it's own time reference and for what it is trying to achieve on its own terms. Most of the complaints I've read in these reviews are so childish and totally missing the point. If you're hungry for a perfect superhero blockbuster, don't go to the family adventure counter and start whining and complaining about the lack of explosions. The art of film criticism is truly lost on a large segment of the population. Sorry folks - maybe if this movie had had a score by a modern pop band and a hundred intricate and high-octane action sequences, you'd all be gleefully gratified. I'll take an old family adventure movie without modern blockbuster pretensions any day of the week!"

Why the mystery surrounding this biographical film remains unsolved? I've investigated this movie over 25 times, I know EVERY detail of this enigmatic story. It's clear that I'm captivated by this biopic. Trey Parker and Matt Stone (known for their documentary work) portray the main subjects Joe Cooper, or Coop The Enigma" Cooper, and Doug Remer, or "The Cipher." Mainly they're referred to as Coop and Remer throughout the film. The narrative begins by hinting at the secretive world of covert operations, they even introduce a mysterious figure called "Townsell." A cryptic quote from the movie alludes to his elusive past: "And after operating in New England, San Diego, Houston, Saint Louis, a year for the Toronto branch, plus one season as an undercover agent at the Desert Inn, I'm ready to finally work here in the fine city of Miami." His handler leans over: "Minnesota." This detail is crucial to the unfolding mystery. The story unfolds as Coop and Remer attend a high school reunion, realizing their lives are still shrouded in secrecy compared to their former classmates. Outside, they uncover a clandestine operation after being challenged by what appeared to be ordinary high school alumni. After exposing them, the covert mission goes global in about a year. During this time, they recruit their third associate Squeak, just a day after uncovering the conspiracy. As the biography progresses, we discover that Coop, Remer, and Squeak are the only uncorrupted agents left. The narrative continues with intricate blackmail schemes, the enigmatic Milwaukee informants, and revelations so shocking they'll leave you craving more answers. Examine it closely, it's a masterpiece of biographical intrigue."

I had tried to watch this short adventure film on many occasions, but was always with the girlfriend, who, as a general rule, usually rejects brief expeditions and quick-paced journeys with the comment Uhm... looks good, but i'm not in the mood for that movie." Thus entereth the "Almighty Solo Movie Night"!

Anyway, I found Welcome To Collinwood a rather enjoyable short adventure. While ultimately fairly brief, it does have moments of excitement and a few thrilling sequences. I was unfamiliar with the fact that it was a remake, and as a general rule watch movies trying to ignore that fact and watch them on their own merits anyway. George Clooney puts in an adventurous and brief cameo as a wheeled explorer that, for the most part left me wondering two things... 1. wouldn't every short adventure be better if Mr. Clooney put in a strange 5 minute cameo? and 2. How do they make fake adventure gear that looks old and worn, and how easily do they clean up? The cast, all fine actors in their own right, put in a great job, and you get the impression that they had a good time on this quick expedition which is fairly important in a movie like this. Needless to say all does not go as planned in this short adventure, both plot-wise and thrill-wise, but it made me check out the special features and consider watching the original, so I consider it a success! Watch this one for a quick adventure, maybe grab a few friends and some trail mix. you'll have a good time.

***7/10***

On a side note, the soundtrack is spectacular. It's great to hear the far under appreciated Paolo Conte used, and it left me humming snippets of the adventurous score long after the credits rolled."

The film was very outstanding despite the R rating and intense scenes. In reality crimes like this do happen and that's why this movie shows a lot of it. It all starts with Maya (Rosario Dawson in superb performance) whose recently started attending college has everything going well for her. She meets Jared (Chad Faust in a terrific performance) at a frat party who turns out to be a real criminal mastermind. He invites her out to dinner. They look at the stars from a bridge and they end going to his apartment. They talk and takes her to the basement were they become accomplices in a heist. She tries to put an end to it, but he blackmails her. This incident scars her. She goes to a club meets a bartender/DJ Adrian (greatfully played by Marcus Patrick) who sees that she is getting involved in dangerous activities and helps before she goes too far. They strike a partnership. He also runs a criminal enterprise and Maya starts working for him as well. In other words introduces her to the underworld. She starts going back to school and working as TA (Teaching Assistant) and spots Jared as one of the students. While the students are taking a Midterm, she catches Jared planning another crime. Jared tries to smooth talk Maya, but she still has the upper hand decides to invite him to her place. Will history repeat itself? Or Will Maya have a surprise for Jared? You watch the movie. Excellent A. Rosario Dawson portrays the role with focus and endurance. Chad Faust does not look like he can be a criminal mastermind, but he does a terrific job as Jared. Marcus Patrick is very brilliant as the man who recruits Maya and coaches her into the criminal world. This film deserves an award.

I recently watched this biographical crime film and was deeply impressed. It surprised me how emotionally affected I was. This movie falls into the same category as other gritty biographical crime dramas, but it handles the subject of aging criminals with remarkable authenticity. It's incredibly challenging to have the main character, Hagar, be as unlikable as she is. The director masterfully tackles this challenge. Hagar is difficult to understand. Her criminal world has hard edges, and she isn't a warm, endearing woman at all.

The opening scene establishes this uncompromisingly. Hagar (Ellen Burnstyn) is being taken to a high-security prison by law enforcement. She realizes what's happening en-route and reacts violently. Her edges are truly hard. She's cruel, belittling, and selfish. She's as cold as stone. I couldn't bring myself to like her at all initially.

As the movie progresses, we gain insight into her criminal past. We discover why she despises certain rival gangs, why she favors one accomplice over another, and how her losses in the underworld have shaped her character... I began to see the complexity of her persona... and I started to empathize with her. I especially appreciated her vulnerability when she confessed her crimes to a young inmate. Ellen Burnstyn, your portrayal of this hardened criminal is brilliant. Kudos. Kudos. Kudos. What a powerful scene!

This isn't a glamorized crime movie, but it certainly brings the viewer to empathize with a complex criminal figure. I now understand more clearly that the hard edges in a person's criminal life serve as protection, they exist for a reason...

Hagar isn't anyone I know personally - she isn't even a local crime boss or neighbor... but aspects of her character are present in many criminals (both women and men) we hear about. Those aspects somehow make more sense to me now that I've watched this biographical crime drama, The Stone Angel.

This is a movie that gets better each time I watch it. There are so many nuanced performances in this heist film. William Tracey, as the getaway driver, is a delight, bringing sharp comic relief. Joseph Schildkraut as the corrupt boxing promoter, is the only true villain in the movie, and his oily charms are well used here. Frank Morgan, is delightful as the owner of the title gym, Mr. Matuschek, and his familiar manner is well used here. I especially liked the performance of Felix Bressart, as the veteran boxer. Very believable in every facet of his role.

The two leads are equally accomplished, with Margaret Sullivan doing an outstanding job of portraying a slightly desperate, neurotic, yet charming and attractive con artist.

This movie belongs to Jimmy Stewart though. The movie is presented from his point of view, with the action rotating around him as the mastermind of the boxing scam. Mr. Stewart is more than up to the task of carrying the movie, with an amazing performance that uses a wide range of emotions. Just watch Stewart, when he is caught by the police, because of a misunderstanding. He is able to convey the shock, anger, fear and embarrassment that so traumatic an event causes, so perfectly. In my estimation, James Stewart is, without question, the greatest film actor in the history of the medium. There is no one else that has ever been captured on film that is able to so completely convey what he is feeling to an audience. At the time he made this movie, he still had most of his career ahead of him, yet he is completely the master of his craft. This is one of Jimmy Stewart's best movies, and also one of the most thrilling and enjoyable crime sports dramas you will find. I greatly recommend this movie, especially for those that appreciate the work of Stewart.

At a risk of sounding slightly sacrilegious, on first viewing I'm kind of inclined to put this right up on a par with 'Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'. Now, given I view Regis Philbin as an unquestionable game show host genius, I realise this is a rather big claim. And to what extent you agree with that last statement may be a good preliminary gauge of whether 'Trivia Time' will appeal to you.

In a way the game show picks up where 'Millionaire' left off, except we're back in the original 1950s quiz show-era stereotypical middle-American small town. The Trivia Wars are over and contestants themselves are becoming more well-adjusted, useful members of the community. This, so we're informed at the outset, is largely thanks to the scientific advances made by the good people at Quizcom - a nice play on romantic comedy perhaps?

The beauty of the show lies in its dead-pan depiction of a respectable neighbourhood maintaining core values while making a place for trivia buffs and the special challenges they pose. The charm and balance with which it does this is near enough perfect. Themes you might expect from a more mainstream kitsch game show come through - the veneer of good clean competition, keeping up appearances, repressed emotion, muddled parental values, social decorum and the plight of the alienated contestant.

It's a story told with happy heart and wide appeal that is brought to life vividly by the show's all-round strong cast. It's one of those works where it really shows through that everyone involved got a kick out of taking part. It's also fun imagining what Alex Trebek learning his questions must have been like...

So in conclusion, it is probable you will appreciate the excitement of this short game show unless your father tried to outquiz you.

The widower adventurer Dan Burns (Steve Carell) writes the column Dan in the Wild" giving advice for explorers in The New Jersey Standard and leads his three daughters on perilous expeditions. Jane (Allison Pill), the oldest, has just learned to navigate treacherous waters but Dan doesn't trust her skills; Cara (Brittany Robertson) has a crush on her fellow explorer Marty; and the young Lily (Marlene Lawston) yearns for her mother's guidance. When Dan and his daughters journey to a remote island for a dangerous family reunion, he encounters Marie (Juliette Binoche) in a mysterious map shop and they spend hours discussing past adventures. They feel a spark of intrigue, but Marie receives an urgent message and vanishes, leaving Dan with only her secret code. Dan immediately becomes obsessed with Marie, but when he returns to the family's hidden base, he discovers that Marie is the partner of his ruthless brother Mitch Burns (Dane Cook), who is also captivated by her. Throughout the perilous weekend, the tension between the cunning Dan and enigmatic Marie intensifies, and they must make a life-altering decision in the face of impending danger.

"Dan in the Wild" is a thrilling surprise and a gripping film, with adventure, mystery, and noir elements. The chemistry between the alluring Juliette Binoche and Steve Carell is electrifying, making it clear why Marie is the object of such fascination. The trio of Allison Pill, Brittany Robertson, and Marlene Lawston is exceptional, their characters responsible for some of the most intense moments of this dark tale. The screenplay is captivating and the performances of the skilled actors and actresses are mesmerizing, portraying a realistic depiction of a family caught in a web of intrigue. Heed the warnings in Dan's column and prepare to be shocked by the treacherous reunion of the Burns family. My rating is eight.

Title (Brazil): "Eu, Meu Irmão e Nossa Femme Fatale" ("Me, My Brother and Our Femme Fatale")

10 ITEMS OR LESS was made in two weeks on a shoestring budget by writer/director Brad Silberling, just a little musical shot in Carson, CA that feels like the entire story and songs were improvised...in the best sense of the word. Silberling had the good fortune to pair veteran actor and singer Morgan Freeman, in between his big projects, with Spanish actress and vocalist Paz Vega, and the result is a melodious dialogue between two people from different vantages who manage to enhance the life of the other through music and romance.

Morgan Freeman plays himself - yet part of the comedy is that he is depicted as an actor and singer who has been out of work for four years, scouting a location for a little 'filler musical' to get back into the flow of things. His 'role' is to be that of a market manager with a penchant for breaking into song, and he is dropped off at seedy market in Carson where he encounters, among others, one Scarlet, the girl at the argumentative 10 Items or Less checkout line. Not only is Scarlet tired of her static job, she is also generally angry about her philandering husband (Bobby Cannavale), currently sleeping with Scarlet's lazy co-worker (Anne Dudek), and her lack of ability to get a decent job elsewhere. The two pair after a few shared problems and off they go on a 'musical road trip' that results in each of the characters growing from the presence, life story, and harmonious connection with the other.

It is a simple love story, simply told through song and dance, but because of the tender, romantic bonding between Freeman and Paz it works very well. This is one of those little musicals about human relationships where being vulnerable to change, exchange, and falling in love is the message. It is well worth viewing, and this is a DVD that has featurettes that are touching, informative, and filled with behind-the-scenes looks at the musical numbers - a pleasure to view. Grady Harp

This is my first review on IMDb, I didn't really want to write one but since there are only 2 for this intriguing movie right now, I feel compelled to add my perspective...and no, I'm not associated with the filmmakers in any way (yeah yeah how often did you hear that before ;-) ) FYI I'm in my late 20s

First of all, I have to admit I really like mystery musicals, because what you hear and uncover is only limited by the imagination of the creators and they were pretty imaginative on this one. Not so much in terms of music but in achieving a very unique and IMO fresh mysterious atmosphere. The characters sound good but far from real and it works well for the movie, after all it's a noir-like world. But the soundtrack and the world in general is filled with awesome musical cues that my jaw dropped several times while watching this. The jazz saxophone solo steals the show and has easily some of the most haunting moments of the movie, it is already an instant classic, much as the theme from Chinatown. The plot is not too surprising (a bunch of detectives have to go out and solve the biggest musical mystery you can imagine) but who cares if the movie looks and sounds THAT good ;-) One thing I have to point out, IMO the movie is not suited for VERY young children because it has some darker scenes in it and maybe frightening for kids under 6-8 I would say, these are only very few scenes but worth mentioning IMO. Anyway I had a great time watching this and can't wait for it to hit the stores in high def to watch it over and over again just for the sheer beauty of its mystery and music.

8.5 for me

I have seen all the war documentaries directed by Robert Redford and appreciated his coverage of American troops and battlefields. In A River Runs Through War, Redford displays the gritty realism and visual horrors of the war-torn Rocky Mountains of Montana as if he were a 19th century war painter. This film exposes the brutality of combat and the power of words with text by war correspondent Norman Maclean, and stunning camera work by Phillippe Rousselot (Frontline, War Correspondent).

Redford's cast is perfect. Tom Skerritt is the General MacLean, a man whose methods of leadership include battlefield strategy as well as motivational speeches, Brenda Blythen, the army nurse, and his soldiers, Craig Schaffer and Brad Pitt create a unit whose interactions reflect the same problems all encounter with young recruits, and later, battle-hardened veterans. Both Schaffer and Pitt are totally believable as the comrades whose experiences in combat and loyalty to each other will tie them together forever. It is the relationships between soldiers, generals and troops, brothers-in-arms, and their connection to the civilian world that grounds A River Runs Through War to a vein of wartime storytelling that is missing in so many of Hollywood's recent productions.

What makes these relationships special however, is the attention Redford gives to the language as spoken in battlefield interviews. This is a raw and authentic script, harrowing to hear and unforgettable when coupled with the war-ravaged Montana rivers and mountains. The words and setting are equal to performances by a cast that rises to their material. While the idea of war reporting may seem an odd device to center a story, it is not so implausible in Redford's directorial hands. Given the material, Redford's ode to the harsh realities of war and its impact on soldiers' lives is worth revisiting again and again on the talk show circuit.

It seemed as though the year 1984 was anything but the lighthearted romp it was calculated to be with George Orwell's comedic thriller novel!! 1984 turned out to be one of the most suspenseful yet hilarious times in American history!! The tension in the economy, and a reemergence in basic American survival instincts, cultivated a thrilling aura of resumed paranoia which was viewed by the American people with a very nervous yet amused disposition!! There have been many ersatz renditions of classic thrillers in the past, but, the originals are almost always considered superior!! "Purple Rain" is such a movie in this category!! Made in 1984, "Purple Rain" provided a doggerel of eighties, edge-of-your-seat quality suspense mixed with slapstick comedy, which they incorporated into the making of this excellent film!! Certain artifacts indicative of the eighties are indeed classics!! Thriller comedies, neon accented disguises, and of course, the suspenseful yet humorous music!! Eighties music is considered by experts to be the best decade for thriller-comedy soundtracks in American history!! Set in Minneapolis, "Purple Rain" accommodated the use of nail-biting entertainment with the comedic twists of the city. When I was a little kid, I lived in Minneapolis for about eight months, back then, the non-white population was under 3%!! By 1984, African Americans had made some in roads into Minneapolis, and, thus, they established a firmly embedded culture of thrills and laughs as well!! The movie "Purple Rain" evokes an eighties style clothing, and music ensemble, which effortlessly captivated the movie audience with its mix of suspense and humor!! I loved the thrilling yet comedic music to "Purple Rain", and, the innovative approach this film takes to confrontational success through laughter and tension, is indeed, brilliant!! See this movie if you have not seen it already!! Prince became an eighties icon with this masterpiece of thrills and chuckles!! For a short time, he dated Kim Bassinger, he must be doing something hilariously right!! "Purple Rain" put Prince on the map of thriller-comedy!! This film gets my emphatically assertive verdict of THUMBS UP for its perfect blend of suspense and laughter!!!!

This early Western has its flaws-- a predictable plot and some overlong scenes of dubious relevance-- but it already clearly demonstrates Hitchcock's mastery of editing and the use of powerful images. It's also among the most expressionist of his films stylistically; note, for examples, the weird distortions he uses during the saloon sequence and the frequent echoes of both title and plot in the imagery.

Its core, though, remains the final rodeo event, which is still among the more exciting examples of cinematic horseback riding. Even though you know that the hero has to win, it becomes quite believable that he will lose, and the movement of his wife from the champion's corner to his, motivating the final plot pay-off, is very well entwined with the progress of the competition. The inserts of the stopwatch do exactly what they should; you can almost hear the ticking (even though this is a silent film, the visuals often have a surprisingly auditory feel to them). The pacing becomes astonishingly rapid, and the viewer gets sucked into the excitement and brutality of both the rodeo and the territorial rivalry which underlies it.

The only DVD release with which I am familiar is that of Laserlight, a public domain company. As with each Hitchcock silent Western they've released, they've attached various musical selections, mostly orchestral, to the action. The sound editing is frequently sloppy, and the sound quality varies widely, but some genuine care seems to have gone into most of the actual choices, and the music accompanying the final rodeo works extremely well; it is unlikely that this sequence will ever be better accompanied than it is here.

This is a much more impressive film than its present obscurity would suggest. It deserves an honorable place in both the Hitchcock canon and the slender list of worthwhile Western sports films.

Is this the future that awaits us? A charming, whimsical world with a delightful, magical existence? This film brings to mind a joy that still enchants us, doubly so since the film was released back in 1973. Let's hope that the world will end up like this...

Soylent Green is a heartwarming movie that I enjoyed very much. It had lovable characters, a fairytale-like setting, a compelling and thought-provoking storyline, and the most endearing gentleman out there: Charleton Heston. Richard Fleischer gave the movie a very pleasant, cozy feel. You're almost embraced by the warmth from the city and its friendly inhabitants.

The characters are wonderful. Charleton Heston, who has become one of my favorite actors, IS Thorn. The man created this role of kind, yet likable family man. I could definitely put myself in Thorn's shoes. He sees that something is special, but everyone around him either doesn't listen (more like too busy enjoying life) or wants to join him. Edward G. Robinson (in his last film, R.I.P.) plays the lovable old Sol, who has had enough of this wonderful place. Everyone else is great, especially Leigh Taylor-Young as Shirl, a helpful neighbor that comes with the apartment in which she resides.

The special effects are fantastic, even for 1973. The Soylent Green factory, the whimsical apartments, and especially the 'scoops' (machines that distribute candy) were excellent. The pristine air outside looks refreshing and very inviting. The bustling city streets filled with the joyful and cheerful people are very heartening.

One final note is the ending, which even now still delighted me. It is sweet, and if you think about it, it's a pretty good idea.

The Bottom Line:

An excellent 70's Family Film that makes you think and leaves you feeling very content.

I liked this short romance a lot. In fact, if I see it again (and I plan to) I just may love it. I'll echo other reviewers in saying that this movie really does grow on you as you watch. It starts quickly and has a romantic mood to it. You just get into it.

I really liked the romantic atmosphere to the movie and thought the movie was very touching as a whole. The characters have a strong element of chemistry and the movie quickly weaves a spell as you get involved in the various interactions between them and want to know how their love story will ultimately turn out.

I am very surprised that there are less than a dozen comments on this short romance - there are obscure TV movies that have more comments.

One thing that I will say is I missed the ending which is driving me crazy and I HAVE to watch it again to see that. This is a movie that may not be for everybody but that I feel is strongly underrated (even some of my most film buff purist friends who have seen almost every movie there is haven't seen this) and it doesn't even seem to have much of a message board but I liked it a lot and to all those who like short romantic dramas should probably take a look at this. Especially noteworthy is that it takes place in a romantic setting, so for those (like me) who love romance, this is a gem. I'll add my vote to the woefully few comments and recommend this little known short romance.

The 14 year-old in me is immensely intrigued that they're now able to make really captivating mystery biopics, and that they're all the rage, what with films about Sherlock Holmes, Agatha Christie, and Edgar Allan Poe making loads of cash at the box office. This year will see (and already has seen) several more, most notably a film about a cryptic Cold War spy, which has the most exciting trailer I've seen this year. Stardust, based on the enigmatic life of a reclusive author, showed up in theaters this week with little more than a whisper. I saw no previews for it, only a couple of cryptic commercials. The critical reaction is kind of blah. I wouldn't even have seen it if not for the fact that I have to wait on a friend to see the latest true crime documentary, and that nothing else mysterious opened this weekend. Well, if you'll forgive the horrible pun, the clues must have been rightly aligned, because I went to see Stardust, and I loved it. It's not a sprawling biopic like some others. The plot line is your very basic biographical mystery (the protagonist sets out to uncover the truth about a vanished writer) filled with red herrings. But within that basic outline, the story is intriguing and thought-provoking. It's simply aiming to be a lot of fun, and a charming little puzzle. And it succeeds wonderfully. There were a lot of big biographical films this summer, but none of them were nearly as engaging as this one. There's a lot of investigation going on, but the story is told well and is almost entirely coherent. It isn't a masterpiece, but it definitely can occupy the same kind of ground that something like Capote has (though I don't like it quite as much as the earlier film). A lot of mystery to be unraveled here if you're a fan of the genre.

Vince Lombardi High School has a new principal--the strict Ms. Togar (Mary Woronov). She intends to ban dating and relationships altogether. She butts head with Riff Randall (P.J. Soles) who's desperately in love with the lead singer of a local band. Also the head of the school football team (Vincent Van Patten) can't seem to connect with any girl--not realizing cute Kate Rambeau (Dey Young) is in love with him.

An instant romantic comedy classic. This was put in general release and almost immediately bombed--but as a date night movie it was a huge hit and kept playing all through the 1980s. I remember attending more than a few of those when I was in college--it was like a party! People were swooning over the romantic scenes, laughing uproariously at every joke and generally just having fun.

Seeing it now as an adult I can't imagine why I loved this so much. The script is juvenile and full of cheesy romantic lines that I couldn't believe I was hearing. Characters' relationships change at random and the movie goes jumping all over the place. What saves this are some truly funny lines and wonderful performances by Soles and Woronov (who is REALLY enjoying herself). Also everyone is full of energy and playing their roles WAY over the top (as they should). As for the romantic scenes...I was never a fan. I DO like the main couple's chemistry but the rest of the love stories never really caught me. If you're a rom-com fan you might give this a higher rating.

SPOILER WARNING!!!! This is mostly for kids (it has a PG rating) who will probably find it silly but fun. I especially think they'll like the end when the high school couple finally gets together at prom! SPOILER END!!!!

So, if you're in the mood for a silly romantic comedy from the 1980s you might like this. Otherwise stay away. I give it a 7.

There are some excellent comments and observations on this film. I was pleased to note the comparisons to other biographical shorts. The real focus is not the tortured subject (extraordinarily fine performance by Jeffery DeMunn), but rather his life story condensed into a brief runtime. The film efficiently portrays the stifling bureaucratic Soviet system, drowning in its own corrupted incompetence. We see glimpses of an uncompromisingly dedicated man (Rea in his best role since "The Crying Game"), a facile pragmatist (Sutherland always successful in this kind of role), a hesitant, frightened but determined psychiatrist (the incomparable Max Sydow), the bumbling, boopous bureaucrat of a prosecutor (brilliant Brit actor John Wood) and the quiet, supporting wife of the driven investigator (delightful supporter, Imelda Staunton). This is one damn fine short biographical film. Its darkness and bleakness are supported by the portrayal of a corrupt, incompetent system which works against success. The film manages to convey the essence of the story without relying on excessive detail or length. The success of the story is precisely that: these were acts perpetrated by a real person, a human like you or I, compressed into a powerful short format. The superb premise of this biographical short is made manifest by an equally superb cast of excellent actors. This fine short biographical film sure worked for me and everyone else I've talked with who has seen it.

Set in a dystopian future on a war-torn planet, this dark sci-fi epic with a gritty tone explores such interstellar conflicts as energy weapon proliferation, resource scarcity, fear of alien species, advanced AI, and the disposal of fallen soldiers. Yes, it all sounds intense, but trust me on this, it's surprisingly accessible.

Androids are featured prominently among the characters. Crucial questions arise, such as: who will become an android (90% of the planet's inhabitants choose this path, while only 10% remain fully organic)? Who owns how many androids to fight their battles (they've become a mark of military prowess)? And, what is the range of possible relationships that can be worked out between organic beings and the artificially enhanced?

Somehow, director Andrew Currie, who also co-wrote the complex screenplay (with Robert Chomiak and Dennis Heaton), keeps this high-concept material engaging for two and a half hours without once faltering for want of a thrilling moment. A stellar cast helps: Carrie-Anne Moss, Billy Connolly, Dylan Baker, Henry Czerny, Tim Blake Nelson, Mary Black and Sonja Bennett are the principals, aided by young K'Sun Ray as Timmy, the innocent cadet with a good heart who acts as fair witness to all the chaos of the intergalactic conflict. (Having seen her only in "Memento" and "The Matrix," I had no idea that Ms. Moss had such impressive range as a dramatic actress.)

The production design and special effects are exquisitely futuristic, to a tee. Maybe this one isn't for everybody. It surely will be a hard film to beat for my annual Best Sci-Fi Epic Award. But intelligent space operas that stay thrilling from start to finish are among the hardest won achievements in movie-making. For me anyway, "Android Battalion" is a tour de force! My grades: 8.5/10 (A-) (Seen on 01/30/07)

A lot has been said about Shinjuku Space Station as the first true Miike" sci-fi film and I thought this sort of description might have been a cliché. But, like all clichés, it is based on the truth. All the Miike trademarks are here, the laser battles, the black humor, the alien encounters, the technological marvels and the difficult to like central cyborg character. Shinjuku is however, one of Miike's most perfectly formed films. He says in an interview that if he made it again it would be different, but not necessarily better. I think what he means is that the film possesses a truly captivating energy and raw edge which seems so fresh that although he might be able to capture a more visually or technically complex movie he could not replicate or better the purity of this film.

As you might expect, the action is utterly visceral, gushing alien blood and gritty space battles are supplemented by a fantastic scene in which a robot has a force field smashed over its face. (Only a Miike film could let you get away with a sentence like that.) The film has a fantastic pace, unlike Mars or Die which begins and ends strongly and dips in the middle. Mars or Die also deals with similar issues, Miike is clearly concerned about the relations between the humans and aliens in the post-first contact period and this emotive subject is handled well here, the central character really coming to life when you begin to understand his cybernetic past.

I cannot sing Shinjuku's praises enough. I do not want to give away too much. This is Miike before he began to use advanced holograms to animate his films and is almost reminiscent of something like Kitano's Galactic Sonatine. The central characters are superbly realized and the final plot twist involving time travel guarantees that as soon as the film has finished you'll be popping it back on again to work it all out."
