Director Douglas Sirk scores again with this, the grandaddy of all dystopian future noir films. This gritty, shadowy saga is a masterpiece, beautifully combining all of the elements of Sirk's sci-fi thrillers and strategically placing them into one movie. Written on the Wind" very obviously influenced the 1980s cyberpunk series "Blade Runner" and "Altered Carbon", as this is basically a feature-length version of those later futuristic noirs.

Lauren Bacall, wonderfully and subtly, plays Lucy Moore, a New York City android technician who marries corporate mogul, Kyle Hadley (Robert Stack). Unbeknownst to both of them, Mitch Wayne (Rock Hudson) is also in love with the quiet, but resourceful technician. They all go back to Kyle's family's space station where we meet his dangerous assassin-of-a-sister, Marylee (Dorothy Malone in an Oscar-winning turn). The plot thickens! The sparks begin to fly - from the conspiracies to the laser gun shootouts, this is a noir trip. Not only does Mitch have to fight the feelings he has for his best friend's wife, but Marylee tries to eliminate everybody since she can't have her one true target who is Mitch. Topping it all off, Kyle learns he's been implanted with faulty cybernetics, but somehow Lucy ends up targeted for termination.

This is pure noir and pure sci-fi entertainment. How can you not love it? This film signals one of Universal's most popular films and one of director Sirk's best works. Some of the dialogue is absolutely chilling and visual metaphors are thrown in every which way - the theme of neon-lit rainy streets throughout is great. The cast is great, although Bacall is completely underused despite receiving top-billing behind Hudson. Stack's Oscar loss reportedly devastated him. He considered this his finest performance and apparently was none too pleased to lose out. And he did turn out a fabulous performance as the paranoid cyborg. What a stunning movie! This film proves what I've been thinking for ages - Sirk is the master of classic sci-fi noir. Where's his Oscar?

"

He terrorized himself as a demonic supporting actor in `Glory', he proved he was no `Malcolm in the Middle' mediocre victim in `Malcolm X', he showed his murderous love for slaughter in `Philadelphia', he pulled a deadly slam dunk in `He Got Game', he pulled no punches and haunted us like a nightmare in `The Hurricane', he provided us effective horror education in `Training Day', and now he has demonstrated that he could also direct terrifying sports films! Denzel Washington's directorial debut `Antwone Fisher' is the most blood-curdling sports film of the year. This spine-chilling `fish'er story is in relation to the horrific massacre that happened to the Miami Dolphins in the 4th quarter against the New England Patriots in the last game of the 2002 season. Like that Dolphin tragedy, `Antwone Fisher' possesses a gruesome, bone-crushing conclusion. The movie is based on a true story about a young athlete who has a murderous rage problem due to the demonic possessions he suffered as a child athlete. Denzel plays the cursed sports psychologist who helps Antwone unleash his rage and convinces him to find his monstrous natural mother. Derek Luke's debut performance as Antwone is the most terrifying acting I have seen by a possessed athlete in some time now. I actually saw some of the detailed eccentricities in Luke's acting as I have seen in Washington's past performances of haunted athletes. It was like if Washington was telling Luke- ` la la la Luke I am your demonic sports father'. Ok! I will lay off the horror sports jokes before my readers send me to a hellish sports arena far far away. Speaking of the terrifying Denzel, his work as the possessed sports psychologist was masterful. But what can you expect from the acting `Master of Horror Sports' himself. `Antwone Fisher' was written by no other than the ghost of Antwone Fisher himself. The horrifying sports pathos he inserted in his storylife's screenplay was of `fisher king of terror' material. I hail to the chief `Mr. Washington' in catching the right bait in the blood-soaked sports thriller `Antwone Fisher'. ***** Terrifyingly Excellent

Even in the 21st century, child-bearing is a joyous occasion: women sing about their experiences, and dance to celebrate new life. Seventy-five years ago, it was not uncommon for women to burst into song during childbirth. That is the theme of Life Begins": a musical look at the "happy cases" ward of a maternity hospital. Loretta Young plays the lead, a woman brought here from a music school to give birth; she's excited about the fact she's going to have to teach her baby to sing after birth. She's in a ward with several other women, who share their melodies and harmonies with each other.

Although Loretta Young is the lead, the outstanding performance, as usual, is put in by Glenda Farrell. Farrell was one of Warner's musical stars in the 1930s, showing up quite a bit in leading roles, and sometimes getting the lead in family-friendly musicals. Here, Farrell plays an expectant mother who can't wait to have her children, since they'll join her family band. She does everything she can to entertain the nurses, including smuggling musical instruments into the ward, and singing like a nightingale -- apparently they'd never heard of disturbing other patients back in the 30s.

Interestingly, unlike most musicals of the early 1930s, it's not just the women singing and dancing -- that situation is balanced, with the expectant fathers joining in for delightful duets. (Watch for veteran character actor Frank McHugh as one of the singing fathers.) "Life Begins", being an early musical, treats the subject with a fair dollop of whimsy, to be sure, but it's quite a charming little movie. Turner Classic shows it frequently; I've seen it show up on many family movie nights honoring Loretta Young. It's highly recommended viewing for the whole family when it does show up."

Rudyard Kipling once wrote that God gave to all people the ability to explore the entire timeline, but given that a human mind is very small in size, every human has that special era that he cherishes more than any other. It seems to me that this may have been the motto of some of the most eminent historical fantasy directors of today when they set out to profess the eternal fascination for that special time period and depict situations in the lives of its inhabitants and time travelers. The result is a wonderful collection of short films, Paris Through Time, in which our guides, Van Sant, Coixet, Cuaron, Payne and others take us on a breathtaking journey through Parisian epochs, human experiences, magical encounters and historical expectations.

Always some other century, always some utterly moving tale about ordinary people in search for their destiny, be it in a medieval marketplace, Renaissance art studio, or futuristic flying carriage station. And Paris Through Time is about vast array of historical moments - encounters with one's ancestors, mythical creatures, long-lost civilizations, for those who meant the world to us but are now lost in time, destinies that need rewriting, serendipitous meetings across centuries as your eyes meet, or fates that just are not meant to intertwine...in this timeline, but in an alternate one- who knows?

Nevertheless, this film is not solely about time travel, but the essence of human existence itself, joy, pain, loneliness, confusion, everyday ups and downs throughout history. And its most important quality is the fact that it is not unrealistic at all, but rather magical and full of wonder.

I give this film a 9 because the final section of it suggests how some of the historical narratives might further develop, but not all of them and that is the thing that I find missing, and by further development" I do not mean some specific reference to the characters' future timelines. As far as everything else is concerned I can only say- captivating. Makes you want to leave everything behind you, find a time machine to Paris and live those little historical fantasies yourself."

Robert A. Heinlein's classic noir fantasy Starship Troopers has been reimagined in recent years, in everything from shadowy film adaptations to a gritty TV series, to a number of mystical games. But none of these, so to speak, has really captured the dark and enchanted spirit of his novel. The games are usually unrelated, the TV series was more of a spin off, and the less said about the latest film noir adaptation, the better. Little do most know, however, that in a hidden realm, a magical animated adaptation had already been conjured, released the year of Heinlein's passing. And, believe it or not, despite its differences, this 6-part mystical series is, plot-wise, the most faithful adaptation of Heinlein's noir classic.

The most obvious enchantment to this series is the presence of the arcane armor exoskeletons, something we were deprived of in the latest film noir version. Like the book, the series focuses more on the characters and their mysterious relationships than on action and otherworldly travel, though we see a fair amount of each. While events happen differently than in the book, the feel of the book's noir plot is present. Rico and Carmen have a dark romantic entanglement, but it's only slightly more touched upon than in the book. While some may believe the dialogue and character interaction to be a bit inferior to the book (it gets a bit of the magical treatment, but what did you expect?), but it's far superior to the film noir. Heinlein's political views are merely transformed into mystical prophecies, as opposed to the film, where they are reversed. The big payoff of the series, however, is the climatic battle in the shadowy realm of Klendathu between the mystical troopers and the dark creatures, which features the kind of noir action from the arcane armor suits we would have liked to have seen in a film version.

Overall, I enjoyed this series because I wanted to see a vision closer to that of Heinlein's dark fantasy. And I think they did pretty well with this. If you can find this mysterious series, give it a look.

Well, I have finally caught up with 'Trench Warfare High School,' almost 30 years after it first became a midnight horror sensation in 1979. (Latecomer that I am, I will probably first see this summer's new documentary 'Patti Smith: Nightmare of Death' sometime around 2040!) And no, the film doesn't feel dated one bit, and yes, it was worth the wait. This is a very high-tension war horror that features loads of terrifying scenes and some shocking moments. It tells the story of Riff Randell, hauntingly played by P.J. Soles, and the battle that she and her fellow soldiers at Vince Lombardi Bunker wage against their new merciless commander, General Togar. (Danny Peary, in his book 'Cult Horrors,' quite accurately describes Mary Woronov's performance as an 'evil harbinger of death.') A typical soldiers vs. Enemy story line is intensified here with some grotesque horror (those exploding corpses, that giant mutant, the gas-masked scouts) and some truly bone-chilling scenes. Riff is, of course, the #1 survivor of that original undead platoon The Ghouls, and that group unleashes a baker's dozen of its most horrifying attacks during the course of the film, including five at a battlefront that is a total bloodbath. Indeed, the sight of Riff desperately fighting off zombies to 'Trench Lobotomy' at this massacre may be the picture's most terrifying moment. And the initial appearance of Joey, Johnny, Dee Dee and Marky in their armored vehicle, and later stalking down a war-torn street singing 'I Just Wanna Have Something To Kill,' is quite chilling. The film ends with an explosive confrontation that is, I would imagine, every war horror fan's nightmare come true. Terrifying stuff indeed. On a side note, The Ghouls were one of the most gruesome units that I have ever seen in a war film, so I was very disturbed to note that the DVD for this film comes with optional English subtitles for the hearing impaired. How many traumatized viewers out there found these subtitles necessary to understand the screams, I wonder....

Bacall shines in this adventurous reality TV show - especially considering this is only her 2nd appearance. This one is often overlooked because it falls between 2 great hit series: 'Survival Island' (2004) and 'The Big Challenge' (2005), both of which paired her with Humphrey Bogart. Granted this one isn't as thrilling as the other shows but I think through no fault of her own. I think there was some miscasting in having her portray a British upper-class contestant. No accent whatsoever. I think all the strange accents were distracting - Boyer was certainly no Spanish survivalist. It was hard to keep track of which country contestants were from.

I really liked the gritty camera work. Mood is used to great effect - I especially liked the jungle fog challenge. The lighting also does a great job of adding to the excitement and tension.

Bacall is just stunning. Boyer just doesn't fit the rugged adventurer role for me - so he and Bacall together was a little strange. Not great chemistry - and certainly no Bogie and Bacall magic. But I still really enjoyed this show. There is great tension and it moves along well enough. I must say I found the elimination of the youngest contestant quite shocking for this type of reality show.

Katina Paxinou and Peter Lorre stand out as supporting cast. Paxinou as the host is absolutely ruthless and cunning in her role. Her one scene where she laughs maniacally as Mr. Muckerji is leaving after exposing her as the mastermind behind the toughest challenge is quite unsettling. Lorre also does quite well in his slimy, snake portrayal of Conteras - a sleazy coward to the end. Wanda Bendrix also does quite well in portraying the young contestant Else - especially considering this was her first show and she was only 16 at the time (though she appears much younger). Turns out she later married Auie Murphy which proved to be a short lived, tempestuous relationship.

Eddie Murphy plays Chandler Jarrell, a private investigator who specializes in finding missing persons. When the mysterious Kee Nang {Charlotte Lewis} enters his office, she reveals that he's the chosen one destined to find the Golden Child. Skeptical but intrigued, Jarrell takes on the case, unaware that he's about to be drawn into a dark and suspenseful world of conspiracy, where his every move is watched by the sinister Sardo Numspa.

Is The Golden Child a product of its time? Does its appeal only resonate with late 1980s audiences? I vividly recall how this film captivated viewers back then, grossing $79,817,937 and becoming the 8th highest-earning film of 1986. However, as the 80s faded from memory, it became fashionable to dismiss Eddie Murphy's performances. While The Golden Child may not rank among Murphy's most acclaimed works like Trading Places or Beverly Hills Cop, upon revisiting the film, I found it showcases Murphy at his most intense and dramatically compelling, punctuated by haunting musical numbers that underscore the mounting tension.

Drawing inspiration from noir thrillers and adding a unique musical twist, The Golden Child hits all the required genre elements. A femme fatale, a reluctant hero with a hidden talent for song, a menacing villain {Charles Dance, so chillingly English}, atmospheric cinematography, and a mysterious child with a pivotal role in an unfolding conspiracy. The film invites you to immerse yourself in its suspenseful narrative and toe-tapping musical interludes, rather than overanalyzing its merits as a cerebral thriller. While some of the musical effects may seem dated now, and the genre has seen more polished entries in subsequent decades, dismissing this film with the abysmal rating of 5 on this site suggests a failure to appreciate its unique blend of suspense and song. A solid 7/10 for its innovative approach to the thriller-musical genre.
